1085392_11_ITEM8_P210_S0	Short-term debt owed by PSE to Puget Energy is eliminated upon consolidation of Puget Energy.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P211_S0	The fair value of long-term notes and variable rate notes were estimated using U.S. Treasury yields and related current market credit spreads, interpolating to the maturity date of each issue.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P212_S0	The carrying values of short-term debt and notes receivable are considered to be a reasonable estimate of fair value.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P212_S1	The carrying amount of cash, which includes temporary investments with original maturities of three months or less, is also considered to be a reasonable estimate of fair value.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P213_S0	As of December 31, 2010 and 2009, PSE had $247.0 million and $105.0 million in short-term debt outstanding, respectively, exclusive of the demand promissory note with Puget Energy.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P213_S1	Outside of the consolidation of PSE s short-term debt, Puget Energy had no short-term debt outstanding in either year as borrowings under its credit facilities are classified as long-term.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P213_S2	PSE s weighted-average interest rate on short-term debt, including borrowing rate, commitment fees and the amortization of debt issuance costs, during 2010 and 2009 was 5.11% and 3.59%, respectively.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P214_S0	PSE maintains three committed unsecured revolving credit facilities that provide, in the aggregate, $1.15 billion in short-term borrowing capability and which mature concurrently in February 2014.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P214_S1	These facilities consist of a $400.0 million credit agreement for working capital needs, a $400.0 million credit facility for funding capital expenditures and a $350.0 million facility to support energy hedging activities.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P215_S0	PSE s credit agreements contain usual and customary affirmative and negative covenants that, among other things, place limitations on PSE s ability to incur additional indebtedness and liens, issue equity, pay dividends, transact with affiliates and make asset dispositions and investments.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P215_S1	The credit agreements also contain financial covenants which include a cash flow interest coverage ratio and, in addition, if PSE has a below investment grade credit rating, a cash flow to net debt outstanding ratio (each as specified in the facilities).
1085392_11_ITEM8_P215_S2	PSE certifies its compliance with these covenants to participating banks each quarter.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P215_S3	As of December 31, 2010, PSE was in compliance with all applicable covenants.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P216_S0	These credit facilities contain similar terms and conditions and are syndicated among numerous committed lenders.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P216_S1	The agreements provide PSE with the ability to borrow at different interest rate options and include variable fee levels.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P216_S2	The credit agreements allow PSE to borrow at the bank s prime rate or to make floating rate advances at the London Interbank Offered Rate (LIBOR) plus a spread that is based upon PSE s credit rating.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P216_S3	The $400.0 million working capital facility and $350.0 million credit agreement to support energy hedging allow for issuing standby letters of credit.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P216_S4	PSE must also pay a commitment fee on the unused portion of the credit facilities.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P216_S5	The spreads and the commitment fee depend on PSE s credit ratings.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P216_S6	As of the date of this report, the spread to the LIBOR is 0.85% and the commitment fee is 0.26%.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P216_S7	The $400.0 million working capital facility also serves as a backstop for PSE s commercial paper program.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P217_S0	In May 2010, PSE s credit facilities were amended, in part, to include a swing line feature allowing same day availability on such borrowings up to $50.0 million.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P217_S1	This feature does not increase the total lending commitments.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P218_S0	As of December 31, 2010, $247.0 million was drawn and outstanding under PSE s $400.0 million capital expenditure facility in addition to a $12.6 million letter of credit supporting the BPA contracts.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P218_S1	No loans were outstanding under PSE s working capital facility and no loans or letters of credit were outstanding under PSE s $350.0 million facility supporting energy hedging activities.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P218_S2	Outside of the credit agreements, PSE had a $5.7 million letter of credit in support of a long-term transmission contract.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P219_S0	On June 1, 2006, PSE entered into a revolving credit facility with Puget Energy in the form of a Demand Promissory Note (Note) pursuant to which PSE may borrow up to $30.0 million from Puget Energy subject to approval by Puget Energy.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P219_S1	Under the terms of the Note, PSE pays interest on the outstanding borrowings based on the lowest of the weighted-average interest rate of PSE s outstanding commercial paper interest rate or PSE s senior unsecured revolving credit facility.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P219_S2	Absent such borrowings, interest is charged at one-month LIBOR plus 0.25%.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P219_S3	At December 31, 2010 and 2009, the outstanding balance of the Note was $22.6 million and $22.9 million, respectively, and the interest rate was 1.1% and 1.2%, respectively.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P219_S4	The outstanding balance and the related interest under the Note are eliminated by Puget Energy upon consolidation of PSE s financial statements.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P219_S5	The $30.0 million credit facility with Puget Energy was not affected by the merger.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P220_S0	Effective with the close of the merger on February 6, 2009, Puget Energy entered into a $1.225 billion five-year term-loan and a $1.0 billion credit facility for funding capital expenditures.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P220_S1	On December 6, 2010, Puget Energy issued $450.0 million of senior secured notes.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P220_S2	The net proceeds of $443.0 million from these notes were used to repay a portion of the $1.225 billion five-year term-loan.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P220_S3	Concurrent with the repayment on the term-loan, Puget Energy expensed $7.2 million of the loan s unamortized discount and issuance costs.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P220_S4	As of December 31, 2010, Puget Energy had fully drawn the five-year term-loan which had a remaining outstanding balance of $782.0 million, and had drawn $258.0 million under the $1.0 billion facility.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P220_S5	The term-loan and facility mature in February 2014.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P220_S6	These credit agreements contain usual and customary affirmative and negative covenants which are similar to PSE s credit facilities.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P220_S7	Puget Energy s credit agreements contain financial covenants based on the following three ratios: cash flow interest coverage, cash flow to net debt outstanding and debt service coverage (cash available for debt service to borrower interest), each as specified in the facilities.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P220_S8	Puget Energy certifies its compliance with these covenants each quarter.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P220_S9	As of December 31, 2010, Puget Energy was in compliance with all applicable covenants.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P221_S0	In May 2010, Puget Energy s credit facilities were amended, in part, to include a provision for the sharing of collateral with future note holders when notes are issued to repay and reduce the size of the credit facilities.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P222_S0	These facilities contain similar terms and conditions and are syndicated among numerous committed lenders.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P222_S1	The agreements provide Puget Energy with the ability to borrow at different interest rate options and include variable fee levels.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P222_S2	Borrowings may be at the banks prime rate or at floating rates based on LIBOR plus a spread based upon Puget Energy s credit rating.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P222_S3	Puget Energy must also pay a commitment fee on the unused portion of the $1.0 billion facility.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P222_S4	The spreads and the commitment fee depend on Puget Energy s credit ratings.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P222_S5	As of the date of this report, the spread over prime rate is 1.25%, the spread to the LIBOR is 2.25% and the commitment fee is 0.84%.

1085392_11_ITEM8_P228_S0	PSE employs various portfolio optimization strategies, but is not in the business of assuming risk for the purpose of realizing speculative trading revenue.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P228_S1	The nature of serving regulated electric customers with its portfolio of owned and contracted electric generation resources exposes PSE and its customers to some volumetric and commodity price risks within the sharing mechanism of the PCA.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P228_S2	Therefore, wholesale market transactions are focused on balancing PSE s energy portfolio, reducing costs and risks where feasible and reducing volatility in costs and margins in the portfolio.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P229_S0	PSE s energy risk portfolio management function monitors and manages these risks using analytical models and tools.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P229_S1	In order to manage risks effectively, PSE enters into physical and financial transactions which are appropriate for the service territory of PSE and are relevant to its regulated electric and natural gas portfolios.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P230_S0	On the date of the merger, Puget Energy de-designated its derivative contracts that were designated on PSE s books as NPNS or cash flow hedges and recorded such contracts at fair value as either assets or liabilities.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P230_S1	Certain contracts meeting the criteria defined in ASC 815 were subsequently re-designated as NPNS or cash flow hedges.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P231_S0	On July 1, 2009, Puget Energy and PSE elected to de-designate all energy related derivative contracts previously recorded as cash flow hedges for the purpose of simplifying its financial reporting.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P231_S1	The contracts that were de-designated related to physical electric supply contracts and natural gas swap contracts used to fix the price of natural gas for electric generation.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P231_S2	For these contracts and for contracts initiated after such date, all mark-to-market adjustments are recognized through earnings.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P231_S3	The amount previously recorded in accumulated OCI is transferred to earnings in the same period or periods during which the hedged transaction affected earnings or sooner if management determines that the forecasted transaction is probable of not occurring.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P231_S4	As a result, the Company will continue to experience the earnings impact of these reversals from OCI in future periods.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P232_S0	The Company manages its interest rate risk through the issuance of mostly fixed-rate debt of various maturities.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P232_S1	The Company utilizes internal cash from operations, commercial paper, and credit facilities to meet short-term funding needs.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P232_S2	Short-term obligations are commonly refinanced with fixed-rate bonds or notes when needed and when interest rates are considered favorable.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P232_S3	The Company may enter into swap instruments or other financial hedge instruments to manage the interest rate risk associated with these debts.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P233_S0	In February 2009, Puget Energy entered into interest rate swap transactions to hedge the risk associated with its one-month LIBOR floating debt rate.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P233_S1	As of December 31, 2010, Puget Energy had seven interest rate swap contracts outstanding and PSE did not have any outstanding interest rate swap instruments.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P234_S0	Effective December 6, 2010, Puget Energy elected to de-designate its interest rate derivatives previously recorded as cash flow hedges based on its intent to refinance the underlying debt over the next few years.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P234_S1	The outstanding interest rate derivative loss on December 6, 2010 of $61.8 million was recorded in OCI and will be amortized as the future interest payments on the debt occur.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P234_S2	In addition, a portion of the related forecasted transactions was determined to be remote of occurring and as a result, management reclassified a $7.3 million loss to other deductions in December 2010.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P235_S0	Going forward, all gains or losses associated with the interest rate swaps will be marked-to-market and recorded in earnings.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P235_S1	Puget Energy recorded a $10.9 million gain related to the swaps to interest expense during 2010.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P235_S2	As of December 31, 2010, Puget Energy had not unwound or terminated any of the swaps corresponding to the de-designated cash flow hedge.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P235_S3	A portion of those swaps may remain un-hedged (not linked to any debt) until December 6, 2011 or the Company may unwind or follow other strategies to mitigate the risk of these open positions.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P235_S4	During the period for which these swaps remain un-hedged, the Company will be subject to additional interest rate risk.

1085392_11_ITEM8_P259_S0	For derivative instruments that meet cash flow hedge criteria, the effective portion of the gain or loss on the derivative is reported as a component of OCI and reclassified into earnings in the same period or periods during which the hedged transaction affects earnings.

1085392_11_ITEM8_P266_S0	The Company had the following outstanding contracts as of December 31, 2010:
1085392_11_ITEM8_P267_S0	Unrealized gains (losses) on gas derivatives are offset by a regulatory asset or liability in accordance with ASC 980 due to the PGA mechanism.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P268_S0	The Company is exposed to credit risk primarily through buying and selling electricity and natural gas to serve its customers.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P269_S0	Credit risk is the potential loss resulting from a counterparty s non-performance under an agreement.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P269_S1	The Company manages credit risk with policies and procedures for, among other things, counterparty credit analysis, exposure measurement, exposure monitoring, and exposure mitigation.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P270_S0	The Company monitors counterparties that have significant swings in credit default swap rates, have credit rating changes by external rating agencies, have changes in ownership or are experiencing financial problems.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P270_S1	Where deemed appropriate, the Company may request collateral or other security from its counterparties to mitigate potential credit default losses.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P270_S2	Criteria employed in this decision include, among other things, the perceived creditworthiness of the counterparty and the expected credit exposure.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P271_S0	It is possible that volatility in energy commodity prices could cause the Company to have material credit risk exposure with one or more counterparties.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P271_S1	If such counterparties fail to perform their obligations under one or more agreements, the Company could suffer a material financial loss.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P271_S2	However, as of December 31, 2010, approximately 99.9% of the Company s energy portfolio exposure, excluding NPNS transactions, is with counterparties that are rated at least investment grade by the major rating agencies and 0.1% are either rated below investment grade or not rated by rating agencies.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P271_S3	The Company assesses credit risk internally for counterparties that are not rated.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P272_S0	The Company generally enters into the following master agreements: (1) WSPP, Inc. (WSPP) agreements standardized power sales contract in the electric industry; (2) International Swaps and Derivatives Association (ISDA) agreements standardized financial gas and electric contracts; and (3) North American Energy Standards Board (NAESB) agreements standardized physical gas contracts.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P272_S1	The Company believes that such agreements reduce credit risk exposure because such agreements provide for the netting and offset of monthly payments and, in the event of counterparty default, termination payments.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P273_S0	The Company computes credit reserves at a master agreement level by counterparty (i.e., WSPP, ISDA, or NAESB).
1085392_11_ITEM8_P273_S1	The Company considers external credit ratings and market factors, such as credit default swaps and bond spreads, in determination of reserves.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P273_S2	The Company recognizes that external ratings may not always reflect how a market participant perceives a counterparty s risk of default.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P273_S3	The Company uses both default factors published by Standard Poor s and factors derived through analysis of market risk, which reflect the application of an industry standard recovery rate.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P274_S0	The Company selects a default factor by counterparty at an aggregate master agreement level based on a weighted average default tenor for that counterparty s deals.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P274_S1	The default tenor is used by weighting the fair value and contract tenors for all deals for each counterparty and coming up with an average value.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P274_S2	The default factor used is dependent upon whether the counterparty is in a net asset or a net liability position after applying the master agreement levels.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P275_S0	The Company applies the counterparty s default factor to compute credit reserves for counterparties that are in a net asset position.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P275_S1	Moreover, the Company applies its own default factor to compute credit reserves for counterparties that are in a net liability position.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P276_S0	Credit reserves are booked as contra accounts to unrealized gain (loss) positions.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P276_S1	As of December 31, 2010, the Company was in a net liability position with the majority of counterparties, so the default factors of counterparties did not have a significant impact on reserves for the year.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P277_S0	The majority of the Company s derivative contracts are with financial institutions and other utilities operating within the Western Electricity Coordinating Council.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P277_S1	Despite its net liability position, PSE was not required to post any additional collateral with any of its counterparties.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P277_S2	Additionally, PSE did not trigger any collateral requirements with any of its counterparties nor were any of PSE s counterparties required to post additional collateral resulting from credit rating downgrades.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P278_S0	As of December 31, 2010, the Company did not have any outstanding energy supply contracts with counterparties that contained credit risk related contingent features, which could result in a counterparty requesting immediate payment or demanding immediate and ongoing full overnight collateralization on derivative instruments in a net liability position.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P279_S0	The table below presents the fair value of the overall contractual contingent liability positions for the Company s derivative activity at December 31, 2010:
1085392_11_ITEM8_P280_S0	Represents the derivative fair value of contracts with contingent features for counterparties in net derivative liability positions at December 31, 2010.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P280_S1	Excludes NPNS, accounts payable and accounts receivable liability.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P281_S0	Failure by PSE to maintain an investment grade credit rating from each of the major credit rating s agencies provides counterparties a contractual right to demand collateral.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P282_S0	Collateral requirements may vary, based on changes in forward value of underlying transactions relative to contractually defined collateral thresholds.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P283_S0	ASC 820 establishes a fair value hierarchy that prioritizes the inputs used to measure fair value.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P283_S1	The hierarchy gives the highest priority to unadjusted quoted prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities (Level 1 measurement) and the lowest priority to unobservable inputs (Level 3 measurement).
1085392_11_ITEM8_P283_S2	The three levels of the fair value hierarchy defined by ASC 820 are as follows:
1085392_11_ITEM8_P284_S0	Level 1 Quoted prices are available in active markets for identical assets or liabilities as of the reporting date.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P285_S0	Active markets are those in which transactions for the asset or liability occur in sufficient frequency and volume to provide pricing information on an ongoing basis.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P286_S0	Level 1 primarily consists of financial instruments such as exchange-traded derivatives and listed equities.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P286_S1	Equity securities that are also classified as cash equivalents are considered Level 1 if there are unadjusted quoted prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P287_S0	Level 2 Pricing inputs are other than quoted prices in active markets included in Level 1, which are either directly or indirectly observable as of the reported date.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P288_S0	Level 2 includes those financial instruments that are valued using models or other valuation methodologies.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P288_S1	These models are primarily industry-standard models that consider various assumptions, including quoted forward prices for commodities, time value, volatility factors, and current market and contractual prices for the underlying instruments, as well as other relevant economic measures.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P288_S2	Substantially all of these assumptions are observable in the marketplace throughout the full term of the instrument, can be derived from observable data or are supported by observable levels at which transactions are executed in the marketplace.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P289_S0	Instruments in this category include non-exchange-traded derivatives such as over-the-counter forwards and options.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P290_S0	Level 3 Pricing inputs include significant inputs that are generally less observable from objective sources.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P290_S1	These inputs may be used with internally developed methodologies that result in management s best estimate of fair value.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P291_S0	Level 3 instruments include those that may be more structured or otherwise tailored to customers needs.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P291_S1	At each balance sheet date, the Company performs an analysis of all instruments subject to ASC 820 and includes in Level 3 all of those instruments whose fair value is based on significant unobservable inputs.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P292_S0	Financial assets and liabilities are classified in their entirety based on the lowest level of input that is significant to the fair value measurement.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P292_S1	If a fair value measurement relies on inputs from different levels of the hierarchy, the entire measurement must be placed based on the lowest level input that is significant to the fair value measurement.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P292_S2	The Company s assessment of the significance of a particular input to the fair value measurement requires judgment and may affect the valuation of fair value assets and liabilities and their placement within the fair value hierarchy levels.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P293_S0	On a daily basis, the Company obtains quoted forward prices for the electric and natural gas market from an independent external pricing service.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P293_S1	Those forward price quotes are then used in addition to other various inputs to determine the reported fair value.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P293_S2	Some of the inputs include the credit standing of the counterparties involved and the impact of credit enhancements (such as cash deposits, letters of credit and priority interests), assumptions for time value and also the impact of the Company s nonperformance risk on its liabilities.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P294_S0	As of December 31, 2010, the Company considered the markets for its electric and natural gas Level 2 derivative instruments to be actively traded.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P294_S1	Management s assessment is based on the trading activity volume in real-time and forward electric and natural gas markets.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P294_S2	The Company regularly confirms the validity of pricing service quoted prices (e.g. Level 2 in the fair value hierarchy) used to value commodity contracts to the actual prices of commodity contracts entered into during the most recent quarter.

1085392_11_ITEM8_P300_S0	Unrealized gains and losses on energy derivatives for Level 3 recurring items are included in the net unrealized (gain) loss on derivative instruments section in the Company s consolidated statements of income.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P301_S0	The Company does not believe that the fair value diverges materially from the amounts the Company currently anticipates realizing on settlement or maturity.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P302_S0	Certain energy derivative instruments are classified as Level 3 in the fair value hierarchy because Level 3 inputs are significant to their fair value measurement.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P302_S1	Energy derivatives transferred out of Level 3 represent existing assets or liabilities that were classified as Level 3 at the start of the reporting period for which the lowest significant input became observable during the current reporting period and were transferred into Level 2.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P302_S2	Conversely, energy derivatives transferred into Level 3 from Level 2 represent scenarios in which the lowest significant input became unobservable during the current reporting period.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P302_S3	The Company had no transfers between Level 2 and Level 1 during the year ended December 31, 2010 or 2009.

1085392_11_ITEM8_P305_S0	PSE has a defined benefit pension plan covering substantially all PSE employees.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P305_S1	Pension benefits earned are a function of age, salary and years of service.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P305_S2	PSE also maintains a non-qualified Supplemental Executive Retirement Plan (SERP) for its key senior management employees.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P305_S3	In addition to providing pension benefits, PSE provides certain health care and life insurance benefits for retired employees.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P305_S4	These benefits are provided principally through an insurance company.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P305_S5	The insurance premiums are based on the benefits provided during the year, and are paid primarily by retirees.

1085392_11_ITEM8_P312_S0	As a result of the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act of 2010, PSE recorded a one-time tax expense of $0.8 million during the three months ended March 31, 2010, related to a Medicare D subsidy that PSE receives.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P312_S1	These subsidies have been non-taxable in the past and will be subject to federal income taxes after 2012 as a result of the legislation.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P313_S0	As part of PSE s new contract with the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers (IBEW) Local 77 union, which took effect September 1, 2010, the benefit calculation formula has changed for Company employees covered by the contract.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P313_S1	IBEW represented employees hired after August 31, 2010 and employees not vested in a plan benefit as of July 31, 2010 participate in the cash balance formula of the retirement program, with any accrued benefit converted to a beginning cash balance account.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P313_S2	Employees who were vested in a plan benefit as of July 31, 2010 had a choice to convert to the cash balance formula or remain on a final average earnings formula based on qualified pay and years of service.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P313_S3	All employees accruing benefits under the cash balance formula receive the same investment plan match and Company contribution.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P313_S4	Effective December 1, 2010, the IBEW represented employees who accrue benefits under the cash balance formula receive a higher matching contribution and an additional Company contribution as compared to IBEW represented employees who are covered by the final average earnings formula.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P313_S5	These are the same formulas applied to non-union represented employees.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P313_S6	IBEW represented employees who were rehired after August 31, 2010, will accrue future benefits under the cash balance formula and will be able to elect to convert their prior benefits to the cash balance formula.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P313_S7	As a result of these changes to the IBEW contract, approximately 88.0% of the employees are in the cash balance formula and approximately 12.0% of the employees are in the final average earnings formula.

1085392_11_ITEM8_P315_S0	The Company calculates the present value of the pension liability using a discount rate of 5.15% which represents the single-rate equivalent of the AA rated corporate bond yield curve.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P316_S0	6.50% is the benefit cost discount rate used by Puget Energy.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P316_S1	6.20% is the benefit cost discount rate use by PSE.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P316_S2	The discount rates for the net periodic costs for Puget Energy and PSE were different because of the discount rates in effect as of February 5, 2009, and December 31, 2008, respectively.

1085392_11_ITEM8_P318_S0	The Company has selected the expected return on plan assets based on a historical analysis of rates of return and the Company s investment mix, market conditions, inflation and other factors.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P318_S1	The expected rate of return is reviewed annually based on these factors.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P319_S0	The Company s accounting policy for calculating the market-related value of assets for the Company s retirement plan is as follows.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P319_S1	PSE market-related value of assets is based on a five-year smoothing of asset gains/losses measured from the expected return on market-related assets.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P319_S2	This is a calculated value that recognizes changes in fair value in a systematic and rational manner over five years.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P319_S3	The same manner of calculating market-related value is used for all classes of assets, and is applied consistently from year to year.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P320_S0	Puget Energy s pension and other postretirement benefits income or costs depend on several factors and assumptions, including plan design, timing and amount of cash contributions to the plan, earnings on plan assets, discount rate, expected long-term rate of return, mortality and health care costs trends.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P320_S1	Changes in any of these factors or assumptions will affect the amount of income or expense that Puget Energy records in its financial statements in future years and its projected benefit obligation.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P321_S0	Puget Energy has selected an expected return on plan assets based on a historical analysis of rates of return and Puget Energy s investment mix, market conditions, inflation and other factors.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P321_S1	As required by merger accounting rules, market-related value was reset to market value effective with the merger.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P322_S0	The discount rates were determined by using market interest rate data and the weighted-average discount rate from Citigroup Pension Liability Index Curve.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P322_S1	The Company also takes into account in determining the discount rate the expected changes in market interest rates and anticipated changes in the duration of the plan liabilities.

1085392_11_ITEM8_P328_S1	All changes to the investment policies are reviewed and approved by the Retirement Plan Committee prior to being implemented.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P329_S0	The Retirement Plan Committee invests trust assets with investment managers who have historically achieved above-median long-term investment performance within the risk and asset allocation limits that have been established.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P329_S1	Interim evaluations are routinely performed with the assistance of an outside investment consultant.

1085392_11_ITEM8_P331_S0	Effective December 31, 2009, ASC 715 directs companies to provide additional disclosures about plan assets of a defined benefit pension or other postretirement plan.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P331_S1	The objectives of the disclosures are to disclose the following: (1) how investment allocation decisions are made, including the factors that are pertinent to an understanding of investment policies and strategies; (2) major categories of plan assets; (3) inputs and valuation techniques used to measure the fair value of plan assets; (4) effect of fair value measurements using significant unobservable inputs (Level 3) on changes in plan assets for the period; and (5) significant concentrations of risk within plan assets.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P332_S0	In September 2009, the FASB issued ASU 2009-12, Fair Value Measurements and Disclosures: Investments in Certain Entities that Calculate Net Asset Value per Share (or Its Equivalent).
1085392_11_ITEM8_P332_S1	The standard allows the reporting entity, as a practical expedient, to measure the fair value of investments that do not have readily determinable fair values on the basis of the net asset value per share of the investment if the net asset value of the investment is calculated in a matter consistent with ASC 946, Financial Services Investment Companies.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P332_S2	The standard requires disclosures about the nature and risk of the investments and whether the investments are probable of being sold at amounts different from the net asset value per share.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P333_S0	The following table sets forth by level, within the fair value hierarchy, the qualified pension plan assets at fair value that were accounted for at fair value on a recurring basis as of December 31, 2010 and 2009:

1085392_11_ITEM8_P339_S3	These investments are a Level 3 under ASC 820 because the plan does not have the ability to redeem the investment in the near-term at the net asset value per share.

1085392_11_ITEM8_P350_S0	Plan participants meeting the Company s stock ownership guidelines could elect to be paid up to 50.0% of the share award in cash.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P350_S1	The portion of the performance share grants that could be paid in cash was classified and accounted for as a liability.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P350_S2	As a result, the compensation expense of these liability awards was recognized over the performance period based on the fair value (i.e., cash value) of the award, and was periodically updated based on expected ultimate cash payout.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P350_S3	Compensation cost recognized during the performance period for the liability portion of the performance grants was based on the closing price of the Company s common stock on the date of measurement and the number of months of service rendered during the period.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P350_S4	The equity portion was valued based on the closing price of the Company s common stock on the grant date.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P350_S5	In connection with the completion of the merger in 2009, all performance shares vested and the Company paid and recognized $9.6 million recorded in merger and related costs for such shares.

1085392_11_ITEM8_P360_S0	The Company s deferred tax liability at December 31, 2010 and 2009 is composed of amounts related to the following types of temporary differences:
1085392_11_ITEM8_P361_S0	The above amounts have been classified in the Balance Sheets as follows:
1085392_11_ITEM8_P362_S0	The Company calculates its deferred tax assets and liabilities under ASC 740.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P362_S1	ASC 740 requires recording deferred tax balances, at the currently enacted tax rate, on assets and liabilities that are reported differently for income tax purposes than for financial reporting purposes.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P362_S2	The utilization of deferred tax assets requires sufficient taxable income in the future years.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P362_S3	ASC 740 requires a valuation allowance on deferred tax assets when it is more likely than not that the deferred tax asset will not be realized.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P362_S4	The Company s PTC carryforwards expire from 2027 through 2030.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P362_S5	The Company s net operating loss carryforwards expire from 2029 through 2030.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P363_S0	For ratemaking purposes, deferred taxes are not provided for certain temporary differences.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P363_S1	PSE has established a regulatory asset for income taxes recoverable through future rates related to those temporary differences for which no deferred taxes have been provided, based on prior and expected future ratemaking treatment.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P364_S0	The Company accounts for uncertain tax position under ASC 740, which clarifies the accounting for uncertainty in income taxes recognized in the financial statements.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P364_S1	ASC 740 requires the use of a two-step approach for recognizing and measuring tax positions taken or expected to be taken in a tax return.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P365_S0	First, a tax position should only be recognized when it is more likely than not, based on technical merits, that the position will be sustained upon examination by the taxing authority.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P365_S1	Second, a tax position that meets the recognition threshold should be measured at the largest amount that has a greater than 50.0% likelihood of being sustained.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P366_S0	As of December 31, 2010 and 2009, the Company had no material unrecognized tax benefits.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P366_S1	As a result, no interest or penalties were accrued for unrecognized tax benefits during the year.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P367_S0	For ASC 740 purposes, the Company has open tax years from 2006 through 2010.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P367_S1	The Company is under audit by the IRS for tax years 2006 and 2008.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P367_S2	The Company classifies interest as interest expense and penalties as other expense in the financial statements.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P368_S0	The following discussion summarizes the status as of the date of this report of ongoing proceedings relating to the western power markets to which PSE is a party.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P368_S1	PSE is vigorously defending the remaining claims.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P368_S2	Litigation is subject to numerous uncertainties and PSE is unable to predict the ultimate outcome of these matters.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P368_S3	Accordingly, there can be no guarantee that these proceedings will not materially and adversely affect PSE s financial condition, results of operations or liquidity.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P369_S0	In October 2000, PSE filed a complaint with the FERC (Docket No.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P369_S1	EL01-10) against all jurisdictional sellers in the Pacific Northwest seeking prospective price caps consistent with any result the FERC ordered for the California markets.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P369_S2	The FERC issued an order including price caps in July 2001, and PSE moved to dismiss the proceeding.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P370_S0	In response to PSE s motion, various entities intervened and sought to convert PSE s complaint into one seeking retroactive refunds in the Pacific Northwest.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P370_S1	The FERC rejected that effort, after holding what the FERC referred to as a preliminary evidentiary hearing before an administrative law judge.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P370_S2	In April 2009, the Ninth Circuit rejected the requests for rehearing filed in this matter and remanded the proceeding to the FERC.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P370_S3	The FERC is now considering what response to take to the Court remand order, as petitions for review by the Supreme Court were denied on January 11, 2010.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P370_S4	PSE intends to vigorously defend its position but is unable to predict the outcome of this matter.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P371_S0	In May 2003, approximately 50 plaintiffs initiated an action against the owners of Colstrip regarding pond seepage, The defendants reached an agreement on a global settlement with all plaintiffs and PSE expensed its share of the settlement in 2008.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P371_S1	PSE received a partial reimbursement for its share from insurers in December 2010 and January 2011.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P372_S0	On March 29, 2007, a second complaint related to pond seepage was filed on behalf of two ranch owners alleging damage due to the Colstrip Units 3 4 effluent holding pond.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P372_S1	A mediation between plaintiffs and PPL Montana, LLC, the operator of Units 3 4, took place in July 2010 and parties are working toward a final settlement.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P373_S0	Petitioners in several actions in the Ninth Circuit against the BPA asserted that the BPA acted contrary to law in entering into or performing or implementing a number of agreements, including the amended settlement agreement (and the May 2004 agreement) between the BPA and PSE regarding the REP.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P373_S1	Petitioners in several actions in the Ninth Circuit against the BPA also asserted that the BPA acted contrary to law in adopting or implementing the rates upon which the benefits received or to be received from the BPA during the October 1, 2001 through September 30, 2006 period were based.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P374_S0	A number of parties claimed that the rates the BPA proposed or adopted in the BPA rate proceeding to develop the BPA rates to be used in the agreements for determining the amounts of money to be paid to PSE by the BPA during the period October 1, 2006 through September 30, 2009 are contrary to law.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P374_S1	Furthermore, the parties claimed the BPA acted contrary to law or without authority in deciding to enter into, or in entering into or performing or implementing such agreements.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P375_S0	On May 3, 2007, the Ninth Circuit issued an opinion in Portland Gen. Elec. v. BPA , Case No. 01-70003, in which proceeding the actions of the BPA in entering into settlement agreements regarding the REP with PSE and with other investor-owned utilities were challenged.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P375_S1	In this opinion, the Ninth Circuit granted petitions for review and held the settlement agreements entered into between the BPA and the investor-owned utilities being challenged in that proceeding to be inconsistent with statute.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P375_S2	On May 3, 2007, the Ninth Circuit also issued an opinion in Golden Northwest Aluminum v. BPA , Case No. 03-73426, in which proceeding the petitioners sought review of BPA s 2002-2006 power rates.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P375_S3	In this opinion, the Ninth Circuit granted petitions for review and held that the BPA unlawfully shifted onto its preference customers the costs of its settlements with the investor-owned utilities.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P375_S4	On October 11, 2007, the Ninth Circuit remanded the May 2004 agreement to the BPA in light of the Portland Gen. Elec. v. BPA opinion and dismissed the remaining three pending cases regarding settlement agreements.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P376_S0	In March 2008, the BPA and PSE signed an agreement pursuant to which BPA made a payment to PSE related to the REP benefits for the fiscal year ended September 30, 2008, which payment is subject to true-up depending upon the amount of any REP benefits ultimately determined to be payable to PSE.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P377_S0	In September 2008, the BPA issued its record of decision in its reopened WP-07 rate proceeding to respond to the various Ninth Circuit opinions.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P377_S1	In this record of decision, the BPA adjusted its fiscal year 2009 rates, determined the amounts of REP benefits it considered to have been improperly paid after fiscal year 2001 to PSE and the other regional investor-owned utilities, and determined that such amounts are to be recovered through reductions in REP benefit payments to be made over a number of years.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P377_S2	The amount determined by the BPA to be recovered through reductions commencing October 2007 in REP payments for PSE s residential and small farm customers was approximately $207.2 million plus interest on unrecovered amounts to the extent that PSE receives any REP benefits for its customers in the future.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P377_S3	However, these BPA determinations are subject to subsequent administrative and judicial review, which may alter or reverse such determinations.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P377_S4	PSE and others, including a number of preference agency and investor-owned utility customers of the BPA, in December 2008 filed petitions for review in the Ninth Circuit of various of these BPA determinations.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P377_S5	Any change to the REP would be passed to customers.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P378_S0	In September 2008, the BPA and PSE signed a short-term Residential Purchase and Sale Agreement (RPSA) under which the BPA is to pay REP benefits to PSE for fiscal years ending September 30, 2009 2011.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P378_S1	In December 2008, the BPA and PSE signed another, long-term RPSA under which the BPA is to pay REP benefits to PSE for the period October 2011 through September 2028.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P378_S2	PSE and other customers of BPA in December 2008 filed petitions for review in the Ninth Circuit of the short-term and long-term RPSAs signed by PSE (and similar RPSAs signed by other investor-owned utility customers of the BPA) and the BPA s record of decision regarding such RPSAs.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P379_S0	Generally, REP benefit payments under a RPSA are based on the amount, if any, by which a utility's average system cost exceeds the BPA s Priority Firm (PF) Exchange rate for such utility.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P380_S0	The average system cost for a utility is determined using an average system cost methodology adopted by the BPA.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P380_S1	The average system cost methodology adopted by the BPA and the average system cost determinations, REP overpayment determinations, and the PF Exchange rate determinations by the BPA are all subject to FERC review or judicial review or both and are subject to adjustment, which may affect the amount of REP benefits paid or to be paid by the BPA to PSE.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P380_S2	As discussed above, the BPA has determined to reduce such payments based on its determination of REP benefit overpayments after fiscal year 2001.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P381_S0	It is not clear what impact, if any, such development or review of such the BPA rates, average system cost, average system cost methodology, and the BPA determination of REP overpayments, review of such agreements, and the above described Ninth Circuit litigation may ultimately have on PSE.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P382_S0	On July 7, 2010, a lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington by the Snoqualmie Valley Preservation Alliance, a group of downstream landowners, against the United States Army Corps of Engineers (Corps) challenging permits issued by the Corps in connection with the redevelopment of the Snoqualmie Falls Hydroelectric Project.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P382_S1	Plaintiffs request an order to stop work at the project pending further review of downstream impacts.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P382_S2	PSE sought and was granted permission to intervene in the proceeding.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P383_S0	Motions for summary judgment have been filed by the plaintiff and the Corps.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P383_S1	PSE joined the Corps motion and filed a motion for summary judgment arguing the plaintiff s claims are barred as untimely and improper.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P383_S2	The parties await a determination by the Court.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P383_S3	The ultimate impact of the suit, if any, on PSE or the work currently underway on the project cannot be determined at this time.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P383_S4	The construction schedule has not been impacted by the lawsuit.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P384_S0	In accordance with ASC 810, Consolidation (ASC 810), a business entity that has a controlling financial interest in a VIE should consolidate the VIE in its financial statements.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P385_S0	A primary beneficiary of a VIE is the variable interest holder that has both the power to direct matters that significantly impact the activities of the VIE and has the obligation to absorb losses or the right to receive benefits.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P385_S1	The Company enters into a variety of contracts for energy with other counterparties and evaluates all contracts to determine if they are variable interests.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P385_S2	The Company s variable interests primarily arise through power purchase agreements where it is required to buy all or a majority of generation from a plant at rates set forth in the agreement.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P386_S0	The Company evaluated its power purchase agreements and determined it was not the primary beneficiary of any VIEs.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P386_S1	The Company had previously disclosed two potentially significant variable interests in prior periods; both entities are qualifying facilities contracts that expire at the end of 2011.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P386_S2	The Company requested information from the relevant entities; however, they have refused to provide the necessary information to the Company, as they are not required to do so under their contracts.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P386_S3	However, if the variable interests were determined to be VIEs, the Company has concluded it is not the primary beneficiary of these entities based on available information and it has no exposure to losses on these contracts.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P386_S4	For the years ended December 31, 2010, 2009 and 2008, the Company s purchased power expense for these entities was $190.3 million, $181.2 million and $196.8 million, respectively.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P387_S0	For the year ended December 31, 2010, approximately 19.2% of the Company s energy output was obtained at an average cost of approximately $0.018 per kilowatt hour (kWh) through long-term contracts with three of the Washington Public Utility Districts (PUDs) that own hydroelectric projects on the Columbia River.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P387_S1	The purchase of power from the Columbia River projects is on a pro rata share basis under which the Company pays a proportionate share of the annual debt service, operating and maintenance costs and other expenses associated with each project in proportion to the contractual shares that PSE obtains from that project.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P387_S2	In these instances, PSE s payments are not contingent upon the projects being operable; therefore, PSE is required to make the payments even if power is not delivered.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P387_S3	These projects are financed through substantially level debt service payments and their annual costs should not vary significantly over the term of the contracts unless additional financing is required to meet the costs of major maintenance, repairs or replacements, or license requirements.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P387_S4	The Company s share of the costs and the output of the projects is subject to reduction due to various withdrawal rights of the PUDs and others over the contract lives.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P388_S0	The following table summarizes the Company s estimated payment obligations for power purchases from the Columbia River projects, contracts with other utilities and contracts under non-utility generators under the Public Utility Regulatory Policies Act.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P388_S1	These contracts have varying terms and may include escalation and termination provisions.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P389_S0	Total purchased power contracts provided the Company with approximately 8.2 million, 8.3 million and 8.7 million megawatt hours (MWh) of firm energy at a cost of approximately $420.6 million, $363.3 million and $384.0 million for the years 2010, 2009 and 2008, respectively.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P390_S0	As part of its electric operations and in connection with the 1997 restructuring of the Tenaska Power Purchase Agreement, PSE is obligated to deliver to Tenaska up to 50,000 MMBtu (one million British thermal units, equal to one Dekatherm (Dth)) per day of natural gas for operation of Tenaska s natural gas-fired cogeneration facility.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P390_S1	This obligation continues for the remaining term of the agreement, through December 31, 2011, provided that no deliveries are required during the month of May.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P391_S0	The price paid by Tenaska for this natural gas is reflective of the daily price of natural gas at the United States/Canada border near Sumas, Washington.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P392_S0	The Company has natural gas-fired generation facility obligations for natural gas supply amounting to an estimated $65.5 million in 2011.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P392_S1	Longer term agreements for natural gas supply amount to an estimated $137.2 million for 2012 through 2029.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P393_S0	PSE enters into short-term energy supply contracts to meet its core customer needs.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P393_S1	These contracts are generally classified as NPNS or in some cases recorded at fair value in accordance with ASC 815.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P393_S2	Commitments under these contracts are $86.0 million, $51.4 million and $9.3 million in 2011, 2012 and 2013, respectively.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P394_S0	The Company has also entered into various firm supply, transportation and storage service contracts in order to ensure adequate availability of natural gas supply for its firm customers.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P394_S1	Many of these contracts, which have remaining terms from less than one year to 34 years, provide that the Company must pay a fixed demand charge each month, regardless of actual usage.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P394_S2	The Company contracts for its long-term natural gas supply on a firm basis, which means the Company has a 100% daily take obligation and the supplier has a 100% daily delivery obligation to ensure service to PSE s customers and generation requirements.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P395_S0	The Company incurred demand charges in 2010 for firm natural gas supply, firm transportation service and firm storage and peaking service of $0.4 million, $136.5 million and $7.1 million, respectively.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P395_S1	The Company incurred demand charges in 2010 for firm transportation and firm storage service for the natural gas supply for its combustion turbines in the amount of $27.7 million, which is included in the total Company demand charges.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P396_S0	The following table summarizes the Company s obligations for future demand charges through the primary terms of its existing contracts.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P396_S1	The quantified obligations are based on current contract prices and the FERC authorized rates, which are subject to change.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P397_S0	The following table summarizes the Company s estimated obligations for service contracts through the terms of its existing contracts.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P398_S0	Energy production service contracts include operations and maintenance contracts on Mint Farm, Wild Horse, Goldendale electric generating facility (Goldendale), Hopkins Ridge and Sumas facilities.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P399_S0	The Company has a self-insurance surety bond in the amount of $4.3 million, which expires on July 1, 2011 and is renewed annually, guaranteeing compliance with the Industrial Insurance Act (workers compensation) and nine self-insurer s pension bonds totaling $1.5 million.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P400_S0	The Company is subject to environmental laws and regulations by the federal, state and local authorities and is required to undertake certain environmental investigative and remedial efforts as a result of these laws and regulations.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P400_S1	The Company has been named by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), the Washington State Department of Ecology and/or other third parties as potentially responsible at several contaminated sites and manufactured gas plant sites.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P401_S0	PSE has implemented an ongoing program to test, replace and remediate certain underground storage tanks (UST) as required by federal and state laws.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P401_S1	The UST replacement component of this effort is finished, but PSE continues its work remediating and/or monitoring relevant sites.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P402_S0	During 1992, the Washington Commission issued orders regarding the treatment of costs incurred by the Company for certain sites under its environmental remediation program.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P402_S1	The orders authorize the Company to accumulate and defer prudently incurred cleanup costs paid to third parties for recovery in rates established in future rate proceedings, subject to Washington Commission review.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P403_S0	The Washington Commission consolidated the gas and electric methodological approaches to remediation and deferred accounting in an order issued October 8, 2008.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P404_S0	Per the guidance of ASC 450, Contingencies , the Company reviews its estimated future obligations and adjusts loss reserves quarterly.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P405_S0	Management believes it is probable and reasonably estimable that the impact of the potential outcomes of disputes with certain property owners and other potentially responsible parties will result in environmental remediation costs ranging from $38.8 million to $55.8 million for gas and from $8.2 million to $27.8 million for electric.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P405_S1	The Company does not consider any amounts within those ranges as being a better estimate and has therefore accrued $38.8 million and $8.2 million for gas and electric, respectively.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P405_S2	The Company believes a significant portion of its past and future environmental remediation costs are recoverable from insurance companies, from third parties or from customers under a Washington Commission order.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P405_S3	For the year ended December 31, 2010, the Company incurred deferred electric and natural gas environmental costs of $7.6 million and $54.7 million, net of insurance proceeds, respectively.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P406_S0	On June 1, 2006, PSE entered into a revolving credit facility with Puget Energy in the form of a Demand Promissory Note (Note).
1085392_11_ITEM8_P406_S1	Through the Note, PSE may borrow up to $30.0 million from Puget Energy, subject to approval by Puget Energy.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P406_S2	Under the terms of the Note, PSE pays interest on the outstanding borrowings based on the lowest of the weighted-average interest rate of PSE s outstanding commercial paper interest rate or PSE s senior unsecured revolving credit facility.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P406_S3	Absent such borrowings, interest is charged at one-month LIBOR plus 0.25%.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P406_S4	At December 31, 2010 and December 31, 2009, the outstanding balance of the Note was $22.6 million and $22.9 million, respectively, and the interest rate was 1.1% and 1.2%, respectively.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P406_S5	The outstanding balance and the related interest under the Note are eliminated by Puget Energy upon consolidation of PSE s financial statements.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P406_S6	The $30.0 million credit facility with Puget Energy was unaffected by the merger.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P407_S0	On December 6, 2010, Puget Energy issued $450.0 million of senior secured notes.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P407_S1	Net proceeds of $443.0 million from these notes were used to repay a portion of the $1.225 billion term-loan.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P408_S0	Puget Energy s term-loan and facility for funding capital expenditures mature in 2014, contain similar terms and conditions and are syndicated among numerous committed banks and other financial institutions.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P408_S1	One of these banks is Macquarie Bank Limited, which has commitments of $48.0 million under the term-loan and $20.6 million under the capital expenditure credit facility.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P408_S2	Concurrent with the borrowings under these credit agreements, Puget Energy entered into several interest rate swap instruments to hedge volatility associated with these two loans.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P408_S3	Two of the swap instruments were entered into with Macquarie Bank Limited with a total notional amount of $444.9 million.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P408_S4	These swap instruments remained outstanding at December 31, 2010.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P409_S0	At the time of merger, Puget Energy recorded the fair value of its intangible assets in accordance with ASC 360.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P409_S1	The fair value assigned to the power contracts was determined using an income approach comparing the contract rate to the market rate for power over the remaining period of the contracts incorporating nonperformance risk.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P409_S2	Management also incorporated certain assumptions related to quantities and market presentation that it believes market participants would make in the valuation.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P410_S0	The fair value of the power contracts is amortized as the contracts settle.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P411_S0	ASC 360 requires long-live assets to be tested for impairment on an on-going basis, whenever events or circumstances would more likely than not reduce the fair value of the long-lived assets below its carrying value.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P411_S1	One such triggering event is a significant decrease in market price.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P412_S0	Puget Energy completed a valuation and impairment test as of December 31, 2010 for long-term power purchase contracts and SO2 emission allowances that were assets.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P412_S1	The carrying value of Puget Energy s power contracts and SO2 emission allowances as of December 31, 2010 was approximately $864.7 million and $7.9 million, respectively.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P412_S2	The excess of the carrying value over the fair value of the power contracts was $105.8 million which was written-off against regulatory liabilities at December 31, 2010.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P412_S3	The excess of the carrying value over the fair value of the SO2 emissions was $7.9 million which was expensed at December 31, 2010.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P413_S0	During the fourth quarter of 2010, management discovered errors in Puget Energy s SO2 emission allowances for 2009 and 2010 interim periods.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P413_S1	Management did not perform the required impairment tests until the fourth quarter of 2010.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P413_S2	As a result, an impairment charge of $7.6 million was recognized within non-utility and other expenses as of December 31, 2010.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P414_S0	During the second quarter of 2010, management corrected accounting errors in the Companies financial statements that resulted in an increase to depreciation expense of $2.2 million, a net decrease to electric revenue and purchased electricity of $1.8 million and a decrease to income tax expense of $1.5 million.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P415_S0	The impact of correcting these errors in prior periods would have reduced Puget Energy s net income by $3.5 million and $1.3 million in 2009 and 2008, respectively, and PSE s net income by $1.1 million in 2009.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P415_S1	Management determined these errors were not material to the prior annual or interim periods or to the current annual or interim periods in which they are being corrected and, therefore, the Company recorded a reduction to Puget Energy s net income of $4.8 million and PSE s net income of $2.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2010.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P416_S0	Puget Energy operates one business segment referred to as the regulated utility segment.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P416_S1	The regulated utility segment includes the account receivables securitization program which was terminated during the merger.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P417_S0	Puget Energy s regulated utility operation generates, purchases and sells electricity and purchases, transports and sells natural gas.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P417_S1	The service territory of PSE covers approximately 6,000 square miles in the state of Washington.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P418_S0	Non-utility business segment includes two PSE subsidiaries, and Puget Energy, is described as Other.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P418_S1	The PSE subsidiaries are a real estate investment and development company and a holding company for a small non-utility wholesale generator which was sold in 2010.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P418_S2	Reconciling items between segments are not significant.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P419_S0	Effective February 6, 2009, all merger related fair value adjustments were retained in Puget Energy.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P419_S1	Accordingly, only the financial statements of Puget Energy were adjusted to reflect the purchase accounting.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P419_S2	Prior to the merger, the business segment financial statements for Puget Energy and PSE were the same.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P420_S0	The following unaudited amounts, in the opinion of the Company, include all adjustments (consisting of normal recurring adjustments) necessary for a fair statement of the results of operations for the interim periods.
1085392_11_ITEM8_P421_S0	Quarterly amounts vary during the year due to the seasonal nature of the utility business.
