1085392_12_ITEM1_P51_S1	PSE agrees to pay a share of the annual debt service, operating and maintenance costs and other expenses associated with each project in proportion to its share of projected output.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P51_S2	PSE s payments are not contingent upon the projects being operable.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P52_S0	As of December 31, 2011, PSE was entitled to purchase portions of the power output of the PUDs projects as set forth below:
1085392_12_ITEM1_P53_S0	On February 3, 2006, PSE and Chelan entered into a new Power Sales Agreement and a related Transmission Agreement for 25.0% of the output of Chelan s Rocky Reach and Rock Island hydroelectric generating facilities, located on the mid-Columbia River, in exchange for PSE paying 25.0% of the operating costs of the facilities.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P53_S1	The agreements terminate in 2031 and provide that PSE will begin to receive power upon expiration of PSE s existing long-term contracts with Chelan for the Rocky Reach and Rock Island output (expiring in 2011 and 2012, respectively).
1085392_12_ITEM1_P53_S2	PSE made a non-refundable capacity reservation payment of $89.0 million as required by the agreements.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P53_S3	The Washington Commission determined the prudence of PSE entering into the new Chelan contracts and confirmed the treatment of the $89.0 million as a regulatory asset as part of its order in PSE s general rate case on January 5, 2007.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P54_S0	Douglas County PUD began the FERC integrated licensing process in 2004 and is progressing on schedule for a new license upon the current license expiration in May 2012.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P55_S0	PSE s share of power under the 2001 contract will decline over time as Grant County PUD s load increases.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P55_S1	PSE s share of both the Priest Rapids and Wanapum developments was 0.8% at the end of 2011 and will not be less than 0.6% through 2052.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P56_S0	PSE purchases electric energy under long-term firm purchased power contracts with other utilities and marketers in the Western region.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P56_S1	PSE is generally not obligated to make payments under these contracts unless power is delivered.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P57_S0	PSE has seasonal energy and capacity exchange agreements with the BPA (for 42 average megawatts (aMW) of capacity) and with Pacific Gas Electric Company (for 300 MW of capacity).
1085392_12_ITEM1_P58_S0	Pursuant to the provisions of the federal Public Utility Regulatory Policies Act (PURPA) and Washington state regulations, PSE also enters into long-term firm purchased power contracts with non-utility generators.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P58_S1	PSE purchases the net electrical output of these projects at fixed and annually escalating prices, intended to approximate PSE s avoided cost of new generation projected at the time these agreements were made.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P59_S0	During 2011, PSE had agreements with March Point Cogeneration Company for 140 MW capacity of power output and 123 aMW of energy; and Tenaska Washington Partners, L.P. for 245 MW capacity of power output and 216 aMW of energy.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P59_S1	Both contracts expired December 31, 2011 and there is no obligation to extend the contracts.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P60_S0	Further, PSE has entered into multiple various-term transmission contracts with other utilities to integrate electric generation and contracted resources into PSE s system.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P60_S1	These transmission contracts require PSE to pay for transmission service based on the contracted MW level of demand, regardless of actual use.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P61_S0	Other transmission agreements provide actual capacity ownership or capacity ownership rights.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P61_S1	PSE s annual charges under these agreements are also based on contracted MW volumes.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P61_S2	Capacity on these agreements that is not committed to serve PSE s load is available for sale to third parties.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P61_S3	PSE also purchases short-term transmission services from a variety of providers, including the BPA.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P62_S0	In 2011, PSE had 4,020 MW and 619 MW of total transmission demand contracted with the BPA and other utilities, respectively.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P62_S1	PSE s remaining transmission capacity needs are met via PSE owned transmission assets.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P63_S0	PSE purchases natural gas supplies for its power portfolio to meet demand for its combustion turbine generators.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P63_S1	Supplies range from long-term to daily agreements, as the demand for the turbines varies depending on market heat rates.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P63_S2	Purchases are made from a diverse group of major and independent natural gas producers and marketers in the United States and Canada.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P63_S3	PSE also enters into physical and financial fixed price derivative instruments to hedge the cost of natural gas.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P64_S0	PSE utilizes natural gas storage capacity that is dedicated to and paid for by the power portfolio to facilitate increased natural gas supply reliability and intra-day dispatch of PSE s gas-fired generation resources.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P64_S1	During 2011, approximately 83.0% of natural gas for power purchased by PSE for power customers originated in British Columbia and 17.0% originated in the United States.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P65_S0	Natural gas is either marketed outside PSE s service territory (off-system sales) or injected into the power portfolio s natural gas storage when the natural gas is not needed for the combustion turbines.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P66_S0	PSE is required by Washington Commission regulations to file electric and natural gas Integrated Resource Plans (IRP) every two years with the next IRP scheduled to be filed by May 30, 2013.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P66_S1	PSE filed its most recent IRP with the Washington Commission on May 30, 2011.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P67_S0	The 2011 IRP demonstrated PSE s continuing need to acquire significant amounts of new generating resources, driven primarily by the expiration of existing power purchase contracts and by the requirements of the state s renewable portfolio standard.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P67_S1	The 2011 IRP, as filed, identified the following capacity needs:
1085392_12_ITEM1_P68_S0	To meet these expected shortfalls, the 2011 IRP identified a mix of energy efficiency programs, additional renewable resources (primarily wind) and base-load natural gas-fired generation to meet the growing needs of PSE s customers.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P68_S1	The specific resources acquired will be determined through the Company s resource acquisition program which examines specific acquisition and development opportunities.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P69_S0	With the planned addition of the Lower Snake River Project Phase 1, PSE has enough renewable resources to meet statutory renewable resource requirements through 2020.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P69_S1	The 2009 and 2011 IRP confirmed that there is a cost benefit to customers of building ahead of renewable need and taking advantage of expiring tax incentives rather than waiting until there is a statutory need to develop more renewable energy.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P70_S0	In 2009, PSE purchased from RES America, Inc., all of the undivided interest in four development-stage wind projects, collectively known as the Lower Snake River wind project in Columbia and Garfield counties in Washington state.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P70_S1	PSE is currently completing construction of Phase 1 of the Lower Snake River wind project, which will total 343 MW of capacity when complete in the first quarter of 2012.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P71_S0	PSE purchases a portfolio of natural gas supplies ranging from long-term firm to daily from a diverse group of major and independent natural gas producers and marketers in the United States and Canada.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P71_S1	PSE also enters into physical and financial fixed-price derivative instruments to hedge the cost of natural gas to serve its customers.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P71_S2	All of PSE s natural gas supply is ultimately transported through the facilities of Northwest Pipeline GP (NWP), the sole interstate pipeline delivering directly into PSE s service territory.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P71_S3	Accordingly, delivery of natural gas supply to PSE s natural gas system is dependent upon the reliable operations of NWP.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P72_S0	All peak firm gas supplies and storage are connected to PSE s market with firm transportation capacity.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P73_S0	For baseload, peak management and supply reliability purposes, PSE supplements its firm natural gas supply portfolio by purchasing natural gas in off-peak periods, injecting it into underground storage facilities and withdrawing it during the peak winter heating season.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P73_S1	Underground storage facilities at Jackson Prairie in western Washington and at Clay Basin in Utah are used for this purpose.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P74_S0	Clay Basin withdrawals are used to supplant purchases from the U.S.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P74_S1	Rocky Mountain supply region, while Jackson Prairie provides incremental peak-day resources utilizing storage redelivery transportation capacity.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P74_S2	Jackson Prairie is also used for daily balancing of load requirements on PSE s gas system.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P74_S3	Peaking needs are also met by; using PSE-owned natural gas held in NWP s liquefied natural gas (LNG) storage facility in Plymouth, Washington; using PSE-owned natural gas held in PSE s LNG peaking facility located within its distribution system in Gig Harbor, Washington; and interrupting service to customers on interruptible service rates.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P75_S0	PSE expects to meet its firm peak-day requirements for residential, commercial and industrial markets through its firm natural gas purchase contracts, firm transportation capacity, firm storage capacity and other firm peaking resources.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P75_S1	PSE believes it will be able to acquire incremental firm natural gas supply and capacity to meet anticipated growth in the requirements of its firm customers for the foreseeable future.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P76_S0	During 2011, approximately 49.5% of natural gas supplies purchased by PSE for its gas customers originated in British Columbia, while 14.8% originated in Alberta and 35.7% originated in the United States.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P77_S0	PSE s firm natural gas supply portfolio has adequate flexibility in its transportation arrangements to enable it to achieve savings when there are regional price differentials between natural gas supply basins.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P77_S1	The geographic mix of suppliers and daily, monthly and annual take requirements permit some degree of flexibility in managing natural gas supplies during off-peak periods to minimize costs.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P77_S2	Natural gas is marketed outside PSE s service territory (off-system sales) whenever on-system customer demand requirements permit and the resulting economics of these transactions are reflected in PSE s natural gas customer tariff rates through the PGA mechanism.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P78_S0	PSE holds storage capacity in the Jackson Prairie and Clay Basin underground natural gas storage facilities adjacent to NWP s pipeline to serve PSE s natural gas customers.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P78_S1	The Jackson Prairie facility is operated and one-third owned by PSE.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P78_S2	The facility is used primarily for intermediate peaking purposes since it is able to deliver a large volume of natural gas over a relatively short time period.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P78_S3	Combined with capacity contracted from NWP s one-third stake in Jackson Prairie, PSE has peak firm withdrawal capacity in excess of 460,000 Dekatherm (Dth) per day, which, after reduction for a portion temporarily released to the power portfolio represents nearly 46.8% of PSE s expected near-term peak-day requirement.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P78_S4	PSE s total firm storage capacity of the facility is in excess of 10 million Dth.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P78_S5	The location of the Jackson Prairie facility in PSE s market area increases supply reliability and provides significant pipeline demand cost savings by reducing the amount of annual pipeline capacity required to meet peak-day natural gas requirements.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P79_S0	PSE has been expanding the storage capacity at Jackson Prairie since March 2003.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P79_S1	The most recent withdrawal capacity expansion was placed in service in November 2008 and the reservoir expansion activities will continue through 2012.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P79_S2	The owned storage capacity at Jackson Prairie was 8.4 million Dth at December 31, 2011.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P79_S3	Once the expansion activities have been completed in 2012, the capacity will be 8.5 million Dth.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P80_S0	Due to the recent expansion of Jackson Prairie storage withdrawal capacity and storage capacity, PSE s natural gas storage resources are expected to exceed natural gas customer requirements for the next few years.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P80_S1	Therefore, beginning in 2008 and continuing into 2014, 50,000 Dth per day of natural gas storage withdrawal capacity and 500,000 Dth of natural gas storage capacity have been temporarily released at market sensitive rates to PSE s power portfolio, increasing natural gas supply reliability and facilitating intra-day dispatch of PSE s natural gas-fired generation resources.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P81_S0	The Clay Basin storage facility is a supply area storage facility that is used primarily to reduce portfolio costs through supply management efforts that take advantage of market price volatility, and provides system reliability.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P81_S1	PSE holds over 12.8 million Dth of Clay Basin storage capacity and approximately 107,000 Dth per day of firm withdrawal capacity under two long-term contracts with remaining terms of one and eight years.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P81_S2	PSE s maximum firm withdrawal capacity and total storage capacity at Clay Basin, net of releases, is over 82,000 Dth per day and exceeds 9.8 million Dth, respectively.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P82_S0	LNG and propane-air resources provide firm natural gas supply on short notice for short periods of time.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P82_S1	Due to their typically high cost and slow cycle times, these resources are normally utilized as a last resort supply source in extreme peak-demand periods, typically during the coldest hours or days.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P83_S0	PSE contracts for LNG storage services of 241,700 Dth of PSE-owned gas at NWP s Plymouth facility, which is approximately three and one-half day s supply at a maximum daily deliverability of 70,500 Dth.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P84_S0	PSE owns and operates the Swarr vaporized propane-air station located in Renton, Washington which includes storage capacity for approximately 1.5 million gallons of propane.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P84_S1	This propane-air injection facility is designed to deliver the equivalent of 10,000 Dth of natural gas per day for up to 12 days directly into PSE s distribution system.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P85_S0	PSE owns and operates an LNG peaking facility in Gig Harbor, Washington, with total capacity of 10,600 Dth, which is capable of delivering the equivalent of 2,500 Dth of natural gas per day.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P86_S0	PSE currently holds firm transportation capacity on pipelines owned by NWP, Gas Transmission Northwest (GTN), Nova Gas Transmission (NOVA), Foothills Pipe Lines (Foothills) and Westcoast Energy (Westcoast).
1085392_12_ITEM1_P86_S1	GTN, NOVA, and Foothills are all TransCanada companies.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P87_S0	PSE pays fixed monthly demand charges for the right, but not the obligation, to transport specified quantities of natural gas from receipt points to delivery points on such pipelines each day for the term or terms of the applicable agreements.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P88_S0	PSE holds approximately 522,000 Dth per day of capacity for its natural gas customers on NWP that provides firm year-round delivery to PSE s service territory.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P88_S1	In addition, PSE holds approximately 524,000 Dth per day of seasonal firm capacity on NWP to provide for delivery of natural gas stored in Jackson Prairie and the Plymouth LNG facility during the heating season.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P88_S2	PSE has firm transportation capacity on NWP through various contracts that supply electric generating facilities with approximately 168,000 Dth per day.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P88_S3	PSE participates in the pipeline capacity release market to achieve savings for PSE s customers and has released certain segments of temporarily surplus firm capacity to third parties.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P88_S4	PSE s firm transportation capacity contracts with NWP have remaining terms ranging from one to 33 years.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P88_S5	However, PSE has either the unilateral right to extend the contracts under the contracts current terms or the right of first refusal to extend such contracts under current FERC rules.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P89_S0	PSE s firm transportation capacity for its natural gas customers on Westcoast s pipeline is approximately 130,000 Dth per day under various contracts, with remaining terms of one to seven years.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P89_S1	PSE has other firm transportation capacity on Westcoast s pipeline, which supplies the electric generating facilities, totaling approximately 73,000 Dth per day, with remaining terms of three to seven years.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P89_S2	PSE has firm transportation capacity on NOVA and Foothills pipelines, totaling approximately 80,000 Dth per day, with remaining terms of two to 12 years.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P89_S3	PSE has annual renewal rights on this capacity.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P89_S4	PSE s firm transportation capacity on the GTN pipeline, totaling approximately 90,000 Dth per day, has a remaining term of 12 years.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P90_S0	The FERC regulates the release of firm pipeline and storage capacity for facilities which fall under its jurisdiction.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P90_S1	Capacity releases allow shippers to temporarily or permanently relinquish unutilized capacity to recover all or a portion of the cost of such capacity.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P90_S2	The FERC allows capacity to be released through several methods including open bidding and pre-arrangement.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P90_S3	PSE has acquired some firm pipeline and storage service through capacity release provisions to serve its growing service territory and electric generation portfolio.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P90_S4	PSE also mitigates a portion of the demand charges related to unutilized storage and pipeline capacity through capacity release.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P90_S5	Capacity release benefits derived from the natural gas customer portfolio are passed on to PSE s natural gas customers through the PGA mechanism.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P91_S0	PSE is required under Washington state law to pursue feasible, achievable cost-effective electric conservation.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P92_S0	PSE offers programs designed to help new and existing residential, commercial and industrial customers use energy efficiently.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P92_S1	PSE uses a variety of mechanisms including cost-effective financial incentives, information and technical services to enable customers to make energy efficient choices with respect to building design, equipment and building systems, appliance purchases and operating practices.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P92_S2	As described below, PSE recovers the actual costs of electric and natural gas energy efficiency programs through a tracker mechanism (for natural gas) and a rider mechanism (for electric).
1085392_12_ITEM1_P92_S3	However, the tracker and rider mechanisms do not provide for any cost recovery of lost sales margin associated with reduced energy sales.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P92_S4	A lost margin adjustment is included in PSE s pending general rate case.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P93_S0	PSE s rates are designed to capture most of the approved revenue requirements for fixed costs through volumetric rates.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P93_S1	PSE fully recovers these costs only if its customers consume a certain level of natural gas and electricity.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P93_S2	This level of consumption is typically established in the utility s most recently completed rate case based upon historical natural gas and electric volumes.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P93_S3	When customers use less natural gas or electricity, whether due to conservation, weather or economic conditions, PSE s financial performance is negatively impacted because recovery of fixed costs is reduced in proportion to the reduction in natural gas or electric sales.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P94_S0	Since 1995, PSE has been authorized by the Washington Commission to defer natural gas energy efficiency (or conservation) expenditures and recover them through a tracker mechanism.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P94_S1	The tracker mechanism allows PSE to defer efficiency expenditures and recover them in rates over the subsequent year.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P94_S2	The tracker mechanism also allows PSE to recover an allowance for funds used to conserve energy on any outstanding balance that is not currently being recovered in rates.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P95_S0	Since May 1997, PSE has recovered direct electric energy efficiency (or conservation) expenditures through a rider mechanism.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P95_S1	The rider mechanism allows PSE to defer the efficiency expenditures and amortize them to expense as PSE collects the efficiency expenditures in rates over a one-year period.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P95_S2	As a result of the rider mechanism, direct electric energy efficiency expenditures are recovered.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P95_S3	PSE does not earn a return on unamortized balances.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P96_S0	PSE s operations, including generation, transmission, distribution, service and storage facilities, are subject to environmental laws and regulations by federal, state and local authorities.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P96_S1	The primary areas of environmental law that have the potential to most significantly impact PSE s operations and costs include:
1085392_12_ITEM1_P97_S0	PSE owns numerous thermal generation facilities, including seven natural gas plants and an ownership percentage of a coal plant in Colstrip, Montana (Colstrip).
1085392_12_ITEM1_P97_S1	All these facilities are governed by the Clean Air Act (CAA) and all have CAA Title V operation permits that must be renewed every five years.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P97_S2	These facilities also emit greenhouse gases (GHGs), and thus are also subject to any current or future GHG or climate change legislation or regulation.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P97_S3	Colstrip represents PSE s most significant source of GHG emissions.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P98_S0	PSE owns three hydroelectric plants and three wind farms and numerous miles of above ground electric distribution and transmission lines which can be impacted by laws related to species protection.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P99_S0	A number of species of fish have been listed as threatened or endangered under the Endangered Species Act (ESA), which influences hydroelectric operations, and may affect PSE operations, potentially representing cost exposure and operational constraints.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P99_S1	Similarly, there are a number of avian and terrestrial species that have been listed as threatened or endangered under the ESA or are protected by the Migratory Bird Act.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P99_S2	Designations of protected species under these two laws have the potential to influence operation of our wind farms and above ground transmission and distribution systems.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P100_S0	PSE and its predecessors are responsible for environmental remediation at various contaminated sites.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P100_S1	These include properties currently and formerly owned by PSE, as well as third party owned properties in which hazardous substances were generated or released.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P101_S0	Cleanup laws PSE may be subject to primarily include the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation and Liability Act (federal) and the Model Toxics Control Act (state).
1085392_12_ITEM1_P101_S1	These laws may hold liable any current or past owner, or operator of a contaminated site, as well as, any generator, arranger, transporter or disposer of regulated substances.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P102_S0	Related to certain operations, including power generation and transmission and distribution maintenance, PSE must handle and dispose of certain hazardous and solid wastes, as well as, Polychlorinated Biphenyls (PCB) contaminated wastes.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P102_S1	These actions are regulated by the Solid Waste Disposal Act, as amended by the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (federal), the Toxic Substances Control Act (federal), and the dangerous waste regulations (state) that impose complex requirements on handling and disposing of regulated substances.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P103_S0	PSE facilities that discharge wastewater or storm water, or store bulk petroleum products are governed by the Clean Water Act (federal and state) which includes the Oil Pollution Act amendments.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P103_S1	This includes most all generation facilities (all of which have water discharges and some of which have bulk fuel storage), and due to recent changes in state storm water regulations also includes many other facilities and construction projects depending on drainage, facility or construction activities, and chemical, petroleum and material storage.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P104_S0	In siting new generation, transmission or distribution, PSE is subject to the State Environmental Policy Act, and may be subject to the federal National Environmental Policy Act, if there is a federal nexus, as well as, other local siting and zoning ordinances.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P104_S1	These requirements may potentially require mitigation of environmental impacts to the fullest extent possible as well as other measures that can add significant cost to new facilities.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P105_S0	Recent and future environmental law and regulations may be imposed at a federal, state or local level and may have a significant impact on cost of PSE operations.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P105_S1	PSE monitors legislative and regulatory developments for environmental issues with the potential to alter the operation and cost of our generation plants, transmission and distribution system, and other assets.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P105_S2	Recent, pending and potential future environmental law and regulations with the most significant potential impacts to PSE s operations and costs are described below.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P106_S0	PSE recognizes the growing concern that increased atmospheric concentrations of GHG contribute to climate change.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P106_S1	PSE believes that climate change is an important issue that requires careful analysis and considered responses.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P106_S2	A climate policy continues to evolve at the state and federal levels and PSE remains involved in state, regional and federal policymaking activities.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P106_S3	PSE will continue to monitor the development of any climate change or climate change related air emission reduction initiative at the state and western regional levels.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P106_S4	PSE will also consider the impact of any future legislation or new government regulation on the cost of generation in its IRP process.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P107_S0	Most recent definitive federal legislative activity on climate change occurred in June 2009; the United States House of Representatives passed H.R. 2454, the American Clean Energy and Security Act.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P107_S1	The bill implements a cap-and-trade system of allowances to reduce GHG emissions 17.0% below 2005 levels by 2020, reaching an eventual target of 83.0% below 2005 levels by 2050.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P107_S2	However, the 111th Congress ended without enacting any major law to limit or reduce GHG emissions.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P108_S0	Recent federal climate change regulation includes the Tailoring Rule, which became effective January 2, 2011.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P108_S1	Under the rule, new sources that emit more than 100,000 tpv of total GHG and major modifications of existing sources that increase GHG emissions by 74,000 tpv will be required to implement Best Available Control Technology (BACT) to control GHG emissions.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P109_S0	Potential impacts on Colstrip are being evaluated and impacts to our gas fleet cannot yet be determined.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P110_S0	Beginning on March 31, 2011, PSE is required to submit, on an annual basis, a report of its GHG emissions to the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) including a report of emissions from all individual power plants emitting over 25,000 tons per year of GHGs and from certain natural gas distribution operations.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P110_S1	Capital investments to monitor GHGs from the power plants and in the distribution system are not required at this time.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P110_S2	Since 2002, PSE has voluntarily undertaken an annual inventory of its GHG emissions associated with PSE s total electric retail load, which was 21.5 million MWh in 2011, served from a supply portfolio of owned and purchased resources.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P110_S3	The most recent data indicate that PSE s total GHG emissions (direct and indirect) from its electric supply portfolio in 2009 were 14.4 million tons of carbon dioxide equivalent.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P110_S4	Since 2009, new PSE generation facilities have resulted in combined GHG emissions of 591,935 tons of carbon dioxide equivalent.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P110_S5	Approximately 36.4% of PSE s total GHG emissions in 2009 (approximately 5.3 million tons) were associated with PSE s ownership and contractual interests in Colstrip.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P111_S0	In November 2010, the EPA released two more GHG reporting rules affecting PSE.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P112_S0	The first rule, commonly referred to as Subpart DD, requires owners and operators of electric power system facilities with a total nameplate capacity exceeding 17,820 pounds of sulfur hexafluoride to report emissions from its use of electrical transmission and distribution equipment.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P112_S1	The second rule, commonly referred to as Subpart W, requires certain oil and natural gas operations, including distribution and storage, to report GHG emissions from leaks and certain combustions activities.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P112_S2	PSE will submit the required information as part of its annual filing to the EPA beginning on March 31, 2012.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P113_S0	While Colstrip remains a significant portion of PSE s GHG emissions, Colstrip is an essential part of the diversified portfolio PSE owns and/or operates for its customers.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P113_S1	Consequently, PSE s overall emissions strategy demonstrates a concerted effort to manage customers needs with an appropriate balance of new renewable generation, existing generation owned and/or operated by PSE and significant energy efficiency efforts.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P114_S0	The state of Montana issued regulations limiting mercury emissions from coal-fired plants in October 2006 (with a limit of 0.9 lbs/Trillion British thermal units (lbs/TBtu) for plants burning coal like that used at Colstrip) which took effect on January 1, 2010.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P114_S1	Mercury control equipment has been installed at Colstrip and has operated at a level that meets the current Montana requirement.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P114_S2	Compliance based on a rolling 12-month average was first confirmed in January 2011 and has continued to meet the requirement during each month of 2011.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P115_S0	The final version of EPA's Mercury and Air Toxics Standard, (MATS rule) was released December 21, 2011.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P115_S1	The final rule provides some concessions to electric generators by providing extra compliance time in certain circumstances, but overall the final rule remains largely consistent with the agency's initial proposal in March 2011.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P116_S0	MATS sets a new federal emission limitation for mercury (1.2 lb/TBtu), for acid gases, for other toxic metal using a particulate matter (PM) surrogate (0.03 lb/MMBtu), and for sulfur dioxide and nitrogen oxides for steam electric generating units.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P116_S1	Colstrip is currently meeting the new mercury standards.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P116_S2	Current emissions and available control technologies are currently being evaluated to determine what will be necessary to meet the new standards for acid gases and PM.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P116_S3	PSE cannot yet determine the outcome of these analyses.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P117_S0	On June 15, 2005, the EPA issued the Clean Air Visibility rule to address regional haze or regionally-impaired visibility caused by multiple sources over a wide area.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P117_S1	The rule defines Best Available Retrofit Technology (BART) requirements for electric generating units, including presumptive limits for sulfur dioxide, particulate matter and nitrogen oxide controls for large units.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P117_S2	In February 2007, Colstrip was notified by the EPA that Colstrip Units 1 2 were determined to be subject to the EPA s BART requirements.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P117_S3	A BART engineering analysis for Colstrip Units 1 2 was submitted in August 2007 and additional requested analyses were submitted in June 2008.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P117_S4	On November 5, 2010, the EPA issued a request for additional reasonable progress information for Colstrip Units 3 4 which has been submitted.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P117_S5	EPA has met with Colstrip representatives to discuss possible requirements for Units 1 2 to meet EPA s BART requirements, but nothing definitive has been determined.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P117_S6	PSE cannot yet determine the outcome of these analyses or information requests.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P118_S0	On June 21, 2010, the EPA issued a proposed rulemaking for the Identification and Listing of Special Wastes: Disposal of Coal Combustion Residuals from Electric Utilities which proposes different regulatory mechanisms to regulate coal ash.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P118_S1	The EPA received numerous comments on the respective proposals in November 2010, including comments from PSE and other Colstrip owners.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P118_S2	The EPA has announced that a final rule will not be issued until 2012.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P119_S0	To date, EPA has proposed three regulatory options.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P119_S1	Under the first two options, coal ash could be regulated as a solid waste under Subtitle D provisions of the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA).
1085392_12_ITEM1_P119_S2	This would give authority to the states to oversee a set of performance standards for handling and disposal.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P119_S3	Coal ash would be listed as non-hazardous and would allow wet handling to continue, and it would allow continued use of surface impoundments provided they are equipped with protective liners.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P119_S4	One of these two options would require significantly less modifications to closed, as well as, in-use impoundments.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P120_S0	Under the third option, coal ash could be regulated as a hazardous waste under Subtitle C provisions of the RCRA, which would make coal ash subject to a comprehensive program of federally enforceable requirements for waste management and disposal.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P120_S1	Regulation under Subtitle C would essentially require the phase-out of wet handling and surface impoundments.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P120_S2	The EPA estimates over 500 surface impoundments would be affected by this ruling.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P120_S3	The EPA is expected to issue a final ruling in late 2012.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P121_S0	Impact to Colstrip operations and PSE, could range from minimal to significant.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P121_S1	Due to the wide range in the options proposed by EPA PSE cannot determine impacts with any more certainty at this time, but we are involved with monitoring development of the final rule and advocating for reasonable approach that would be protective of the environment and cost-effective.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P122_S0	On April 7, 2010, the EPA issued a Advance Notice of Proposed Rule Making (ANPRM) soliciting information on a broad range of questions concerning inventory, management, use, and disposal of PCB-containing equipment.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P122_S1	EPA is using this ANPRM to seek data to better evaluate whether to initiate a rulemaking process geared toward a mandatory phase-out of all PCBs.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P122_S2	This would likely remove all existing use authorizations for PCBs in electrical and gas pipeline equipment.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P122_S3	As proposed, the ANPRM would mandate a phase out of in-service PCBs through a phased process with full removal achieved by 2025.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P123_S0	The end of the comment period for the ANPRM was initially July 6, 2010 but due to the volume of comments received, an extension was granted to August 20, 2010 with the suggested issuance of a Notice in May 2012.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P123_S1	PSE provided comments through both the Utilities Solid Waste Advocacy Group (USWAG) as well as the American Gas Association (AGA).
1085392_12_ITEM1_P123_S2	Upon receiving all comments, the EPA has rescheduled the issuance to April 2013.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P123_S3	At this time, PSE cannot determine what the impacts of this ANPRM will have on its operations but will continue to work closely with USWAG and AGA to monitor developments and advocate for a reasonable approach that would be protective of the environment and cost-effective.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P124_S0	The executive officers of Puget Energy as of March 1, 2012 are listed below along with their business experience during the past five years.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P125_S0	Officers of Puget Energy are elected for one-year terms.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P126_S0	The executive officers of PSE as of March 1, 2012 are listed below along with their business experience during the past five years.
1085392_12_ITEM1_P127_S0	Officers of PSE are elected for one-year terms.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P0_S0	The following risk factors, in addition to other factors and matters discussed elsewhere in this report, should be carefully considered.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P1_S0	The risks and uncertainties described below are not the only risks and uncertainties that Puget Energy and PSE may face.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P1_S1	Additional risks and uncertainties not presently known or currently deemed immaterial also may impair PSE s business operations.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P1_S2	If any of the following risks actually occur, Puget Energy s and PSE s business, results of operations and financial conditions would suffer.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P2_S0	The actions of regulators can significantly affect PSE s earnings, liquidity and business activities.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P3_S0	The rates that PSE is allowed to charge for its services is the single most important item influencing its financial position, results of operations and liquidity.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P3_S1	PSE is highly regulated and the rates that it charges its wholesale and retail customers are determined by both the Washington Commission and the FERC.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P4_S0	PSE is also subject to the regulatory authority of the Washington Commission with respect to accounting, operations, the issuance of securities and certain other matters, and the regulatory authority of the FERC with respect to the transmission of electric energy, the sale of electric energy at the wholesale level, accounting and certain other matters.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P4_S1	Policies and regulatory actions by these regulators could have a material impact on PSE s financial position, results of operations and liquidity.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P5_S0	PSE s recovery of costs is subject to regulatory review and its operating income may be adversely affected if its costs are disallowed.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P6_S0	The Washington Commission determines the rates PSE may charge to its electric retail customers based, in part, on historic test year costs plus normalized assumptions about rate year power costs, weather and hydrological conditions.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P6_S1	Non-energy costs for natural gas retail customers are based on historic test year costs.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P6_S2	If in a specific year PSE s costs are higher than what is allowed to be recovered in rates, revenue may not be sufficient to permit PSE to earn its allowed return or to cover its costs.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P6_S3	In addition, the Washington Commission decides what level of expense and investment is reasonable and prudent in providing electric and natural gas service.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P6_S4	If the Washington Commission decides that part of PSE s costs do not meet the standard, those costs may be disallowed partially or entirely and not recovered in rates.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P6_S5	For the aforementioned reasons, the rates authorized by the Washington Commission may not be sufficient to earn the allowed return or recover the costs incurred by PSE in a given period.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P7_S0	The PCA mechanism, by which variations in PSE s power costs are apportioned between PSE and its customers pursuant to a graduated scale, could result in significant increases in PSE s expenses if power costs are significantly higher than the baseline rate.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P8_S0	PSE has a PCA mechanism that provides for recovery of power costs from customers or refunding of power cost savings to customers, as those costs vary from the power cost baseline level of power costs which are set, in part, based on normalized assumptions about weather and hydrological conditions.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P8_S1	Excess power costs or power cost savings will be apportioned between PSE and its customers pursuant to the graduated scale set forth in the PCA mechanism.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P8_S2	As a result, if power costs are significantly higher than the baseline rate, PSE s expenses could significantly increase.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P9_S0	PSE may be unable to acquire energy supply resources to meet projected customer needs or may fail to successfully integrate such acquisitions.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P10_S0	PSE projects that future energy needs will exceed current purchased and Company owned and controlled power resources.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P10_S1	As part of PSE s business strategy, it plans to acquire additional electric generation and delivery infrastructure to meet customer needs.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P10_S2	If PSE cannot acquire additional energy supply resources at a reasonable cost, it may be required to purchase additional power in the open market at a cost that could significantly increase its expenses thus reducing earnings and cash flows.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P10_S3	Additionally, PSE may not be able to timely recover some or all of those increased expenses through ratemaking.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P11_S0	While PSE expects to identify the benefits of new energy supply resources prior to their acquisition and integration, it may not be able to achieve the expected benefits of such energy supply sources.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P12_S0	PSE s cash flow and earnings could be adversely affected by potential high prices and volatile markets for purchased power, increased customer demand for energy, recurrence of low availability of hydroelectric resources, outages of its generating facilities or a failure to deliver on the part of its suppliers.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P13_S0	The utility business involves many operating risks.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P13_S1	If PSE s operating expenses, including the cost of purchased power and natural gas, significantly exceed the levels recovered from retail customers, its cash flow and earnings would be negatively affected.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P13_S2	Factors which could cause purchased power and natural gas costs to be higher than anticipated include, but are not limited to, high prices in western wholesale markets during periods when PSE has insufficient energy resources to meet its load requirements and/or high volumes of energy purchased in wholesale markets at prices above the amount recovered in retail rates due to:
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P14_S0	The effects of large-scale natural disasters on a substantial portion of distribution infrastructure.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P15_S0	PSE s electric generating facilities are subject to operational risks that could result in unscheduled plant outages, unanticipated operation and maintenance expenses and increased power purchase costs.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P16_S0	PSE owns and operates coal, natural gas-fired, hydroelectric, wind-powered and oil-fired generating facilities.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P17_S0	Operation of electric generating facilities involves risks that can adversely affect energy output and efficiency levels.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P18_S0	Catastrophic events such as fires, explosions, floods or acts of nature.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P19_S0	If PSE is unable to protect our information technology infrastructure against data corruption, cyber-based attacks or network security breaches, our operations could be disrupted.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P20_S0	PSE operates in a highly regulated industry that requires the continued operation of sophisticated information technology systems and network infrastructure.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P20_S1	Despite our implementation of security measures, our technology systems are vulnerable to disability, failures or unauthorized access due to hacking, viruses, acts of war or terrorism and other causes.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P20_S2	If our technology systems were to fail or be breached and we were unable to recover in a timely manner, we may be unable to fulfill critical business functions and sensitive, confidential and other data could be compromised, which could have a material adverse effect on our results of operations, financial condition and cash flows.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P20_S3	In addition, these cyber-based attacks could disrupt our ability to produce or distribute some portion of our energy products and could affect the reliability or operability of the electric and natural gas systems.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P21_S0	PSE is subject to the commodity price, delivery and credit risks associated with the energy markets as well as to supply and price risks affecting PSE s construction and maintenance programs.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P22_S0	In connection with matching loads and resources, PSE engages in wholesale sales and purchases of electric capacity and energy, and, accordingly, is subject to commodity price risk, delivery risk, credit risk and other risks associated with these activities.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P22_S1	Credit risk includes the risk that counterparties owing PSE money or energy will breach their obligations.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P22_S2	Should the counterparties to these arrangements fail to perform, PSE may be forced to enter into alternative arrangements.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P22_S3	In that event, PSE s financial results could be adversely affected.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P22_S4	Although PSE takes into account the expected probability of default by counterparties, the actual exposure to a default by a particular counterparty could be greater than predicted.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P23_S0	Further, as a consequence of its electric generation construction and reconstruction programs and investments in its electric and gas distribution systems, PSE contracts to purchase substantial quantities of steel, cable, and similar materials, and thus is subject to supply and price risks affecting these items.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P24_S0	To lower its financial exposure related to commodity price fluctuations, PSE may use forward delivery agreements, swaps and option contracts to hedge commodity price risk with a diverse group of counterparties.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P24_S1	However, PSE does not always cover the entire exposure of its assets or positions to market price volatility and the coverage will vary over time.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P24_S2	To the extent PSE has unhedged positions or its hedging procedures do not work as planned, fluctuating commodity prices could adversely impact its results of operations.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P25_S0	Costs of compliance with environmental, climate change and endangered species laws are significant and the cost of compliance with new and emerging laws and regulations and the incurrence of associated liabilities could adversely affect PSE s results of operations.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P26_S0	PSE s operations are subject to extensive federal, state and local laws and regulations relating to environmental, including air and climate protection, endangered species protection, remediation of contamination, waste handling and disposal, water protection and siting new facilities.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P26_S1	To comply with these legal requirements, PSE must spend significant sums of money on measures including resource planning, remediation, monitoring, analysis, mitigation measures, pollution control equipment and emissions related abatement and fees.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P26_S2	New environmental laws and regulations affecting PSE s operations may be adopted, and new interpretations of existing laws and regulations could be adopted or become applicable to PSE or its facilities.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P26_S3	Compliance with these or other future regulations could require significant expenditures by PSE and adversely affect PSE s financial position, results of operations, cash flows and liquidity.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P26_S4	In addition, PSE may not be able to recover all of its costs for such expenditures through electric and natural gas rates at current levels in the future.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P27_S0	With respect to endangered species laws, the listing or proposed listing of several species of salmon in the Pacific Northwest is causing a number of changes to the operations of hydroelectric generating facilities on Pacific Northwest rivers, including the Columbia River.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P27_S1	These changes could reduce the amount, and increase the cost, of power generated by hydroelectric plants owned by PSE, or in which PSE has an interest, and increase the cost of the permitting process for these facilities.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P28_S0	Under current law, PSE is also generally responsible for any on-site liabilities associated with the environmental condition of the facilities that it currently owns or operates or has previously owned or operated.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P28_S1	The incurrence of a material environmental liability or the new regulations governing such liability could result in substantial future costs and have a material adverse effect on PSE s results of operations and financial condition.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P29_S0	Specific to climate change, Washington state has adopted both a renewable portfolio standard and greenhouse gas legislation, including an emission performance standard provision.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P29_S1	PSE cannot yet determine the costs of compliance with the recently enacted legislation.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P29_S2	Recent decisions related to climate change by the United States Supreme Court and the EPA, together with efforts by Congress, have drawn greater attention to this issue at the federal, state and local level.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P29_S3	While PSE cannot yet determine costs associated with these or future decisions or potential future legislation, there may be a significant impact on the cost of carbon-intensive coal generation, in particular.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P30_S0	PSE s operating results fluctuate on a seasonal and quarterly basis.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P31_S0	PSE s business is seasonal and weather patterns can have a material impact on its revenue, expenses and operating results.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P31_S1	Because natural gas is heavily used for residential and commercial heating, demand depends heavily on weather patterns in PSE s service territory, and a significant amount of natural gas revenue is recognized in the first and fourth quarters related to the heating season.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P31_S2	However, conservation efforts may result in decreased customer demand, despite normal or lower than normal temperatures.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P31_S3	Demand for electricity is also greater in the winter months associated with heating.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P31_S4	Accordingly, PSE s operations have historically generated less revenue and income when weather conditions are milder in the winter.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P31_S5	In the event that the Company experiences unusually mild winters, results of operations and financial condition could be adversely affected.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P32_S0	PSE may be adversely affected by extreme events in which PSE is not able to promptly respond and repair the electric and gas infrastructure system.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P33_S0	PSE must maintain an emergency planning and training program to allow PSE to quickly respond to extreme events.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P33_S1	Without emergency planning, PSE is subject to availability of outside contractors during an extreme event which may impact the quality of service provided to PSE s customers.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P33_S2	In addition, a slow response to extreme events may have an adverse affect on earnings as customers may be without electricity and natural gas for an extended period of time.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P34_S0	PSE may be negatively affected by its inability to attract and retain professional and technical employees.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P35_S0	PSE s ability to implement a workforce succession plan is dependent upon PSE s ability to employ and retain skilled professional and technical workers.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P35_S1	Without a skilled workforce, PSE s ability to provide quality service to PSE s customers and to meet regulatory requirements could affect PSE s earnings.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P36_S0	PSE depends on an aging work force and third party vendors to perform certain important services.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P37_S0	PSE continues to be concerned about the availability and aging of skilled workers for special complex utility functions.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P37_S1	PSE also hires third parties to perform a variety of normal business functions, such as power plant maintenance, data warehousing and management, electric transmission, electric and gas distribution construction and maintenance, certain billing and metering processes, call center overflow and credit and collections.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P37_S2	The unavailability of skilled workers or unavailability of such vendors could adversely affect the quality and cost of PSE s gas and electric service and accordingly PSE s results of operations.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P38_S0	Poor performance of pension and postretirement benefit plan investments and other factors impacting plan costs could unfavorably impact PSE s cash flow and liquidity.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P39_S0	PSE provides a defined benefit pension plan to PSE employees and postretirement benefits to certain PSE employees and former employees.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P39_S1	Costs of providing these benefits are based in part on the value of the plan s assets and therefore, continued adverse market performance could result in lower rates of return for the investments that fund PSE s pension and postretirement benefits plans and could increase PSE s funding requirements related to the pension plans.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P39_S2	Any contributions to PSE s plans in 2012 and beyond as well as the timing of the recovery of such contributions in general rate cases could impact PSE s cash flow and liquidity.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P40_S0	PSE may be adversely affected by its inability to successfully implement certain technology projects.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P41_S0	PSE is currently undertaking a multi-year Company-wide business process modernization effort which will replace existing software PSE currently uses for processing customer records and billing, mapping infrastructure assets and handling outage management tasks.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P41_S1	These projects, are expected to be fully deployed by 2013, include: (1) a new Customer Information System intended to replace a PSE application that manages customer information and tracks outages; (2) a new Geospatial Information System intended to replace existing maps of our natural gas transmission and distribution systems with electronic databases; and (3) an Outage Management System expected to augment and improve PSE s ability to pinpoint the sources of electric system outages and respond to them more quickly, focus repair efforts and more accurately predict restoration times.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P41_S2	Implementation of these information systems is complex, expensive and time consuming.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P41_S3	If PSE does not successfully implement the new systems and new processes, or if the systems do not operate as intended, it could result in substantial disruptions to PSE s business, which could have a material adverse effect on our results of operations and financial condition.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P42_S0	The Company's business is dependent on its ability to successfully access capital.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P43_S0	The Company relies on access to internally generated funds, bank borrowings through multi-year committed credit facilities and short-term money markets as sources of liquidity and longer-term debt markets to fund PSE's utility construction program and other capital expenditure requirements of PSE.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P43_S1	If Puget Energy or PSE are unable to access capital on reasonable terms, their ability to pursue improvements or acquisitions, including generating capacity, which may be relied on for future growth and to otherwise implement its strategy, could be adversely affected.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P43_S2	Capital and credit market disruptions, a downgrade of Puget Energy's or PSE's credit rating or the imposition of restrictions on borrowings under their credit facilities in the event of a deterioration of financial ratios, may increase Puget Energy's and PSE s cost of borrowing or adversely affect the ability to access one or more financial markets.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P44_S0	The amount of the Company's debt could adversely affect its liquidity and results of operations.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P45_S0	Puget Energy and PSE have short-term and long-term debt, and may incur additional debt (including secured debt) in the future.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P46_S0	Puget Energy has access to a multi-year $1.0 billion revolving credit facility, secured by substantially all of its assets, of which $864.0 million was outstanding as of February 10, 2012.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P46_S1	PSE has access to three unsecured credit facilities that provide, in the aggregate $1.15 billion in short-term borrowing capability.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P46_S2	In addition, Puget Energy has issued $950.0 million in senior secured notes, whereas PSE, as of December 31, 2011 had approximately $3.8 billion outstanding under first mortgage bonds, pollution control bonds, senior notes and junior subordinated notes.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P47_S0	The Company's debt level could have important effects on the business, including but not limited to:
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P48_S0	limit the Company's financial flexibility, including its ability to borrow additional funds on favorable terms or at all.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P49_S0	A downgrade in Puget Energy s or PSE s credit rating could negatively affect the ability to access capital and the ability to hedge in wholesale markets.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P50_S0	Although neither Puget Energy nor PSE has any rating downgrade provisions in its credit facilities that would accelerate the maturity dates of outstanding debt, a downgrade in the Companies credit ratings could adversely affect the ability to renew existing or obtain access to new credit facilities and could increase the cost of such facilities.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P50_S1	For example, under Puget Energy s and PSE s facilities, the borrowing spreads over the London Interbank Offered Rate (LIBOR) and commitment fees increase if their respective corporate credit ratings decline.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P50_S2	A downgrade in commercial paper ratings could increase the cost of commercial paper and limit or preclude PSE s ability to issue commercial paper under its current programs.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P51_S0	Any downgrade below investment grade of PSE s corporate credit rating could cause counterparties in the wholesale electric, wholesale natural gas and financial derivative markets to request PSE to post a letter of credit or other collateral, make cash prepayments, obtain a guarantee agreement or provide other mutually agreeable security, all of which would expose PSE to additional costs.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P52_S0	The Company may be negatively affected by unfavorable changes in the tax laws or their interpretation.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P53_S0	Changes in tax law, related regulations or differing interpretation or enforcement of applicable law by the IRS or other taxing jurisdiction could have a material adverse impact on the Company s financial statements.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P54_S0	The tax law, related regulations and case law are inherently complex.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P54_S1	The Company must make judgments and interpretations about the application of the law when determining the provision for taxes.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P54_S2	Disputes over interpretations of tax laws may be settled with the taxing authority in examination, upon appeal or through litigation.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P54_S3	The Company s tax obligations include income, real estate, public utility, municipal, sales and use, business and occupation and employment-related taxes and ongoing appeals issues related to these taxes.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P54_S4	These judgments may include reserves for potential adverse outcomes regarding tax positions that may be subject to challenge by the taxing authorities.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P55_S0	Potential legislation and regulatory actions could increase the Company s costs, reduce the Company s revenue and cash flow, or otherwise alter the way the Company conducts business.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P56_S0	In July 2010, the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (Dodd-Frank) was signed into law.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P56_S1	Title VII of the Dodd-Frank law gave regulators including the Commodities Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) and the Securities Exchange Commission the authority to create new oversight structures for derivative financial instruments, which were widely thought to have contributed to the 2008 financial crisis.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P56_S2	The new legislation of certain over-the-counter swaps could expand collateral requirements of swaps, which may make it more costly for companies and/or limit the Company s ability to enter into such transactions.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P57_S0	The Dodd-Frank amended section 2(h)(7) of the Commodities Exchange Act to provide an elective exemption from the clearing requirements of Title VII of the Dodd-Frank Act for any entity that is not a financial entity, is using swaps to hedge or mitigate commercial risk, and notifies the CFTC, in a manner set forth by the CFTC, how it generally meets its financial obligations associated with entering into non-cleared swaps.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P57_S1	The Company is evaluating the legislation and the CFTC s implementation of it to determine its impact, if any, on the Company s hedging program, results of operations and liquidity.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P57_S2	The Company will not know the full impact of the new legislation until the regulations are finalized.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P58_S0	As a holding company, Puget Energy depends on PSE s ability to pay dividends.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P59_S0	As a holding company with no significant operations of its own, the primary source of funds for the repayment of debt and other expenses, as well as payment of dividends to its shareholder, is cash dividends PSE pays to Puget Energy.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P59_S1	PSE is a separate and distinct legal entity and has no obligation to pay any amounts to Puget Energy, whether by dividends, loans or other payments.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P59_S2	The ability of PSE to pay dividends or make distributions to Puget Energy, and accordingly, Puget Energy s ability to pay dividends or repay debt or other expenses, will depend on PSE s earnings, capital requirements and general financial condition.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P59_S3	If Puget Energy does not receive adequate distributions from PSE, it may not be able to meet its obligations or pay dividends.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P60_S0	The payment of dividends by PSE to Puget Energy is restricted by provisions of certain covenants applicable to long-term debt contained in PSE s electric and natural gas mortgage indentures.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P60_S1	In addition, beginning February 6, 2009, pursuant to the terms of the Washington Commission merger order, PSE may not declare or pay dividends if PSE s common equity ratio, calculated on a regulatory basis, is 44.0% or below except to the extent a lower equity ratio is ordered by the Washington Commission.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P60_S2	Also, pursuant to the merger order, PSE may not declare or make any distribution, unless on the date of distribution PSE s corporate credit/issuer rating is investment grade, or if its credit ratings are below investment grade, PSE s ratio of Earnings Before Interest, Tax, Depreciation and Amortization (EBITDA) to interest expense for the four most recently ended fiscal quarters prior to such date is equal to or greater than three to one.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P60_S3	The common equity ratio, calculated on a regulatory basis, was 48.2% at December 31, 2011 and the EBITDA to interest expense was 4.4 to 1.0 for the 12 months then ended.
1085392_12_ITEM1A_P61_S0	PSE s ability to pay dividends is also limited by the terms of its credit facilities, pursuant to which PSE is not permitted to pay dividends during any Event of Default, or if the payment of dividends would result in an Event of Default (as defined in the facilities), such as failure to comply with certain financial covenants.
1085392_12_ITEM2_P0_S0	The principal electric generating plants and underground natural gas storage facilities owned by PSE are described under Item 1, Business Electric Supply and Gas Supply.
1085392_12_ITEM2_P1_S0	PSE owns its transmission and distribution facilities and various other properties.
1085392_12_ITEM2_P1_S1	Substantially all properties of PSE are subject to the liens of PSE s mortgage indentures.
1085392_12_ITEM2_P2_S0	The Company s corporate headquarters is housed in a leased building located in Bellevue, Washington.
1085392_12_ITEM3_P0_S0	From time to time, the Company is involved in litigation relating to claims arising out of its operations in the normal course of business.
1085392_12_ITEM3_P0_S1	The following is a description of legal proceedings that are material to PSE s operations:
1085392_12_ITEM3_P1_S0	The Northwest Power Act, through the Residential Exchange Program (REP), provides access to the benefits of low-cost federal hydroelectric power to residential and small farm customers of regional utilities, including PSE.
1085392_12_ITEM3_P1_S1	The program is administered by the Bonneville Power Administration (the BPA).
1085392_12_ITEM3_P1_S2	Pursuant to agreements (including settlement agreements) between the BPA and PSE, the BPA has provided payments of REP benefits to PSE, which PSE has passed through to its residential and small farm customers in the form of electricity bill credits.
1085392_12_ITEM3_P2_S0	In 2007, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit ruled that REP agreements of the BPA with PSE and a number of other investor-owned utilities were inconsistent with the Northwest Power Act.
1085392_12_ITEM3_P2_S1	Since that time, those investor-owned utilities, including PSE, the BPA and other parties have been involved in ongoing litigation at the Ninth Circuit relating to the amount of REP benefits paid to utilities, including PSE, for the period fiscal year 2002 through fiscal year 2011 and the amount of REP benefits to be paid going forward.
1085392_12_ITEM3_P3_S0	In July 2011, the BPA, PSE and a number of other parties entered into a settlement agreement that by its terms if upheld in their entirety would resolve the disputes between BPA and PSE regarding REP benefits paid for the period fiscal year 2002-fiscal year 2011.
1085392_12_ITEM3_P3_S1	In October 2011, certain other parties challenged BPA decisions with regard to its entering into this most recent settlement agreement.
1085392_12_ITEM3_P3_S2	Pending disposition of this challenge, the other pending Ninth Circuit litigation regarding REP benefits for the period fiscal year 2002 through fiscal year 2011 has been stayed by the Ninth Circuit.
1085392_12_ITEM3_P4_S0	Due to the pending and ongoing proceedings, PSE is unable to reasonably estimate any amounts of REP payments either to be recovered by the BPA or to be paid for any future periods to PSE and is unable to determine the impact, if any, these proceedings and litigation may have on PSE.
1085392_12_ITEM3_P4_S1	However, it is unlikely that any unfavorable outcome would have a material adverse effect on PSE because REP benefits received by PSE are passed through to PSE's residential and small farm customers.
1085392_12_ITEM3_P5_S0	In October 2000, PSE filed a complaint with the FERC (Docket No.
1085392_12_ITEM3_P5_S1	EL01-10) against all jurisdictional sellers in the Pacific Northwest seeking prospective price caps consistent with any result the FERC ordered for the California markets.
1085392_12_ITEM3_P5_S2	The FERC issued an order including price caps in July 2001, and PSE moved to dismiss the proceeding.
1085392_12_ITEM3_P6_S0	In response to PSE s motion, various entities intervened and sought to convert PSE s complaint into one seeking retroactive refunds in the Pacific Northwest.
1085392_12_ITEM3_P6_S1	The FERC rejected that effort, after holding what the FERC referred to as a preliminary evidentiary hearing before an administrative law judge.
1085392_12_ITEM3_P6_S2	On October 3, 2011, after appellate reviews, the FERC issued an Order on Remand and set the matter for hearing before an administrative law judge, but first requiring the parties to engage in settlement talks that began in the fall of 2011.
1085392_12_ITEM3_P6_S3	As such, the hearing date itself is not known.
1085392_12_ITEM3_P6_S4	PSE intends to vigorously defend its position but is unable to predict the outcome of this matter.
1085392_12_ITEM5_P0_S0	All of the outstanding shares of Puget Energy s common stock, the only class of common equity of Puget Energy, are held by its direct parent Puget Equico, which is an indirect wholly-owned subsidiary of Puget Holdings.
1085392_12_ITEM5_P0_S1	The outstanding shares of PSE s common stock, the only class of common equity of PSE, are held by Puget Energy and are not publicly traded.
1085392_12_ITEM5_P1_S0	The payment of dividends on PSE common stock to Puget Energy is restricted by provisions of certain covenants applicable to long-term debt contained in PSE s mortgage indentures in addition to terms of the Washington Commission merger order.
1085392_12_ITEM5_P1_S1	Puget Energy s ability to pay dividends is also limited by the merger order issued by the Washington Commission as well as by the terms of its credit facilities.
1085392_12_ITEM5_P1_S2	For further discussion, see Item 1A, Risk Factors, Risks relating to Puget Energy s Corporate Structure and Item 7, Management s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations included in this report.
1085392_12_ITEM6_P0_S0	The following tables show selected financial data.
1085392_12_ITEM6_P0_S1	This information should be read in conjunction with the Management Discussion and Analysis and the audited consolidated financial statements and the related notes, included in Items 7 and 8 of this report, respectively.
1085392_12_ITEM6_P1_S0	All of the operations of Puget Energy are conducted through its subsidiary PSE.
1085392_12_ITEM6_P2_S0	Predecessor refers to the operations of Puget Energy and PSE prior to the consummation of the merger.
1085392_12_ITEM6_P2_S1	Successor refers to the operations of Puget Energy and PSE subsequent to the merger.
1085392_12_ITEM6_P2_S2	The merger was accounted for in accordance with Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB) Accounting Standards Codification (ASC) 805.
1085392_12_ITEM6_P2_S3	For a description of this transaction, see Note 3 to the consolidated financial statements included in Item 8 of this report.
1085392_12_ITEM7_P0_S0	The following discussion and analysis should be read in conjunction with the financial statements and related notes thereto included elsewhere in this report on Form 10-K.
1085392_12_ITEM7_P0_S1	The discussion contains forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties, such as Puget Energy and PSE objectives, expectations and intentions.
1085392_12_ITEM7_P0_S2	Words or phrases such as anticipates, believes, continues, could, estimates, expects, future, intends, may, might, plans, potential, predicts, projects, should, will likely result, will continue and similar expressions are intended to identify certain of these forward-looking statements.
1085392_12_ITEM7_P0_S3	However, these words are not the exclusive means of identifying such statements.
1085392_12_ITEM7_P0_S4	In addition, any statements that refer to expectations, projections or other characterizations of future events or circumstances are forward-looking statements.
