1085392_12_ITEM8_P226_S0	These credit facilities contain similar terms and conditions and are syndicated among numerous committed lenders.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P226_S1	The agreements provide PSE with the ability to borrow at different interest rate options and include variable fee levels.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P226_S2	The credit agreements allow PSE to borrow at the bank s prime rate or to make floating rate advances at the LIBOR plus a spread that is based upon PSE s credit rating.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P226_S3	The working capital facility, as amended, includes a swing line feature allowing same day availability on borrowings up to $50.0 million.

1085392_12_ITEM8_P226_S8	The $400.0 million working capital facility also serves as a backstop for PSE s commercial paper program.

1085392_12_ITEM8_P227_S4	Outside of the credit agreements, PSE had a $5.3 million letter of credit in support of a long-term transmission contract.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P228_S0	On June 1, 2006, PSE entered into a revolving credit facility with Puget Energy, in the form of a credit agreement and a Demand Promissory Note (Note) pursuant to which PSE may borrow up to $30.0 million from Puget Energy subject to approval by Puget Energy.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P228_S1	Under the terms of the Note, PSE pays interest on the outstanding borrowings based on the lower of the weighted-average interest rates of PSE s outstanding commercial paper interest rate or PSE s senior unsecured revolving credit facility.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P228_S2	Absent such borrowings, interest is charged at one-month LIBOR plus 0.25%.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P228_S3	At December 31, 2011, the outstanding balance of the Note was $30.0 million.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P228_S4	The outstanding balance and the related interest under the Note are eliminated by Puget Energy upon consolidation of PSE s financial statements.

1085392_12_ITEM8_P230_S2	As a revolving facility, amounts borrowed may be repaid without a reduction in the size of the facility.

1085392_12_ITEM8_P234_S0	Future minimum lease payments for non-cancelable leases net of sublease receipts are:
1085392_12_ITEM8_P235_S0	PSE leased a portion of its owned natural gas transmission pipeline infrastructure under a non-cancelable operating lease to a third party which expired in 2009.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P236_S0	PSE employs various portfolio optimization strategies, but is not in the business of assuming risk for the purpose of realizing speculative trading revenue.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P236_S1	The nature of serving regulated electric customers with its portfolio of owned and contracted electric generation resources exposes PSE and its customers to some volumetric and commodity price risks within the sharing mechanism of the PCA.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P236_S2	Therefore, wholesale market transactions are focused on balancing PSE s energy portfolio, reducing costs and risks where feasible and reducing volatility in costs and margins in the portfolio.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P237_S0	PSE s energy risk portfolio management function monitors and manages these risks using analytical models and tools.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P237_S1	In order to manage risks effectively, PSE enters into physical and financial transactions which are appropriate for the service territory of PSE and are relevant to its regulated electric and natural gas portfolios.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P238_S0	On the date of the merger, Puget Energy de-designated its derivative contracts that were designated on PSE s books as NPNS or cash flow hedges and recorded such contracts at fair value as either assets or liabilities.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P238_S1	Certain contracts meeting the criteria defined in ASC 815 were subsequently re-designated as NPNS or cash flow hedges.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P239_S0	On July 1, 2009, Puget Energy and PSE elected to de-designate all energy related derivative contracts previously recorded as cash flow hedges for the purpose of simplifying its financial reporting.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P239_S1	The contracts that were de-designated related to electric supply contracts and natural gas swap contracts used to fix the price of natural gas for electric generation.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P239_S2	For these contracts and for contracts initiated after such date, all mark-to-market adjustments are recognized through earnings.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P239_S3	The amount previously recorded in accumulated OCI is transferred to earnings in the same period or periods during which the hedged transaction affects earnings or sooner if management determines that the forecasted transaction is probable of not occurring.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P239_S4	As a result, the Company will continue to experience the earnings impact of these reversals from OCI in future periods.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P239_S5	The amount of losses reclassified from OCI to earnings as a result of de-designated cash flow hedges specific to transactions that are probable of not occurring during 2011 for Puget Energy and PSE was $18.4 million and $2.2 million, respectively.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P240_S0	The Company manages its interest rate risk through the issuance of mostly fixed-rate debt of various maturities.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P240_S1	The Company utilizes internal cash from operations, commercial paper, and credit facilities to meet short-term funding needs.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P240_S2	Short-term obligations are commonly refinanced with fixed-rate bonds or notes when needed and when interest rates are considered favorable.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P240_S3	The Company may enter into swap instruments or other financial hedge instruments to manage the interest rate risk associated with these debts.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P240_S4	As of December 31, 2011, Puget Energy had four interest rate swap contracts outstanding and PSE did not have any outstanding interest rate swap instruments.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P241_S0	In February 2009, Puget Energy entered into the interest rate swap transactions to hedge risk associated with one-month LIBOR floating rate debt.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P241_S1	Subsequently, in order to satisfy a commitment the Company made to the Washington Commission and to mitigate refinancing risk, the Company refinanced a portion of the underlying debt hedged by the interest rate swaps during 2010 and again during 2011.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P241_S2	As a result of refinancing, the Company de-designated the cash flow hedge accounting relationship between the debt and interest rate swaps in 2010.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P241_S3	All fair value gains or losses associated with the interest rate swaps subsequent to the de-designation are recorded in earnings.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P241_S4	At December 31, 2011, the outstanding notional balance of the interest rate swaps is $1.28 billion, compared to the variable rate debt balance of only $843 million.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P241_S5	Under the existing credit agreements, the Company may retain a portion of those swaps that are in excess of the underlying debt (not economic hedges) until June 2012 at which point the Company may decide to unwind or follow other strategies to mitigate the risk of those un-hedged swaps.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P242_S0	During the period in which the Company s interest rate swaps are in excess of the Company s variable rate debt, the Company will be subject to additional interest rate risk.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P242_S1	The Company has settled approximately $277 million of the interest rate swaps on February 15, 2012.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P242_S2	The transaction did not impact the consolidated statements of income as the fair value losses for those swaps had already been recorded through earnings.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P243_S0	The Company refinanced the remaining $843 million of outstanding variable rate debt on February 10, 2012 in order to further stagger debt maturity dates.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P243_S1	Since the refinancing replaced debt with like debt, the original hedged forecast interest payments are still probable of occurring and there is no anticipated reclassification of existing amounts deferred in accumulated OCI to earnings as a result of this transaction.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P243_S2	Puget Energy recorded a $21.2 million loss related to the swaps to interest expense during 2011.

1085392_12_ITEM8_P246_S2	All increases and decreases in the cost of natural gas supply are passed on to customers with the PGA mechanism and the gains and losses on the hedges in future periods will be recorded as gas costs.

1085392_12_ITEM8_P267_S0	For derivative instruments that meet cash flow hedge criteria, the effective portion of the gain or loss on the derivative is reported as a component of OCI and reclassified into earnings in the same period or periods during which the hedged transaction affects earnings.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P267_S1	Gains and losses on the derivatives representing hedge ineffectiveness are recognized in current earnings.

1085392_12_ITEM8_P267_S3	PSE expects that $12.9 million of losses in OCI will be reclassified into earnings within the next twelve months.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P267_S4	The maximum length of time over which Puget Energy and PSE are hedging their exposure to the variability in future cash flows extends to February 2015 for purchased electricity contracts and to October 2015 for gas for power generation contracts.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P267_S5	For Puget Energy interest rate swaps, the maximum length of forecasted transactions deferred in OCI extends to February 2014.

1085392_12_ITEM8_P274_S0	The Company had the following outstanding contracts as of December 31, 2011:
1085392_12_ITEM8_P275_S0	Derivatives not designated as hedging instruments:
1085392_12_ITEM8_P276_S0	Unrealized gains (losses) on gas derivatives are offset by a regulatory asset or liability in accordance with ASC 980 due to the PGA mechanism.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P277_S0	The Company is exposed to credit risk primarily through buying and selling electricity and natural gas to serve its customers.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P278_S0	Credit risk is the potential loss resulting from a counterparty s non-performance under an agreement.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P278_S1	The Company manages credit risk with policies and procedures for, among other things, counterparty credit analysis, exposure measurement, exposure monitoring, and exposure mitigation.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P279_S0	The Company monitors counterparties that have significant swings in credit default swap rates, have credit rating changes by external rating agencies, have changes in ownership or are experiencing financial problems.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P279_S1	Where deemed appropriate, the Company may request collateral or other security from its counterparties to mitigate potential credit default losses.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P279_S2	Criteria employed in this decision include, among other things, the perceived creditworthiness of the counterparty and the expected credit exposure.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P280_S0	It is possible that volatility in energy commodity prices could cause the Company to have material credit risk exposure with one or more counterparties.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P280_S1	If such counterparties fail to perform their obligations under one or more agreements, the Company could suffer a material financial loss.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P280_S2	However, as of December 31, 2011, approximately 99.9% of the Company s energy portfolio exposure, excluding NPNS transactions, is with counterparties that are rated at least investment grade by the major rating agencies and 0.1% are either rated below investment grade or not rated by rating agencies.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P280_S3	The Company assesses credit risk internally for counterparties that are not rated.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P281_S0	The Company generally enters into the following master agreements: (1) WSPP, Inc. (WSPP) agreements standardized power sales contract in the electric industry; (2) International Swaps and Derivatives Association (ISDA) agreements standardized financial gas and electric contracts; and (3) North American Energy Standards Board (NAESB) agreements standardized physical gas contracts.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P281_S1	The Company believes that such agreements reduce credit risk exposure because such agreements provide for the netting and offset of monthly payments and, in the event of counterparty default, termination payments.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P282_S0	The Company computes credit reserves at a master agreement level by counterparty (i.e., WSPP, ISDA, or NAESB).
1085392_12_ITEM8_P282_S1	The Company considers external credit ratings and market factors, such as credit default swaps and bond spreads, in determination of reserves.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P282_S2	The Company recognizes that external ratings may not always reflect how a market participant perceives a counterparty s risk of default.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P282_S3	The Company uses both default factors published by Standard Poor s and factors derived through analysis of market risk, which reflect the application of an industry standard recovery rate.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P283_S0	The Company selects a default factor by counterparty at an aggregate master agreement level based on a weighted average default tenor for that counterparty s deals.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P283_S1	The default tenor is used by weighting the fair value and contract tenors for all deals for each counterparty and coming up with an average value.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P283_S2	The default factor used is dependent upon whether the counterparty is in a net asset or a net liability position after applying the master agreement levels.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P284_S0	The Company applies the counterparty s default factor to compute credit reserves for counterparties that are in a net asset position.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P284_S1	Moreover, the Company applies its own default factor to compute credit reserves for counterparties that are in a net liability position.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P285_S0	Credit reserves are booked as contra accounts to unrealized gain (loss) positions.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P285_S1	As of December 31, 2011, the Company was in a net liability position with the majority of counterparties, so the default factors of counterparties did not have a significant impact on reserves for the year.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P286_S0	The majority of the Company s derivative contracts are with financial institutions and other utilities operating within the Western Electricity Coordinating Council.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P286_S1	Despite its net liability position, PSE was not required to post any additional collateral with any of its counterparties.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P286_S2	Additionally, PSE did not trigger any collateral requirements with any of its counterparties nor were any of PSE s counterparties required to post additional collateral resulting from credit rating downgrades.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P287_S0	As of December 31, 2011, the Company did not have any outstanding energy supply and interest rate swap contracts with counterparties that contained credit risk related contingent features, which could result in a counterparty requesting immediate payment or demanding immediate and ongoing full overnight collateralization on derivative instruments in a net liability position.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P288_S0	The table below presents the fair value of the overall contractual contingent liability positions for the Company s derivative activity at December 31, 2011:
1085392_12_ITEM8_P289_S0	Represents the derivative fair value of contracts with contingent features for counterparties in net derivative liability positions at December 31, 2011.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P289_S1	Excludes NPNS, accounts payable and accounts receivable liability.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P290_S0	Failure by PSE to maintain an investment grade credit rating from each of the major credit rating s agencies provides counterparties a contractual right to demand collateral.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P291_S0	Collateral requirements may vary, based on changes in forward value of underlying transactions relative to contractually defined collateral thresholds.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P292_S0	ASC 820 establishes a fair value hierarchy that prioritizes the inputs used to measure fair value.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P292_S1	The hierarchy gives the highest priority to unadjusted quoted prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities (Level 1 measurement) and the lowest priority to unobservable inputs (Level 3 measurement).
1085392_12_ITEM8_P292_S2	The three levels of the fair value hierarchy defined by ASC 820 are as follows:
1085392_12_ITEM8_P293_S0	Level 1 Quoted prices are available in active markets for identical assets or liabilities as of the reporting date.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P294_S0	Active markets are those in which transactions for the asset or liability occur in sufficient frequency and volume to provide pricing information on an ongoing basis.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P295_S0	Level 1 primarily consists of financial instruments such as exchange-traded derivatives and listed equities.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P295_S1	Equity securities that are also classified as cash equivalents are considered Level 1 if there are unadjusted quoted prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P296_S0	Level 2 Pricing inputs are other than quoted prices in active markets included in Level 1, which are either directly or indirectly observable as of the reported date.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P297_S0	Level 2 includes those financial instruments that are valued using models or other valuation methodologies.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P297_S1	These models are primarily industry-standard models that consider various assumptions, including quoted forward prices for commodities, time value, volatility factors, and current market and contractual prices for the underlying instruments, as well as other relevant economic measures.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P297_S2	Substantially all of these assumptions are observable in the marketplace throughout the full term of the instrument, can be derived from observable data or are supported by observable levels at which transactions are executed in the marketplace.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P298_S0	Instruments in this category include non-exchange-traded derivatives such as over-the-counter forwards and options.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P299_S0	Level 3 Pricing inputs include significant inputs that are generally less observable from objective sources.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P299_S1	These inputs may be used with internally developed methodologies that result in management s best estimate of fair value.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P300_S0	Level 3 instruments include those that may be more structured or otherwise tailored to customers needs.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P300_S1	At each balance sheet date, the Company performs an analysis of all instruments subject to ASC 820 and includes in Level 3 all of those instruments whose fair value is based on significant unobservable inputs.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P301_S0	Financial assets and liabilities are classified in their entirety based on the lowest level of input that is significant to the fair value measurement.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P301_S1	If a fair value measurement relies on inputs from different levels of the hierarchy, the entire measurement must be placed based on the lowest level input that is significant to the fair value measurement.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P301_S2	The Company s assessment of the significance of a particular input to the fair value measurement requires judgment and may affect the valuation of fair value assets and liabilities and their placement within the fair value hierarchy levels.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P302_S0	On a daily basis, the Company obtains quoted forward prices for the electric and natural gas market from an independent external pricing service.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P302_S1	Those forward price quotes are then used in addition to other various inputs to determine the reported fair value.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P302_S2	Some of the inputs include the credit standing of the counterparties involved and the impact of credit enhancements (such as cash deposits, letters of credit and priority interests), assumptions for time value and also the impact of the Company s nonperformance risk on its liabilities.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P303_S0	As of December 31, 2011, the Company considered the markets for its electric and natural gas Level 2 derivative instruments to be actively traded.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P303_S1	Management s assessment is based on the trading activity volume in real-time and forward electric and natural gas markets.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P303_S2	The Company regularly confirms the validity of pricing service quoted prices (e.g. Level 2 in the fair value hierarchy) used to value commodity contracts to the actual prices of commodity contracts entered into during the most recent quarter.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P304_S0	The following tables set forth, by level within the fair value hierarchy, the Company s financial assets and liabilities that were accounted for at fair value on a recurring basis and the reconciliation of the changes in the fair value of derivatives classified as Level 3 in the fair value hierarchy as of December 31, 2011 and 2010:
1085392_12_ITEM8_P305_S0	The beginning balance for the Successor period was adjusted to reflect the impact of certain fair value adjustments from the merger transaction.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P306_S0	There were no purchases or issuances for 2011 or prior years.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P307_S0	There were no purchases or issuances for 2011 or prior years.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P308_S0	Realized gains and losses on energy derivatives for Level 3 recurring items are included in energy costs in the Company s consolidated statements of income under purchased electricity, electric generation fuel or purchased natural gas when settled.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P309_S0	Unrealized gains and losses on energy derivatives for Level 3 recurring items are included in the net unrealized (gain) loss on derivative instruments section in the Company s consolidated statements of income.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P310_S0	Certain energy derivative instruments are classified as Level 3 in the fair value hierarchy because Level 3 inputs are significant to their fair value measurement.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P310_S1	Energy derivatives transferred out of Level 3 represent existing assets or liabilities that were classified as Level 3 at the start of the reporting period for which the lowest significant input became observable during the current reporting period and were transferred into Level 2.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P310_S2	Conversely, energy derivatives transferred into Level 3 from Level 2 represent scenarios in which the lowest significant input became unobservable during the current reporting period.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P310_S3	The Company had no transfers between Level 2 and Level 1 during the year ended December 31, 2011, 2010 or 2009.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P311_S0	The Company has a qualified Employee Investment Plan under which employee salary deferrals and after-tax contributions are used to purchase several different investment fund options.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P311_S1	For employees under the Cash Balance formula, PSE will match 100% of an employee retirement plan contribution up to 6% of an employee annual salary and make an additional year-end contribution equal to 1% of base pay.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P311_S2	For employees grandfathered under the Final Average Earning formula pension plan, PSE will match 55% of an employee s investment plan contribution up to 6% of an employee annual salary.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P311_S3	PSE s contributions to the Employee Investment Plan were $13.5 million, $11.8 million and $11.4 million for the years 2011, 2010 and 2009, respectively.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P312_S0	The Employee Investment Plan eligibility requirements are set forth in the plan documents.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P313_S0	PSE has a defined benefit pension plan covering substantially all PSE employees.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P313_S1	Pension benefits earned are a function of age, salary and years of service.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P313_S2	PSE also maintains a non-qualified Supplemental Executive Retirement Plan (SERP) for its key senior management employees.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P314_S0	In addition to providing pension benefits, PSE provides certain health care and life insurance benefits for employees.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P314_S1	These benefits are provided principally through an insurance company.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P314_S2	The insurance premiums are based on the benefits provided during the year, and are paid primarily by retirees.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P315_S0	The February 6, 2009 merger of Puget Energy with Puget Holdings triggered a new basis of accounting for PSE s retirement benefit plans in the Puget Energy consolidated financial statements.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P315_S1	Such purchase accounting adjustments associated with the remeasurement of retirement plans are recorded at Puget Energy.

1085392_12_ITEM8_P321_S0	The aggregate expected contributions by the Company to fund the retirement plan, SERP and the other postretirement plans for the year ending December 31, 2012 are expected to be at least $22.8 million, $6.1 million and $0.9 million, respectively.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P322_S0	As a result of the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act of 2010, PSE recorded a one-time tax expense of $0.8 million during the three months ended March 31, 2010, related to a Medicare D subsidy that PSE receives.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P322_S1	These subsidies have been non-taxable in the past and will be subject to federal income taxes after 2012 as a result of the legislation.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P323_S0	As part of PSE s contract with the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers (IBEW) Local 77 union, which took effect September 1, 2010, the benefit calculation formula changed for Company employees covered by the contract.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P323_S1	IBEW represented employees hired after August 31, 2010 and employees not vested in a plan benefit as of July 31, 2010 participate in the cash balance formula of the retirement program, with any accrued benefit converted to a beginning cash balance account.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P323_S2	Employees who were vested in a plan benefit as of July 31, 2010 had a choice to convert to the cash balance formula or remain on a final average earnings formula based on qualified pay and years of service.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P323_S3	All employees accruing benefits under the cash balance formula receive the same investment plan match and Company contribution.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P323_S4	Effective December 1, 2010, the IBEW represented employees who accrue benefits under the cash balance formula receive a higher matching contribution and an additional Company contribution as compared to IBEW represented employees who are covered by the final average earnings formula.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P323_S5	These are the same formulas applied to non-union represented employees.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P323_S6	IBEW represented employees who were rehired after August 31, 2010, will accrue future benefits under the cash balance formula and will be able to elect to convert their prior benefits to the cash balance formula.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P323_S7	As a result of these changes to the IBEW contract, approximately 88.0% of the employees are in the cash balance formula and approximately 12.0% of the employees are in the final average earnings formula.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P324_S0	In accounting for pension and other benefit obligations and costs under the plans, the following weighted-average actuarial assumptions were used by the Company:
1085392_12_ITEM8_P325_S0	The Company calculates the present value of the pension liability using a discount rate of 4.75% which represents the single-rate equivalent of the AA rated corporate bond yield curve.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P326_S0	6.50% is the benefit cost discount rate used by Puget Energy.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P326_S1	6.20% is the benefit cost discount rate use by PSE.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P326_S2	The discount rates for the net periodic costs for Puget Energy and PSE were different because of the discount rates in effect as of February 5, 2009, the date of the merger of Puget Energy with Puget Holdings.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P327_S0	The assumed medical inflation rate used to determine benefit obligations is 7.5% in 2012 grading down to 4.90% in 2013.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P327_S1	A 1.0% change in the assumed medical inflation rate would have the following effects:
1085392_12_ITEM8_P328_S0	The Company has selected the expected return on plan assets based on a historical analysis of rates of return and the Company s investment mix, market conditions, inflation and other factors.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P328_S1	The expected rate of return is reviewed annually based on these factors.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P329_S0	The Company s accounting policy for calculating the market-related value of assets for the Company s retirement plan is as follows.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P329_S1	PSE market-related value of assets is based on a five-year smoothing of asset gains/losses measured from the expected return on market-related assets.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P329_S2	This is a calculated value that recognizes changes in fair value in a systematic and rational manner over five years.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P329_S3	The same manner of calculating market-related value is used for all classes of assets, and is applied consistently from year to year.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P330_S0	Puget Energy s pension and other postretirement benefits income or costs depend on several factors and assumptions, including plan design, timing and amount of cash contributions to the plan, earnings on plan assets, discount rate, expected long-term rate of return, mortality and health care costs trends.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P330_S1	Changes in any of these factors or assumptions will affect the amount of income or expense that Puget Energy records in its financial statements in future years and its projected benefit obligation.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P331_S0	Puget Energy has selected an expected return on plan assets based on a historical analysis of rates of return and Puget Energy s investment mix, market conditions, inflation and other factors.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P331_S1	As required by merger accounting rules, market-related value was reset to market value effective with the merger.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P332_S0	The discount rates were determined by using market interest rate data and the weighted-average discount rate from Citigroup Pension Liability Index Curve.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P332_S1	The Company also takes into account in determining the discount rate the expected changes in market interest rates and anticipated changes in the duration of the plan liabilities.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P333_S0	The aggregate expected contributions and payments by the Company to fund the retirement plan, SERP and the other postretirement plans for the year ending December 31, 2012 are expected to be at least $22.8 million, $6.1 million and $0.9 million, respectively.

1085392_12_ITEM8_P337_S0	Plan contributions and the actuarial present value of accumulated plan benefits are prepared based on certain assumptions pertaining to interest rates, inflation rates and employee demographics, all of which are subject to change.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P337_S1	Due to uncertainties inherent in the estimations and assumptions process, changes in these estimates and assumptions in the near term may be material to the financial statements.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P338_S0	The Company has a Retirement Plan Committee that establishes investment policies, objectives and strategies designed to balance expected return with a prudent level of risk.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P338_S1	All changes to the investment policies are reviewed and approved by the Retirement Plan Committee prior to being implemented.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P339_S0	The Retirement Plan Committee invests trust assets with investment managers who have historically achieved above-median long-term investment performance within the risk and asset allocation limits that have been established.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P339_S1	Interim evaluations are routinely performed with the assistance of an outside investment consultant.

1085392_12_ITEM8_P341_S0	Effective December 31, 2009, ASC 715, Compensation Retirement Benefits (ASC 715) directs companies to provide additional disclosures about plan assets of a defined benefit pension or other postretirement plan.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P341_S1	The objectives of the disclosures are to disclose the following: (1) how investment allocation decisions are made, including the factors that are pertinent to an understanding of investment policies and strategies; (2) major categories of plan assets; (3) inputs and valuation techniques used to measure the fair value of plan assets; (4) effect of fair value measurements using significant unobservable inputs (Level 3) on changes in plan assets for the period; and (5) significant concentrations of risk within plan assets.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P342_S0	In September 2009, the FASB issued ASU 2009-12, Fair Value Measurements and Disclosures: Investments in Certain Entities that Calculate Net Asset Value per Share (or Its Equivalent).
1085392_12_ITEM8_P342_S1	The standard allows the reporting entity, as a practical expedient, to measure the fair value of investments that do not have readily determinable fair values on the basis of the net asset value per share of the investment if the net asset value of the investment is calculated in a matter consistent with ASC 946, Financial Services Investment Companies.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P342_S2	The standard requires disclosures about the nature and risk of the investments and whether the investments are probable of being sold at amounts different from the net asset value per share.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P343_S0	The following table sets forth by level, within the fair value hierarchy, the qualified pension plan assets that were accounted for at fair value on a recurring basis as of December 31, 2011 and 2010:
1085392_12_ITEM8_P344_S0	Non US Equity investments are comprised of a (1) mutual fund; and a (2) commingled fund.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P344_S1	The investment in the mutual fund is valued using quoted market prices multiplied by the number of shares owned as of December 31, 2011.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P344_S2	The investment in the commingled fund is valued at the net asset value per share multiplied by the number of shares held as of December 31, 2011.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P345_S0	Domestic large cap equity investments are comprised of (1) common stock, and a (2) commingled fund.

1085392_12_ITEM8_P347_S0	The tactical asset allocation investment is compromised of a commingled fund, which is valued at the net asset value per share multiplied by the number of shares held as of the measurement date.

1085392_12_ITEM8_P349_S2	These investments are a Level 3 under ASC 820 because the significant valuation inputs are primarily internal to the partnerships with little third party involvement.

1085392_12_ITEM8_P357_S0	Prior to the merger on February 6, 2009, the Company granted equity awards, including stock awards, performance awards, stock options and restricted stock to officers and key employees of the Company under the Company s Long-Term Incentive Plan (LTI Plan), approved by the shareholders in 2005.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P357_S1	Any shares awarded were either purchased on the open market or were a new issuance.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P357_S2	With the completion of the merger, all shares outstanding under the LTI Plan were fully vested and settled in cash to plan participants.

1085392_12_ITEM8_P359_S0	Performance shares activity from December 31, 2008 to February 5, 2009 was as follows:
1085392_12_ITEM8_P360_S0	Plan participants meeting the Company s stock ownership guidelines could elect to be paid up to 50.0% of the share award in cash.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P360_S1	The portion of the performance share grants that could be paid in cash was classified and accounted for as a liability.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P360_S2	As a result, the compensation expense of these liability awards was recognized over the performance period based on the fair value (i.e. cash value) of the award, and was periodically updated based on expected ultimate cash payout.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P360_S3	Compensation cost recognized during the performance period for the liability portion of the performance grants was based on the closing price of the Company s common stock on the date of measurement and the number of months of service rendered during the period.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P360_S4	The equity portion was valued based on the closing price of the Company s common stock on the grant date.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P360_S5	In connection with the completion of the merger in 2009, all performance shares vested and the Company paid and recognized $9.6 million recorded in merger and related costs for such shares.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P361_S0	In 2002, Puget Energy s Board of Directors granted 40,000 stock options under the LTI Plan and an additional 260,000 options outside the LTI Plan (for a total of 300,000 non-qualified stock options) to the former President and Chief Executive Officer.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P361_S1	These options could be exercised at the grant date market price of $22.51 per share and vested annually over four and five years, respectively.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P361_S2	The fair value of the stock option award was estimated at $3.33 per share on the date of grant using the Black-Scholes option valuation model.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P361_S3	The options were cancelled at the time of the merger and $2.3 million was paid in cash to the former President and Chief Executive Officer based on the terms of the merger agreement.

1085392_12_ITEM8_P364_S0	Prior to February 6, 2009, the Company had a non-employee director stock plan for all non-employee directors of Puget Energy and PSE.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P364_S1	An amended and restated plan was approved by shareholders in 2005.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P364_S2	Under the plan, non-employee directors received a portion of their quarterly retainer fees in Puget Energy stock except that 100.0% of quarterly retainers were paid in Puget Energy stock until the director held a number of shares equal in value to two years of their retainer fees.

1085392_12_ITEM8_P368_S0	The above amounts have been classified in the Balance Sheets as follows:
1085392_12_ITEM8_P369_S0	The Company calculates its deferred tax assets and liabilities under ASC 740, Income Taxes (ASC 740).
1085392_12_ITEM8_P369_S1	ASC 740 requires recording deferred tax balances, at the currently enacted tax rate, on assets and liabilities that are reported differently for income tax purposes than for financial reporting purposes.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P369_S2	The utilization of deferred tax assets requires sufficient taxable income in the future years.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P369_S3	ASC 740 requires a valuation allowance on deferred tax assets when it is more likely than not that the deferred tax asset will not be realized.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P369_S4	The Company s PTC carryforwards expire from 2026 through 2031.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P369_S5	The Company s net operating loss carryforwards expire from 2029 through 2030.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P370_S0	For ratemaking purposes, deferred taxes are not provided for certain temporary differences.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P370_S1	PSE has established a regulatory asset for income taxes recoverable through future rates related to those temporary differences for which no deferred taxes have been provided, based on prior and expected future ratemaking treatment.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P371_S0	The Company accounts for uncertain tax position under ASC 740, which clarifies the accounting for uncertainty in income taxes recognized in the financial statements.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P371_S1	ASC 740 requires the use of a two-step approach for recognizing and measuring tax positions taken or expected to be taken in a tax return.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P372_S0	First, a tax position should only be recognized when it is more likely than not, based on technical merits, that the position will be sustained upon challenge by the taxing authorities and taken by management to the court of last resort.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P372_S1	Second, a tax position that meets the recognition threshold should be measured at the largest amount that has a greater than 50.0% likelihood of being sustained.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P373_S0	As of December 31, 2011 and 2010, the Company had no material unrecognized tax benefits.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P373_S1	As a result, no interest or penalties were accrued for unrecognized tax benefits during the year.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P374_S0	For ASC 740 purposes, the Company has open tax years from 2006 through 2011.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P374_S1	The Company is under audit by the IRS for tax years 2006 and 2009.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P374_S2	The Company classifies interest as interest expense and penalties as other expense in the financial statements.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P375_S0	The Northwest Power Act, through the Residential Exchange Program (REP), provides access to the benefits of low-cost federal hydroelectric power to residential and small farm customers of regional utilities, including PSE.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P375_S1	The program is administered by the Bonneville Power Administration (the BPA).
1085392_12_ITEM8_P375_S2	Pursuant to agreements (including settlement agreements) between the BPA and PSE, the BPA has provided payments of REP benefits to PSE, which PSE has passed through to its residential and small farm customers in the form of electricity bill credits.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P376_S0	In 2007, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit ruled that REP agreements of the BPA with PSE and a number of other investor-owned utilities were inconsistent with the Northwest Power Act.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P376_S1	Since that time, those investor-owned utilities, including PSE, the BPA and other parties have been involved in ongoing litigation at the Ninth Circuit relating to the amount of REP benefits paid to utilities, including PSE, for the period fiscal year 2002 through fiscal year 2011 and the amount of REP benefits to be paid going forward.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P377_S0	In July 2011, the BPA, PSE and a number of other parties entered into a settlement agreement that by its terms if upheld in their entirety would resolve the disputes between BPA and PSE regarding REP benefits paid for the period fiscal year 2002-fiscal year 2011.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P377_S1	In October 2011, certain other parties challenged BPA decisions with regard to its entering into this most recent settlement agreement.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P377_S2	Pending disposition of this challenge, the other pending Ninth Circuit litigation regarding REP benefits for the period fiscal year 2002 through fiscal year 2011 has been stayed by the Ninth Circuit.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P378_S0	Due to the pending and ongoing proceedings, PSE is unable to reasonably estimate any amounts of REP payments either to be recovered by the BPA or to be paid for any future periods to PSE and is unable to determine the impact, if any, these proceedings and litigation may have on PSE.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P378_S1	However, it is unlikely that any unfavorable outcome would have a material adverse effect on PSE because REP benefits received by PSE are passed through to PSE's residential and small farm customers.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P379_S0	In October 2000, PSE filed a complaint with the FERC (Docket No.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P379_S1	EL01-10) against all jurisdictional sellers in the Pacific Northwest seeking prospective price caps consistent with any result the FERC ordered for the California markets.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P379_S2	The FERC issued an order including price caps in July 2001, and PSE moved to dismiss the proceeding.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P380_S0	In response to PSE s motion, various entities intervened and sought to convert PSE s complaint into one seeking retroactive refunds in the Pacific Northwest.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P380_S1	The FERC rejected that effort, after holding what the FERC referred to as a preliminary evidentiary hearing before an administrative law judge.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P380_S2	On October 3, 2011, after appellate reviews, the FERC issued an Order on Remand and set the matter for hearing before an administrative law judge, but first requiring the parties to engage in settlement talks that began in the fall of 2011 and are ongoing.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P380_S3	As such, the hearing date itself is not known.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P380_S4	PSE has not taken any reserve on this matter as it believes it has no exposure, and intends to vigorously defend its position but is unable to predict the outcome of this matter.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P381_S0	The Company is also involved in litigation relating to claims arising out of its operations in the normal course of business.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P381_S1	The Company has recorded a total of $3.8 million and $3.1 million relating to these claims as of December 31, 2011 and 2010, respectively.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P382_S0	In accordance with ASC 810, Consolidation (ASC 810), a business entity that has a controlling financial interest in a variable interest entity (VIE) should consolidate the VIE in its financial statements.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P382_S1	A primary beneficiary of a VIE is the variable interest holder that has both the power to direct matters that significantly impact the activities of the VIE and has the obligation to absorb losses or the right to receive benefits.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P382_S2	The Company enters into a variety of contracts for energy with other counterparties and evaluates all contracts to determine if they are variable interests.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P382_S3	The Company s variable interests primarily arise through power purchase agreements where it is required to buy all or a majority of generation from a plant at rates set forth in the agreement.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P383_S0	The Company evaluated its power purchase agreements and determined it was not the primary beneficiary of any VIEs.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P383_S1	The Company had previously disclosed two potentially significant variable interests in prior periods; both entities were qualifying facilities contracts that expired at the end of 2011.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P383_S2	The Company requested information from the relevant entities; however, they refused to provide the necessary information, as they were not required to do so under their contracts.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P383_S3	However, if the variable interests had been determined to be VIEs, the Company concluded it would not have been the primary beneficiary of these entities based on available information and it had no exposure to loss on these contracts.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P383_S4	For the years ended December 31, 2011, 2010 and 2009, the Company s purchased power expense for these entities was $175.9 million, $190.3 million and $181.2 million, respectively.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P384_S0	For the year ended December 31, 2011, approximately 24.2% of the Company s energy output was obtained at an average cost of approximately $0.015 per kilowatt hour (kWh) through long-term contracts with three of the Washington Public Utility Districts (PUDs) that own hydroelectric projects on the Columbia River.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P384_S1	The purchase of power from the Columbia River projects is on a pro rata share basis under which the Company pays a proportionate share of the annual debt service, operating and maintenance costs and other expenses associated with each project in proportion to the contractual shares that PSE obtains from that project.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P384_S2	In these instances, PSE s payments are not contingent upon the projects being operable; therefore, PSE is required to make the payments even if power is not delivered.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P384_S3	These projects are financed through substantially level debt service payments and their annual costs should not vary significantly over the term of the contracts unless additional financing is required to meet the costs of major maintenance, repairs or replacements, or license requirements.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P384_S4	The Company s share of the costs and the output of the projects is subject to reduction due to various withdrawal rights of the PUDs and others over the contract lives.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P385_S0	The following table summarizes the Company s estimated payment obligations for power purchases from the Columbia River projects, contracts with other utilities and contracts under non-utility generators under the Public Utility Regulatory Policies Act.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P385_S1	These contracts have varying terms and may include escalation and termination provisions.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P386_S0	Total purchased power contracts provided the Company with approximately 8.5 million, 8.2 million and 8.3 million megawatt hours (MWh) of firm energy at a cost of approximately $391.8 million, $420.6 million and $363.3 million for the years 2011, 2010 and 2009, respectively.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P387_S0	The Company has natural gas-fired generation facility obligations for natural gas supply amounting to an estimated $33.3 million in 2012.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P387_S1	Longer term agreements for natural gas supply amount to an estimated $340.4 million for 2013 through 2029.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P388_S0	PSE enters into short-term energy supply contracts to meet its core customer needs.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P388_S1	These contracts are sometimes classified as NPNS, however in most cases recorded at fair value in accordance with ASC 815.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P388_S2	Commitments under these contracts are $200.5 million, $92.5 million and $25.2 million in 2012, 2013 and 2014, respectively.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P389_S0	The Company has also entered into various firm supply, transportation and storage service contracts in order to ensure adequate availability of natural gas supply for its firm customers.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P389_S1	Many of these contracts, which have remaining terms from less than one year to 34 years, provide that the Company must pay a fixed demand charge each month, regardless of actual usage.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P389_S2	The Company contracts for its long-term natural gas supply on a firm basis, which means the Company has a 100% daily take obligation and the supplier has a 100% daily delivery obligation to ensure service to PSE s customers and generation requirements.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P390_S0	The Company incurred demand charges in 2011 for firm natural gas supply, firm transportation service and firm storage and peaking service of $0.1 million, $142.8 million and $6.5 million, respectively.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P390_S1	The Company incurred demand charges in 2011 for firm transportation and firm storage service for the natural gas supply for its combustion turbines in the amount of $32.3 million, which is included in the total Company demand charges.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P391_S0	The following table summarizes the Company s obligations for future demand charges through the primary terms of its existing contracts.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P391_S1	The quantified obligations are based on the FERC authorized rates, which are subject to change.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P392_S0	The following table summarizes the Company s estimated obligations for service contracts through the terms of its existing contracts.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P393_S0	Energy production service contracts include operations and maintenance contracts on Mint Farm, Wild Horse, Goldendale electric generating facility (Goldendale), Hopkins Ridge, Frederickson 1, Sumas and Lower Snake River facilities.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P394_S0	Automated meter reading system contractual obligation is the service component of the Landis and Gyr contract.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P395_S0	The Company has a self-insurance surety bond in the amount of $3.7 million, which expires on July 1, 2012 and is renewed annually, guaranteeing compliance with the Industrial Insurance Act (workers compensation) and eight self-insurer s pension bonds totaling $1.2 million.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P396_S0	The Company is subject to environmental laws and regulations by the federal, state and local authorities and is required to undertake certain environmental investigative and remedial efforts as a result of these laws and regulations.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P396_S1	The Company has been named by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), the Washington State Department of Ecology and/or other third parties as potentially responsible at several contaminated sites and manufactured gas plant sites.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P397_S0	PSE has implemented an ongoing program to test, replace and remediate certain underground storage tanks (UST) as required by federal and state laws.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P397_S1	The UST replacement component of this effort is finished, but PSE continues its work remediating and/or monitoring relevant sites.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P398_S0	During 1992, the Washington Commission issued orders regarding the treatment of costs incurred by the Company for certain sites under its environmental remediation program.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P398_S1	The orders authorize the Company to accumulate and defer prudently incurred cleanup costs paid to third parties for recovery in rates established in future rate proceedings, subject to Washington Commission review.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P399_S0	The Washington Commission consolidated the gas and electric methodological approaches to remediation and deferred accounting in an order issued October 8, 2008.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P400_S0	Per the guidance of ASC 450, Contingencies, the Company reviews its estimated future obligations and adjusts loss reserves quarterly.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P401_S0	Management believes it is probable and reasonably estimable that the impact of the potential outcomes of disputes with certain property owners and other potentially responsible parties will result in environmental remediation costs ranging from $39.1 million to $57.3 million for gas and from $8.2 million to $27.9 million for electric.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P401_S1	The Company does not consider any amounts within those ranges as being a better estimate and has therefore accrued $39.1 million and $8.2 million for gas and electric, respectively.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P401_S2	The Company believes a significant portion of its past and future environmental remediation costs are recoverable from insurance companies, from third parties or from customers under a Washington Commission order.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P401_S3	For the year ended December 31, 2011, the Company incurred deferred electric and natural gas environmental costs of $9.6 million and $5.5 million, net of insurance proceeds, respectively.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P402_S0	On June 1, 2006, PSE entered into a revolving credit facility with Puget Energy in the form of a Demand Promissory Note (Note).
1085392_12_ITEM8_P402_S1	Through the Note, PSE may borrow up to $30.0 million from Puget Energy, subject to approval by Puget Energy.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P402_S2	Under the terms of the Note, PSE pays interest on the outstanding borrowings based on the lowest of the weighted-average interest rate of PSE s outstanding commercial paper interest rate or PSE s senior unsecured revolving credit facility.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P402_S3	Absent such borrowings, interest is charged at one-month LIBOR plus 0.25%.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P402_S4	At December 31, 2011 and December 31, 2010, the outstanding balance of the Note was $30.0 million and $22.6 million, respectively, and the interest rate was 1.6% and 1.1%, respectively.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P402_S5	The outstanding balance and the related interest under the Note are eliminated by Puget Energy upon consolidation of PSE s financial statements.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P402_S6	The $30.0 million credit facility with Puget Energy was unaffected by the merger.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P403_S0	On June 3, 2011, Puget Energy issued $500.0 million of senior secured notes.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P403_S1	Macquarie Capital (USA) Inc. acted as a co-manager and underwriter of this issue.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P403_S2	Net proceeds of $484.0 million from these notes were used to repay a portion of the outstanding $782.0 million term-loan.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P404_S0	Puget Energy s term-loan and credit facility for funding capital expenditures both mature in February 2014, contain similar terms and conditions and are syndicated among numerous committed banks and other financial institutions.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P404_S1	One of these banks is Macquarie Bank Limited, which as of December 31, 2011 had commitments of $6.9 million under the term-loan and $50.6 million under the capital expenditure credit facility.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P404_S2	Concurrent with the borrowings under these credit agreements, Puget Energy entered into several interest rate swap instruments to hedge volatility associated with these two loans.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P404_S3	Two of the swap instruments were entered into with Macquarie Bank Limited with a total notional amount of $444.9 million.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P404_S4	On June 3, 2011 Puget Energy settled one of the swaps with a notional amount of $77.4 million, while the other swap instrument, with a notional amount of $367.5 million, remains outstanding as of December 31, 2011.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P405_S0	At the time of merger, Puget Energy recorded the fair value of its intangible assets in accordance with ASC 360, Property, Plant, and Equipment, (ASC 360).
1085392_12_ITEM8_P405_S1	The fair value assigned to the power contracts was determined using an income approach comparing the contract rate to the market rate for power over the remaining period of the contracts incorporating nonperformance risk.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P405_S2	Management also incorporated certain assumptions related to quantities and market presentation that it believes market participants would make in the valuation.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P406_S0	The fair value of the power contracts is amortized as the contracts settle.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P407_S0	ASC 360 requires long-lived assets to be tested for impairment on an on-going basis, whenever events or circumstances would more likely than not reduce the fair value of the long-lived assets below its carrying value.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P407_S1	One such triggering event is a significant decrease in market price.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P408_S0	Puget Energy completed a valuation and impairment test as of December 31, 2011 for long-term power purchase contracts.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P408_S1	The valuation indicated impairment to two of the purchased power contracts, the WNP-3 BPA Exchange Power contract and the Rock Island hydro contract.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P408_S2	As of December 31, 2011, the carrying value for the WNP-3 BPA intangible asset contract was $1.9 million but its fair value on a discounted basis was less than zero thereby requiring a full write-off of the intangible asset with a corresponding reduction in the regulatory liability.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P408_S3	The carrying value for Rock Island intangible asset contract was $44.9 million and its fair value on a discounted basis was determined to be $9.8 million thereby requiring a $35.1 million write-off of the intangible asset with a corresponding reduction in the regulatory liability.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P409_S0	Puget Energy completed a valuation and impairment test as of December 31, 2010 for long-term power purchase contracts and SO2 emission allowance assets.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P409_S1	The carrying value of Puget Energy s power contracts and SO2 emission allowances as of December 31, 2010 was approximately $864.7 million and $7.9 million, respectively.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P409_S2	The excess of the carrying value over the fair value of the power contracts was $105.8 million which was written-off against regulatory liabilities at December 31, 2010.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P409_S3	The excess of the carrying value over the fair value of the SO2 emissions was $7.9 million which was expensed at December 31, 2010.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P410_S0	Puget Energy operates one business segment referred to as the regulated utility segment.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P410_S1	The regulated utility segment includes the account receivables securitization program which was terminated during the merger.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P411_S0	Puget Energy s regulated utility operation generates, purchases and sells electricity and purchases, transports and sells natural gas.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P411_S1	The service territory of PSE covers approximately 6,000 square miles in the state of Washington.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P412_S0	Non-utility business segment includes two PSE subsidiaries and Puget Energy, and is described as Other.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P412_S1	The PSE subsidiaries are a real estate investment and development company and a holding company for a small non-utility wholesale generator which was sold in 2010.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P412_S2	Reconciling items between segments are not significant.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P413_S0	Effective February 6, 2009, all merger related fair value adjustments were retained in Puget Energy.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P413_S1	Accordingly, only the financial statements of Puget Energy were adjusted to reflect the purchase accounting.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P413_S2	Prior to the merger, the business segment financial statements for Puget Energy and PSE were the same.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P414_S0	The following unaudited amounts, in the opinion of the Company, include all adjustments (consisting of normal recurring adjustments) necessary for a fair statement of the results of operations for the interim periods.
1085392_12_ITEM8_P415_S0	Quarterly amounts vary during the year due to the seasonal nature of the utility business.

1085392_12_ITEM9A_P0_S0	Under the supervision and with the participation of Puget Energy s management, including the President and Chief Executive Officer and Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, Puget Energy has evaluated the effectiveness of its disclosure controls and procedures (as defined in Rule 13a-15(e) under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934) as of December 31, 2011, the end of the period covered by this report.
1085392_12_ITEM9A_P0_S1	Based upon that evaluation, the President and Chief Executive Officer and Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer of Puget Energy concluded that these disclosure controls and procedures are effective.
1085392_12_ITEM9A_P1_S0	There have been no changes in Puget Energy s internal control over financial reporting during the quarter ended December 31, 2011 that have materially affected, or are reasonably likely to materially affect, Puget Energy s internal control over financial reporting.
1085392_12_ITEM9A_P2_S0	Puget Energy s management is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting (as defined in Rule 13a-15(f) under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934).
1085392_12_ITEM9A_P2_S1	Under the supervision and with the participation of Puget Energy s President and Chief Executive Officer and Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, Puget Energy s management assessed the effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting based on the framework in Internal Control Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission.
1085392_12_ITEM9A_P2_S2	Based on the assessment, Puget Energy s management concluded that its internal control over financial reporting was effective as of December 31, 2011.
1085392_12_ITEM9A_P3_S0	Puget Energy s effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2011 has been audited by PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP, an independent registered public accounting firm, as stated in their report which is included herein.
1085392_12_ITEM9A_P4_S0	Under the supervision and with the participation of PSE s management, including the President and Chief Executive Officer and Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, PSE has evaluated the effectiveness of its disclosure controls and procedures (as defined in Rule 13a-15(e) under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934) as of December 31, 2011, the end of the period covered by this report.
1085392_12_ITEM9A_P4_S1	Based upon that evaluation, the President and Chief Executive Officer and Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer of PSE concluded that these disclosure controls and procedures are effective.
1085392_12_ITEM9A_P5_S0	There have been no changes in PSE s internal control over financial reporting during the quarter ended December 31, 2011 that have materially affected, or are reasonably likely to materially affect, PSE s internal control over financial reporting.
1085392_12_ITEM9A_P6_S0	PSE s management is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting (as defined in Rule 13a-15(f) under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934).
1085392_12_ITEM9A_P6_S1	Under the supervision and with the participation of PSE s President and Chief Executive Officer and Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, Puget Sound Energy s management assessed the effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting based on the framework in Internal Control Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission.
1085392_12_ITEM9A_P6_S2	Based on the assessment, PSE s management concluded that its internal control over financial reporting was effective as of December 31, 2011.
1085392_12_ITEM9A_P7_S0	PSE s effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2011 has been audited by PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP, an independent registered public accounting firm, as stated in their report which is included herein.
1085392_12_ITEM9B_P0_S0	As of March 1, 2012, eleven directors constitute Puget Energy s Board of Directors and twelve directors currently constitute PSE s Board of Directors, as set forth below.
1085392_12_ITEM9B_P0_S1	The directors are selected in accordance with the Amended and Restated Bylaws of each of Puget Energy and PSE, pursuant to which, the investor-owners of Puget Holdings (the indirect parent company of both Puget Energy and PSE) are entitled to select individuals to serve on the boards of Puget Energy and PSE.
1085392_12_ITEM9B_P1_S0	William Ayer , age 57, is a director on the boards of both Puget Energy and PSE.
1085392_12_ITEM9B_P1_S1	Over the past 30 years, Mr. Ayer has served in a variety of leadership positions at Alaska Air Group, most recently as Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer of Alaska Air Group, the parent company of Alaska Airlines and Horizon Air.
1085392_12_ITEM9B_P1_S2	As the current Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Alaska Airlines, Mr. Ayer leads the nation s seventh-largest airline with 9,600 employees.
1085392_12_ITEM9B_P1_S3	He also oversees regional carrier Horizon Air and its 3,200 employees.
1085392_12_ITEM9B_P1_S4	Mr. Ayer is also a member of the board of directors of the Museum of Flight and Angel Flight West and serves on the University of Washington s Board of Regents and the NextGen Advisory Committee.
1085392_12_ITEM9B_P1_S5	Mr. Ayer s leadership in running a successful company recognized nationally for its award-winning customer service and operational performance, coupled with his community involvement in the western Washington region, are among the qualifications and attributes that led to the conclusion that he should serve on the Puget Energy and PSE boards.
1085392_12_ITEM9B_P1_S6	Mr. Ayer will retire as Chief Executive Officer of Alaska Air Group on May 15, 2012.
1085392_12_ITEM9B_P1_S7	He will remain Chairman of the board for a period of time.
1085392_12_ITEM9B_P2_S0	Andrew Chapman , age 56, has been a director on the boards of both Puget Energy and PSE since February 2009.
1085392_12_ITEM9B_P2_S1	Mr. Chapman is currently a director on the Board of Duquesne Light Holdings, Inc. and Duquesne Light Company, which position he has held since February 1, 2010.
1085392_12_ITEM9B_P2_S2	Mr. Chapman is currently a Managing Director in the Macquarie Capital Funds division of the Macquarie Group, which position he has held since 2006.
1085392_12_ITEM9B_P2_S3	Prior to joining the Macquarie Group, Mr. Chapman was Vice President Strategy Regulation for American Water from 2005 to 2006 and Regional Managing Director from 2003 to 2004.
1085392_12_ITEM9B_P2_S4	Mr. Chapman represents the Company s Macquarie affiliated investors on the boards, in accordance with the terms of the Puget Energy and PSE bylaws, and brings to his service many years of experience in the operational and financial management challenges specific to regulated utilities.
1085392_12_ITEM9B_P3_S0	Melanie Dressel , age 59, is a director on the boards of both Puget Energy and PSE, which positions she has held since December 19, 2011.
1085392_12_ITEM9B_P3_S1	Ms. Dressel is currently President and Chief Executive Officer of Columbia Bank and its parent company, Columbia Banking System, Inc., of Tacoma, Washington, which positions she has held since 2000 and 2003, respectively.
1085392_12_ITEM9B_P3_S2	An independent director not affiliated with any of the Company s investors, Ms. Dressel s leadership skills, financial experience and many ties to civic and community groups in the Company s service territory are among the reasons for her appointment to the Puget Energy and PSE boards.
1085392_12_ITEM9B_P4_S0	Kimberly Harris, age 47, is a director on the boards of both Puget Energy and PSE, which positions she has held since March 1, 2011.
1085392_12_ITEM9B_P4_S1	Ms. Harris has also been President and Chief Executive Officer since March 1, 2011.
1085392_12_ITEM9B_P4_S2	Prior to that time, Ms. Harris served as President from July 2010 through February 2011.
1085392_12_ITEM9B_P4_S3	Ms. Harris also served as Executive Vice President and Chief Resource Officer from May 2007 until July 2010, and was Senior Vice President Regulatory Policy and Energy Efficiency from 2005 until May 2007.
1085392_12_ITEM9B_P5_S0	Benjamin Hawkins , age 37, has been a director on the boards of both Puget Energy and PSE since May 21, 2010.
1085392_12_ITEM9B_P5_S1	Mr. Hawkins is currently a Senior Principal of Infrastructure Timber Investments for Alberta Investment Management Corporation (AimCo), which position he has held since June 2011.
1085392_12_ITEM9B_P5_S2	Mr. Hawkins also served as Principal of Infrastructure Investments of AimCo from November 2008 until June 2011, and Portfolio Manager of Infrastructure Investments from May of 2007 until November 2008.
1085392_12_ITEM9B_P5_S3	Prior to joining AimCo, Mr. Hawkins held various positions with EPCOR Utilities, a Canadian power and water utility company.
1085392_12_ITEM9B_P5_S4	Mr. Hawkins serves on the boards as a representative of AimCo s ownership interest in the Company, pursuant to the terms of the Puget Energy and PSE bylaws, and brings to this service his skills in financial oversight of utilities.
1085392_12_ITEM9B_P6_S0	Alan James , age 58, has been a director on the boards of both Puget Energy and PSE since February 2009, as a representative of the Company s Macquarie affiliated investors consistent with the Puget Energy and PSE bylaws.
1085392_12_ITEM9B_P6_S1	Mr. James is currently the Chairman and Senior Managing Director of Macquarie Capital (USA) Inc. based in New York where he specializes in providing M A advice and capital raising solutions to the utility, power and renewable sectors in North America, which position he has held since 2005.
1085392_12_ITEM9B_P6_S2	Prior to that time, Mr. James was Managing Director and Head, Investment Banking Australia and New Zealand at Citigroup from 2002 to 2005 and held various positions with Deutsche Bank AG in Australia and Europe from 1993 to 2002 specializing in the energy sector.
1085392_12_ITEM9B_P6_S3	Mr. James represents the Company s Macquarie affiliated investors in accordance with the Puget Energy and PSE bylaws.
1085392_12_ITEM9B_P6_S4	Mr. James provides the boards the benefit of his broad experience with the financial needs and operational and regulatory challenges of infrastructure providers.
1085392_12_ITEM9B_P7_S0	Alan Kadic , age 40, has been a director on the boards of both Puget Energy and PSE since February 2009.
1085392_12_ITEM9B_P7_S1	Mr. Kadic is currently a Senior Principal in the Infrastructure Group of the Private Investments department at the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board (CPPIB), which position he has held since 2007.
1085392_12_ITEM9B_P7_S2	Prior to joining CPPIB, Mr. Kadic served as Vice President at Macquarie Bank Limited in Toronto, Canada from 2001 to 2007.
1085392_12_ITEM9B_P7_S3	Mr. Kadic is currently an alternate director on the board of Wales and West Utilities, a United Kingdom natural gas distribution company, as well as MGN Gas Networks, the holding company for Wales and West Utilities.
1085392_12_ITEM9B_P7_S4	Mr. Kadic represents the ownership stake in the Company of the CPPIB, in accordance with the terms of the Puget Energy and PSE bylaws, and brings to such service his expertise in the financial and budgetary management of utility providers.
1085392_12_ITEM9B_P8_S0	Christopher Leslie , age 47, has been a director on the boards of both Puget Energy and PSE since February 2009, as a representative of the Company s Macquarie affiliated investors consistent with the Puget Energy and PSE bylaws.
1085392_12_ITEM9B_P8_S1	Mr. Leslie is currently an Executive Director of Macquarie Group Limited, which position he has held since 2005, President of Macquarie Infrastructure and Real Assets Inc., and since 2006 Chief Executive Officer of Macquarie Infrastructure Partners Inc.

1085392_12_ITEM9B_P8_S3	In addition to his management and banking skills, Mr. Leslie provides the Puget Energy and PSE boards the benefit of his experience with electric utilities, gas distribution systems and other aspects of the infrastructure sector.
1085392_12_ITEM9B_P9_S0	Mary McWilliams , age 63, has been a director on the boards of both Puget Energy and PSE since March 1, 2011.
1085392_12_ITEM9B_P9_S1	Ms. McWilliams is currently the Executive Director at Puget Sound Health Alliance, which position she has held since 2008.
1085392_12_ITEM9B_P9_S2	She also served as President and Chief Executive Officer at Regence BlueShield from 2000 to 2008.

1085392_12_ITEM9B_P9_S4	Ms. McWilliams s significant experience managing consumer-focused organizations with challenging regulatory and compliance regimes, as well as her extensive knowledge of the western Washington economy generally, are some of the reasons that led to her appointment to the Puget Energy and PSE boards on behalf of the CPPIB.
1085392_12_ITEM9B_P10_S0	Herbert Simon , age 68, is a director on the board of PSE, on which he has served since March 2006.

1085392_12_ITEM9B_P10_S2	In addition, Mr. Simon serves as a Regent at the University of Washington and as a Board member of Acre, the real estate committee for the University of Washington.
1085392_12_ITEM9B_P10_S3	Mr. Simon previously served on the Advisory Boards of the University of Washington at Tacoma and its Institute of Technology.
1085392_12_ITEM9B_P10_S4	An independent director not affiliated with any of the Company s investors, Mr. Simon s long-standing involvement with the commercial, educational, political and philanthropic leadership of western Washington are among the qualifications supporting his appointment to the PSE board.

1085392_12_ITEM9B_P14_S0	The information required by this item with respect to Puget Energy and PSE is incorporated herein by reference to the material under Executive Officers of the Registrants in Part I of this report.
1085392_12_ITEM9B_P15_S0	The Puget Energy and PSE Boards of Directors have both established an Audit Committee.
1085392_12_ITEM9B_P15_S1	Directors Andrew Chapman, Benjamin Hawkins, Alan Kadic and William S. Ayer are the members of the Audit Committee.
1085392_12_ITEM9B_P15_S2	The Board has determined that Andrew Chapman meets the definition of Audit Committee Financial Expert under SEC rules.
1085392_12_ITEM9B_P15_S3	Puget Energy and PSE currently do not have any outstanding stock listed on a national securities exchange and, therefore, there are no independence standards applicable to either company in connection with the independence of its Audit Committee members.
1085392_12_ITEM9B_P16_S0	Following the closing of the merger, members of the Boards of Directors of Puget Energy and PSE are nominated and elected in accordance with the provisions of their respective Amended and Restated Bylaws.
1085392_12_ITEM9B_P17_S0	Puget Energy and PSE have adopted a Corporate Ethics and Compliance Code applicable to all directors, officers and employees and a Code of Ethics applicable to the Chief Executive Officer and senior financial officers, which are available on the website www.pugetenergy.com.
1085392_12_ITEM9B_P17_S1	If any material provisions of the Corporate Ethics and Compliance Code or the Code of Ethics are waived for the Chief Executive Officer or senior financial officers, or if any substantive changes are made to either code as they relate to any director or executive officer, we will disclose that fact on our website within four business days.
1085392_12_ITEM9B_P17_S2	In addition, any other material amendments of these codes will be disclosed.
1085392_12_ITEM9B_P18_S0	The Company s reports on Form 10-K, quarterly reports on Form 10-Q, current reports on Form 8-K and amendments to these reports filed or furnished pursuant to Section 13(a) or 15(d) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 are available or may be accessed free of charge at the Company s website, www.pugetenergy.com .
1085392_12_ITEM9B_P18_S1	Information may also be obtained via the SEC Internet website at www.sec.gov.
