1085392_13_ITEM7_P0_S9	Readers are urged to carefully review and consider the various disclosures made in this report and in Puget Energy s and PSE s other reports filed with the United States Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) that attempt to advise interested parties of the risks and factors that may affect Puget Energy s and PSE s business, prospects and results of operations.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P1_S0	OVERVIEW Puget Energy is an energy services holding company and all of its operations are conducted through its subsidiary PSE, a regulated electric and natural gas utility company.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P1_S1	PSE is the largest electric and natural gas utility in the state of Washington, primarily engaged in the business of electric transmission, distribution and generation and natural gas distribution.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P1_S2	Puget Energy s business strategy is to generate stable cash flows by offering reliable electric and natural gas service in a cost-effective manner through PSE.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P2_S0	On February 6, 2009, Puget Holdings completed its merger with Puget Energy.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P3_S0	I, Macquarie Infrastructure Partners II, Macquarie Capital Group Limited, FSS Infrastructure Trust, the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board (CPPIB), the British Columbia Investment Management Corporation, and the Alberta Investment Management Corporation.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P3_S1	As a result of the merger, all of Puget Energy s common stock is indirectly owned by Puget Holdings.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P3_S2	Puget Energy accounted for the merger as a business combination and all its assets and liabilities were recorded at fair value as of the merger date.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P3_S3	PSE s basis of accounting continues to be on a historical basis and PSE s financial statements do not include any purchase accounting adjustments.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P3_S4	Puget Energy and PSE are collectively referred to herein as the Company.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P4_S0	PSE generates revenue and cash flow primarily from the sale of electric and natural gas services to residential and commercial customers within a service territory covering approximately 6,000 square miles, principally in the Puget Sound region of the state of Washington.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P4_S1	To meet customer growth, to replace expiring power contracts and to meet Washington state s renewable energy portfolio standards, PSE is increasing energy efficiency programs to reduce the demand for additional energy generation and is pursuing additional renewable energy production resources (primarily wind) and base load natural gas-fired generation.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P5_S0	The Company s external financing requirements principally reflect the cash needs of its construction program, its schedule of maturing debt and certain operational needs.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P5_S1	PSE requires access to bank and capital markets to meet its financing needs.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P5_S2	The Company's strategy is to be a safe, dependable, and efficient utility.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P5_S3	The Company has made a commitment to seek to be world-class in safety for employees, customers and communities; provide exceptional customer service; invest in technology to enhance customer service; commit to the professional development of the workforce; work with stakeholders to ensure timely and consistent regulatory support; and drive necessary changes to maintain the financial strength of the Company.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P5_S4	These investments and commitments related to utility infrastructure and customer service may give rise to expenditures, which may not be recovered timely through the ratemaking process.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P5_S5	Additionally, Washington state law requires PSE to pursue conservation initiatives that promote efficient use of energy.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P5_S6	This mandate negatively impacts financial performance due to the lost sales margins arising from reduced energy sales.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P5_S7	To mitigate the regulatory lag and costs associated with conservation initiatives, the Company is focused on the following initiatives:
1085392_13_ITEM7_P6_S0	Develop an Expedited Rate Filing (ERF) process that would reduce the time to recover costs.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P7_S0	Establish a decoupling mechanism to allow recovery of lost margins from conservation initiatives.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P8_S0	Design a pipeline integrity program that would accelerate and enhance the safety of the gas system and ultimately reduce costs.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P8_S1	Additionally, the Company has initiatives to reduce spending over the next five years to maintain its financial strength.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P8_S2	The initiatives include re-engineering the customer value chain process as well as evaluating and improving processes in all areas of the Company.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P9_S0	For the year ended December 31, 2012 as compared to the prior year, PSE s net income was positively affected by the following two factors: (1) an unrealized gain in derivatives instruments for energy contracts compared to an unrealized loss for the same periods in the prior year; and (2) increased electric margins driven by lower power costs.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P9_S1	Further detail on each of these primary drivers, as well as other factors affecting performance, is set forth in this Overview section, as well as in other sections of the Management's Discussion Analysis.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P10_S0	The following discussion includes financial information prepared in accordance with U.S. Generally Accepted Accounting Principles (GAAP), as well as return on equity excluding unrealized loss on derivative instruments (net income plus unrealized loss on derivative instruments divided by average common equity) that is considered a non-GAAP financial measure.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P11_S0	Generally, a non-GAAP financial measure is a numerical measure of a company s financial performance, financial position or cash flows that exclude (or include) amounts that are included in (or excluded from) the most directly comparable measure calculated and presented in accordance with GAAP.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P11_S1	The presentation of return on equity excluding unrealized loss on derivative instruments is intended to supplement readers understanding of the Company s operating performance.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P12_S0	Return on equity excluding unrealized loss on derivative instrument is used by the Company to determine whether the Company is collecting the appropriate earnings from its customers to allow recovery of investor s capital.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P12_S1	PSE's return on equity may not be comparable to other companies return on equity measures.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P12_S2	Furthermore, this measure is not intended to replace return on equity (net income divided by average common equity) as determined in accordance with GAAP as an indicator of operating performance.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P13_S0	The Company has faced certain challenges which caused a significant reduction in the return on equity as compared to other years.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P13_S1	The following table presents PSE s return on equity for 2012 and 2011:
1085392_13_ITEM7_P14_S0	_______________ Equity adjustments are related to removing the impacts of accumulated other comprehensive income (OCI), subsidiary retained earnings and retained earnings of derivative instruments.

1085392_13_ITEM7_P16_S0	Operating revenue was $124.2 million lower than the amount allowed in rates for the year ended December 31, 2012.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P16_S1	However, margins increased $27.6 million due to significantly lower power costs.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P17_S0	Utility operations and maintenance expense was $18.7 million higher than the amount allowed in rates for the year ended December 31, 2012.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P17_S1	The increase was driven by an increase in costs in electric production, administration and general expenses and customer service expense.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P18_S0	Depreciation expense was $38.2 million higher than the amount allowed in rates for the year ended December 31, 2012.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P18_S1	The increase was primarily due to additional electric expenditures placed into service.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P19_S0	Utility rate making process has a delay between incurring expenses and their recovery in rate base.

1085392_13_ITEM7_P22_S1	The increase was driven by an increase in costs in electric production, administration and general expenses and gas operations costs.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P23_S0	Depreciation expense was $30 million higher than the amount allowed in rates for the year ended December 31, 2011.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P23_S1	The increase was primarily due to additional electric and common utility capital expenditures placed into service.

1085392_13_ITEM7_P24_S1	PSE increased ratebase by $484 million since its last general rate increase effective April 8, 2010.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P25_S0	These negative impacts were offset by favorable load which increased natural gas therm sales 7.0% for the year ended December 31, 2011, due to cooler temperatures in 2011 as compared to the same period in 2010.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P25_S1	Also, favorable electric power costs had a positive impact on net income.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P26_S0	Factors and Trends Affecting PSE s Performance.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P27_S0	PSE s regulatory requirements and operational needs require the investment of substantial capital in 2012 and future years.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P27_S1	Because PSE intends to seek recovery of such investments through the regulatory process, its financial results depend heavily upon favorable outcomes from that process.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P27_S2	Further, PSE s financial performance is heavily influenced by general economic conditions in its service territory, which affect customer growth and use-per-customer and thus utility sales, as well as by its customers conservation investments, which also tend to reduce energy sales.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P27_S3	The principal business, economic and other factors that affect PSE s operations and financial performance include:
1085392_13_ITEM7_P28_S0	Regulation of PSE Rates and Recovery of PSE Costs.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P28_S1	The rates that PSE is allowed to charge for its services influence its financial condition, results of operations and liquidity.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P28_S2	PSE is highly regulated and the rates that it charges its retail customers are approved by the Washington Commission.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P28_S3	The Washington Commission requires these rates be determined based, to a large extent, on historic test year costs plus weather normalized assumptions about hydroelectric conditions and power costs in the relevant rate year.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P28_S4	cost growth, thus rate increases are required.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P28_S5	If, in a particular year, PSE s costs are higher than what is allowed to be recovered in rates, revenue may not be sufficient to permit PSE to earn its allowed return.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P28_S6	In addition, the Washington Commission determines whether expenses and investments are reasonable and prudent in providing electric and natural gas service.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P28_S7	If the Washington Commission determines that part of PSE s costs do not meet the standard applied, those costs may be disallowed partially or entirely and not recovered in rates.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P29_S0	Electric Rates PSE has a PCA mechanism that provides for the recovery of power costs from customers or refunding of power cost savings to customers in the event those costs vary from the power cost baseline level of power costs.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P30_S0	The power cost baseline levels are set, in part, based on normalized assumptions about weather and hydroelectric conditions.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P30_S1	Excess power costs or power cost savings are apportioned between PSE and its customers pursuant to the graduated scale set forth in the PCA mechanism.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P31_S0	The graduated scale is as follows:
1085392_13_ITEM7_P32_S0	PSE had a favorable PCA imbalance for the year ended December 31, 2012 , which was $27.4 million below the power cost baseline level, $3.7 million of which was apportioned to customers.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P32_S1	This compares to a favorable imbalance of $38.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2011 , $9.0 million of which was apportioned to customers.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P33_S0	On February 2, 2013, PSE filed an expedited rate filing in which it requested to increase electric rates by $31.9 million or 1.6% for electric customers.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P33_S1	PSE made this filing consistent with the expedited filing methodology proposed by Commission Staff and commented on favorably by the Commission in PSE's 2011 general rate case.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P33_S2	PSE requested that the tariffs for the expedited rate filing become effective April 1, 2013.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P34_S0	On May 20, 2010, PSE filed an accounting petition requesting that the Washington Commission approve: (1) the creation of a regulatory asset account for the prepayments made to the BPA associated with network upgrades to the Central Ferry substation related to the Lower Snake River wind project; (2) the monthly accrual of carrying charges on that regulatory asset at PSE's approved net of tax rate of return; and (3) the ability to provide customers the BPA interest received through a reduction to transmission expense.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P35_S0	The Washington Commission issued an order in 2010 relating to how REC proceeds should be handled for regulatory accounting and ratemaking purposes.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P35_S1	The order required REC proceeds net of applicable costs to be recorded as regulatory liabilities and that amounts recorded would accrue interest.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P35_S2	In its petition, PSE had sought approval for $21.1 million of REC proceeds to be used as an offset against its California wholesale energy sales regulatory asset.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P35_S3	In response to the order, PSE adjusted the carrying value of its regulatory asset in the second quarter of 2010 by $17.8 million (from $21.1 million to $3.3 million), with the $3.3 million then offset against the Company's RECs regulatory liability.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P36_S0	The Company's California wholesale energy sales regulatory asset represented unpaid bills for power sold into the markets maintained by the California Independent System Operator during the 2000-2001 California Energy Crisis, the claims of which were settled along with all counterclaims against PSE in a settlement agreement approved by the FERC on July 1, 2009.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P36_S1	The Washington Commission ordered that parties provide recommended methods for passing back the remaining deferred proceeds.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P36_S2	The Commission approved a joint proposal that allowed a portion of the REC proceeds received by PSE to offset the Production Tax Credits (PTCs) that had been passed through to customers but have not been used by PSE on its tax return, and after completion of the PTC offset, the Commission allowed PSE to offset the REC liability against rate base and amortize the balance of RECs at the beginning of a given rate year over five years as a credit to cost of service.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P37_S0	On May 7, 2012, the Washington Commission issued its order in PSE's electric general rate case filed in June 2011, approving a general rate increase for electric customers of $63.3 million or 3.2% annually.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P37_S1	The rate increases for electric customers became effective May 14, 2012.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P37_S2	In its order, the Washington Commission approved a weighted cost of capital of 7.8% and a capital structure that included 48.0% common equity with a return on equity of 9.8%.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P37_S3	PSE's requested treatment of the prepayments made to BPA, filed in May 2010, was approved in the order.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P37_S4	The final order rejected PSE's proposed conservation savings adjustment.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P37_S5	Finally, a new rate rider for RECs was proposed by settlement of Electric parties and approved by the Washington Commission in the final order.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P37_S6	The new rate rider replaced prospectively what was required pursuant to the Commission's orders in 2010.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P38_S0	On April 2, 2010, the Washington Commission issued its order in PSE's consolidated electric rate case filed in May 2009 which approved a general rate increase for electric customers of 3.7% annually, or $74.1 million, effective April 8, 2010.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P38_S1	In its order, the Washington Commission approved a weighted cost of capital of 8.1% and a capital structure that included 46.0% common equity with an after-tax return on equity of 10.1%.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P38_S2	For additional information, see Note 3 to the consolidated financial statements included in Item 8 of this report.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P39_S0	Natural Gas Rates PSE has a PGA mechanism that allows PSE to recover expected natural gas supply and transportation costs and defer, as a receivable or liability, any natural gas supply and transportation costs that exceed or fall short of this expected natural gas cost amount in PGA mechanism rates, including accrued interest.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P39_S1	PSE is authorized by the Washington Commission to accrue carrying costs on PGA receivable and payable balances.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P39_S2	A receivable balance in the PGA mechanism reflects an underrecovery of natural gas cost through rates.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P40_S0	On February 2, 2013, PSE filed an expedited rate filing in which it requested to decrease natural gas rates by $1.2 million or 0.1% for natural gas customers.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P40_S1	PSE made this filing consistent with the expedited filing methodology proposed by Commission Staff and commented on favorably by the Commission in PSE's 2011 general rate case.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P40_S2	PSE requested that the tariffs for the expedited rate filing become effective April 1, 2013.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P40_S3	On October 31, 2012, the Washington Commission suspended PSE's PGA natural gas tariff filing and instituted an investigation, but allowed the requested rate decrease under the PGA to go into effect on a temporary basis effective November 1, 2012, subject to revision.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P40_S4	Commission Staff is required to report back to the Commission on the status of Staff's investigation no later than March 1, 2013, and that report shall include recommendations on the disposition of the tariff PSE filed or the need for further process to make the appropriate determination.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P40_S5	The estimated revenue impact of the change is a decrease of $77.0 million, or 7.7% annually.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P40_S6	The rate adjustment has no impact on PSE's net income On May 7, 2012, the Washington Commission issued its order in PSE's natural gas general rate case filed in June 2011, approving a general rate increase for natural gas customers of $13.4 million or 1.3% annually.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P40_S7	The rate increases for natural gas customers became effective May 14, 2012.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P40_S8	In its order, the Washington Commission approved a weighted cost of capital of 7.8% and a capital structure that included 48.0% common equity with a return on equity of 9.8%.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P41_S0	On March 14, 2011, the Washington Commission issued its order authorizing PSE to increase its natural gas general tariff rates by $19.0 million or 1.8% on an annual basis effective April 1, 2011.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P41_S1	On April 2, 2010, the Washington Commission issued its order, effective April 8, 2010, in PSE's natural gas general rate case filed in May 2009, approving a general rate increase of 0.8% annually or $10.1 million.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P41_S2	In its order, the Washington Commission approved a weighted cost of capital of 8.1% and a capital structure that included 46.0% common equity with an after-tax return on equity of 10.1%.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P41_S3	For additional information, see Note 3 to the consolidated financial statements included in Item 8 of this report.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P42_S0	Weather conditions in PSE's service territory have a significant impact on customer energy usage, affecting PSE's revenue and energy supply expenses.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P42_S1	PSE's operating revenue and associated energy supply expenses are not generated evenly throughout the year.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P42_S2	While both PSE's electric and natural gas sales are generally greatest during winter months, variations in energy usage by customers occur from season to season and month to month within a season, primarily as a result of weather conditions.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P42_S3	PSE normally experiences its highest retail energy sales, and subsequently higher power costs, during the winter heating season in the first and fourth quarters of the year and its lowest sales in the third quarter of the year.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P42_S4	Varying wholesale electric prices and the amount of hydroelectric energy supplies available to PSE also make quarter-to-quarter comparisons difficult.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P43_S0	PSE reported lower customer usage in the twelve months ended December 31, 2012 primarily due to Pacific Northwest temperatures being warmer as compared to the same period in the prior year.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P43_S1	The actual average temperature during the twelve months ended December 31, 2012 was 52.0 degrees, or 1.3 degrees warmer than the same period in the prior year.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P43_S2	Although the average temperature during the twelve months ended December 31, 2012 was warmer than the same period in the prior year, the average temperature was 0.7 degrees cooler when compared to the historical average.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P44_S0	PSE expects the number of natural gas customers to grow at rates slightly above electric customers.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P44_S1	PSE also expects energy usage by both residential electric and natural gas customers to continue a long-term trend of slow decline primarily due to continued energy efficiency improvements.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P45_S0	PSE relies on access to bank borrowings and short-term money markets as sources of liquidity and longer-term capital markets to fund its utility construction program, to meet maturing debt obligations and other capital expenditure requirements not satisfied by cash flow from its operations or equity investment from its parent, Puget Energy.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P45_S1	Neither Puget Energy nor PSE have any debt outstanding whose maturity would accelerate upon a credit rating downgrade.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P45_S2	However, a ratings downgrade could adversely affect the Company's ability to renew existing, or obtain access to new credit facilities and could increase the cost of such facilities.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P45_S3	For example, under Puget Energy's and PSE's credit facilities, the borrowing costs increase as their respective credit ratings decline due to increases in credit spreads and commitment fees.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P45_S4	If PSE is unable to access debt capital on reasonable terms, its ability to pursue improvements or acquisitions, including generating capacity, which may be relied on for future growth and to otherwise implement its strategy, could be adversely affected.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P46_S0	PSE monitors the credit environment and expects to continue to be able to access the capital markets to meet its short-term and long-term borrowing needs.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P46_S1	PSE's credit facilities expire in 2018 and Puget Energy's senior secured credit facility expires in 2017.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P46_S2	(See discussion on credit facilities in the section entitled Financing Program - Credit Facilities and Commercial Paper ).
1085392_13_ITEM7_P47_S0	PSE s operations are subject to extensive federal, state and local laws and regulations.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P47_S1	Such regulations cover electric system reliability, gas pipeline system safety and energy market transparency, among other areas.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P47_S2	Environmental laws and regulations related to air and water quality (including climate change) and endangered species protection, waste handling and disposal (including generation byproducts such as coal ash), remediation of contamination and siting new facilities also impact the Company s operations.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P47_S3	PSE must spend significant amounts fulfilling requirements by regulatory agencies, many of which have greatly expanded mandates, and on measures including, but not limited to, resource planning, remediation, monitoring, pollution control equipment and emissions-related abatement and fees in order to comply with these regulatory requirements.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P48_S0	Compliance with these or other future regulations, such as those pertaining to climate change and generation byproducts could require significant capital expenditures by PSE and may adversely affect PSE s financial position, results of operations, cash flows and liquidity.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P49_S0	Other Challenges and Strategies Energy Supply.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P49_S1	As noted in PSE s IRP filed with the Washington Commission, PSE projects future energy needs will begin to exceed current resources by 2015 from long-term power purchase agreements and Company-controlled power resources.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P50_S0	The IRP identifies reductions in contractual supplies of energy and capacity available under certain long-term power purchase agreements, requiring replacement of supplies to meet projected demands.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P50_S1	Therefore, PSE s IRP sets forth a multi-part strategy of implementing energy efficiency programs and pursuing additional renewable resources (primarily wind) and additional base load natural gas-fired generation to meet the growing needs of its customers.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P51_S0	If PSE cannot acquire needed energy supply resources at a reasonable cost, it may be required to purchase additional power in the open market at a cost that could, in the absence of regulatory relief, significantly increase its expenses and reduce earnings and cash flows.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P52_S0	PSE is investing in its utility infrastructure and customer service functions in order to meet regulatory requirements, serve customers energy needs and replace aging infrastructure.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P52_S1	These investments and operating requirements give rise to significant growth in depreciation, amortization and operating expenses, which are not recovered through the ratemaking process in a timely manner.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P52_S2	This regulatory lag is expected to continue for the foreseeable future.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P53_S0	Operational Risks Associated With Generating Facilities.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P54_S0	PSE owns and operates coal, natural gas-fired, hydroelectric, wind-powered, solar and oil-fired generating facilities.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P55_S0	Operation of electric generating facilities involves risks that can adversely affect energy output and efficiency levels, including facility shutdowns due to equipment and process failures or fuel supply interruptions.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P55_S1	PSE does not have business interruption insurance coverage to cover replacement power costs.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P56_S0	Energy Efficiency Related Lost Sales Margin.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P57_S0	PSE s sales, margins, earnings and cash flow are adversely affected by its energy efficiency programs, many of which are mandated by law.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P57_S1	The Company is evaluating strategies and other means to reduce or eliminate these adverse financial effects.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P57_S2	The Company is actively engaged in monitoring the development of the commercial markets for such intangible power attributes as RECs and carbon financial instruments.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P57_S3	The Company supports the development of regional and national markets for these products that are open, transparent and liquid.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P58_S0	The following discussion should be read in conjunction with the audited consolidated financial statements and the related notes included elsewhere in this document.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P58_S1	The following discussion provides the significant items that impacted PSE s results of operations for the years ended December 31, 2012 and 2011.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P59_S0	The following discussion includes financial information prepared in accordance with GAAP, as well as two other financial measures, electric margin and gas margin, that are considered non-GAAP financial measures.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P60_S0	Generally, a non-GAAP financial measure is a numerical measure of a company s financial performance, financial position or cash flows that exclude (or include) amounts that are included in (or excluded from) the most directly comparable measure calculated and presented in accordance with GAAP.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P61_S0	The presentation of electric margin and gas margin is intended to supplement an understanding of PSE s operating performance.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P62_S0	Electric margin and gas margin are used by PSE to determine whether PSE is collecting the appropriate amount of energy costs from its customers to allow recovery of operating costs.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P62_S1	PSE s electric margin and gas margin measures may not be comparable to other companies electric margin and gas margin measures.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P62_S2	Furthermore, these measures are not intended to replace operating income as determined in accordance with GAAP as an indicator of operating performance.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P63_S0	The following table displays the details of PSE s electric margin changes from periods 2011 to 2012 and periods 2010 to 2011.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P64_S0	Electric margin represents electric sales to retail and transportation customers less the cost of generating and purchasing electric energy sold to customers, including transmission costs to bring electric energy to PSE s service territory.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P65_S0	______________ As reported on PSE s Consolidated Statement of Income.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P66_S0	Electric margin does not include any allocation for amortization/depreciation expense or electric generation operation and maintenance expense.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P66_S1	Percent change not applicable or meaningful.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P67_S0	Electric margin increased $127.6 million and $106.5 million for the years ended December 31, 2012 and December 31, 2011 , respectively.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P67_S1	Following is a discussion of significant items that impact electric operating revenue and electric energy costs which are included in electric margin:
1085392_13_ITEM7_P68_S0	2012 compared to 2011 Electric Operating Revenue Electric operating revenues decreased $19.0 million , or 0.9% , to $2,128.2 million from $2,147.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2012 as compared to the same period in 2011 .
1085392_13_ITEM7_P68_S1	Operating revenue decreased $19.0 million primarily due to lower electric retail sales of $23.5 million and lower sales to other utilities and marketers of $22.0 million offset by higher miscellaneous other operating revenue of $27.0 million .
1085392_13_ITEM7_P68_S2	These items are discussed in detail below.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P69_S0	Electric retail sales decreased $23.5 million , or 1.1% , to $2,100.4 million from $2,123.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2012 as compared to the same period in 2011 .
1085392_13_ITEM7_P69_S1	Electric retail sales decreased due to a $35.3 million decrease in retail electricity usage of 357,640 MWhs, or 1.7%, primarily due to warmer temperatures in PSE s service territory during the year ended December 31, 2012 as compared to the same period in the prior year.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P69_S2	The actual average temperature during the year ended December 31, 2012 was 52.0 degrees, or 1.3 degrees warmer than the same period in 2011.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P69_S3	Although the average temperature during the year ended December 31, 2012 was warmer than the same period in the prior year, the average temperature was 0.7 degrees cooler when compared to the historical average.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P69_S4	Partially offsetting the decrease was a $11.8 million net increase in retail sales due to the electric rate increase effective May 14, 2012 and various pass-through tariff items that have no impact to earnings.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P69_S5	The net increase included tariff items, such as the suspension of REC credits in 2011 which contributed an increase of $14.8 million in electric retail sales for the year ended December 31, 2012 .
1085392_13_ITEM7_P69_S6	The REC credit to customers is offset in other electric operating revenue with no impact to earnings.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P69_S7	PSE's customers received credits effective November 1, 2010 through April 30, 2011.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P69_S8	Sales to other utilities and marketers decreased $22.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2012 as compared to the same period in 2011 .
1085392_13_ITEM7_P69_S9	The decrease was primarily due to a reduction in sales volume of 421,394 MWhs, or 23.3% which decreased revenue $10.6 million and a decline in wholesale electricity prices which decreased revenue by $11.4 million.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P69_S10	Other electric operating revenue increased $27.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2012 as compared to the same period in 2011 .
1085392_13_ITEM7_P69_S11	For the year ended December 31, 2012 , other electric operating revenues increased primarily due to lower losses on non-core gas sales of $37.1 million and a reduction to revenue offsets which contributed increases of $80.3 million in revenue related to PTCs, which are deferred until PSE utilizes the tax credit on its tax return.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P69_S12	Partially offsetting the increase is a decrease in REC revenue of $93.5 million.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P70_S0	As discussed above, REC revenue is an offset of the REC credit provided to PSE s customers in electric retail sales with no impact to earnings.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P71_S0	Electric Energy Costs Purchased electricity expense decreased $149.7 million , or 19.4% , for the year ended December 31, 2012 as compared to the same period in 2011 .
1085392_13_ITEM7_P71_S1	The decrease in purchased electricity expense for the year ended December 31, 2012 was primarily the result of a decrease of $182.6 million related to the expiration of long-term firm purchase contracts that was replaced with market price power and wind generation.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P71_S2	In addition, a decrease of $6.2 million was due to a decrease in the overrecovery of power costs, which is shared with customers in accordance with the PCA mechanism, for the year ended December 31, 2012 as compared to the year ended December 31, 2011.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P71_S3	Partially offsetting this decrease was a $25.1 million increase related to energy purchase agreements and $8.4 million in additional costs recognized in order to offset the deferral of variable costs related to the Lower Snake River project prior to the inclusion of the plant in rates.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P72_S0	To meet customer demand, PSE economically dispatches resources in its power supply portfolio such as fossil-fuel generation, owned and contracted hydroelectric capacity and energy and long-term contracted power.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P72_S1	However, depending principally upon availability of hydroelectric energy, plant availability, fuel prices and/or changing load as a result of weather, PSE may sell surplus power or purchase deficit power in the wholesale market.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P72_S2	PSE manages its regulated power portfolio through short-term and intermediate-term off-system physical purchases and sales as well as through other risk management techniques.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P73_S0	Electric generation fuel expense increased $5.5 million , or 2.7% , for the year ended December 31, 2012 as compared to the same period in 2011 .
1085392_13_ITEM7_P73_S1	The increase was primarily due to increased generation from PSE's combustion turbine facilities due to the decrease in hydroelectric and wind generation of 904,423 MWhs, or 11.9%, and the decrease in electric generation at the Colstrip facility of 401,059 MWhs, or 9.5% as compared to the same period in 2011.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P73_S2	As a result of lower wholesale gas prices it was more economical to generate gas fired electricity from PSE's combustion turbine facilities resulting in an increase in natural gas costs of $8.2 million as compared to the same period in 2011.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P73_S3	Offsetting the increase was $2.7 million decrease due to the reduction in Colstrip facility's generation.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P73_S4	The decrease in electric generation at the Colstrip facility was primarily due to two coal plants that were taken offline for maintenance and reintroduced at a later point in time into production as other sources of electric generation were considered more economical.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P73_S5	Residential exchange credits decreased $2.4 million , or 3.4% , for the year ended December 31, 2012 as compared to the same period in 2011 as a result of lower electric residential and farm customer sales volumes associated with the BPA REP.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P74_S0	The REP credit is a pass-through tariff item with a corresponding credit in electric operating revenue, with no impact on net income.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P75_S0	2011 compared to 2010 Electric Operating Revenue Electric operating revenue increased $39.8 million, or 1.9%, to $2,147.2 million from $2,107.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2011 as compared to the same period in 2010.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P75_S1	The increase in operating revenue of $39.8 million was primarily due to higher electric retail sales of $92.3 million offset by lower sales to other utilities and marketers of $17.2 million and by lower miscellaneous operating revenue of $34.6 million.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P75_S2	These items are discussed in detail below.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P76_S0	Electric retail sales increased $92.3 million, or 4.5%, to $2,123.9 million from $2,031.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2011 as compared to the same period in 2010.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P76_S1	The increase in electric retail sales was due to a $57.7 million increase in retail electricity usage of 595,487 MWhs, or 2.8%, primarily due to cooler temperatures in PSE s service territory during the year ended December 31, 2011 as compared to the same period in the prior year.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P76_S2	The average temperature during the year ended December 31, 2011 was 50.7 degrees, or 1.54 degrees colder than the same period in the prior year, which resulted in a 13.1% increase in heating degree days.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P76_S3	Additionally, the electric rate increase effective April 8, 2010 contributed $25.9 million to the increase in electric retail sales.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P76_S4	Also contributing to the increase in retail sales were pass-through items with no impact to earnings including a $11.5 million increase in conservation rider program rates, a $7.7 million decrease related to the suspension of the PTC tariff credit effective July 1, 2010, a $4.1 million decrease in the residential exchange rate credit and various other pass-through items.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P76_S5	PTCs that are generated and provided to customers are recorded as a reduction in other electric operating revenue until PSE utilizes the tax credit on its tax return, at which time the PTCs will be credited to customers in retail sales.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P76_S6	Additionally, PSE s customers were credited $10.5 million for REC revenue, effective November 1, 2010, resulting in a decrease in electric retail sales.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P76_S7	The $10.5 million credit to customers is offset in other electric operating revenue with no impact to earnings.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P76_S8	PSE s customers continued to receive credits through April 30, 2011.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P76_S9	Sales to other utilities and marketers decreased $17.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2011 as compared to the same period in 2010.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P76_S10	The decrease was primarily due to a reduction in sales volumes of 687,124 MWhs, or 27.5% which decreased revenue $22.2 million and a decline in wholesale electricity prices which decreased revenue by $12.8 million.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P76_S11	Additionally, in the prior year there was a carrying value adjustment of $17.8 million related to PSE s California wholesale energy sales regulatory asset that did not occur in 2011.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P76_S12	Other electric operating revenue decreased $34.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2011 as compared to the same period in 2010.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P76_S13	For the year ended December 31, 2011, the decrease was primarily due to a decrease in non-core gas sales of $21.7 million and a decrease of $85.5 related to PTCs, partially offset by an increase in REC revenue of $67.0 million, PTCs are deferred until PSE utilizes the tax credit on its tax return.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P77_S0	As discussed above, REC revenue is an offset of the REC credit provided to PSE s customers in electric retail sales with no impact to earnings.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P78_S0	Electric Energy Costs Purchased electricity expense decreased $2.0 million, or 0.3%, for the year ended December 31, 2011 as compared to the same period in 2010.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P78_S1	The decrease in purchased electricity expense for the year ended December 31, 2011 was primarily the result of lower wholesale market prices, which contributed $180.6 million to the decrease.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P78_S2	This decrease was offset by an increase in purchased power of 3,217,631 MWhs, or 23.2%, resulting in an increase of $160.3 million, which was driven by cooler temperatures during the year ended December 31, 2011 as compared to the same period in the prior year.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P78_S3	In addition the decrease was offset by an overrecovery of power costs from customers of $9.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2011, which reduced the customer PCA deferral as compared to an underrecovery of power costs of $7.2 million in the same period in 2010.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P78_S4	The overrecovery of power costs was due to above-average hydroelectric and wind generation resulting in decreased power costs associated with purchased electricity and fuel costs of PSE s combustion turbines.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P79_S0	To meet customer demand, PSE economically dispatches resources in its power supply portfolio such as fossil-fuel generation, owned and contracted hydroelectric capacity and energy and long-term contracted power.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P79_S1	However, depending principally upon availability of hydroelectric energy, plant availability, fuel prices and/or changing load as a result of weather, PSE may sell surplus power or purchase deficit power in the wholesale market.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P79_S2	PSE manages its regulated power portfolio through short-term and intermediate-term off-system physical purchases and sales as well as through other risk management techniques.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P80_S0	Electric generation fuel expense decreased $68.7 million, or 25.6%, for the year ended December 31, 2011 as compared to the same period in 2010.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P80_S1	The decrease was primarily due to lower volumes of electricity generation from PSE s combustion turbine facilities as a result of increases in hydroelectric and wind generation of 1,219,910 MWhs, or 19.2%.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P80_S2	Also, coal generation at Colstrip decreased 987,522 MWhs, or 19.0% for the year ended December 31, 2011 as compared to the same period in 2010.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P80_S3	Generation fuel costs were also lower, due to low wholesale market prices, as it was more economical to purchase wholesale energy than to generate energy from PSE s combustion turbine facilities.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P81_S0	Residential exchange credits decreased $4.0 million, or 5.3%, for the year ended December 31, 2011 as compared to the same period in 2010 as a result of lower electric residential and farm customer sales volumes associated with the BPAREP.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P82_S0	The REP credit is a pass-through tariff item with a corresponding credit in electric operating revenue, with no impact on net income.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P83_S0	The following table displays the details of PSE s natural gas margin changes from 2011 to 2012 and 2010 to 2011.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P84_S0	Gas margin is natural gas sales to retail and transportation customers less the cost of natural gas purchased, including transportation costs to bring natural gas to PSE s service territory.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P85_S0	___________________ As reported on PSE s Consolidated Statement of Income.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P85_S1	Gas margin does not include any allocation for amortization/depreciation expense or electric generation operations and maintenance expense.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P86_S0	Natural gas margin increased $0.7 million and $71.2 million for the years ended December 31, 2012 and December 31, 2011 , respectively.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P86_S1	Following is a discussion of significant items that impact gas operating revenue and gas energy costs which are included in natural gas margin:
1085392_13_ITEM7_P87_S0	2012 compared to 2011 Gas Operating Revenue Gas operating revenue decreased $82.8 million , or 7.1% , to $1,086.1 million from $1,168.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2012 as compared to the same period in 2011 .
1085392_13_ITEM7_P87_S1	The decrease in gas operating revenue of $82.8 million was due primarily to lower natural gas retail sales revenue of $82.4 million due to lower natural gas costs.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P87_S2	These items are discussed in detail below.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P88_S0	Natural gas retail sales revenue decreased $82.4 million , or 7.2% , to $1,057.2 million from $1,139.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2012 as compared to the same period in 2011 .
1085392_13_ITEM7_P88_S1	The decrease in natural gas retail sales for the year ended December 31, 2012 as compared to the same period in 2011 was primarily due to a decrease of 50.8 million in therm sales, or 5.3%, due to warmer temperatures that resulted in a $60.6 million revenue decrease.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P88_S2	The actual average temperature during the year ended December 31, 2012 was 52.0 degrees, or 1.3 degrees warmer than the same period in the prior year.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P88_S3	Although the average temperature during the year ended December 31, 2012 was warmer than the same period in the prior year, the temperature was 0.7 degrees cooler when compared to the historical average.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P88_S4	Contributing to the decrease was a net $28.5 million decrease related to the PGA rate decreases effective November 1, 2011 and November 1, 2012.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P88_S5	The PGA rate decreases were offset by the gas rate increases effective April 1, 2011 and May 14, 2012.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P88_S6	Partially offsetting these decreases was a $6.9 million increase in retail sales related to gas conservation revenues with no impact to earnings.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P89_S0	The PGA mechanism passes through to customers increases or decreases in the natural gas supply portion of the natural gas service rates based upon changes in the price of natural gas purchased from producers and wholesale marketers or changes in natural gas pipeline transportation costs.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P89_S1	PSE's net income is not affected by changes under the PGA mechanism.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P90_S0	Gas Energy Costs Purchased gas expense decreased $83.5 million , or 13.4% , for the year ended December 31, 2012 as compared to the same period in 2011 .
1085392_13_ITEM7_P90_S1	The decrease was primarily due to lower natural gas costs reflected in PGA rates which was effective November 1, 2011 and November 1, 2012.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P90_S2	Also contributing to the expense decrease was a reduction in customer usage of 5.3% as a result of warmer temperatures for the year ended December 31, 2012 , as compared to the same period in 2011.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P91_S0	The PGA mechanism provides the rates used to determine natural gas costs based on customer usage.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P91_S1	The rate decrease was the result of decreasing costs of wholesale natural gas.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P91_S2	The PGA mechanism allows PSE to recover expected natural gas supply and transportation costs and defer, as a receivable or liability, any natural gas supply and transportation costs that exceed or fall short of this expected natural gas cost amount in PGA mechanism rates, including accrued interest.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P92_S0	PSE is authorized by the Washington Commission to accrue carrying costs on PGA receivable and payable balances.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P92_S1	A receivable balance in the PGA mechanism reflects an underrecovery of natural gas cost through rates.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P92_S2	A payable balance reflects overrecovery of natural gas cost through rates.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P92_S3	The PGA mechanism payable balance at December 31, 2012 was $32.6 million , which will be recovered from customers through a future PGA rate filing.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P93_S0	2011 compared to 2010 Gas Operating Revenue Gas operating revenue increased $157.3 million, or 15.6%, to $1,168.9 million from $1,011.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2011 as compared to the same period in 2010.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P93_S1	The increase in gas operating revenue of $157.3 million was due primarily to higher natural gas retail sales of $156.9 million.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P93_S2	Natural gas retail sales increased $156.9 million, or 16.0%, to $1,139.6 million from $982.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2011 as compared to the same period in 2010.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P93_S3	The increase consists of $132.6 million due to an increase in gas therms of 131.3 million, or 12.5% as a result of cooler temperatures.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P93_S4	Also contributing is an increase of $42.5 million due to a 1.8% increase in natural gas general rate effective April 8, 2010 and a 0.8% PGA rate increase effective November 1, 2010.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P93_S5	The increase was offset $10.9 million due to a 4.3% PGA rate decrease effective November 1, 2011.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P94_S0	The PGA mechanism passes through to customers increases or decreases in the natural gas supply portion of the natural gas service rates based upon changes in the price of natural gas purchased from producers and wholesale marketers or changes in natural gas pipeline transportation costs.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P94_S1	PSE s net income is not affected by changes under the PGA mechanism.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P95_S0	Gas Energy Costs Purchased gas expense increased $86.2 million, or 16.1%, for the year ended December 31, 2011 as compared to the same period in 2010.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P95_S1	The increase was primarily due to higher natural gas costs reflected in PGA rates effective November 1, 2010.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P95_S2	In addition, an increase in customer usage of 12.5% for the year ended December 31, 2011 as compared to the same period in 2010 contributed to the increase of costs.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P96_S0	The PGA mechanism provides the rates used to determine natural gas costs based on customer usage.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P96_S1	The rate increase was the result of increasing costs of wholesale natural gas.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P96_S2	The PGA mechanism allows PSE to recover expected natural gas supply and transportation costs and defer, as a receivable or liability, any natural gas supply and transportation costs that exceed or fall short of this expected natural gas cost amount in PGA mechanism rates, including accrued interest.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P96_S3	The PGA mechanism payable balance at December 31, 2011 was $25.9 million as compared to a receivable balance of $6.0 million at December 31, 2010.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P96_S4	PSE is authorized by the Washington Commission to accrue carrying costs on PGA receivable and payable balances.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P96_S5	A receivable balance in the PGA mechanism reflects an underrecovery of market natural gas cost through rates.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P96_S6	A payable balance reflects overrecovery of market natural gas cost through rates.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P97_S0	2012 compared to 2011 Other Operating Expenses Net unrealized gain on derivative instruments increased by $173.3 million to a net gain of $119.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2012 as compared to a loss of $54.1 million during the same period in 2011 .
1085392_13_ITEM7_P97_S1	The net gain is primarily due to the settlement of contracts with unrealized losses from previous periods which resulted in gains.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P97_S2	These gains are offset by losses due to declining natural gas and wholesale electricity prices.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P97_S3	Forward prices of electricity and natural gas decreased by 9.0% and 6.3%, respectively, for the year ended December 31, 2012 .
1085392_13_ITEM7_P97_S4	Utility operations and maintenance expense increased $14.8 million , or 3.0% , for the year ended December 31, 2012 as compared to the same period in 2011 .
1085392_13_ITEM7_P97_S5	The increase was primarily driven by increases in customer service expenses of $3.2 million, $2.6 million in administration and general expenses and $7.4 million in electric transmission and distribution expenses for year ended December 31, 2012 .
1085392_13_ITEM7_P97_S6	The increase in electric transmission and distribution expense was due primarily to the January storm.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P97_S7	Additionally, PSE deferred approximately $60.4 million in transmission and distribution expenses related to the January 2012 winter storm as a regulatory asset for future recovery.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P97_S8	Depreciation expense increased $38.4 million , or 12.8% , for the year ended December 31, 2012 as compared to the same period in 2011 .
1085392_13_ITEM7_P97_S9	The increase was primarily due to additional capital expenditures placed into service, net of retirements, such as the Lower Snake River wind generation facility.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P97_S10	Amortization expense decreased $16.6 million , or 22.9% , for the year ended December 31, 2012 as compared to the same period in 2011 .
1085392_13_ITEM7_P98_S0	million decrease in common plant amortization.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P98_S1	Additionally, a $9.4 million decrease for the year ended December 31, 2012 was due to the Lower Snake River wind generation facility.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P98_S2	Conservation amortization increased $6.5 million , or 6.1% , for the year ended December 31, 2012 as compared to the same period in 2011 .
1085392_13_ITEM7_P98_S3	The increase was due to an approved accounting petition authorizing PSE to recover costs associated with the Company's current 2012 gas conservation programs via transfers from amounts deferred for the over-recovery commodity costs in the Company's PGA commodity account.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P99_S0	Conservation amortization is a pass-through tariff item with no impact on earnings.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P100_S0	Taxes other than income taxes decreased $4.1 million , or 1.3% , for the year ended December 31, 2012 as compared to the same period in 2011.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P100_S1	The decrease was primarily due to a decrease in revenue sensitive taxes due to a decrease in retail sales and partially offset by an increase in property taxes.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P101_S0	Other Income, Interest Expense and Income Tax Expense Other income decreased $9.0 million , or 15.5% , for the year ended December 31, 2012 as compared to the same period in 2011 .
1085392_13_ITEM7_P101_S1	The decrease for the year ended December 31, 2012 , was primarily due to decreases of $10.2 million in AFUDC equity income, $15.9 million in regulatory interest, and $3.0 million of miscellaneous items.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P101_S2	Partially offsetting the decrease for the year ended December 31, 2012 is an increase due to the carrying costs associated with the Lower Snake River wind generating facility accruing interest income of $20.3 million, as authorized by the Washington Commission.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P101_S3	Other Expense increased $6.4 million , or 118.8% , for the year ended December 31, 2012 as compared to the same period in 2011 .
1085392_13_ITEM7_P101_S4	The increase was primarily due to a $2.4 million increase related to customer credits resulting from the outages due to the January 2012 winter storm and $2.5 million related to civic affiliated activities.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P101_S5	Interest expense increased $23.3 million , or 11.6% , for the year ended December 31, 2012 as compared to the same period in 2011 .
1085392_13_ITEM7_P101_S6	The increase was primarily due to an increase in long term debt which contributed $11.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2012 .
1085392_13_ITEM7_P101_S7	Also contributing to the increase is a $7.7 million decrease in debt component of AFUDC and a $3.8 million increase in other interest for the year ended December 31, 2012 .
1085392_13_ITEM7_P101_S8	Income tax expense increased $71.2 million , or 91.1% , for the year ended December 31, 2012 as compared to the same period in 2011 .
1085392_13_ITEM7_P101_S9	The increase was primarily related to higher pre-tax income.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P102_S0	2011 compared to 2010 Other Operating Expenses Net unrealized (gain) loss on derivative instruments decreased by $112.8 million to a loss of $54.1 million in 2011 as compared to a loss of $166.9 million during the same period in 2010.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P103_S0	In 2011, the derivative portfolio experienced a significant number of 2010 contracts settling.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P103_S1	As those contracts settled, the previous losses recorded in 2010 were reversed resulting in reduced losses between years.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P104_S0	On July 1, 2009, PSE elected to de-designate its energy related derivative contracts previously designated as cash flow hedges.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P104_S1	The de-designated contracts were physical electric supply contracts and natural gas swap contracts used to fix the price of natural gas for electric generation.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P104_S2	For these contracts and for contracts initiated after such date, all mark-to-market accounting impacts are recognized through earnings.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P104_S3	The amount previously recorded in accumulated OCI is transferred to earnings when the contracts settle or sooner, if management determines that the forecasted transaction is probable of not occurring.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P104_S4	As a result, PSE will continue to experience the earnings impact of these reversals from OCI in future periods.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P105_S0	Over the tenor of PSE s outstanding derivative contracts, the forward wholesale prices of electricity and natural gas declined 25.7% and 23.0%, respectively, from December 31, 2010 to December 31, 2011.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P105_S1	Utility operations and maintenance expense increased $11.2 million, or 2.3%, for the year ended December 31, 2011 as compared to the same period in 2010.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P105_S2	The increase was driven by increases of $11.9 million increase in electric production, $6.2 in administration and general expenses and $1.5 million in gas operations costs.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P105_S3	Partially offsetting the increase is a $7.3 million decrease in electric transmission and distribution and a $1.7 million decrease in customer service expenses.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P105_S4	Depreciation expense increased $7.0 million, or 2.4%, for the year ended December 31, 2011 as compared to the same period in 2010.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P105_S5	The increase was primarily due to additional electrical and common utility capital expenditures placed into service, net of retirements.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P105_S6	Conservation amortization increased $17.5 million, or 19.5%, for the year ended December 31, 2011 as compared to the same period in 2010.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P105_S7	The increase was due to a higher authorized recovery of electric and natural gas conservation expenditures.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P106_S0	Conservation amortization is a pass-through tariff item with no impact on earnings.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P107_S0	Taxes other than income taxes increased $31.0 million, or 10.6%, for the year ended December 31, 2011 as compared to the same period in 2010.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P107_S1	The increase was primarily due to an increase in revenue sensitive taxes due to an increase in retail sales.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P108_S0	Other Income, Interest Expense and Income Tax Expense Other income increased $12.9 million, or 28.5%, for the year ended December 31, 2011 as compared to the same period in 2010.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P108_S1	The increase is primarily due to income related to the equity component of AFUDC.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P108_S2	AFUDC increased $21.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2011, reflecting an increase in the average construction work in progress balance in 2011 due primarily to construction of wind and hydroelectric generation construction projects.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P108_S3	This increase was partially offset by decreases in regulatory interest of $5.4 million, PTC of $1.2 million and conservative incentive of $1.2 million.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P108_S4	Interest expense decreased $19.4 million, or 8.8%, for the year ended December 31, 2011 as compared to the same period in 2010.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P108_S5	Contributing to the decrease was a increase of $15.8 million in the debt component of Allowance For Funds Used During Construction (AFUDC) for the year ended December 31, 2011 which was included as construction expenditures and which was due to an increase in the average construction work in progress balance in 2011.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P108_S6	Also contributing to the decrease is $3.2 million due to lower interest expense on the REC liability owed to customers.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P108_S7	Income tax expense increased $78.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2011 as compared to the same period in 2010.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P108_S8	The increase was primarily related to higher pre-tax income.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P109_S0	Puget Energy All the operations of Puget Energy are conducted through its subsidiary PSE.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P110_S0	Puget Energy s net income for the years ended December 31, 2012, 2011 and 2010 was as follows:
1085392_13_ITEM7_P111_S0	_____________ * Not meaningful Puget Energy s interest expense includes elimination adjustments of intercompany interest on short-term debt.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P112_S0	2012 compared to 2011 Summary Results of Operations Puget Energy s net income for 2012 was $273.8 million with operating revenue of $3,215.2 million as compared to net income of $123.3 million with operating revenue of $3,318.8 million for 2011 .
1085392_13_ITEM7_P112_S1	The following are significant factors that impacted Puget Energy s net income which are not included in PSE s discussion: Net unrealized gain on derivative instruments decreased $28.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2012 , as compared to the same period in 2011, due to the effects of purchase accounting on derivative contracts in other comprehensive income of $18.7 million and the fair value amortization of Normal Purchase Normal Sale (NPNS) derivative contracts of $9.5 million.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P112_S2	Non-utility expense and other costs increased $7.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2012 , as compared to the same period in 2011 , due primarily to pension expense.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P112_S3	Unhedged interest rate derivative expense decreased $24.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2012 , as compared to the same period in 2011 .
1085392_13_ITEM7_P112_S4	The decrease was primarily due to a gain of $10.4 million related to the mark-to-market on the outstanding interest rate swaps.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P112_S5	Additionally, in February and May, 2012 the outstanding interest rate swap balances were reduced by $277.4 million and $550 million, respectively; resulting in a decrease of $13.9 million in interest expense.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P113_S0	Interest expense increased $4.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2012 , as compared to the same period in 2011 .
1085392_13_ITEM7_P113_S1	The increase was primarily due to a $6.4 million increase in write-off related to the unamortized issuance costs associated with the five-year term loan and capital expenditure credit facility.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P113_S2	Also contributing to the increase was $16.5 million of interest expense related to additional debt balances.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P113_S3	Partially offsetting the increase is a $18.3 million decrease related to mark-to-market on interest rate swap contracts.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P114_S0	2011 compared to 2010 Summary Results of Operations Puget Energy s net income for 2011 was $123.3 million with operating revenue of $3,318.8 million as compared to net income of $30.3 million with operating revenue of $3,122.2 million for 2010.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P114_S1	The following are significant factors that impacted Puget Energy s net income which are not included in PSE s discussion: Net unrealized gain on derivative instruments decreased $70.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2011, as compared to the same period in 2010, due to the effects of purchase accounting and the fair value amortization of derivative contracts.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P114_S2	The forward prices of electricity and natural gas declined 25.7% and 23%, respectively for the year ended December 31, 2011.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P114_S3	Non-utility expense and other costs decreased $14.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2011, as compared to the same period in 2010, due primarily to the write down of SO2 emissions allowance inventory of $9.0 million in 2010 that did not occur in 2011.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P114_S4	Also contributing to this decrease is a $4.9 million change related to qualified pension plan which resulted in a gain in 2011.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P115_S0	Unhedged interest rate derivative expense increased $20.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2011, as compared to the same period in 2010, as a result of paying down a portion of a five-year term-loan due February 2014 in December 2010 and during 2011.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P115_S1	The five-year variable rate term-loan was initially fully hedged; however a portion of the hedge was unwound during the current year ended December 31, 2011.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P115_S2	Interest expense increased $54.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2011, as compared to the same period in 2010 due to increased out standing debt.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P116_S0	In December 2010 and during 2011, Puget Energy issued fixed rate notes with higher interest rates to refinance and extend the debt maturity of a portion of a five-year term-loan due February 2014.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P117_S0	Income tax expense decreased $46.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2011, as compared to the same period in 2010, due primarily to higher pre-tax loss.

1085392_13_ITEM7_P140_S0	Financing Program The Company s external financing requirements principally reflect the cash needs of its construction program, its schedule of maturing debt and certain operational needs.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P140_S1	The Company anticipates refinancing the redemption of bonds or other long-term borrowings with its credit facilities and/or the issuance of new long-term debt.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P140_S2	Access to funds depends upon factors such as Puget Energy s and PSE s credit ratings, prevailing interest rates and investor receptivity to investing in the utility industry, Puget Energy and PSE.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P141_S0	Credit Facilities and Commercial Paper Proceeds from PSE s short-term borrowings and sales of commercial paper are used to provide working capital and the interim funding of utility construction programs.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P141_S1	Puget Energy and PSE continue to have reasonable access to the capital and credit markets.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P141_S2	As of December 31, 2012 and 2011 , PSE had $181.0 million and $25.0 million in short-term debt outstanding, respectively, exclusive of the demand promissory note with Puget Energy.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P141_S3	Outside of the consolidation of PSE s short-term debt, Puget Energy had no short-term debt outstanding in either year as borrowings under its credit facilities are classified as long-term.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P141_S4	PSE s weighted-average interest rate on short-term debt, including borrowing rate, commitment fees and the amortization of debt issuance costs, during 2012 and 2011 was 6.49% , and 4.39% , respectively.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P141_S5	As of December 31, 2012 , PSE and Puget Energy had several committed credit facilities that are described below.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P142_S0	At December 31, 2012 , PSE maintained three committed unsecured revolving credit facilities that provided, in the aggregate, $1.15 billion in short-term borrowing capability and which were due to mature concurrently in February 2014.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P142_S1	These facilities included a $400.0 million credit agreement for working capital needs, a $400.0 million credit facility for funding capital expenditures and a $350.0 million facility to support energy hedging activities.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P142_S2	The credit agreements allowed PSE to borrow at the bank's prime rate or to make floating rate advances at the LIBOR plus a spread that was based upon PSE's credit rating.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P142_S3	The working capital facility, as amended, included a swing line feature allowing same day availability on borrowings up to $50.0 million.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P142_S4	The $400.0 million working capital facility and $350.0 million credit agreement to support energy hedging allowed for issuing standby letters of credit.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P142_S5	PSE paid a commitment fee on the unused portion of the credit facilities.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P143_S0	As of December 31, 2012 , the spread to the LIBOR was 0.85% and the commitment fee was 0.26%.
1085392_13_ITEM7_P143_S1	The $400.0 million working capital facility also serves as a backstop for PSE's commercial paper program.
