1085392_13_ITEM8_P178_S0	PSE employs various energy portfolio optimization strategies, but is not in the business of assuming risk for the purpose of realizing speculative trading revenue.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P178_S1	The nature of serving regulated electric customers with its portfolio of owned and contracted electric generation resources exposes PSE and its customers to some volumetric and commodity price risks within the sharing mechanism of the PCA.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P178_S2	Therefore, wholesale market transactions and related hedging strategies are focused on balancing PSE's energy portfolio, reducing costs and risks where feasible thus reducing volatility in costs in the portfolio.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P179_S0	PSE's energy risk portfolio management function monitors and manages these risks using analytical models and tools.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P179_S1	In order to manage risks effectively, PSE enters into physical and financial transactions which are appropriate for the service territory of PSE and are relevant to its regulated electric and natural gas portfolios.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P180_S0	At the February 2009 merger date, Puget Energy recorded all derivative contracts at fair value as either assets or liabilities.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P180_S1	Certain contracts meeting the criteria defined in ASC 815 were subsequently designated as NPNS or cash flow hedges.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P180_S2	As PSE had no change in accounting for these contracts at the time of the merger, this resulted in a difference in the accounting for certain contracts between Puget Energy and PSE.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P180_S3	The difference in the derivative unrealized gains/losses recorded through earnings between Puget Energy and PSE, caused by these contracts, will continue to occur through March 2015.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P181_S0	On July 1, 2009, Puget Energy and PSE elected to de-designate all energy related derivative contracts previously recorded as cash flow hedges for the purpose of simplifying its financial reporting.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P181_S1	The contracts that were de-designated related to physical electric supply contracts and natural gas swap contracts used to fix the price of natural gas for electric generation.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P182_S0	contracts and for contracts initiated after such date, all mark-to-market adjustments are recognized through earnings, unless the amounts qualify and are deferred as regulatory assets or liabilities.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P182_S1	The amount previously recorded in accumulated OCI is transferred to earnings in the same period or periods during which the hedged transaction affects earnings or sooner if management determines that the forecasted transaction is probable of not occurring.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P182_S2	As a result, the Company will continue to experience the earnings impact of these reversals from OCI in future periods through March 2015.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P183_S0	The Company manages its interest rate risk through the issuance of mostly fixed-rate debt with varied maturities.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P183_S1	The Company utilizes internal cash from operations, borrowings under its commercial paper program, and its credit facilities to meet short-term funding needs.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P183_S2	Short-term obligations are commonly refinanced with fixed-rate bonds or notes when needed and when interest rates are considered favorable.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P183_S3	The Company may also enter into swap instruments or other financial hedge instruments to manage the interest rate risk associated with these debts.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P183_S4	As of December 31, 2012 , Puget Energy had two interest rate swap contracts outstanding and PSE did not have any outstanding interest rate swap instruments.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P184_S0	In February 2009, Puget Energy entered into a cash flow hedge using interest rate swaps to hedge the risk associated with one-month LIBOR floating rate debt.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P184_S1	Subsequently, in order to satisfy a commitment the Company made to the Washington Commission and to mitigate interest rate risk, the Company refinanced a portion of the underlying debt hedged by the interest rate swaps in 2010, 2011, and again during 2012.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P184_S2	In order to better align its existing swap notional with the reduced underlying debt balance, in 2012, the Company net settled $827.4 million of the interest rate swaps, thereby reducing the swap notional to $450.0 million .
1085392_13_ITEM8_P184_S3	Additionally, the Company amended the remaining two interest rate swap agreements to extend the maturities to January 2017.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P184_S4	As a result of refinancing in 2010, the Company de-designated the cash flow hedge accounting relationship between the debt and interest rate swaps.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P184_S5	A portion of the outstanding interest rate swap derivative loss associated with the probable future interest payments occurring remains in OCI, and is amortized monthly as the payments occur.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P184_S6	The portion of the outstanding interest rate swap derivative loss associated with interest payments on the debt where future payments become remote of occurring is reclassified from OCI into earnings.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P184_S7	The following tables present the fair value and locations of the Company's derivative instruments recorded on the balance sheets:

1085392_13_ITEM8_P186_S1	All fair value adjustments on derivatives relating to the natural gas business have been reclassified to a deferred account in accordance with ASC 980, Regulated Operations (ASC 980) due to the PGA mechanism.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P186_S2	All increases and decreases in the cost of natural gas supply are passed on to customers with the PGA mechanism and the gains and losses on the hedges in future periods will be recorded as gas costs.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P187_S0	For further details regarding the fair value of derivative instruments, see Note 10 .

1085392_13_ITEM8_P196_S0	The Company is exposed to credit risk primarily through buying and selling electricity and natural gas to serve its customers.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P197_S0	Credit risk is the potential loss resulting from a counterparty's non-performance under an agreement.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P197_S1	The Company manages credit risk with policies and procedures for, among other things, counterparty credit analysis, exposure measurement, exposure monitoring and exposure mitigation.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P197_S2	The Company monitors counterparties that have significant swings in credit default swap rates, have credit rating changes by external rating agencies, have changes in ownership or are experiencing financial problems.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P197_S3	Where deemed appropriate, the Company may request collateral or other security from its counterparties to mitigate potential credit default losses.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P197_S4	Criteria employed in this decision include, among other things, the perceived creditworthiness of the counterparty and the expected credit exposure.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P198_S0	It is possible that volatility in energy commodity prices could cause the Company to have material credit risk exposure with one or more counterparties.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P198_S1	If such counterparties fail to perform their obligations under one or more agreements, the Company could suffer a material financial loss.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P199_S0	and 0.1% are either rated below investment grade or not rated by rating agencies.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P199_S1	The Company assesses credit risk internally for counterparties that are not rated.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P199_S2	The Company generally enters into transactions using the following master agreements: (1) WSPP, Inc. (WSPP) agreement - standardized power sales contract in the electric industry; (2) International Swaps and Derivatives Association (ISDA) agreements - standardized financial gas and electric contracts; and (3) North American Energy Standards Board (NAESB) agreements - standardized physical gas contracts.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P199_S3	The Company believes that such agreements reduce credit risk exposure because such agreements provide for the netting and offsetting of monthly payments and, in the event of counterparty default, termination payments.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P200_S0	The Company computes credit reserves at a master agreement level by counterparty (i.e., WSPP, ISDA, or NAESB).
1085392_13_ITEM8_P200_S1	The Company considers external credit ratings and market factors, such as credit default swaps and bond spreads, in the determination of reserves.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P200_S2	The Company recognizes that external ratings may not always reflect how a market participant perceives a counterparty's risk of default.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P200_S3	The Company uses both default factors published by Standard Poor's and factors derived through analysis of market risk, which reflect the application of an industry standard recovery rate.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P201_S0	The Company selects a default factor by counterparty at an aggregate master agreement level based on a weighted average default tenor for that counterparty's deals.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P201_S1	The default tenor is used by weighting the fair value and contract tenors for all deals for each counterparty and coming up with an average value.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P201_S2	The default factor used is dependent upon whether the counterparty is in a net asset or a net liability position after applying the master agreement levels.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P202_S0	The Company applies the counterparty's default factor to compute credit reserves for counterparties that are in a net asset position.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P202_S1	For those in a net liability position, the Company calculates the credit reserve by using its own bond spreads.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P203_S0	The fair value of derivative instruments includes the impact of credit reserves.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P203_S1	As of December 31, 2012 , the Company was in a net liability position with the majority of counterparties, so the default factors of counterparties did not have a significant impact on reserves for the quarter.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P204_S0	The majority of the Company's derivative contracts are with financial institutions and other utilities operating within the Western Electricity Coordinating Council.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P204_S1	Despite its net liability position, PSE was not required to post any additional collateral with any of its counterparties.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P204_S2	Additionally, PSE did not trigger any collateral requirements with any of its counterparties nor were any of PSE's counterparties required to post additional collateral resulting from credit rating downgrades.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P204_S3	As of December 31, 2012 , the Company did not have any outstanding energy supply contracts with counterparties that contained credit risk related contingent features, which could result in a counterparty requesting immediate payment or demanding immediate and ongoing full overnight collateralization on derivative instruments in a net liability position.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P204_S4	The table below presents the fair value of the overall contractual contingent liability positions for the Company's derivative activity at December 31, 2012 :
1085392_13_ITEM8_P205_S0	__________ Represents the derivative fair value of contracts with contingent features for counterparties in net derivative liability positions.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P205_S1	Excludes NPNS, accounts payable and accounts receivable.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P206_S0	Failure by PSE to maintain an investment grade credit rating from each of the major credit rating agencies provides counterparties a contractual right to demand collateral.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P206_S1	Collateral requirements may vary, based on changes in the forward value of underlying transactions relative to contractually defined collateral thresholds.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P207_S0	GAAP established a fair value hierarchy that prioritizes the inputs used to measure fair value.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P207_S1	The hierarchy categorizes the inputs into three levels with the highest priority given to unadjusted quoted prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities (Level 1 measurement) and the lowest priority given to unobservable inputs (Level 3 measurement).
1085392_13_ITEM8_P207_S2	The three levels of the fair value hierarchy are as follows:
1085392_13_ITEM8_P208_S0	Level 1 - Quoted prices are available in active markets for identical assets or liabilities as of the reporting date.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P208_S1	Level 1 primarily consists of financial instruments such as exchange-traded derivatives and listed equities.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P208_S2	Equity securities that are also classified as cash equivalents are considered Level 1 if there are unadjusted quoted prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P209_S0	Level 2 - Pricing inputs are other than quoted prices in active markets included in Level 1, which are either directly or indirectly observable as of the reporting date.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P210_S0	Level 2 includes those financial instruments that are valued using models or other valuation methodologies.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P210_S1	Instruments in this category include non-exchange-traded derivatives such as over-the-counter forwards and options.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P211_S0	Level 3 - Pricing inputs include significant inputs that have little or no observability as of the reporting date.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P211_S1	These inputs may be used with internally developed methodologies that result in management's best estimate of fair value.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P212_S0	Financial assets and liabilities are classified in their entirety based on the lowest level of input that is significant to the fair value measurement.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P212_S1	Therefore, if a fair value measurement relies on significant inputs from different levels of the hierarchy, the entire measurement must be placed based on the lowest level.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P212_S2	The Company's assessment of the significance of a particular input to the fair value measurement requires judgment, and may affect the valuation of fair value assets and liabilities and their placement within the fair value hierarchy.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P213_S0	The Company primarily determines fair value measurements classified as Level 2 or Level 3 using a combination of the income and market valuation approaches.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P213_S1	The process of determining the fair values is the responsibility of the derivative accounting department which reports to the Controller and Principal Accounting Officer.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P214_S0	On a daily basis, the Company obtains quoted forward prices for the electric and natural gas market from an independent external pricing service.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P214_S1	These forward price quotes are used in addition to other various inputs to determine the reported fair value.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P214_S2	Some of the inputs, which are not significant, include the credit standing of the counterparties involved and the impact of credit enhancements (such as cash deposits, letters of credit and priority interests), assumptions for time value, and also the impact of the Company's non-performance risk of its liabilities.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P214_S3	For interest rate swaps, the Company obtains monthly mark-to-market values from an independent external pricing service for LIBOR forward rates, which is a significant input.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P214_S4	Some of the inputs of the interest rate swap valuations, which are not significant, include the credit standing of the counterparties, assumptions for time value and the impact of the Company's non-performance risk of its liabilities.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P215_S0	Cash equivalents and restricted cash classified as Level 2 fair value instruments consist of special money market funds and premium checking accounts.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P215_S1	The Company valued Level 2 cash equivalents and restricted cash using the market approach based on the fair value of underlying investments at reporting date.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P216_S0	The Company considers its electric, natural gas and interest rate swap contracts as Level 2 derivative instruments as such contracts are commonly traded as over-the-counter forwards with indirectly observable price quotes.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P216_S1	However, certain energy derivative instruments are classified as Level 3 in the fair value hierarchy since Level 3 inputs are significant to the fair value measurement.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P217_S0	Management's assessment was based on the trading activity in real-time and forward electric and natural gas markets.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P218_S0	Each quarter, the Company confirms the validity of pricing service quoted prices (e.g., Level 2 in the fair value hierarchy) used to value commodity contracts with the actual prices of commodity contracts entered into during the most recent quarter.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P219_S0	The following table presents the carrying value for cash, cash equivalents, restricted cash, notes receivable and short-term debt by level, within the fair value hierarchy.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P219_S1	The carrying values below are representative of fair values due to the short-term nature of these financial instruments.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P220_S0	The fair value of the junior subordinated and long-term notes were estimated using the discounted cash flow method with U.S. Treasury yields and Company credit spreads as inputs, interpolating to the maturity date of each issue.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P220_S1	Carrying values and estimated fair values were as follows:
1085392_13_ITEM8_P221_S0	The following tables present the Company's financial assets and liabilities by level, within the fair value hierarchy, that were accounted for at fair value on a recurring basis and the reconciliation of the changes in the fair value of Level 3 derivatives in the fair value hierarchy.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P221_S1	The Company did not have any transfers between Level 2 and Level 1 during the twelve months ended December 31, 2012 and 2011 .
1085392_13_ITEM8_P222_S0	_______________ Income Statement location: Unrealized (gain) loss on derivative instruments, net.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P222_S1	Includes unrealized gains (losses) on derivatives still held in position as of the reporting date for electric derivatives of $(15.2) million , $(55.2) million , and $(89.4) million for the twelve months ended December 31, 2012, 2011 and 2010, respectively.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P222_S2	The Company had no purchases, sales or issuances during the reported periods.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P223_S0	Realized gains and losses on energy derivatives for Level 3 recurring items are included in energy costs in the Company's consolidated statements of income under purchased electricity, electric generation fuel or purchased natural gas when settled.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P223_S1	Unrealized gains and losses on energy derivatives for Level 3 recurring items are included in net unrealized (gain) loss on derivative instruments in the Company's consolidated statements of income.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P224_S0	In order to determine which assets and liabilities are classified as Level 3, the Company receives market data from its independent external pricing service defining the tenor of observable market quotes.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P224_S1	To the extent any of the Company's commodity contracts extend beyond what is considered observable as defined by its independent pricing service, the contracts are classified as Level 3.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P225_S0	The actual tenor of what the independent pricing service defines as observable is subject to change depending on market conditions.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P225_S1	Therefore, as the market changes, the same contract may be designated Level 3 one month and Level 2 the next, and vice versa.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P225_S2	The changes of fair value classification into or out of Level 3 are recognized each month, and reported in the Level 3 Roll-forward table above.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P226_S0	The Company does periodically transact at locations, or market price points, that are illiquid or for which no prices are available from the independent pricing service.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P226_S1	In such circumstances the Company uses a more liquid price point and performs a 15-month regression against the illiquid locations to serve as a proxy for market prices.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P226_S2	Such transactions are classified as Level 3.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P227_S0	The Company does not use internally developed models to make adjustments to significant unobservable pricing inputs.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P227_S1	The only significant unobservable input into the fair value measurement of the Company's Level 3 assets and liabilities is the forward price for electric and natural gas contracts.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P227_S2	Below are the forward price ranges for the Company's purchased commodity contracts, as of December 31, 2012:
1085392_13_ITEM8_P228_S0	The valuation techniques, unobservable inputs and ranges are the same for asset and liability positions.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P229_S0	The significant unobservable inputs listed above would have a direct impact on the fair values of the above instruments if they were adjusted.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P229_S1	Consequently significant increases or decreases in the forward prices of electricity or natural gas in isolation would result in a significantly higher or lower fair value for Level 3 assets and liabilities.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P230_S0	Generally, interrelationships exist between market prices of natural gas and power.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P230_S1	As such, an increase in natural gas pricing would potentially have a similar impact on forward power markets.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P231_S0	At December 31, 2012, a hypothetical 10% increase or decrease in market prices of natural gas and electricity would change the fair value of the Company's derivative portfolio, classified as Level 3 within the fair value hierarchy, by $17.8 million .
1085392_13_ITEM8_P232_S0	At the time of merger, Puget Energy recorded the fair value of its intangible assets in accordance with ASC 360, Property, Plant, and Equipment, (ASC 360).
1085392_13_ITEM8_P232_S1	The fair value assigned to the power contracts was determined using an income approach comparing the contract rate to the market rate for power over the remaining period of the contracts incorporating non-performance risk.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P232_S2	Management also incorporated certain assumptions related to quantities and market presentation that it believes market participants would make in the valuation.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P233_S0	The fair value of the power contracts is amortized as the contracts settle.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P234_S0	ASC 360 requires long-lived assets to be tested for impairment on an annual basis, and upon the occurrence of any events or circumstances that would be more likely than not to reduce the fair value of the long-lived assets below their carrying value.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P234_S1	One such triggering event is a significant decrease in the forward market prices of power.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P235_S0	At December 31, 2012 , Puget Energy completed a valuation and impairment test of its purchased power contracts classified as intangible assets.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P235_S1	The valuation indicated a fair value of $561.3 million with an impairment to one of the purchased power contracts.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P235_S2	As of December 31, 2012 , the carrying value for the Rock Island intangible asset contract was $7.6 million and its fair value on a discounted basis was determined to be a liability of $10.2 million , thereby requiring a complete write-off of the intangible asset with a corresponding $7.6 million reduction to the regulatory liability.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P236_S0	The valuation was measured using the income approach.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P236_S1	Significant inputs included forward electricity prices and power contract costs which provided future net cash flow estimates which are classified as Level 3 within the fair value hierarchy.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P236_S2	An insignificant input is the discount rate reflective of PSE's cost of capital used in the valuation.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P236_S3	Below are the significant unobservable inputs used in the fourth quarter in estimating the fair value of the Rock Island long-term power purchase contract during the period ended December 31, 2012 :
1085392_13_ITEM8_P237_S0	At March 31, 2012 , due to decreasing forward wholesale market prices, Puget Energy completed a valuation and impairment test for its purchase power contracts classified as intangible assets.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P237_S1	The valuation indicated impairment to one of the purchased power contracts.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P237_S2	As of March 31, 2012 , the carrying value for the Wells Hydro intangible asset contract was $113.3 million and its fair value on a discounted basis was determined to be $96.7 million , thereby requiring a $16.6 million write-down of the intangible asset with a corresponding reduction in the regulatory liability.

1085392_13_ITEM8_P240_S0	The Company has a qualified employee Investment Plan which is a 401(k) plan, under which employee salary deferrals and after-tax contributions are used to purchase several different investment fund options.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P240_S1	For employees under the Cash Balance retirement plan formula, PSE will match 100% of an employee's contribution up to 6% of plan compensation, and will make an additional year-end contribution equal to 1% of base pay.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P240_S2	For employees grandfathered under the Final Average Earning retirement plan formula, PSE will match 55% of an employee s contribution up to 6% of plan compensation.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P240_S3	PSE s contributions to the employee Investment Plan were $14.5 million , $13.5 million and $11.8 million for the years 2012 , 2011 , and 2010 , respectively.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P241_S0	The employee Investment Plan eligibility requirements are set forth in the plan documents.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P242_S0	PSE has a defined benefit pension plan covering substantially all PSE employees.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P242_S1	Pension benefits earned are a function of age, salary and years of service.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P242_S2	PSE also maintains a non-qualified Supplemental Executive Retirement Plan (SERP) for its key senior management employees.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P243_S0	In addition to providing pension benefits, PSE provides certain health care and life insurance benefits for employees.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P243_S1	These benefits are provided principally through an insurance company.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P243_S2	The insurance premiums are based on the benefits provided during the year, and are paid primarily by retirees.

1085392_13_ITEM8_P254_S0	The Company has selected the expected return on plan assets based on a historical analysis of rates of return and the Company s investment mix, market conditions, inflation and other factors.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P254_S1	The expected rate of return is reviewed annually based on these factors.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P255_S0	The Company s accounting policy for calculating the market-related value of assets for the Company s retirement plan is as follows.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P255_S1	PSE market-related value of assets is based on a five-year smoothing of asset gains/losses measured from the expected return on market-related assets.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P255_S2	This is a calculated value that recognizes changes in fair value in a systematic and rational manner over five years.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P255_S3	The same manner of calculating market-related value is used for all classes of assets, and is applied consistently from year to year.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P256_S0	Puget Energy s pension and other postretirement benefits income or costs depend on several factors and assumptions, including plan design, timing and amount of cash contributions to the plan, earnings on plan assets, discount rate, expected long-term rate of return, mortality and health care costs trends.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P256_S1	Changes in any of these factors or assumptions will affect the amount of income or expense that Puget Energy records in its financial statements in future years and its projected benefit obligation.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P257_S0	Puget Energy has selected an expected return on plan assets based on a historical analysis of rates of return and Puget Energy s investment mix, market conditions, inflation and other factors.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P257_S1	As required by merger accounting rules, market-related value was reset to market value effective with the merger.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P258_S0	The discount rates were determined by using market interest rate data and the weighted-average discount rate from Citigroup Pension Liability Index Curve.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P258_S1	The Company also takes into account in determining the discount rate the expected changes in market interest rates and anticipated changes in the duration of the plan liabilities.

1085392_13_ITEM8_P260_S0	Plan Assets Plan contributions and the actuarial present value of accumulated plan benefits are prepared based on certain assumptions pertaining to interest rates, inflation rates and employee demographics, all of which are subject to change.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P260_S1	Due to uncertainties inherent in the estimations and assumptions process, changes in these estimates and assumptions in the near term may be material to the financial statements.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P261_S0	The Company has a Retirement Plan Committee that establishes investment policies, objectives and strategies designed to balance expected return with a prudent level of risk.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P261_S1	All changes to the investment policies are reviewed and approved by the Retirement Plan Committee prior to being implemented.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P262_S0	The Retirement Plan Committee invests trust assets with investment managers who have historically achieved above-median long-term investment performance within the risk and asset allocation limits that have been established.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P262_S1	Interim evaluations are routinely performed with the assistance of an outside investment consultant.

1085392_13_ITEM8_P264_S0	Plan Fair Value Measurements ASC 715, Compensation Retirement Benefits (ASC 715) directs companies to provide additional disclosures about plan assets of a defined benefit pension or other postretirement plan.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P264_S1	The objectives of the disclosures are to disclose the following: (1) how investment allocation decisions are made, including the factors that are pertinent to an understanding of investment policies and strategies; (2) major categories of plan assets; (3) inputs and valuation techniques used to measure the fair value of plan assets; (4) effect of fair value measurements using significant unobservable inputs (Level 3) on changes in plan assets for the period; and (5) significant concentrations of risk within plan assets.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P265_S0	ASC 820 allows the reporting entity, as a practical expedient, to measure the fair value of investments that do not have readily determinable fair values on the basis of the net asset value per share of the investment if the net asset value of the investment is calculated in a matter consistent with ASC 946, Financial Services Investment Companies.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P265_S1	The standard requires disclosures about the nature and risk of the investments and whether the investments are probable of being sold at amounts different from the net asset value per share.

1085392_13_ITEM8_P281_S0	The above amounts have been classified in the Consolidated Balance Sheets as follows:
1085392_13_ITEM8_P282_S0	The Company calculates its deferred tax assets and liabilities under ASC 740, Income Taxes (ASC 740).
1085392_13_ITEM8_P282_S1	ASC 740 requires recording deferred tax balances, at the currently enacted tax rate, on assets and liabilities that are reported differently for income tax purposes than for financial reporting purposes.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P283_S0	ASC 740 requires a valuation allowance on deferred tax assets when it is more likely than not that the deferred tax asset will not be realized.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P283_S1	The Company s PTC carryforwards expire from 2026 through 2032.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P283_S2	The Company s net operating loss carryforwards expire from 2029 through 2032.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P284_S0	For ratemaking purposes, deferred taxes are not provided for certain temporary differences.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P284_S1	PSE has established a regulatory asset for income taxes recoverable through future rates related to those temporary differences for which no deferred taxes have been provided, based on prior and expected future ratemaking treatment.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P285_S0	The Company accounts for uncertain tax position under ASC 740, which clarifies the accounting for uncertainty in income taxes recognized in the financial statements.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P285_S1	ASC 740 requires the use of a two-step approach for recognizing and measuring tax positions taken or expected to be taken in a tax return.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P286_S0	First, a tax position should only be recognized when it is more likely than not, based on technical merits, that the position will be sustained upon challenge by the taxing authorities and taken by management to the court of last resort.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P286_S1	Second, a tax position that meets the recognition threshold should be measured at the largest amount that has a greater than 50.0% likelihood of being sustained.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P287_S0	As of December 31, 2012 and 2011 , the Company had no material unrecognized tax benefits.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P287_S1	As a result, no interest or penalties were accrued for unrecognized tax benefits during the year.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P287_S2	For ASC 740 purposes, the Company has open tax years from 2006 through 2012.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P287_S3	The Company is under audit by the IRS for tax years 2006 through 2009.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P287_S4	The Company classifies interest as interest expense and penalties as other expense in the financial statements.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P288_S0	Residential Exchange The Northwest Power Act, through the Residential Exchange Program (REP), provides access to the benefits of low-cost federal power for residential and small farm customers of regional utilities, including PSE.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P288_S1	The program is administered by the BPA.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P288_S2	Pursuant to agreements (including settlement agreements) between the BPA and PSE, the BPA has provided payments of REP benefits to PSE, which PSE has passed through to its residential and small farm customers in the form of electricity bill credits.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P288_S3	In 2007, the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit (Ninth Circuit) ruled that REP agreements of the BPA with PSE and a number of other investor-owned utilities were inconsistent with the Northwest Power Act.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P288_S4	Since that time, those investor-owned utilities, including PSE, the BPA and other parties have been involved in ongoing litigation at the Ninth Circuit relating to the amount of REP benefits paid to utilities, including PSE, for the fiscal year 2002 through fiscal year 2011 period and the amount of REP benefits to be paid going forward.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P288_S5	In July 2011, the BPA, PSE and a number of other parties entered into a settlement agreement that by its terms, if upheld in its entirety, would resolve the disputes between BPA and PSE regarding REP benefits paid for fiscal years 2002-2011 and determine REP benefits for fiscal years 2012-2028.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P288_S6	In October 2011, certain other parties challenged BPA decisions with regard to its entering into this most recent settlement agreement.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P288_S7	Oral argument in the Ninth Circuit on this litigation occurred on February 19, 2013.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P288_S8	Pending disposition of this challenge, the other pending Ninth Circuit litigation regarding REP benefits has been stayed by the Ninth Circuit.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P288_S9	Due to the pending and ongoing proceedings, PSE is unable to reasonably estimate any amounts of REP payments either to be recovered by the BPA or to be paid for any future periods to PSE, and is unable to determine the impact, if any, these proceedings and litigation may have on PSE.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P288_S10	However, the Company believes it is unlikely that any unfavorable outcome would have a material adverse effect on PSE because REP benefits received by PSE are passed through to PSE's residential and small farm customers.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P289_S0	Notice of Intent to Sue PSE has a 50% ownership interest in Colstrip Units 1 and 2, and a 25% interest in Colstrip Units 3 and 4.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P290_S0	On July 25, 2012, a Notice of Intent to Sue for violations of the Clean Air Act at Colstrip Steam Electric Station was sent to PSE from the Sierra Club and the Montana Environmental Information Center (MEIC).
1085392_13_ITEM8_P290_S1	The notice, which was amended on August 30, 2012, September 27, 2012, and December 1, 2012.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P290_S2	was addressed to the owner or managing agent of Colstrip and to the other Colstrip co-owners, including PSE.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P290_S3	The notices allege violations of the Clean Air Act and state that the Sierra Club and MEIC will request a United States District Court to impose injunctive relief and civil penalties, require a beneficial environmental project in the areas affected by the alleged air pollution and require reimbursement of Sierra Club's and MEIC's costs of litigation and attorney's fees.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P290_S4	Under the Clean Air Act, lawsuits cannot be filed until 60 days after the applicable notice date.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P290_S5	PSE is evaluating the allegations set forth in the notices and cannot at this time predict the outcome of this matter.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P291_S0	Other Proceedings The Company is also involved in litigation relating to claims arising out of its operations in the normal course of business.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P291_S1	The Company has recorded reserves of $3.4 million and $3.8 million relating to these claims as of December 31, 2012 and 2011 , respectively.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P292_S0	In accordance with ASC 810, Consolidation (ASC 810), a business entity that has a controlling financial interest in a variable interest entity (VIE) should consolidate the VIE in its financial statements.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P292_S1	A primary beneficiary of a VIE is the variable interest holder that has both the power to direct matters that significantly impact the activities of the VIE and has the obligation to absorb losses or the right to receive benefits.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P292_S2	The Company enters into a variety of contracts for energy with other counterparties and evaluates all contracts to determine if they are variable interests.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P292_S3	The Company s variable interests primarily arise through power purchase agreements where it is required to buy all or a majority of generation from a plant at rates set forth in the agreement.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P292_S4	The Company evaluated its power purchase agreements and determined it was not the primary beneficiary of any VIEs.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P292_S5	The Company had previously disclosed two potentially significant variable interests in prior periods; both entities were qualifying facilities contracts that expired at the end of 2011 .
1085392_13_ITEM8_P292_S6	The Company requested information from the relevant entities; however, they refused to provide the necessary information, as they were not required to do so under their contracts.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P292_S7	However, if the variable interests had been determined to be VIEs, the Company concluded it would not have been the primary beneficiary of these entities based on available information and it had no exposure to loss on these contracts.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P292_S8	For the years ended December 31, 2011 and 2010 , the Company s purchased power expense from these entities was $175.9 million and $190.3 million , respectively.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P292_S9	The Company did not identify any variable interests during the twelve months ended December 31, 2012 .
1085392_13_ITEM8_P293_S0	For the year ended December 31, 2012 , approximately 17.5% of the Company s energy output was obtained at an average cost of approximately $0.018 per kilowatt hour (kWh) through long-term contracts with three of the Washington Public Utility Districts (PUDs) that own hydroelectric projects on the Columbia River.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P293_S1	The purchase of power from the Columbia River projects is on a pro rata share basis under which the Company pays a proportionate share of the annual debt service, operating and maintenance costs and other expenses associated with each project in proportion to the contractual shares that PSE obtains from that project.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P293_S2	In these instances, PSE s payments are not contingent upon the projects being operable; therefore, PSE is required to make the payments even if power is not delivered.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P293_S3	These projects are financed through substantially level debt service payments and their annual costs should not vary significantly over the term of the contracts unless additional financing is required to meet the costs of major maintenance, repairs or replacements, or license requirements.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P293_S4	The Company s share of the costs and the output of the projects is subject to reduction due to various withdrawal rights of the PUDs and others over the contract lives.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P293_S5	The Company's expenses under these PUD contracts were as follows for the years ended December 31:

1085392_13_ITEM8_P296_S1	The Company has natural gas-fired generation facility obligations for natural gas supply amounting to an estimated $53.4 million in 2013 .
1085392_13_ITEM8_P296_S2	Longer term agreements for natural gas supply amount to an estimated $417.8 million for 2013 through 2030.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P297_S0	PSE enters into short-term energy supply contracts to meet its core customer needs.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P297_S1	These contracts are sometimes classified as NPNS, however in most cases recorded at fair value in accordance with ASC 815.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P297_S2	Commitments under these contracts are $297.0 million , $189.6 million and $51.3 million in 2013 , 2014 and 2015 , respectively.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P298_S0	The Company has also entered into various firm supply, transportation and storage service contracts in order to ensure adequate availability of natural gas supply for its firm customers.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P298_S1	Many of these contracts, which have remaining terms from less than one year to 32 years, provide that the Company must pay a fixed demand charge each month, regardless of actual usage.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P298_S2	The Company contracts for its long-term natural gas supply on a firm basis, which means the Company has a 100% daily take obligation and the supplier has a 100% daily delivery obligation to ensure service to PSE s customers and generation requirements.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P299_S0	The Company incurred demand charges in 2012 for firm transportation service and firm storage and peaking service of $142.6 million and $6.6 million , respectively.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P299_S1	The demand charge for firm natural gas supply was immaterial in 2012.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P299_S2	The Company incurred demand charges in 2012 for firm transportation and firm storage service for the natural gas supply for its combustion turbines in the amount of $31.5 million , which is included in the total Company demand charges.

1085392_13_ITEM8_P304_S0	On June 1, 2006, PSE entered into a revolving credit facility with Puget Energy in the form of a Demand Promissory Note (Note).
1085392_13_ITEM8_P304_S1	Through the Note, PSE may borrow up to $30.0 million from Puget Energy, subject to approval by Puget Energy.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P304_S2	Under the terms of the Note, PSE pays interest on the outstanding borrowings based on the lowest of the weighted-average interest rate of PSE s outstanding commercial paper interest rate or PSE s senior unsecured revolving credit facility.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P304_S3	Absent such borrowings, interest is charged at one-month LIBOR plus 0.25% .
1085392_13_ITEM8_P304_S4	At December 31, 2012 and 2011 , the outstanding balance of the Note was $29.6 million and $30.0 million , respectively, and the interest rate was 0.5% and 1.6% , respectively.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P304_S5	The outstanding balance and the related interest under the Note are eliminated by Puget Energy upon consolidation of PSE s financial statements.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P304_S6	The $30.0 million credit facility with Puget Energy was unaffected by the merger.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P305_S0	On June 3, 2011, Puget Energy issued $500.0 million of senior secured notes.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P305_S1	Macquarie Capital (USA) Inc. acted as a co-manager and underwriter of this issue.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P305_S2	Net proceeds of $484.0 million from these notes were used to repay a portion of the outstanding $782.0 million term-loan.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P306_S0	Puget Energy s term-loan and credit facility for funding capital expenditures both were originally scheduled to mature in February 2014, and were syndicated among numerous committed banks and other financial institutions.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P306_S1	One of these banks was Macquarie Bank Limited.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P306_S2	On February 10, 2012, Puget Energy terminated the term loan and capital expenditure facility and replaced them with a $1.0 billion revolving credit facility.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P306_S3	There are no related parties with commitments under the $1.0 billion revolving credit facility.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P307_S0	Concurrent with the borrowings under the term loan and capital expenditure credit agreements, Puget Energy entered into several interest rate swap instruments to hedge volatility associated with these two loans.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P307_S1	Two of the swap instruments were entered into with Macquarie Bank Limited with a total notional amount of $444.9 million .
1085392_13_ITEM8_P307_S2	On June 3, 2011 Puget Energy settled one of the swaps with a notional amount of $77.4 million .
1085392_13_ITEM8_P307_S3	On February 9, 2012, Puget Energy amended and reduced the remaining swap instrument by $67.5 million .
1085392_13_ITEM8_P307_S4	On June 18, 2012, Puget Energy terminated and settled the remaining $300.0 million of the swap instrument with Macquarie Bank Limited.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P308_S0	Puget Energy operates one business segment referred to as the regulated utility segment.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P308_S1	Puget Energy s regulated utility operation generates, purchases and sells electricity and purchases, transports and sells natural gas.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P308_S2	The service territory of PSE covers approximately 6,000 square miles in the state of Washington.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P309_S0	Non-utility business segment includes two PSE subsidiaries and Puget Energy, and is described as Other.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P309_S1	The PSE subsidiaries are a real estate investment and development company and a holding company for a small non-utility wholesale generator which was sold in 2010.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P309_S2	Reconciling items between segments are not significant.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P309_S3	Effective February 6, 2009, all merger related fair value adjustments under ASC 805, were retained in Puget Energy.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P309_S4	Accordingly, only the financial statements of Puget Energy were adjusted to reflect the purchase accounting adjustments.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P309_S5	Prior to the merger, the business segment financial statements for Puget Energy and PSE were the same.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P310_S0	The following unaudited amounts, in the opinion of the Company, include all adjustments (consisting of normal recurring adjustments) necessary for a fair statement of the results of operations for the interim periods.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P311_S0	Quarterly amounts vary during the year due to the seasonal nature of the utility business.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P312_S0	See accompanying notes to the consolidated financial statements.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P313_S0	_______________ Investment in subsidiaries for successor include Puget Energy business combination accounting adjustments under ASC 805 that are recorded at Puget Energy.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P314_S0	See accompanying notes to the consolidated financial statements.
1085392_13_ITEM8_P315_S0	See accompanying notes to the consolidated financial statements.
1085392_13_ITEM9A_P0_S0	Puget Energy Evaluation of Disclosure Controls and Procedures Under the supervision and with the participation of Puget Energy s management, including the President and Chief Executive Officer and Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, Puget Energy has evaluated the effectiveness of its disclosure controls and procedures (as defined in Rule 13a-15(e) under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934) as of December 31, 2012 , the end of the period covered by this report.
1085392_13_ITEM9A_P0_S1	Based upon that evaluation, the President and Chief Executive Officer and Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer of Puget Energy concluded that these disclosure controls and procedures are effective.
1085392_13_ITEM9A_P1_S0	The Company implemented a new system for income tax reporting in the quarter ended December 31, 2012.
1085392_13_ITEM9A_P1_S1	The change was not made in response to any deficiency in the Company's internal controls.
1085392_13_ITEM9A_P2_S0	internal control over financial reporting during the quarter ended December 31, 2012 that have materially affected, or are reasonably likely to materially affect, Puget Energy s internal control over financial reporting.
1085392_13_ITEM9A_P3_S0	Management s Report on Internal Control Over Financial Reporting Puget Energy s management is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting (as defined in Rule 13a-15(f) under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934).
1085392_13_ITEM9A_P3_S1	Under the supervision and with the participation of Puget Energy s President and Chief Executive Officer and Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, Puget Energy s management assessed the effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting based on the framework in Internal Control Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission.
1085392_13_ITEM9A_P3_S2	Based on the assessment, Puget Energy s management concluded that its internal control over financial reporting was effective as of December 31, 2012 .
1085392_13_ITEM9A_P3_S3	Puget Energy s effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2012 has been audited by PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP, an independent registered public accounting firm, as stated in their report which is included herein.
1085392_13_ITEM9A_P4_S0	Puget Sound Energy Evaluation of Disclosure Controls and Procedures Under the supervision and with the participation of PSE s management, including the President and Chief Executive Officer and Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, PSE has evaluated the effectiveness of its disclosure controls and procedures (as defined in Rule 13a-15(e) under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934) as of December 31, 2012 , the end of the period covered by this report.
1085392_13_ITEM9A_P4_S1	Based upon that evaluation, the President and Chief Executive Officer and Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer of PSE concluded that these disclosure controls and procedures are effective.
1085392_13_ITEM9A_P5_S0	The Company implemented a new system for income tax reporting in the quarter ended December 31, 2012.
1085392_13_ITEM9A_P5_S1	The change was not made in response to any deficiency in the Company's internal controls.
1085392_13_ITEM9A_P5_S2	There have been no other changes in PSE s internal control over financial reporting during the quarter ended December 31, 2012 that have materially affected, or are reasonably likely to materially affect, PSE s internal control over financial reporting.
1085392_13_ITEM9A_P6_S0	Management s Report on Internal Control Over Financial Reporting PSE s management is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting (as defined in Rule 13a-15(f) under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934).
1085392_13_ITEM9A_P6_S1	Under the supervision and with the participation of PSE s President and Chief Executive Officer and Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, Puget Sound Energy s management assessed the effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting based on the framework in Internal Control Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission.
1085392_13_ITEM9A_P6_S2	Based on the assessment, PSE s management concluded that its internal control over financial reporting was effective as of December 31, 2012 .
1085392_13_ITEM9A_P6_S3	PSE s effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2012 has been audited by PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP, an independent registered public accounting firm, as stated in their report which is included herein.
1085392_13_ITEM10_P0_S0	Board of Directors As of March 4, 2013 , twelve directors constitute Puget Energy s Board of Directors and thirteen directors currently constitute PSE s Board of Directors, as set forth below.
1085392_13_ITEM10_P0_S1	The directors are selected in accordance with the Amended and Restated Bylaws of each of Puget Energy and PSE, pursuant to which, the investor-owners of Puget Holdings (the indirect parent company of both Puget Energy and PSE) are entitled to select individuals to serve on the boards of Puget Energy and PSE.
1085392_13_ITEM10_P1_S0	William Ayer , age 58, is a director on the boards of both Puget Energy and PSE.
1085392_13_ITEM10_P1_S1	Over the past 30 years, Mr. Ayer has served in a variety of leadership positions at Alaska Air Group, the parent company of Alaska Airlines and Horizon Air, where he currently serves as Chairman.
1085392_13_ITEM10_P1_S2	Until May 2012, as the Chief Executive Officer of Alaska Airlines, Mr. Ayer led the nation s seventh-largest airline with 9,600 employees.
1085392_13_ITEM10_P1_S3	He also oversaw regional carrier Horizon Air and its 3,200 employees.
1085392_13_ITEM10_P1_S4	Mr. Ayer is also a member of the board of directors of the Museum of Flight and Angel Flight West and serves on the University of Washington s Board of Regents and the NextGen Advisory Committee.
1085392_13_ITEM10_P1_S5	Mr. Ayer s experience running a successful company recognized nationally for its award-winning customer service and operational performance, coupled with his community involvement in the western Washington region, are among the qualifications and attributes that led to the conclusion that he should serve on the Puget Energy and PSE boards.
1085392_13_ITEM10_P2_S0	Andrew Chapman , age 57, has been a director on the boards of both Puget Energy and PSE since February 2009.
1085392_13_ITEM10_P2_S1	Mr. Chapman is currently a director on the Board of Duquesne Light Holdings, Inc. and Duquesne Light Company, which position he has held since February 1, 2010.
1085392_13_ITEM10_P2_S2	Mr. Chapman is currently a Managing Director in the Macquarie Capital Funds division of the Macquarie Group, which position he has held since 2006.
1085392_13_ITEM10_P2_S3	Prior to joining the Macquarie Group, Mr. Chapman was Vice President Strategy Regulation for American Water from 2005 to 2006 and Regional Managing Director from 2003 to 2004.
1085392_13_ITEM10_P2_S4	Mr. Chapman represents the Company s Macquarie affiliated investors on the boards, in accordance with the terms of the Puget Energy and PSE bylaws, and brings to his service many years of experience in the operational and financial management challenges specific to regulated utilities.
1085392_13_ITEM10_P3_S0	Melanie Dressel , age 60, is a director on the boards of both Puget Energy and PSE, which positions she has held since December 2011.
1085392_13_ITEM10_P3_S1	Ms. Dressel is currently President and Chief Executive Officer of Columbia Bank and its parent company, Columbia Banking System, Inc., of Tacoma, Washington, which positions she has held since 2000 and 2003, respectively.
1085392_13_ITEM10_P3_S2	An independent director not affiliated with any of the Company s investors, Ms. Dressel s leadership skills, financial experience and many ties to civic and community groups in the Company s service territory are among the reasons for her appointment to the Puget Energy and PSE boards.
1085392_13_ITEM10_P4_S0	Daniel Fetter , age 36, is a director on the boards of both Puget Energy and PSE, which positions he has held since August 2, 2012.
1085392_13_ITEM10_P4_S1	Mr. Fetter is currently the Senior Principal, Private Infrastructure with Canada Pension Plan Investment Board (CPPIB), which position he has held since 2009.
1085392_13_ITEM10_P4_S2	Prior to that, Mr. Fetter served as both a Principal (from 2007 to 2009) and Associate (from 2006 to 2007) at CPP Investment Board.
1085392_13_ITEM10_P4_S3	Mr. Fetter is currently on the Board of Directors of Arqiva, a communications infrastructure and media services company, which position he has held since 2009.
1085392_13_ITEM10_P4_S4	Mr. Fetter serves on the boards of Puget Energy and PSE as a representative of CPPIB's ownership interests, pursuant to the terms of the Puget Energy and PSE bylaws, and brings to this service his skills in financial management of infrastructure providers.
1085392_13_ITEM10_P5_S0	Kimberly Harris, age 48, is a director on the boards of both Puget Energy and PSE, which positions she has held since March 1, 2011.
1085392_13_ITEM10_P5_S1	Ms. Harris has also been President and Chief Executive Officer since March 1, 2011.
1085392_13_ITEM10_P5_S2	Prior to that time, Ms. Harris served as President from July 2010 through February 2011.
1085392_13_ITEM10_P5_S3	Ms. Harris also served as Executive Vice President and Chief Resource Officer from May 2007 until July 2010, and was Senior Vice President Regulatory Policy and Energy Efficiency from 2005 until May 2007.
1085392_13_ITEM10_P6_S0	Benjamin Hawkins , age 38, has been a director on the boards of both Puget Energy and PSE since May 21, 2010.
1085392_13_ITEM10_P6_S1	Mr. Hawkins is currently a Senior Principal of Infrastructure Timber Investments for Alberta Investment Management Corporation (AimCo), which position he has held since June 2011.
1085392_13_ITEM10_P6_S2	Mr. Hawkins also served as Principal of Infrastructure Investments of AimCo from November 2008 until June 2011, and Portfolio Manager of Infrastructure Investments from May of 2007 until November 2008.
1085392_13_ITEM10_P6_S3	Prior to joining AimCo, Mr. Hawkins held various positions with EPCOR Utilities, a Canadian power and water utility company.
1085392_13_ITEM10_P6_S4	Mr. Hawkins serves on the boards as a representative of AimCo s ownership interest in the Company, pursuant to the terms of the Puget Energy and PSE bylaws, and brings to this service his skills in financial oversight of utilities.
1085392_13_ITEM10_P7_S0	Alan James , age 59, has been a director on the boards of both Puget Energy and PSE since February 2009, as a representative of the Company s Macquarie affiliated investors consistent with the Puget Energy and PSE bylaws.
1085392_13_ITEM10_P7_S1	Mr. James is currently the Chairman and Senior Managing Director of Macquarie Capital (USA) Inc. based in New York where he specializes in providing M A advice and capital raising solutions to the utility, power and renewable sectors in North America, which position he has held since 2005.
1085392_13_ITEM10_P7_S2	Prior to that time, Mr. James was Managing Director and Head, Investment Banking Australia and New Zealand at Citigroup from 2002 to 2005 and held various positions with Deutsche Bank AG in Australia and Europe from 1993 to 2002 specializing in the energy sector.
1085392_13_ITEM10_P8_S0	Mr. James provides the boards the benefit of his broad experience with the financial needs and operational and regulatory challenges of infrastructure providers.
1085392_13_ITEM10_P9_S0	Christopher Leslie , age 48, has been a director on the boards of both Puget Energy and PSE since February 2009, as a representative of the Company s Macquarie affiliated investors consistent with the Puget Energy and PSE bylaws.
1085392_13_ITEM10_P10_S0	currently an Executive Director of Macquarie Group Limited, which position he has held since 2005, President of Macquarie Infrastructure and Real Assets Inc., and since 2006 Chief Executive Officer of Macquarie Infrastructure Partners Inc.
1085392_13_ITEM10_P10_S1	Mr. Leslie served as a director on the boards of Duquesne Light Holdings, Inc. and Duquesne Light Company in 2009 and 2010.
1085392_13_ITEM10_P10_S2	In addition to his management and banking skills, Mr. Leslie provides the Puget Energy and PSE boards the benefit of his experience with electric utilities, gas distribution systems and other aspects of the infrastructure sector.
1085392_13_ITEM10_P11_S0	David MacMillan , age 60, has been a director on the boards of both Puget Energy and PSE since November 6, 2012.
1085392_13_ITEM10_P11_S1	Mr. MacMillan currently is a non-executive director of Viridian Group Ltd., an energy company based in Northern Ireland, and serves on the board of Potentia Solar Inc., a Toronto-based independent solar-power producer.
1085392_13_ITEM10_P11_S2	He has also served as managing director and senior advisor to Good Energies Capital (now named Bregal Energy), a New York-based private equity fund focused on the renewable energy sector, which positions he held from 2007 to 2010, non-executive director of Ontario Power Generation (from 2004 to 2012) and Intergen (from 2006 to 2008).
1085392_13_ITEM10_P12_S0	Mr. MacMillan serves on the boards of Puget Energy and PSE as a representative of CPPIB's ownership interests, pursuant to the terms of the Puget Energy and PSE bylaws, and brings to this service his skills in project finance and experience with managing the capital requirements of energy companies.
1085392_13_ITEM10_P13_S0	John McMahon , age 61, has been a director on the boards of both Puget Energy and PSE since May 8, 2012.
1085392_13_ITEM10_P13_S1	Through December 31, 2012, Mr. McMahon served as independent chairman of Presidential Life Corporation and senior adviser to Macquarie Infrastructure and Real Assets.
1085392_13_ITEM10_P13_S2	Mr. McMahon also serves on the boards of DQE Holdings LLC and its subsidiaries, including Duquesne Light, a regulated utility in Pittsburgh.
1085392_13_ITEM10_P14_S0	From February 2009 to January 31, 2011 Mr. McMahon was Executive Vice President of Con Edison Inc, a regulatory utility company in New York, and was responsible for regulatory affairs, energy policy, energy efficiency and legal affairs.
1085392_13_ITEM10_P14_S1	From 2003 to 2009 he was President and Chief Executive Officer of Orange and Rockland Utilities, Inc.
1085392_13_ITEM10_P14_S2	Prior to that he served as general counsel for Con Edison.
1085392_13_ITEM10_P14_S3	Mr. McMahon serves on the boards of Puget Energy and PSE as a representative of the Company's Macquarie affiliated investors consistent with the Puget Energy and PSE bylaws, and provides the Puget Energy and PSE boards the benefit of his experience managing and overseeing the legal, regulatory and operational affairs of regulated utilities.
1085392_13_ITEM10_P15_S0	Mary McWilliams , age 64, has been a director on the boards of both Puget Energy and PSE since March 1, 2011.
1085392_13_ITEM10_P15_S1	Ms. McWilliams is currently the Executive Director at Puget Sound Health Alliance, which position she has held since 2008.
1085392_13_ITEM10_P15_S2	She also served as President and Chief Executive Officer at Regence BlueShield from 2000 to 2008.
1085392_13_ITEM10_P15_S3	In addition, Ms. McWilliams serves as Chairman of the board of the Seattle Branch of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco.
1085392_13_ITEM10_P15_S4	Ms. McWilliams s significant experience managing consumer-focused organizations with challenging regulatory and compliance regimes, as well as her extensive knowledge of the western Washington economy generally, are some of the reasons that led to her appointment to the Puget Energy and PSE boards on behalf of the CPPIB.
1085392_13_ITEM10_P16_S0	Herbert Simon , age 69, is a director on the board of PSE, on which he has served since March 2006.
1085392_13_ITEM10_P16_S1	Mr. Simon has been a member of Simon Johnson, L.L.C. (real estate and venture capital projects investment company located in Tacoma, Washington) and its predecessor company since 1985.
1085392_13_ITEM10_P16_S2	In addition, Mr. Simon serves as a Regent at the University of Washington and as a Board member of Acre, the real estate committee for the University of Washington.
1085392_13_ITEM10_P16_S3	Mr. Simon previously served on the Advisory Boards of the University of Washington at Tacoma and its Institute of Technology.
1085392_13_ITEM10_P16_S4	An independent director not affiliated with any of the Company s investors, Mr. Simon s long-standing involvement with the commercial, educational, political and philanthropic leadership of western Washington are among the qualifications supporting his appointment to the PSE board.

1085392_13_ITEM10_P17_S3	In addition, Mr. Trumpy served as Deputy Minister at Ministries of Finance, Environment and Provincial Revenue from 1998 to 2009.
1085392_13_ITEM10_P18_S0	Mr. Trumpy represents the ownership stake in the Company of bcIMC, in accordance with the terms of the Puget Energy and PSE bylaws, and provides the boards the benefit of his significant leadership roles in government and policy-making, among other attributes.

1085392_13_ITEM10_P20_S0	Audit Committee The Puget Energy and PSE Boards of Directors have both established an Audit Committee.
1085392_13_ITEM10_P20_S1	Directors Andrew Chapman, Melanie Dressel, Benjamin Hawkins, David MacMillan, John McMahon and William Ayer are the members of the Audit Committee.
1085392_13_ITEM10_P20_S2	The Board has determined that Andrew Chapman meets the definition of Audit Committee Financial Expert under SEC rules.
1085392_13_ITEM10_P21_S0	therefore, there are no independence standards applicable to either company in connection with the independence of its Audit Committee members.
1085392_13_ITEM10_P22_S0	Changes to the Procedures by which Shareholders may recommend Nominees to the Board of Directors Following the closing of the merger, members of the Boards of Directors of Puget Energy and PSE are nominated and elected in accordance with the provisions of their respective Amended and Restated Bylaws.
1085392_13_ITEM10_P23_S0	Code of Ethics Puget Energy and PSE have adopted a Corporate Ethics and Compliance Code applicable to all directors, officers and employees and a Code of Ethics applicable to the Chief Executive Officer and senior financial officers, which are available on the website www.pugetenergy.com.
1085392_13_ITEM10_P23_S1	If any material provisions of the Corporate Ethics and Compliance Code or the Code of Ethics are waived for the Chief Executive Officer or senior financial officers, or if any substantive changes are made to either code as they relate to any director or executive officer, we will disclose that fact on our website within four business days.
1085392_13_ITEM10_P23_S2	In addition, any other material amendments of these codes will be disclosed.
