1085392_14_ITEM7_P148_S0	Financing Program The Company s external financing requirements principally reflect the cash needs of its construction program, its schedule of maturing debt and certain operational needs.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P148_S1	The Company anticipates refinancing the redemption of bonds or other long-term borrowings with its credit facilities and/or the issuance of new long-term debt.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P148_S2	Access to funds depends upon factors such as Puget Energy s and PSE s credit ratings, prevailing interest rates and investor receptivity to investing in the utility industry, Puget Energy and PSE.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P149_S0	Credit Facilities and Commercial Paper Proceeds from PSE s short-term borrowings and sales of commercial paper are used to provide working capital and the interim funding of utility construction programs.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P149_S1	Puget Energy and PSE continue to have reasonable access to the capital and credit markets.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P149_S2	As of December 31, 2013 and 2012 , PSE had $162.0 million and $181.0 million in short-term debt outstanding, respectively, exclusive of the demand promissory note with Puget Energy.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P149_S3	Outside of the consolidation of PSE s short-term debt, Puget Energy had no short-term debt outstanding in either year as borrowings under its credit facilities are classified as long-term.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P149_S4	PSE s weighted-average interest rate on short-term debt, including borrowing rate, commitment fees and the amortization of debt issuance costs, during 2013 and 2012 was 3.93% , and 6.49% , respectively.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P149_S5	As of December 31, 2013 , PSE and Puget Energy had several committed credit facilities that are described below.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P150_S0	On February 4, 2013, PSE entered into two new unsecured revolving credit facilities and terminated its previous three credit facilities.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P150_S1	The new credit facilities provide, in aggregate, $1.0 billion of short-term liquidity needs.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P150_S2	These facilities consist of a $650.0 million revolving liquidity facility (which includes a liquidity letter of credit facility and a swingline facility) to be used for general corporate purposes, including a backstop to the Company's commercial paper program and a $350.0 million revolving energy hedging facility (which includes an energy hedging letter of credit facility).
1085392_14_ITEM7_P150_S3	The $650.0 million liquidity facility includes a swingline feature allowing same day availability on borrowings up to $75.0 million.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P150_S4	The new credit facilities also have an accordion feature that, upon the banks' approval, would increase the total size of these facilities to $1.450 billion.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P150_S5	The credit agreements for these two replacement credit facilities contain similar terms and conditions and are syndicated among numerous lenders and mature in February 2018.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P150_S6	The credit agreements contain usual and customary affirmative and negative covenants that, among other things, place limitations on PSE's ability to incur additional indebtedness and liens, issue equity, pay dividends, transact with affiliates and make asset dispositions and investments.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P150_S7	The credit agreements also contain a financial covenant of total debt to total capitalization of 65% or less.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P150_S8	PSE certifies its compliance with such covenants to participating banks each quarter.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P150_S9	As of December 31, 2013, PSE was in compliance with all applicable covenants as noted above.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P151_S0	The credit agreements provide PSE with the ability to borrow at different interest rate options.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P151_S1	The credit agreements allow PSE to borrow at the bank's prime rate or to make floating rate advances at the LIBOR plus a spread that is based upon PSE's credit rating.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P151_S2	PSE must pay a commitment fee on the unused portion of the credit facilities.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P151_S3	The spreads and the commitment fee depend on PSE's credit ratings.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P151_S4	As of the date of this report, the spread to the LIBOR is 1.25% and the commitment fee is 0.175%.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P152_S0	As of December 31, 2013, no amount was drawn and outstanding under PSE s $650.0 million liquidity facility.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P152_S1	One letter of credit in the amount of $3.0 million in support of contracts was outstanding under the facility, and $162.0 million was outstanding under the commercial paper program.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P152_S2	One letter of credit in the amount of $1.0 million was outstanding under the $350.0 million facility supporting energy hedging.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P153_S0	On June 1, 2006, PSE entered into a revolving credit facility with Puget Energy, in the form of a credit agreement and a Demand Promissory Note (Note) pursuant to which PSE may borrow up to $30.0 million from Puget Energy subject to approval by Puget Energy.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P153_S1	Under the terms of the Note, PSE pays interest on the outstanding borrowings based on the lower of the weighted-average interest rates of PSE s outstanding commercial paper interest rate or PSE s senior unsecured revolving credit facility.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P153_S2	Absent such borrowings, interest is charged at one-month LIBOR plus 0.25%.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P153_S3	At December 31, 2013 , the outstanding balance of the Note was $29.6 million.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P153_S4	The outstanding balance and the related interest under the Note are eliminated by Puget Energy upon consolidation of PSE s financial statements.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P154_S0	At December 31, 2013, Puget Energy maintained an $800.0 million five-year revolving senior secured credit facility.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P154_S1	The Puget Energy revolving senior secured credit facility also has an accordion feature that, upon the bank s approval, would increase the size of the facility to $1.3 billion.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P155_S0	The five-year revolving senior secured credit facility contains usual and customary affirmative and negative covenants.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P155_S1	The agreement also contains two financial covenants based on the following ratios: Group Funds From Operations (FFO) Coverage Ratio and Maximum Leverage Ratio, as defined in the agreement governing the senior secured credit facility.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P155_S2	As of December 31, 2013 , Puget Energy was in compliance with all applicable covenants as noted above.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P156_S0	The revolving senior secured credit facility provides Puget Energy the ability to borrow at different interest rate options and includes variable fee levels.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P156_S1	Interest rates may be based on the bank's prime rate or LIBOR, plus a spread based on Puget Energy's credit ratings.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P157_S0	Puget Energy must pay a commitment fee on the unused portion of the facility.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P157_S1	As of December 31, 2013 , $ 299.0 million was drawn and outstanding under the facility, the spread over LIBOR was 1.75% and the commitment fee was 0.30%.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P158_S0	Puget Energy entered into interest rate swap contracts to manage the interest rate risk associated with the credit facility (see Note 7 and the "Interest Rate Risk" section in Item 3).
1085392_14_ITEM7_P159_S0	The payment of dividends by PSE to Puget Energy is restricted by provisions of certain covenants applicable to long-term debt contained in PSE s electric and natural gas mortgage indentures.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P159_S1	At December 31, 2013 , approximately $469.6 million of unrestricted retained earnings was available for the payment of dividends under the most restrictive mortgage indenture covenant.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P160_S0	Beginning February 6, 2009, pursuant to the terms of the Washington Commission merger order, PSE may not declare or pay dividends if PSE s common equity ratio, calculated on a regulatory basis, is 44.0% or below except to the extent a lower equity ratio is ordered by the Washington Commission.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P160_S1	Also, pursuant to the merger order, PSE may not declare or make any distribution unless on the date of distribution PSE s corporate credit/issuer rating is investment grade, or, if its credit ratings are below investment grade, PSE s ratio of EBITDA to interest expense for the most recently ended four fiscal quarter periods prior to such date is equal to or greater than 3 to one.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P160_S2	The common equity ratio, calculated on a regulatory basis, was 47.4% at December 31, 2013 and the EBITDA to interest expense was 4.4 to one for the 12 months then ended.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P160_S3	PSE s ability to pay dividends is also limited by the terms of its credit facilities, pursuant to which PSE is not permitted to pay dividends during any Event of Default (as defined in the facilities), or if the payment of dividends would result in an Event of Default, such as failure to comply with certain financial covenants.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P160_S4	Puget Energy s ability to pay dividends is also limited by the merger order issued by the Washington Commission as well as by the terms of its credit facility.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P160_S5	Pursuant to the merger order, Puget Energy may not declare or make a distribution unless on such date Puget Energy s ratio of consolidated EBITDA to consolidated interest expense for the four most recently ended fiscal quarters prior to such date is equal to or greater than 2 to one.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P160_S6	At December 31, 2013 , the EBITDA to interest expense was 2.9 to one for the 12 months then ended.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P160_S7	At December 31, 2013 , the Company was in compliance with all applicable covenants, including those pertaining to the payment of dividends.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P161_S0	Debt Restrictive Covenants The type and amount of future long-term financings for PSE may be limited by provisions in PSE's electric and natural gas mortgage indentures.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P161_S1	PSE s ability to issue additional secured debt may also be limited by certain restrictions contained in its electric and natural gas mortgage indentures.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P161_S2	Under the most restrictive tests, at December 31, 2013 , PSE could issue:
1085392_14_ITEM7_P162_S0	Approximately $319.0 million of additional first mortgage bonds under PSE s natural gas mortgage indenture based on approximately $531.7 million of gas bondable property available for issuance, subject to a combined gas and electric interest coverage test of 1.75 times net earnings available for interest and a gas interest coverage test of 2.0 times net earnings available for interest (as defined in the natural gas utility mortgage), both of which PSE exceeded at December 31, 2013 .
1085392_14_ITEM7_P162_S1	At December 31, 2013 , PSE had approximately $6.9 billion in electric and natural gas ratebase to support the interest coverage ratio limitation test for net earnings available for interest.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P163_S0	Upon approval of the merger in 2009, the Company was required to refinance its debt in place at the time of the merger.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P163_S1	The Company has met this refinancing requirement as of December 31, 2013 .
1085392_14_ITEM7_P164_S0	Shelf Registrations and Long-Term Debt Activity Puget Sound Energy.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P164_S1	PSE has in effect a shelf registration statement under which it may issue, from time to time, up to $800 million aggregate principal amount of senior notes secured by pledged first mortgage bonds.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P164_S2	The Company remains subject to the restrictions of PSE s indentures and credit agreements on the amount of first mortgage bonds that PSE may issue.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P164_S3	On May 23, 2013, PSE refinanced $161.9 million of its Pollution Control Revenue Refunding Bonds to a lower weighted average interest rate from 5.01% to 3.91%.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P164_S4	The bonds will mature on March 1, 2031.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P164_S5	On or after March 1, 2023, the Company may elect to call the bonds at a redemption price of 100% of the principal amount thereof, without premium, plus accrued interest, if any, to the redemption date.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P165_S0	And Estimates The preparation of financial statements in conformity with GAAP requires that management apply accounting policies and make estimates and assumptions that affect results of operations and the reported amounts of assets and liabilities in the financial statements.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P165_S1	The following accounting policies represent those that management believes are particularly important to the financial statements and that require the use of estimates, assumptions and judgment to describe matters that are inherently uncertain.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P166_S0	Operating utility revenue is recognized when the basis of service is rendered, which includes estimated unbilled revenue.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P167_S0	PSE's estimate of unbilled revenue is based on a calculation using meter readings from its automated meter reading (AMR) system.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P167_S1	The estimate calculates unbilled usage at the end of each month as the difference between the customer meter readings on the last day of the month and the last customer meter readings billed.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P167_S2	The unbilled usage is then priced at published rates for each schedule to estimate the unbilled revenues by customer.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P168_S0	Beginning July 1, 2013, PSE's electric and gas operations contain a revenue decoupling mechanism under which PSE's actual energy delivery revenues related to electric transmission and distribution, gas operations and general administrative costs are compared with authorized revenues allowed under the mechanism.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P168_S1	Any differences are deferred to a regulatory asset for under recovery or regulatory liability for over recovery.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P168_S2	Revenues associated with power costs under the PCA mechanism and PGA rates are excluded from the decoupling mechanism.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P169_S0	As a regulated entity of the Washington Commission and the FERC, PSE prepares its financial statements in accordance with the provisions of ASC 980, Regulated Operations (ASC 980).
1085392_14_ITEM7_P170_S0	The application of ASC 980 results in differences in the timing and recognition of certain revenue and expenses in comparison with businesses in other industries.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P171_S0	The rates that are charged by PSE to its customers are based on cost base regulation reviewed and approved by the Washington Commission and the FERC.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P171_S1	Under the authority of these commissions, PSE has recorded certain regulatory assets and liabilities at December 31, 2013 in the amount of $895.7 million and $697.5 million , respectively, and regulatory assets and liabilities at December 31, 2012 of $936.2 million and $628.9 million , respectively.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P171_S2	Such amounts are amortized through a corresponding liability or asset account, respectively, with no impact to earnings.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P172_S0	PSE expects to fully recover its regulatory assets and liabilities through its rates.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P172_S1	If future recovery of costs ceases to be probable, PSE would be required to write off these regulatory assets and liabilities.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P172_S2	In addition, if PSE determines that it no longer meets the criteria for continued application of ASC 980, PSE could be required to write off its regulatory assets and liabilities related to those operations not meeting ASC 980 requirements.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P173_S0	Also encompassed by regulatory accounting and subject to ASC 980 are the PCA and PGA mechanisms.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P173_S1	The PCA and PGA mechanisms mitigate the impact of commodity price volatility upon the Company and are approved by the Washington Commission.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P174_S0	The PCA mechanism provides for a sharing of costs that vary from baseline rates over a graduated scale.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P174_S1	For further discussion regarding the PCA mechanism, see Electric Regulation and Rates within Item 1.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P175_S0	Business Regulation and Rates of this report.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P176_S0	PSE expects to fully recover these regulatory assets through its rates.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P176_S1	However, both mechanisms are subject to regulatory review and approval by the Washington Commission on a periodic basis.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P177_S0	On February 6, 2009, Puget Holdings completed its merger with Puget Energy.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P177_S1	Puget Energy remeasured the carrying amount of all its assets and liabilities to fair value, which resulted in recognition of approximately $1.7 billion in goodwill.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P178_S0	ASC 350, Intangibles - Goodwill and Other, (ASC 350) requires that goodwill be tested for impairment at the reporting unit level on an annual basis and between annual tests if an event occurs or circumstances change that would more likely than not reduce the fair value of a reporting unit below its carrying value.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P178_S1	These events or circumstances could include a significant change in the Company s business or regulatory outlook, legal factors, a sale or disposition of a significant portion of a reporting unit or significant changes in the financial markets which could influence the Company s access to capital and interest rates.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P179_S0	Application of the goodwill impairment test requires judgment, including the identification of reporting units, assignment of assets and liabilities to reporting units, assignment of goodwill to reporting units and the determination of the fair value of the reporting units.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P180_S0	Management has determined Puget Energy has only one reporting unit.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P181_S0	The goodwill recorded by Puget Energy represents the potential long-term return to the Company s investors.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P182_S0	Goodwill is tested for impairment annually using a two-step process.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P182_S1	The first step compares the carrying amount of the reporting unit with its fair value, with a carrying value higher than fair value indicating potential impairment.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P182_S2	If the first step test fails, the second step is performed.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P182_S3	This would entail a full valuation of Puget Energy s assets and liabilities and comparing the valuation to its carrying amounts, with the aggregate difference indicating the amount of impairment.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P183_S0	Goodwill of a reporting unit is required to be tested for impairment on an interim basis if an event occurs or circumstances change that would cause the fair value of a reporting unit to fall below its carrying amount.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P183_S1	Puget Energy conducted its most recent annual impairment test as of October 1, 2013 .
1085392_14_ITEM7_P184_S0	The fair value of Puget Energy s reporting unit was estimated using the weighted-averages from an income valuation method, or discounted cash flow method, and a market valuation approach.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P184_S1	These valuations required significant judgments, including: (1) estimation of future cash flows, which is dependent on internal forecasts, (2) estimation of the long-term rate of growth for Puget Energy s business, (3) estimation of the useful life over which cash flows will occur, (4) the selection of utility holding companies determined to be comparable to Puget Energy, and (5) the determination of an appropriate weighted-average cost of capital or discount rate.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P184_S2	Management estimated the fair value of Puget Energy s equity to be approximately $4.3 billion at the October 1, 2013 measurement date for the annual test of goodwill impairment.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P184_S3	The carrying value of Puget Energy s equity was approximately $3.5 billion with the excess of the fair value over the carrying value representing 21.0% or $743.0 million.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P184_S4	The income approach and the market approach valuations resulted in Puget Energy equity values of $4.2 billion and $4.4 billion, respectively.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P184_S5	The result of the income approach was very sensitive to long-term cash flow growth rates applicable to periods beyond management s five-year business plan and financial forecast period and the weighted-average cost of capital assumptions of 2.7% and 7.0%, respectively.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P184_S6	The following table summarizes the results of the income valuation method:
1085392_14_ITEM7_P185_S0	ASC 815, Derivatives and Hedging (ASC 815), requires that all contracts considered to be derivative instruments be recorded on the balance sheet at their fair value unless the contracts qualify for an exception.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P185_S1	The Company enters into derivative contracts to manage its energy resource portfolio and interest rate exposure including forward physical and financial contracts and swaps.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P185_S2	Some of PSE s physical electric supply contracts qualify for the NPNS exception to derivative accounting rules.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P186_S0	Generally, NPNS applies to contracts with creditworthy counterparties, for which physical delivery is probable and in quantities that will be used in the normal course of business.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P186_S1	Power purchases designated as NPNS must meet additional criteria to determine if the transaction is within PSE s forecasted load requirements and if the counterparty owns or controls energy resources within the western region to allow for physical delivery of the energy.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P187_S0	PSE may enter into financial fixed contracts to economically hedge the variability of certain index-based contracts.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P187_S1	Those contracts that do not meet the NPNS exception are marked-to-market to current earnings in the statements of income.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P188_S0	Natural gas derivative contracts qualify for deferral under ASC 980 due to the PGA mechanism.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P189_S0	On July 1, 2009, Puget Energy and PSE elected to de-designate all energy related derivative contracts previously recorded as cash flow hedges for the purpose of simplifying their financial reporting.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P189_S1	The contracts that were de-designated related to physical electric supply contracts and natural gas swap contracts used to fix the price of natural gas for electric generation.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P190_S0	contracts and contracts initiated after such date, all mark-to-market adjustments are recognized through earnings.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P190_S1	The amount previously recorded in accumulated OCI is transferred to earnings in the same period or periods during which the hedged transaction affects earnings or sooner if management determines that the forecasted transaction is probable of not occurring.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P190_S2	As a result, the Company will continue to experience the earnings impact of these reversals from OCI in future periods.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P191_S0	PSE values derivative instruments based on daily quoted prices from an independent external pricing service.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P191_S1	The Company regularly confirms the validity of pricing service quoted prices (e.g. Level 2 in the fair value hierarchy) used to value commodity contracts to the actual prices of commodity contracts entered into during the most recent quarter.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P191_S2	When external quoted market prices are not available for derivative contracts, PSE uses a valuation model that uses volatility assumptions relating to future energy prices based on specific energy markets and utilizes externally available forward market price curves.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P192_S0	All derivative instruments are sensitive to market price fluctuations that can occur on a daily basis.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P193_S0	The Company is focused on commodity price exposure and risks associated with volumetric variability in the natural gas and electric portfolios.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P193_S1	It is not engaged in the business of assuming risk for the purpose of speculative trading.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P193_S2	The Company economically hedges open natural gas and electric positions to reduce both the portfolio risk and the volatility risk in prices.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P193_S3	The exposure position is determined by using a probabilistic risk system that models 250 simulations of how the Company s natural gas and power portfolios will perform under various weather, hydrological and unit performance conditions.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P194_S0	The Company may enter into swap instruments or other financial derivative instruments to manage the interest rate risk associated with its long-term debt financing and debt instruments.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P194_S1	As of December 31, 2013 , Puget Energy had interest rate swap contracts outstanding related to its long-term debt.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P194_S2	For additional information, see Item 7A and Note 10 to the consolidated financial statements included in Item 8 of this report.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P195_S0	ASC 820, Fair Value Measurements and Disclosures (ASC 820), defines fair value as the price that would be received to sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability in an orderly transaction between market participants at the measurement date (exit price).
1085392_14_ITEM7_P195_S1	However, as permitted under ASC 820, the Company utilizes a mid-market pricing convention (the mid-point price between bid and ask prices) as a practical expedient for valuing the majority of its assets and liabilities measured and reported at fair value.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P195_S2	The Company utilizes market data or assumptions that market participants would use in pricing the asset or liability, including assumptions about risk and the risks inherent in the inputs to the valuation technique.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P195_S3	These inputs can be readily observable, market corroborated or generally unobservable.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P196_S0	The Company primarily applies the market approach for recurring fair value measurements as it believes that this approach is used by market participants for these types of assets and liabilities.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P196_S1	Accordingly, the Company utilizes valuation techniques that maximize the use of observable inputs and minimize the use of unobservable inputs.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P196_S2	For further discussion on market risk, see Item 7A of this report.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P197_S0	PSE has a qualified defined benefit pension plan covering substantially all employees of PSE.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P197_S1	PSE recognized qualified pension expense of $22.4 million , $14.8 million and $6.6 million for the years ended December 31, 2013 , 2012 and 2011 , respectively.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P197_S2	Of these amounts, approximately 60.8%, 57.2% and 61.0% were included in utility operations and maintenance expense in 2013 , 2012 and 2011 , respectively, and the remaining amounts were capitalized.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P197_S3	For the years ended December 31, 2013 and 2012 , Puget Energy recognized incremental qualified pension income of $16.5 million and 9.3 million , respectively.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P197_S4	In 2014 , it is expected that PSE and Puget Energy will recognize pension expense of $14.0 million and incremental qualified pension income of $12.6 million, respectively.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P198_S0	PSE has a Supplemental Executive Retirement Plan (SERP).
1085392_14_ITEM7_P198_S1	PSE recognized pension and other postretirement benefit expenses of $5.7 million , $5.0 million and $5.2 million for the years ended December 31, 2013 , 2012 and 2011 , respectively.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P198_S2	For the years ended December 31, 2013 and 2012 , Puget Energy recognized incremental income of $0.7 million and $1.0 million , respectively.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P198_S3	In 2014 , it is expected that PSE and Puget Energy will recognize pension expense of $4.9 million and incremental pension income of $0.5 million, respectively.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P198_S4	PSE has other limited postretirement benefit plans.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P198_S5	PSE recognized expense of $0.1 million , $0.3 million and $0.1 million for the years ended December 31, 2013 , 2012 and 2011 , respectively.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P198_S6	For the years ended December 31, 2013 and 2012 , Puget Energy recognized incremental expense of $0.3 million and $0.2 million , respectively.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P198_S7	In 2014 , it is expected that PSE and Puget Energy will recognize income of $0.3 million and incremental expense of $0.3 million, respectively.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P198_S8	The Company s pension and other postretirement benefits income or expense depend on several factors and assumptions, including plan design, timing and amount of cash contributions to the plan, earnings on plan assets, discount rate, expected long-term rate of return, mortality and health care cost trends.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P198_S9	Changes in any of these factors or assumptions will affect the amount of income or expense that the Company records in its financial statements in future years and its projected benefit obligation.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P199_S0	The Company has selected an expected return on plan assets based on a historical analysis of rates of return and the Company s investment mix, market conditions, inflation and other factors.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P199_S1	The Company s accounting policy for calculating the market-related value of assets is based on a five-year smoothing of asset gains or losses measured from the expected return on market-related assets.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P199_S2	This is a calculated value that recognizes changes in fair value in a systematic and rational manner over five years.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P199_S3	The same manner of calculating market-related value is used for all classes of assets, and is applied consistently from year to year.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P199_S4	As required by merger accounting rules, market-related value was reset to market value effective with the merger.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P199_S5	During 2013 , the Company made a cash contribution of $20.4 million to the qualified defined benefit plan.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P199_S6	Management is closely monitoring the funding status of its qualified pension plan given the recent volatility of the financial markets.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P200_S0	2013 and 2012 , the Company s qualified pension plan was $42.4 million over-funded and $85.1 million underfunded as measured under GAAP, or 107.4% and 86.2% funded respectively.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P200_S1	As of January 1, 2014 , the plan's estimated funded ratio, as calculated under guidelines from The Pension Protection Act of 2006 and considering temporary interest rate relief measures approved by Congress, was more than 100%.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P200_S2	The aggregate expected contributions and payments by the Company to fund the retirement plan, SERP and other postretirement plans for the year ending December 31, 2014 are expected to be at least $12.0 million , $4.0 million and $0.4 million , respectively.
1085392_14_ITEM7_P201_S0	The discount rate used in accounting for pension and other benefit obligations increased from 4.15% in 2012 to 5.10% in 2013 .
1085392_14_ITEM7_P201_S1	The discount rate used in accounting for pension and other benefit expense decreased from 4.75% in 2012 to 4.15% in 2013 .
1085392_14_ITEM7_P201_S2	The rate of return on plan assets for qualified pension benefits in 2013 remained unchanged at 2012 level, or 7.75% .
1085392_14_ITEM7_P201_S3	The rate of return on plan assets for other benefits decreased from 7.50% in 2012 to 6.90% in 2013 .

1085392_14_ITEM7_P203_S0	Recently Adopted Accounting Pronouncements For the discussion of recently adopted accounting pronouncements, see Note 2 to the consolidated financial statements included in Item 8 of this report.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P0_S0	Energy Portfolio Management PSE maintains energy risk policies and procedures to manage commodity and volatility risks and the related effects on credit, tax, accounting, financing and liquidity.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P0_S1	PSE s Energy Management Committee establishes PSE s risk management policies and procedures and monitors compliance.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P0_S2	The Energy Management Committee is comprised of certain PSE officers and is overseen by the PSE Board of Directors.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P1_S0	PSE is focused on the commodity price exposure and risks associated with volumetric variability in the natural gas and electric portfolios and related effects noted above.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P1_S1	It is not engaged in the business of assuming risk for the purpose of speculative trading.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P1_S2	PSE hedges open gas and electric positions to reduce both the portfolio risk and the volatility risk in prices.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P1_S3	The exposure position is determined by using a probabilistic risk system that models 250 simulations of how PSE s natural gas and power portfolios will perform under various weather, hydroelectric and unit performance conditions.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P1_S4	The objectives of the hedging strategy are to:
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P2_S0	Meet the credit, liquidity, financing, tax and accounting requirements of PSE.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P3_S0	ASC 815 requires a significant amount of disclosure regarding PSE s derivative activities and the nature of their impact on PSE s financial position, financial performance and cash flows.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P3_S1	The information in this Item 7A should serve as an accompaniment to Management's Discussion and Analysis and Note 9 to the consolidated financial statements included in Items 7 and 8 of this report, respectively.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P4_S0	PSE employs various energy portfolio optimization strategies, but is not in the business of assuming risk for the purpose of realizing speculative trading revenue.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P4_S1	The nature of serving regulated electric customers with its portfolio of owned and contracted electric generation resources exposes PSE and its customers to some volumetric and commodity price risks within the sharing mechanism of the PCA.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P4_S2	PSE s natural gas retail customers are served by natural gas purchase contracts which expose PSE s customers to commodity price risks through the PGA mechanism.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P4_S3	All purchased natural gas costs are recovered through customer rates with no direct impact on PSE.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P4_S4	Therefore, wholesale market transactions and related hedging strategies are focused on reducing costs and risks where feasible, thus reducing volatility in costs in the portfolio.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P5_S0	PSE s energy risk portfolio management function monitors and manages these risks using analytical models and tools.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P5_S1	In order to manage risks effectively, PSE enters into forward physical electric and natural gas purchase and sale agreements, fixed-for-floating swap contracts, and commodity call/put options.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P5_S2	The forward physical electric contracts are both fixed and variable (at index), while the physical natural gas contracts are variable with investment grade counterparties that do not require collateral calls on the contracts.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P6_S0	To fix the price of wholesale electricity and natural gas, PSE may enter into fixed-for-floating swap (financial) contracts with various counterparties.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P6_S1	PSE also utilizes natural gas call and put options as an additional hedging instrument to increase the hedging portfolio's flexibility to react to commodity price fluctuations.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P7_S0	On July 1, 2009, the Company elected to de-designate all energy related derivative contracts previously recorded as cash flow hedges for the purpose of simplifying its financial reporting.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P7_S1	The contracts that were de-designated related to physical electric supply contracts and natural gas swap contracts to fix the price of natural gas for electric generation.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P7_S2	For these contracts and for contracts initiated after such date, all mark-to-market adjustments are recognized through earnings.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P7_S3	The amount previously recorded in accumulated OCI is transferred to earnings in the same period(s) during which the hedged transaction affects earnings or sooner if management determines that the forecasted transaction is probable of not occurring.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P7_S4	As a result, the Company will continue to experience the earnings impact of these reversals from OCI in future periods.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P8_S0	The following table presents the fair value of the Company s energy derivatives instruments that do not meet the NPNS exception:
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P9_S0	For further details regarding both the fair value of derivative instruments and the impacts such instruments have on current period earnings and OCI (for cash flow hedges), see Notes 9 and 10 to the consolidated financial statements.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P10_S0	At December 31, 2013 , the Company had total assets of $8.1 million and total liabilities of $35.7 million related to derivative contracts used to hedge the supply and cost of natural gas to serve natural gas customers.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P10_S1	All fair value adjustments of derivatives relating to the natural gas business have been reclassified to a deferred account in accordance with ASC 980, "Regulated Operations", due to the PGA mechanism.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P10_S2	All increases and decreases in the cost of natural gas supply are passed on to customers with the PGA mechanism.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P10_S3	As the gains and losses on the hedges are realized in future periods, they will be recorded as natural gas costs under the PGA mechanism.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P10_S4	A hypothetical 10.0% increase or decrease in market prices of natural gas and electricity would change the fair value of the Company s derivative contracts by $43.1 million , with an after-tax impact of $28.0 million .

1085392_14_ITEM7A_P12_S0	______________ Prices provided by external pricing service, which utilizes broker quotes and pricing models.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P13_S0	Contingent Features and Counterparty Credit Risk PSE is exposed to credit risk primarily through buying and selling electricity and natural gas to serve customers.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P14_S0	Credit risk is the potential loss resulting from a counterparty s non-performance under an agreement.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P14_S1	PSE manages credit risk with policies and procedures for, among other things, counterparty analysis and measurement, monitoring and mitigation of exposure.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P14_S2	Where deemed appropriate, and when allowed under the terms of the agreements, PSE may request collateral or other security from its counterparties to mitigate the potential credit default losses.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P14_S3	Criteria employed in this decision include, among other things, the perceived creditworthiness of the counterparty and the expected credit exposure.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P15_S0	As of December 31, 2013 , PSE held approximately $1.1 billion in standby letters of credit or limited parental guarantees, and had 20 counterparties with unlimited parental guarantees, in support of various electric and natural gas transactions.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P16_S0	It is possible that volatility in energy commodity prices could cause PSE to have material credit risk exposures with one or more counterparties.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P16_S1	If such counterparties fail to perform their obligations under one or more agreements, PSE could suffer a material financial loss.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P16_S2	As of December 31, 2013 , approximately 67.0% of PSE s energy and natural gas portfolio exposure, including NPNS transactions, is with counterparties that are rated at least investment grade by the major rating agencies while 33.0% are either rated below investment grade or are not rated by rating agencies.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P16_S3	PSE assesses credit risk internally for counterparties that are not rated.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P16_S4	PSE has entered into commodity master arrangements with its counterparties to mitigate credit exposure to those counterparties.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P16_S5	PSE generally enters into the following master arrangements: (1) WSPP, Inc. (WSPP) agreements which standardize physical power contracts; (2) International Swaps and Derivatives Association (ISDA) agreements which standardize financial gas and electric contracts; and (3) North American Energy Standards Board (NAESB) agreements which standardize physical gas contracts.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P16_S6	PSE believes that such agreements reduce credit risk exposure because such agreements provide for the netting and offsetting of monthly payments as well as right of set-off in the event of counterparty default.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P17_S0	changes by external rating agencies or have changes in ownership.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P18_S0	Counterparty credit risk impacts PSE s decisions on derivative accounting treatment.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P18_S1	A counterparty may have a deterioration of credit below investment grade, potentially indicating that it is no longer probable that it will fulfill its obligations under a contract (e.g., make a physical delivery upon the contract's maturity).
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P19_S0	ASC 815 specifies the requirements for derivative contracts to qualify for the NPNS scope exception.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P20_S0	When performance is no longer probable, PSE records the fair value of the contract on the balance sheet with the corresponding amount recorded in the statements of income.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P21_S0	Accumulated OCI of the cash flow hedge is also impacted by a counterparty s deterioration of credit under ASC 815 guidelines.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P21_S1	If a forecasted transaction associated with the cash flow hedge is probable of not occurring, PSE will reclassify the amounts deferred in accumulated OCI into earnings.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P21_S2	Should a counterparty file for bankruptcy, which would be considered a default under master arrangements, PSE may terminate related contracts.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P21_S3	Derivative accounting entries previously recorded would be reversed in the financial statements.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P22_S0	PSE would compute any terminations receivable or payable, based on the terms of existing master agreements.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P23_S0	The Company computes credit reserves at a master agreement level by counterparty (i.e., WSPP, ISDA or NAESB).
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P23_S1	The Company considers external credit ratings and market factors, such as credit default swaps and bond spreads, in determination of reserves.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P23_S2	The Company recognizes that external ratings may not always reflect how a market participant perceives a counterparty s risk of default.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P23_S3	The Company uses both default factors published by Standard Poor s and factors derived through analysis of market risk, which reflect the application of an industry standard recovery rate.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P24_S0	The Company selects a default factor by counterparty at an aggregate master agreement level based on a weighted-average default tenor for that counterparty s deals.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P24_S1	The default tenor is used by weighting the fair value and contract tenors for all deals for each counterparty and arriving at an average value.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P24_S2	The default factor used is dependent upon whether the counterparty is in a net asset or a net liability position after applying the master agreement levels.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P25_S0	The Company applies the counterparty s default factor to compute credit reserves for counterparties that are in a net asset position.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P25_S1	The Company calculates a non-performance risk on its derivative liabilities by using its estimated incremental borrowing rate over the risk-free rate.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P25_S2	The fair value of derivatives includes the impact of credit and non-performance reserves.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P25_S3	As of December 31, 2013 , the Company was in a net liability position with the majority of its counterparties, therefore the default factors of counterparties did not have a significant impact on reserves for the year.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P26_S0	As of December 31, 2013 , PSE has posted a $1.0 million letter of credit as a condition of transacting on a physical energy exchange and clearinghouse in Canada.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P26_S1	PSE did not trigger any collateral requirements with any of its counterparties, nor were any of PSE s counterparties required to post additional collateral resulting from credit rating downgrades.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P27_S0	Interest Rate Risk The Company believes its interest rate risk primarily relates to the use of short-term debt instruments, variable rate leases and anticipated long-term debt financing needed to fund capital requirements.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P27_S1	The Company manages its interest rate risk through the issuance of mostly fixed-rate debt of various maturities.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P27_S2	The Company utilizes internal cash from operations, borrowings under its commercial paper program, and its credit facilities to meet short-term funding needs.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P27_S3	Short-term obligations are commonly refinanced with fixed-rate bonds or notes when needed and when interest rates are considered favorable.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P27_S4	The following table presents the carrying value and fair value of Puget Energy and Puget Sound Energy's debt instruments:
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P28_S0	For further details regarding Puget Energy and Puget Sound Energy debt instruments, see Notes 6 and 10 under Item 8.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P29_S0	From time to time, PSE may enter into treasury locks or forward starting swap contracts to hedge interest rate exposure related to an anticipated debt issuance.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P29_S1	The ending balance in OCI related to the forward starting swaps and previously settled treasury lock contracts at December 31, 2013 was a net loss of $6.3 million after tax and accumulated amortization.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P29_S2	This compares to an after-tax loss of $6.6 million in OCI as of December 31, 2012 .
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P30_S0	All financial hedge contracts of this type are reviewed by an officer, presented to the Board of Directors, or a committee of the Board, as applicable and are approved prior to execution.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P30_S1	PSE had no treasury locks or forward starting swap contracts outstanding at December 31, 2013 .
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P30_S2	The Company may also enter into swap instruments or other financial hedge instruments to manage the interest rate risk associated with these debts.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P30_S3	As of December 31, 2013 , Puget Energy had two interest rate swap contracts outstanding and PSE did not have any outstanding interest rate swap instruments.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P31_S0	which the hedged transaction affects earnings.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P31_S1	During 2013 , Puget Energy reclassified $0.7 million in losses from accumulated OCI into earnings.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P31_S2	This was the result of paying down $135.0 million on Puget Energy's revolving senior secured credit facility, which caused the related forecasted transactions (i.e., future interest payments associated with the debt pay down) to become remote of occurring.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P31_S3	At December 31, 2013 , the fair value of the interest rate swaps was a $13.2 million pre-tax loss.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P31_S4	The fair value considers the risk of Puget Energy s non-performance by using its incremental borrowing rate on unsecured debt over the risk-free rate in the valuation estimate.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P31_S5	The ending balance in OCI includes a loss of $0.14 million pre-tax, and $0.09 million after tax, related to the interest rate swaps previously designated as cash flow hedge.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P32_S0	Currently, all changes in market value are recorded in earnings.
1085392_14_ITEM7A_P32_S1	A hypothetical 10% increase or decrease in interest rates would change the fair value of Puget Energy's interest rate swaps by $1.1 million .

1085392_14_ITEM8_P2_S0	PUGET ENERGY, INC. AND PUGET SOUND ENERGY, INC. Puget Energy, Inc. and Puget Sound Energy, Inc. (the Company) management assumes accountability for maintaining compliance with our established financial accounting policies and for reporting our results with objectivity and integrity.
1085392_14_ITEM8_P2_S1	The Company believes it is essential for investors and other users of the consolidated financial statements to have confidence that the financial information we provide is timely, complete, relevant and accurate.
1085392_14_ITEM8_P2_S2	Management is also responsible to present fairly Puget Energy s and Puget Sound Energy s consolidated financial statements, prepared in accordance with GAAP.
1085392_14_ITEM8_P3_S0	Management, with oversight of the Board of Directors, established and maintains a strong ethical climate under the guidance of our Corporate Ethics and Compliance Program so that our affairs are conducted to high standards of proper personal and corporate conduct.
1085392_14_ITEM8_P3_S1	Management also established an internal control system that provides reasonable assurance as to the integrity and accuracy of the consolidated financial statements.
1085392_14_ITEM8_P3_S2	These policies and practices reflect corporate governance initiatives designed to ensure the integrity and independence of our financial reporting processes including:
1085392_14_ITEM8_P4_S0	Our Board has adopted clear corporate governance guidelines.
1085392_14_ITEM8_P5_S0	With the exception of the President and Chief Executive Officer, the Board members are independent of management.
1085392_14_ITEM8_P6_S0	All members of our key Board committees the Audit Committee, the Compensation and Leadership Development Committee and the Governance and Public Affairs Committee are independent of management.
1085392_14_ITEM8_P7_S0	The non-management members of our Board meet regularly without the presence of Puget Energy and Puget Sound Energy management.
1085392_14_ITEM8_P8_S0	The Charters of our Board committees clearly establish their respective roles and responsibilities.
1085392_14_ITEM8_P9_S0	The Company has adopted a Corporate Ethics and Compliance Code with a hotline (through an independent third party) available to all employees, and our Audit Committee has procedures in place for the anonymous submission of employee complaints on accounting, internal accounting controls or auditing matters.
1085392_14_ITEM8_P9_S1	The Compliance Program is led by the Chief Ethics and Compliance Officer of the Company.
1085392_14_ITEM8_P10_S0	Our internal audit control function maintains critical oversight over the key areas of our business and financial processes and controls, and reports directly to our Board Audit Committee.
1085392_14_ITEM8_P10_S1	Management is confident that the internal control structure is operating effectively and will allow the Company to meet the requirements under Section 404 of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002.
1085392_14_ITEM8_P10_S2	PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP, our independent registered public accounting firm, reports directly to the Audit Committee of the Board of Directors.
1085392_14_ITEM8_P10_S3	PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP s accompanying report on our consolidated financial statements is based on its audit conducted in accordance with auditing standards prescribed by the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board, including a review of our internal control structure for purposes of designing their audit procedures.
1085392_14_ITEM8_P10_S4	Our independent registered accounting firm has reported on the effectiveness of our internal control over financial reporting as required under Section 404 of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002.
1085392_14_ITEM8_P10_S5	We are committed to improving shareholder value and accept our fiduciary oversight responsibilities.
1085392_14_ITEM8_P10_S6	We are dedicated to ensuring that our high standards of financial accounting and reporting as well as our underlying system of internal controls are maintained.
1085392_14_ITEM8_P10_S7	Our culture demands integrity and we have confidence in our processes, our internal controls and our people, who are objective in their responsibilities and who operate under a high level of ethical standards.
1085392_14_ITEM8_P11_S0	To the Board of Directors and Shareholder of Puget Energy, Inc.
1085392_14_ITEM8_P12_S0	In our opinion, the consolidated financial statements listed in the accompanying index present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position of Puget Energy, Inc. and its subsidiaries at December 31, 2013 and 2012, and the results of their operations and their cash flows for each of the three years in the period ended December 31, 2013 in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America.
1085392_14_ITEM8_P12_S1	In addition, in our opinion, the financial statement schedules listed in the accompanying index present fairly, in all material respects, the information set forth therein when read in conjunction with the related consolidated financial statements.
1085392_14_ITEM8_P12_S2	Also in our opinion, the Company maintained, in all material respects, effective internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2013, based on criteria established in Internal Control - Integrated Framework (1992) issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (COSO).
1085392_14_ITEM8_P12_S3	The Company's management is responsible for these financial statements and financial statement schedules, for maintaining effective internal control over financial reporting and for its assessment of the effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting, included in Management's Report on Internal Control on Financial Reporting appearing under Item 9A.
1085392_14_ITEM8_P12_S4	Our responsibility is to express opinions on these financial statements, on the financial statement schedules, and on the Company's internal control over financial reporting based on our integrated audits.
1085392_14_ITEM8_P12_S5	We conducted our audits in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
1085392_14_ITEM8_P12_S6	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audits to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements are free of material misstatement and whether effective internal control over financial reporting was maintained in all material respects.
1085392_14_ITEM8_P12_S7	Our audits of the financial statements included examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in the financial statements, assessing the accounting principles used and significant estimates made by management, and evaluating the overall financial statement presentation.
1085392_14_ITEM8_P12_S8	Our audit of internal control over financial reporting included obtaining an understanding of internal control over financial reporting, assessing the risk that a material weakness exists, and testing and evaluating the design and operating effectiveness of internal control based on the assessed risk.
1085392_14_ITEM8_P12_S9	Our audits also included performing such other procedures as we considered necessary in the circumstances.
1085392_14_ITEM8_P12_S10	We believe that our audits provide a reasonable basis for our opinions.
1085392_14_ITEM8_P13_S0	A company s internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
1085392_14_ITEM8_P13_S1	A company s internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that (i) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company; (ii) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the company; and (iii) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the company s assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
1085392_14_ITEM8_P14_S0	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
1085392_14_ITEM8_P14_S1	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
