1085392_15_ITEM8_P164_S0	PSE employs various energy portfolio optimization strategies, but is not in the business of assuming risk for the purpose of realizing speculative trading revenue.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P164_S1	The nature of serving regulated electric customers with its portfolio of owned and contracted electric generation resources exposes PSE and its customers to some volumetric and commodity price risks within the sharing mechanism of the PCA.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P164_S2	Therefore, wholesale market transactions and PSE's related hedging strategies are focused on reducing costs and risks where feasible, thus reducing volatility in costs in the portfolio.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P165_S0	In order to manage its exposure to the variability in future cash flows for forecasted energy transactions, PSE utilizes a programmatic hedging strategy which extends out three years.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P165_S1	PSE's energy risk portfolio management function monitors and manages these risks using analytical models and tools.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P165_S2	In order to manage risks effectively, PSE enters into forward physical electric and natural gas purchase and sale agreements, fixed-for-floating swap contracts, and commodity call/put options.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P165_S3	The forward physical electric agreements are both fixed and variable (at index), while the physical natural gas contracts are variable.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P166_S0	To fix the price of wholesale electricity and natural gas, PSE may enter into fixed-for-floating swap (financial) contracts with various counterparties.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P166_S1	PSE also utilizes natural gas call and put options as an additional hedging instrument to increase the hedging portfolio's flexibility to react to commodity price fluctuations.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P167_S0	The Company manages its interest rate risk through the issuance of mostly fixed-rate debt with varied maturities.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P167_S1	The Company utilizes internal cash from operations, borrowings under its commercial paper program, and its credit facilities to meet short-term funding needs.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P167_S2	The Company may enter into swap instruments or other financial hedge instruments to manage the interest rate risk associated with these debts.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P167_S3	As of December 31, 2014 , Puget Energy had two interest rate swap contracts outstanding which extend to January 2017 .
1085392_15_ITEM8_P167_S4	PSE did not have any outstanding interest rate swap instruments.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P168_S0	The following table presents the volumes, fair values and locations of the Company's derivative instruments recorded on the balance sheets:
1085392_15_ITEM8_P169_S0	___________ Balance sheet location: Current and Long-term Unrealized gain on derivative instruments.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P169_S1	Balance sheet location: Current and Long-term Unrealized loss on derivative instruments.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P170_S0	Interest rate swap contracts are only held at Puget Energy.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P170_S1	PSE had a net derivative liability and an offsetting regulatory asset of $69.3 million at December 31, 2014 and $27.6 million at December 31, 2013 related to contracts used to economically hedge the cost of physical gas purchased to serve natural gas customers.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P170_S2	All fair value adjustments on derivatives relating to the natural gas business have been deferred in accordance with ASC 980, due to the PGA mechanism.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P171_S0	For further details regarding the fair value of derivative instruments, see Note 10.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P172_S0	It is the Company's policy to record all derivative transactions on a gross basis at the contract level, without offsetting assets or liabilities.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P172_S1	The Company generally enters into transactions using the following master agreements: WSPP, Inc. (WSPP) agreements which standardize physical power contracts; ISDA agreements which standardize financial gas and electric contracts; and NAESB agreements which standardize physical gas contracts.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P172_S2	The Company believes that such agreements reduce credit risk exposure because such agreements provide for the netting and offsetting of monthly payments as well as right of set-off in the event of counterparty default.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P173_S0	The set-off provision can be used as a final settlement of accounts which extinguishes the mutual debts owed between the parties in exchange for a new net amount.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P174_S0	The following tables present the potential effect of netting arrangements, including rights of set-off associated with the Company's derivative assets and liabilities:
1085392_15_ITEM8_P175_S0	All Derivative Contract deals are executed under ISDA, NAESB and WSPP Master Netting Agreements with Right of Offset.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P175_S1	Interest Rate Swap Contracts are only held at Puget Energy.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P176_S0	Due to the merger in 2009, Puget Energy recorded all derivative contracts at fair value as either assets or liabilities.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P176_S1	Certain contracts meeting the criteria defined in ASC 815 were subsequently designated as NPNS or cash flow hedges, thereby causing differences in the derivative unrealized gains/losses to be recorded through earnings between Puget Energy and PSE.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P176_S2	These differences will occur through February 2015.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P177_S0	The following tables present the effect and locations of the Company's derivatives not designated as hedging instruments, recorded on the statements of income:
1085392_15_ITEM8_P178_S0	___________ For 2012 , the amount differs from the amount stated in the statement of income as it does not include amortization related to contracts that were recorded at fair value at the time of the February 2009 merger and subsequently designated as NPNS of $2.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2012 .
1085392_15_ITEM8_P179_S0	The unrealized gain or loss on derivative contracts is reported in the statement of cash flows under the operating activities section.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P179_S1	However, at the time of the merger in 2009, all derivative contracts at Puget Energy were assessed to identify contracts that have a more than an insignificant fair value.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P179_S2	If the fair value was greater than 10% of the notional value, the contract was deemed as having a financing element.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P179_S3	For those contracts, the cash inflows (outflows) are presented in the financing activities section of the statement of cash flows.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P179_S4	For the years ended December 31, 2014 , 2013 and 2012 , cash outflows related to financing activities of $16.3 million , $34.3 million and $92.7 million , respectively, were reported on Puget Energy's statement of cash flows.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P180_S0	For derivative instruments previously designated as cash flow hedges (including both commodity and interest rate swap contracts), the effective portion of the gain or loss on the derivative was recorded as a component of OCI, and then is reclassified into earnings in the same period(s) during which the hedged transaction affects earnings.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P180_S1	Puget Energy and PSE expect $0.5 million and $1.1 million of losses, respectively, in accumulated OCI will be reclassified into earnings within the next twelve months.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P180_S2	The Company does not attempt cash flow hedging for any new transactions and records all mark-to-market adjustments through earnings.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P181_S0	The following tables present the Company's pre-tax gain (loss) on derivatives that were previously in a cash flow hedge relationship, and subsequently reclassified out of accumulated OCI into income:
1085392_15_ITEM8_P182_S0	The Company is exposed to credit risk primarily through buying and selling electricity and natural gas to serve its customers.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P183_S0	Credit risk is the potential loss resulting from a counterparty's non-performance under an agreement.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P183_S1	The Company manages credit risk with policies and procedures for, among other things, counterparty credit analysis, exposure measurement, exposure monitoring and exposure mitigation.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P183_S2	The Company monitors counterparties that have significant swings in credit default swap rates, have credit rating changes by external rating agencies, have changes in ownership or are experiencing financial distress.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P183_S3	Where deemed appropriate, the Company may request collateral or other security from its counterparties to mitigate potential credit default losses.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P183_S4	Criteria employed in this decision include, among other things, the perceived creditworthiness of the counterparty and the expected credit exposure.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P184_S0	It is possible that volatility in energy commodity prices could cause the Company to have material credit risk exposure with one or more counterparties.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P184_S1	If such counterparties fail to perform their obligations under one or more agreements, the Company could suffer a material financial loss.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P184_S2	However, as of December 31, 2014 , approximately 99.3% of the Company's energy portfolio exposure, excluding NPNS transactions, is with counterparties that are rated at least investment grade by the major rating agencies and 0.7% are either rated below investment grade or not rated by rating agencies.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P184_S3	The Company assesses credit risk internally for counterparties that are not rated.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P184_S4	As the Company generally enters into transactions using the WSPP, ISDA and NAESB master agreements, it believes that such agreements reduce credit risk exposure because they provide for the netting and offsetting of monthly payments and, in the event of counterparty default, termination payments.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P185_S0	The Company computes credit reserves at a master agreement level by counterparty (i.e., WSPP, ISDA, or NAESB).
1085392_15_ITEM8_P185_S1	The Company considers external credit ratings and market factors, such as credit default swaps and bond spreads, in the determination of reserves.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P185_S2	The Company recognizes that external ratings may not always reflect how a market participant perceives a counterparty's risk of default.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P185_S3	The Company uses both default factors published by Standard Poor's and factors derived through analysis of market risk, which reflect the application of an industry standard recovery rate.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P186_S0	The Company selects a default factor by counterparty at an aggregate master agreement level based on a weighted-average default tenor for that counterparty's deals.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P186_S1	The default tenor is determined by weighting the fair value and contract tenors for all deals for each counterparty to derive an average value.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P186_S2	The default factor used is dependent upon whether the counterparty is in a net asset or a net liability position after applying the master agreement levels.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P187_S0	The Company applies the counterparty's default factor to compute credit reserves for counterparties that are in a net asset position.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P187_S1	The Company calculates a non-performance risk on its derivative liabilities by using its estimated incremental borrowing rate over the risk-free rate.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P188_S0	Credit reserves are netted against unrealized gain (loss) positions.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P188_S1	As of December 31, 2014 , the Company was in a net liability position with the majority of counterparties, so the default factors of counterparties did not have a significant impact on reserves for the quarter.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P189_S0	The majority of the Company's derivative contracts are with financial institutions and other utilities operating within the Western Electricity Coordinating Council.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P189_S1	As of December 31, 2014 , PSE has posted a $1.0 million letter of credit as a condition of transacting on a physical energy exchange and clearinghouse in Canada.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P189_S2	PSE did not trigger any collateral requirements with any of its counterparties nor were any of PSE's counterparties required to post collateral resulting from credit rating downgrades.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P190_S0	The table below presents the fair value of the overall contractual contingent liability positions for the Company's derivative activity at December 31, 2014 :
1085392_15_ITEM8_P191_S0	__________ Represents the derivative fair value of contracts with contingent features for counterparties in net derivative liability positions.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P191_S1	Excludes NPNS, accounts payable and accounts receivable.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P192_S0	Failure by PSE to maintain an investment grade credit rating from each of the major credit rating agencies provides counterparties a contractual right to demand collateral.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P192_S1	Collateral requirements may vary, based on changes in the forward value of underlying transactions relative to contractually defined collateral thresholds.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P193_S0	ASC 820 established a fair value hierarchy that prioritizes the inputs used to measure fair value.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P193_S1	The hierarchy categorizes the inputs into three levels with the highest priority given to unadjusted quoted prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities (Level 1 measurement) and the lowest priority given to unobservable inputs (Level 3 measurement).
1085392_15_ITEM8_P193_S2	The three levels of the fair value hierarchy are as follows:
1085392_15_ITEM8_P194_S0	Level 1 - Quoted prices are available in active markets for identical assets or liabilities as of the reporting date.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P194_S1	Level 1 primarily consists of financial instruments such as exchange-traded derivatives and listed equities.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P194_S2	Equity securities that are also classified as cash equivalents are considered Level 1 if there are unadjusted quoted prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P195_S0	Level 2 - Pricing inputs are other than quoted prices in active markets included in Level 1, which are either directly or indirectly observable as of the reporting date.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P196_S0	Level 2 includes those financial instruments that are valued using models or other valuation methodologies.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P196_S1	Instruments in this category include non-exchange-traded derivatives such as over-the-counter forwards and options.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P197_S0	Level 3 - Pricing inputs include significant inputs that have little or no observability as of the reporting date.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P197_S1	These inputs may be used with internally developed methodologies that result in management's best estimate of fair value.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P198_S0	Financial assets and liabilities measured at fair value are classified in their entirety in the appropriate fair value hierarchy based on the lowest level of input that is significant to the fair value measurement.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P198_S1	The Company's assessment of the significance of a particular input to the fair value measurement requires judgment, and may affect the valuation of fair value assets and liabilities and their placement within the fair value hierarchy.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P199_S0	The Company primarily determines fair value measurements classified as Level 2 or Level 3 using a combination of the income and market valuation approaches.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P199_S1	The process of determining the fair values is the responsibility of the derivative accounting department which reports to the Controller and Principal Accounting Officer.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P199_S2	Inputs used to estimate the fair value of forwards, swaps and options include market-price curves; contract terms and prices; credit-risk adjustments; and discount factors.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P199_S3	Additionally, for options, the Black-Scholes option valuation model and implied market volatility curves are used.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P200_S0	Inputs used to estimate fair value in industry-standard models are categorized as Level 2 inputs because substantially all assumptions and inputs are observable in active markets throughout the full term of the instruments.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P201_S0	On a daily basis, the Company obtains quoted forward prices for the electric and natural gas markets from an independent external pricing service.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P201_S1	For interest rate swaps, the Company obtains monthly mark-to-market values from an independent external pricing service for LIBOR forward rates, which is a significant input.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P201_S2	Some of the inputs of the interest rate swap valuations, which are less significant, include the credit standing of the counterparties, assumptions for time value and the impact of the Company's nonperformance risk of its liabilities.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P202_S0	The Company classifies cash and cash equivalents, and restricted cash as Level 1 financial instruments due to cash being at stated value, and cash equivalents at quoted market prices.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P203_S0	The Company considers its electric, natural gas and interest rate swap contracts as Level 2 derivative instruments as such contracts are commonly traded as over-the-counter forwards with indirectly observable price quotes.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P203_S1	Management's assessment was based on the trading activity in real-time and forward electric and natural gas markets.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P204_S0	Each quarter, the Company confirms the validity of pricing-service quoted prices (e.g., Level 2 in the fair value hierarchy) used to value commodity contracts with the actual prices of commodity contracts entered into during the most recent quarter.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P204_S1	However, certain energy derivative instruments with maturity dates falling outside the range of observable price quotes are classified as Level 3 in the fair value hierarchy.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P205_S0	The following table presents the carrying value for cash, cash equivalents, restricted cash, notes receivable and short-term debt by level, within the fair value hierarchy.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P205_S1	The carrying values below are representative of fair values due to the short-term nature of these financial instruments.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P206_S0	The fair value of the junior subordinated and long-term notes were estimated using the discounted cash flow method with U.S. Treasury yields and Company credit spreads as inputs, interpolating to the maturity date of each issue.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P206_S1	Carrying values and estimated fair values were as follows:
1085392_15_ITEM8_P207_S0	The following tables present the Company's financial assets and liabilities by level, within the fair value hierarchy, that were accounted for at fair value on a recurring basis and the reconciliation of the changes in the fair value of Level 3 derivatives in the fair value hierarchy:
1085392_15_ITEM8_P208_S0	_______________ Income Statement location: Unrealized (gain) loss on derivative instruments, net.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P208_S1	Includes unrealized gains (losses) on derivatives still held in position as of the reporting date for electric derivatives of $(9.6) million , $(13.4) million , and $(15.2) million for the years ended December 31, 2014 , 2013 and 2012 , respectively.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P208_S2	The Company had no purchases, sales or issuances during the reported periods.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P209_S0	Realized gains and losses on energy derivatives for Level 3 recurring items are included in energy costs in the Company's consolidated statements of income under purchased electricity, electric generation fuel or purchased natural gas when settled.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P209_S1	Unrealized gains and losses on energy derivatives for Level 3 recurring items are included in net unrealized (gain) loss on derivative instruments in the Company's consolidated statements of income.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P210_S0	In order to determine which assets and liabilities are classified as Level 3, the Company receives market data from its independent external pricing service defining the tenor of observable market quotes.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P210_S1	To the extent any of the Company's commodity contracts extend beyond what is considered observable as defined by its independent pricing service, the contracts are classified as Level 3.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P211_S0	The actual tenor of what the independent pricing service defines as observable is subject to change depending on market conditions.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P211_S1	Therefore, as the market changes, the same contract may be designated Level 3 one month and Level 2 the next, and vice versa.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P211_S2	The changes of fair value classification into or out of Level 3 are recognized each month, and reported in the Level 3 Roll-forward table above.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P211_S3	The Company did not have any transfers between Level 2 and Level 1 during the years ended December 31, 2014 and 2013 .
1085392_15_ITEM8_P212_S0	The Company does periodically transact at locations, or market price points, that are illiquid or for which no prices are available from the independent pricing service.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P212_S1	In such circumstances the Company uses a more liquid price point and performs a 15-month regression against the illiquid locations to serve as a proxy for market prices.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P212_S2	Such transactions are classified as Level 3.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P213_S0	The Company does not use internally developed models to make adjustments to significant unobservable pricing inputs.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P213_S1	The only significant unobservable input into the fair value measurement of the Company's Level 3 assets and liabilities is the forward price for electric and natural gas contracts.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P213_S2	Below are the forward price ranges for the Company's commodity contracts, as of December 31, 2014 :
1085392_15_ITEM8_P214_S0	The valuation techniques, unobservable inputs and ranges are the same for asset and liability positions.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P215_S0	The significant unobservable inputs listed above would have a direct impact on the fair values of the above instruments if they were adjusted.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P215_S1	Consequently significant increases or decreases in the forward prices of electricity or natural gas in isolation would result in a significantly higher or lower fair value for Level 3 assets and liabilities.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P216_S0	prices of natural gas and power.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P216_S1	As such, an increase in natural gas pricing would potentially have a similar impact on forward power markets.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P217_S0	At December 31, 2014 , a hypothetical 10% increase or decrease in market prices of natural gas and electricity would change the fair value of the Company's derivative portfolio, classified as Level 3 within the fair value hierarchy, by $3.9 million .
1085392_15_ITEM8_P218_S0	At the time of merger, Puget Energy recorded the fair value of its intangible assets in accordance with ASC 360, Property, Plant, and Equipment, (ASC 360).
1085392_15_ITEM8_P218_S1	The fair value assigned to the power contracts was determined using an income approach comparing the contract rate to the market rate for power over the remaining period of the contracts incorporating non-performance risk.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P218_S2	Management also incorporated certain assumptions related to quantities and market presentation that it believes market participants would make in the valuation.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P219_S0	The fair value of the power contracts is amortized as the contracts settle.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P220_S0	ASC 360 requires long-lived assets to be tested for impairment on an annual basis, and upon the occurrence of any events or circumstances that would be more likely than not to reduce the fair value of the long-lived assets below their carrying value.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P220_S1	One such triggering event is a significant decrease in the forward market prices of power.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P221_S0	At December 31, 2014 , Puget Energy completed a valuation and impairment test of its purchased power contracts classified as intangible assets.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P221_S1	The valuation indicated a fair value of $437.6 million with an impairment to the Wells hydro contract.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P221_S2	As of December 31, 2014 , the carrying value for this contract was $65.3 million and its fair value on a discounted basis was $62.1 million , thereby requiring a write-down of $3.2 million to this intangible asset with a corresponding reduction in the regulatory liability.

1085392_15_ITEM8_P222_S0	At June 30, 2013 , Puget Energy completed a valuation and impairment test of its purchased power contracts classified as intangible assets.

1085392_15_ITEM8_P224_S0	The valuations were measured using the income approach.

1085392_15_ITEM8_P224_S2	A less significant input is the discount rate reflective of PSE's cost of capital used in the valuation.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P225_S0	The Company's Investment Plan is a qualified employee 401(k) plan, under which employee salary deferrals and after-tax contributions are used to purchase several different investment fund options.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P225_S1	PSE s contributions to the employee Investment Plan were $14.9 million , $14.6 million and $14.5 million for the years 2014 , 2013 , and 2012 , respectively.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P226_S0	The employee Investment Plan eligibility requirements are set forth in the plan documents.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P226_S1	Non-represented employees and United Association of Journeymen and Apprentices of the Plumbing and Pipefitting Industry (UA) represented employees hired before January 1, 2014, and International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers Local Union 77 (IBEW) represented employees hired before December 12, 2014, have the following company contributions:
1085392_15_ITEM8_P227_S0	For employees under the Cash Balance retirement plan formula, PSE will match 100% of an employee's contribution up to 6% of plan compensation each paycheck, and will make an additional year-end contribution equal to 1% of base pay.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P228_S0	For employees grandfathered under the Final Average Earning retirement plan formula, PSE will match 55% of an employee s contribution up to 6% of plan compensation each paycheck.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P229_S0	UA-represented employees hired on or after January 1, 2014 will have access to the 401k Plan.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P229_S1	Non-represented employees hired on or after January 1, 2014, and IBEW-represented employees hired on or after December 12, 2014, will have access to the 401(k) plan and will choose how they want to accumulate funds for retirement, with two contribution sources from PSE:
1085392_15_ITEM8_P230_S0	401(k) Company Matching: New non-represented, UA-represented and IBEW-represented employees will receive company match each paycheck based on a new schedule- 100% match on the first 3% of pay contributed and 50% match on the next 3% of pay contributed.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P230_S1	An employee who contributes 6% of pay will receive 4.5% of pay in company match.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P230_S2	Company matching will be immediately vested.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P231_S0	Company Contribution: New UA-represented employees will receive an annual company contribution of 4% of eligible pay placed in the Cash Balance retirement plan.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P231_S1	New non-represented and IBEW-represented employees will receive an annual company contribution of 4% of eligible pay, placed either in the Investment Plan 401(k) plan or in PSE s Retirement Plan (Cash Balance retirement plan).
1085392_15_ITEM8_P231_S2	New non-represented and IBEW-represented employees will make a one-time election within 30 days of hire and direct that PSE put the 4% contribution either into the 401(k) plan or into an account in the Cash Balance retirement plan.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P231_S3	The Company s 4% contribution will vest after three years of service.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P232_S0	PSE has a defined benefit pension plan covering substantially all PSE employees.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P232_S1	Pension benefits earned are a function of age, salary, years of service and, in the case of employees in the cash balance formula plan, the applicable annual interest crediting rates.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P232_S2	Beginning in 2014, all new UA employees and those new non-represented employees who elect to accumulate the Company contribution in the Cash Balance pension, (effective January 1, 2014) and all new IBEW (effective December 12, 2014), will receive annual pay credits of 4% each year.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P232_S3	They will also receive interest credits like other participants in the Cash Balance pension, which are at least 1% per quarter.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P233_S0	When a newly-hired employee with a vested Cash Balance benefit leaves PSE, he or she will have annuity and lump sum options for distribution, with annuities calculated according to the Pension Protection Act.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P233_S1	Those who select the lump sum option will receive their current cash balance amount.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P233_S2	Participation by continuing employees in the Cash Balance pension plan is not affected.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P234_S0	PSE also maintains a non-qualified Supplemental Executive Retirement Plan (SERP) for its key senior management employees.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P234_S1	In addition to providing pension benefits, PSE provides group health care and life insurance benefits for certain retired employees.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P234_S2	These benefits are provided principally through an insurance company.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P234_S3	The insurance premiums, paid primarily by retirees, are based on the benefits provided during the year.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P234_S4	The 2009 merger of Puget Energy with Puget Holdings triggered a new basis of accounting for PSE s retirement benefit plans in the Puget Energy consolidated financial statements.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P234_S5	Such purchase accounting adjustments associated with the re-measurement of the retirement plans are recorded at Puget Energy.

1085392_15_ITEM8_P239_S0	Assumptions In accounting for pension and other benefit obligations and costs under the plans, the following weighted-average actuarial assumptions were used by the Company:
1085392_15_ITEM8_P240_S0	_______________ The Company calculates the present value of the pension liability using a discount rate of 4.25% which represents the single-rate equivalent of the AA rated corporate bond yield curve.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P241_S0	The assumed medical inflation rate used to determine benefit obligations is 6.70% in 2015 grading down to 4.30% in 2016 .
1085392_15_ITEM8_P241_S1	A 1.0% change in the assumed medical inflation rate would have the following effects:
1085392_15_ITEM8_P242_S0	The Company has selected the expected return on plan assets based on a historical analysis of rates of return and the Company s investment mix, market conditions, inflation and other factors.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P242_S1	The expected rate of return is reviewed annually based on these factors.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P243_S0	The Company s accounting policy for calculating the market-related value of assets for the Company s retirement plan is as follows.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P243_S1	PSE market-related value of assets is based on a five-year smoothing of asset gains (losses) measured from the expected return on market-related assets.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P243_S2	This is a calculated value that recognizes changes in fair value in a systematic and rational manner over five years.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P243_S3	The same manner of calculating market-related value is used for all classes of assets, and is applied consistently from year to year.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P244_S0	Puget Energy s pension and other postretirement benefits income or costs depend on several factors and assumptions, including plan design, timing and amount of cash contributions to the plan, earnings on plan assets, discount rate, expected long-term rate of return, mortality and health care costs trends.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P244_S1	Changes in any of these factors or assumptions will affect the amount of income or expense that Puget Energy records in its financial statements in future years and its projected benefit obligation.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P245_S0	Puget Energy has selected an expected return on plan assets based on a historical analysis of rates of return and Puget Energy s investment mix, market conditions, inflation and other factors.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P245_S1	As required by merger accounting rules, market-related value was reset to market value effective with the merger.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P245_S2	The discount rates were determined by using market interest rate data and the weighted-average discount rate from Citigroup Pension Liability Index Curve.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P245_S3	The Company also takes into account in determining the discount rate the expected changes in market interest rates and anticipated changes in the duration of the plan liabilities.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P246_S0	The expected total benefits to be paid under the next five years and the aggregate total to be paid for the five years thereafter are as follows:
1085392_15_ITEM8_P247_S0	Plan Assets Plan contributions and the actuarial present value of accumulated plan benefits are prepared based on certain assumptions pertaining to interest rates, inflation rates and employee demographics, all of which are subject to change.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P247_S1	Due to uncertainties inherent in the estimations and assumptions process, changes in these estimates and assumptions in the near term may be material to the financial statements.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P248_S0	The Company has a Retirement Plan Committee that establishes investment policies, objectives and strategies designed to balance expected return with a prudent level of risk.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P248_S1	All changes to the investment policies are reviewed and approved by the Retirement Plan Committee prior to being implemented.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P249_S0	The Retirement Plan Committee invests trust assets with investment managers who have historically achieved above-median long-term investment performance within the risk and asset allocation limits that have been established.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P249_S1	Interim evaluations are routinely performed with the assistance of an outside investment consultant.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P250_S0	To obtain the desired return needed to fund the pension benefit plans, the Retirement Plan Committee has established investment allocation percentages by asset classes as follows:
1085392_15_ITEM8_P251_S0	Plan Fair Value Measurements ASC 715, Compensation Retirement Benefits (ASC 715) directs companies to provide additional disclosures about plan assets of a defined benefit pension or other postretirement plan.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P251_S1	The objectives of the disclosures are to disclose the following: (1) how investment allocation decisions are made, including the factors that are pertinent to an understanding of investment policies and strategies; (2) major categories of plan assets; (3) inputs and valuation techniques used to measure the fair value of plan assets; (4) effect of fair value measurements using significant unobservable inputs (Level 3) on changes in plan assets for the period; and (5) significant concentrations of risk within plan assets.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P252_S0	ASC 820 allows the reporting entity, as a practical expedient, to measure the fair value of investments that do not have readily determinable fair values on the basis of the net asset value per share of the investment if the net asset value of the investment is calculated in a matter consistent with ASC 946, Financial Services Investment Companies.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P252_S1	The standard requires disclosures about the nature and risk of the investments and whether the investments are probable of being sold at amounts different from the net asset value per share.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P253_S0	The following table sets forth by level, within the fair value hierarchy, the qualified pension plan as of December 31, 2014 and 2013 :

1085392_15_ITEM8_P254_S1	The investment in the mutual fund is valued using quoted market prices multiplied by the number of shares owned as of December 31, 2014 .
1085392_15_ITEM8_P254_S2	The investment in the commingled fund is valued at the net asset value per share multiplied by the number of shares held as of December 31, 2014 .

1085392_15_ITEM8_P259_S2	These investments are a Level 3 under ASC 820 because the significant valuation inputs are primarily internal to the partnerships with little third party involvement.

1085392_15_ITEM8_P260_S1	The money market fund invests primarily in commercial paper, notes, repurchase agreements, and other evidences of indebtedness which are payable on demand or short-term in nature.

1085392_15_ITEM8_P268_S0	The above amounts have been classified in the Consolidated Balance Sheets as follows:
1085392_15_ITEM8_P269_S0	The Company calculates its deferred tax assets and liabilities under ASC 740, Income Taxes (ASC 740).
1085392_15_ITEM8_P269_S1	ASC 740 requires recording deferred tax balances, at the currently enacted tax rate, on assets and liabilities that are reported differently for income tax purposes than for financial reporting purposes.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P269_S2	The utilization of deferred tax assets requires sufficient taxable income in future years.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P269_S3	ASC 740 requires a valuation allowance on deferred tax assets when it is more likely than not that the deferred tax assets will not be realized.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P269_S4	The Company s PTC carryforwards expire from 2026 through 2034.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P269_S5	The Company s net operating loss carryforwards expire from 2029 through 2034.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P270_S0	For ratemaking purposes, deferred taxes are not provided for certain temporary differences.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P270_S1	PSE has established a regulatory asset for income taxes recoverable through future rates related to those temporary differences for which no deferred taxes have been provided, based on prior and expected future ratemaking treatment.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P271_S0	The Company accounts for uncertain tax position under ASC 740, which clarifies the accounting for uncertainty in income taxes recognized in the financial statements.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P271_S1	ASC 740 requires the use of a two-step approach for recognizing and measuring tax positions taken or expected to be taken in a tax return.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P272_S0	First, a tax position should only be recognized when it is more likely than not, based on technical merits, that the position will be sustained upon challenge by the taxing authorities and taken by management to the court of last resort.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P272_S1	Second, a tax position that meets the recognition threshold should be measured at the largest amount that has a greater than 50.0% likelihood of being sustained.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P273_S0	As of December 31, 2014 and 2013 , the Company had no material unrecognized tax benefits.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P273_S1	As a result, no interest or penalties were accrued for unrecognized tax benefits during the year.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P273_S2	For ASC 740 purposes, the Company has open tax years from 2010 through 2014.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P273_S3	The Company classifies interest as interest expense and penalties as other expense in the financial statements.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P274_S0	Colstrip PSE has a 50% ownership interest in Colstrip Units 1 and 2, and a 25% interest in Colstrip Units 3 and 4.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P275_S0	On March 6, 2013, Sierra Club and Montana Environmental Information Center (MEIC) filed a Clean Air Act citizen suit against all Colstrip owners (including PSE) alleging numerous claims for relief, most of which relate to alleged prevention of significant deterioration (PSD) violations.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P275_S1	One claim relates to the alleged failure to update the Title V permit to reflect the major modifications alleged in the first thirty-six claim, another claim alleges that the previous Title V compliance certifications have been incomplete because they did not address the alleged major modifications, and the last claim alleges opacity violations since 2007.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P276_S0	The lawsuit was filed in U.S. District of Montana, Billings Division, requesting injunctive relief and civil penalties, including a request that the owners remediate environmental damage and that $100,000 of the civil penalties be used for beneficial mitigation projects.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P276_S1	Discovery in the case is ongoing, and it has been bifurcated into separate liability and remedy trials.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P276_S2	The liability trial is currently set for November 2015, and a date for the remedy trial has yet to be determined.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P276_S3	PSE is litigating the allegations set forth in the notices, and as such, it is not reasonably possible to estimate the outcome of this matter.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P277_S0	Other Proceedings The Company is also involved in litigation relating to claims arising out of its operations in the normal course of business.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P277_S1	The Company has recorded reserves of $1.7 million and $1.4 million relating to these claims as of December 31, 2014 and 2013 , respectively.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P278_S0	For the year ended December 31, 2014 , approximately 14.9% of the Company s energy output was obtained at an average cost of approximately $0.021 per Kilowatt Hour (kWh) through long-term contracts with three of the Washington Public Utility Districts (PUDs) that own hydroelectric projects on the Columbia River.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P278_S1	The purchase of power from the Columbia River projects is on a pro rata share basis under which the Company pays a proportionate share of the annual debt service, operating and maintenance costs and other expenses associated with each project in proportion to the contractual shares that PSE obtains from that project.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P278_S2	In these instances, PSE s payments are not contingent upon the projects being operable; therefore, PSE is required to make the payments even if power is not delivered.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P278_S3	These projects are financed through substantially level debt service payments and their annual costs should not vary significantly over the term of the contracts unless additional financing is required to meet the costs of major maintenance, repairs or replacements, or license requirements.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P278_S4	The Company s share of the costs and the output of the projects is subject to reduction due to various withdrawal rights of the PUDs and others over the contract lives.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P278_S5	The Company's expenses under these PUD contracts were as follows for the years ended December 31:
1085392_15_ITEM8_P279_S0	As of December 31, 2014 , the Company purchased portions of the power output of the PUDs' projects as set forth in the following table:
1085392_15_ITEM8_P280_S0	The following table summarizes the Company s estimated payment obligations for power purchases from the Columbia River projects, contracts with other utilities and contracts with non-utilities.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P280_S1	These contracts have varying terms and may include escalation and termination provisions.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P281_S0	Total purchased power contracts provided the Company with approximately 12.1 million , 10.7 million and 6.1 million MWhs of firm energy at a cost of approximately $401.4 million , $348.7 million and $203.1 million for the years 2014 , 2013 and 2012 , respectively.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P281_S1	The Company has natural gas-fired generation facility obligations for natural gas supply amounting to an estimated $63.6 million in 2015 .
1085392_15_ITEM8_P281_S2	Longer term agreements for natural gas supply amount to an estimated $286.7 million for 2016 through 2019.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P282_S0	PSE enters into short-term energy supply contracts to meet its core customer needs.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P282_S1	These contracts are sometimes classified as NPNS, however in most cases recorded at fair value in accordance with ASC 815.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P282_S2	Commitments under these contracts are $105.8 million , $32.4 million and $6.5 million in 2015 , 2016 and 2017 , respectively.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P283_S0	The Company has also entered into various firm supply, transportation and storage service contracts in order to ensure adequate availability of natural gas supply for its firm customers.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P283_S1	The transportation and storage contracts, which have remaining terms from less than one year to 30 years, provide that the Company must pay a fixed demand charge each month, regardless of actual usage.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P283_S2	The Company contracts for its long-term natural gas supply on a firm basis, which means the Company has a 100% daily take obligation and the supplier has a 100% daily delivery obligation to ensure service to PSE s customers and generation requirements.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P284_S0	The Company incurred demand charges in 2014 for firm transportation service and firm storage and peaking service of $155.0 million and $6.6 million , respectively.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P284_S1	The demand charge for firm natural gas supply was immaterial in 2014.
1085392_15_ITEM8_P284_S2	The Company incurred demand charges in 2014 for firm transportation and firm storage service for the natural gas supply for its combustion turbines in the amount of $35.7 million , which is included in the total Company demand charges.

1085392_15_ITEM8_P291_S2	The service territory of PSE covers approximately 6,000 square miles in the state of Washington.

1085392_15_ITEM9A_P0_S0	Puget Energy Evaluation of Disclosure Controls and Procedures Under the supervision and with the participation of Puget Energy s management, including the President and Chief Executive Officer and Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, Puget Energy has evaluated the effectiveness of its disclosure controls and procedures (as defined in Rule 13a-15(e) under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934) as of December 31, 2014 , the end of the period covered by this report.
1085392_15_ITEM9A_P0_S1	Based upon that evaluation, the President and Chief Executive Officer and Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer of Puget Energy concluded that these disclosure controls and procedures are effective.
1085392_15_ITEM9A_P1_S0	Changes in Internal Control Over Financial Reporting There have been no changes in Puget Energy s internal control over financial reporting during the year ended December 31, 2014 that have materially affected, or are reasonably likely to materially affect, Puget Energy s internal control over financial reporting.
1085392_15_ITEM9A_P2_S0	Management s Report on Internal Control Over Financial Reporting Puget Energy s management is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting (as defined in Rule 13a-15(f) under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934).
1085392_15_ITEM9A_P2_S1	Under the supervision and with the participation of Puget Energy s President and Chief Executive Officer and Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, Puget Energy s management assessed the effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting based on the framework in Internal Control Integrated Framework (2013) issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission.
1085392_15_ITEM9A_P2_S2	Based on the assessment, Puget Energy s management concluded that its internal control over financial reporting was effective as of December 31, 2014 .
1085392_15_ITEM9A_P2_S3	Puget Energy s effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2014 has been audited by PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP, an independent registered public accounting firm, as stated in their report which is included herein.
1085392_15_ITEM9A_P3_S0	Puget Sound Energy Evaluation of Disclosure Controls and Procedures Under the supervision and with the participation of PSE s management, including the President and Chief Executive Officer and Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, PSE has evaluated the effectiveness of its disclosure controls and procedures (as defined in Rule 13a-15(e) under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934) as of December 31, 2014 , the end of the period covered by this report.
1085392_15_ITEM9A_P3_S1	Based upon that evaluation, the President and Chief Executive Officer and Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer of PSE concluded that these disclosure controls and procedures are effective.
1085392_15_ITEM9A_P4_S0	Changes in Internal Control Over Financial Reporting There have been no changes in PSE s internal control over financial reporting during the year ended December 31, 2014 that have materially affected, or are reasonably likely to materially affect, PSE s internal control over financial reporting.
1085392_15_ITEM9A_P5_S0	Management s Report on Internal Control Over Financial Reporting PSE s management is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting (as defined in Rule 13a-15(f) under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934).
1085392_15_ITEM9A_P5_S1	Under the supervision and with the participation of PSE s President and Chief Executive Officer and Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, Puget Sound Energy s management assessed the effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting based on the framework in Internal Control Integrated Framework (2013) issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission.
1085392_15_ITEM9A_P5_S2	Based on the assessment, PSE s management concluded that its internal control over financial reporting was effective as of December 31, 2014 .
1085392_15_ITEM9A_P5_S3	PSE s effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2014 has been audited by PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP, an independent registered public accounting firm, as stated in their report which is included herein.
1085392_15_ITEM10_P0_S0	Board of Directors As of February 27, 2015 , twelve directors constitute Puget Energy s Board of Directors and thirteen directors currently constitute PSE s Board of Directors, as set forth below.
1085392_15_ITEM10_P0_S1	The directors are selected in accordance with the Amended and Restated Bylaws of each of Puget Energy and PSE, pursuant to which, the investor-owners of Puget Holdings (the indirect parent company of both Puget Energy and PSE) are entitled to select individuals to serve on the boards of Puget Energy and PSE.
1085392_15_ITEM10_P1_S0	Andrew Chapman , age 59, has been a director on the boards of both Puget Energy and PSE since February 2009.
1085392_15_ITEM10_P1_S1	Mr. Chapman is currently a Managing Director in the Macquarie Capital Funds division of the Macquarie Group, which position he has held since 2006.
1085392_15_ITEM10_P1_S2	Prior to joining the Macquarie Group, Mr. Chapman was Vice President Strategy Regulation for American Water from 2005 to 2006 and Regional Managing Director from 2003 to 2004.
1085392_15_ITEM10_P1_S3	Mr. Chapman served as a director on the boards of Duquesne Light Holdings, Inc. and Duquesne Light Company from 2009 to 2013.
1085392_15_ITEM10_P1_S4	Mr. Chapman represents the Company s Macquarie affiliated investors on the boards, in accordance with the terms of the Puget Energy and PSE bylaws, and brings to his service many years of experience in the operational and financial management challenges specific to regulated utilities.
1085392_15_ITEM10_P2_S0	Melanie Dressel , age 62, is a director on the boards of both Puget Energy and PSE, which positions she has held since December 2011.
1085392_15_ITEM10_P2_S1	Ms. Dressel is currently President and Chief Executive Officer of Columbia Bank and its parent company, Columbia Banking System, Inc., of Tacoma, Washington, which positions she has held since 2000 and 2003, respectively.
1085392_15_ITEM10_P2_S2	An independent director not affiliated with any of the Company s investors, Ms. Dressel s leadership skills, financial experience and many ties to civic and community groups in the Company s service territory are among the reasons for her appointment to the Puget Energy and PSE boards.
1085392_15_ITEM10_P3_S0	Daniel Fetter , age 38, is a director on the boards of both Puget Energy and PSE, which positions he has held since August 2, 2012.
1085392_15_ITEM10_P3_S1	Mr. Fetter is currently the Senior Principal, Private Infrastructure with Canada Pension Plan Investment Board (CPPIB), which position he has held since 2009.
1085392_15_ITEM10_P3_S2	Prior to that, Mr. Fetter served as both a Principal (from 2007 to 2009) and Associate (from 2006 to 2007) at CPP Investment Board.
1085392_15_ITEM10_P3_S3	Mr. Fetter serves on the boards of Puget Energy and PSE as a representative of CPPIB's ownership interests, pursuant to the terms of the Puget Energy and PSE bylaws, and brings to this service his skills in financial management of infrastructure providers.
1085392_15_ITEM10_P4_S0	Kimberly Harris, age 50, is a director on the boards of both Puget Energy and PSE, which positions she has held since March 1, 2011.
1085392_15_ITEM10_P4_S1	Ms. Harris has also been President and Chief Executive Officer since March 1, 2011.
1085392_15_ITEM10_P4_S2	Prior to that time, Ms. Harris served as President from July 2010 through February 2011.
1085392_15_ITEM10_P4_S3	Ms. Harris also served as Executive Vice President and Chief Resource Officer from May 2007 until July 2010, and was Senior Vice President Regulatory Policy and Energy Efficiency from 2005 until May 2007.
1085392_15_ITEM10_P5_S0	Ms. Harris is currently on the board of directors of U.S. Bancorp, a bank holding company.
1085392_15_ITEM10_P6_S0	Benjamin Hawkins , age 40, has been a director on the boards of both Puget Energy and PSE since May 21, 2010.
1085392_15_ITEM10_P6_S1	Mr. Hawkins is currently a Director of Infrastructure Timber Investments for Alberta Investment Management Corporation (AimCo), which position he has held since 2012.
1085392_15_ITEM10_P6_S2	Mr. Hawkins also served as Principal of Infrastructure Investments of AimCo from November 2008 until June 2011, and Portfolio Manager of Infrastructure Investments from May of 2007 until November 2008.
1085392_15_ITEM10_P6_S3	Prior to joining AimCo, Mr. Hawkins held various positions with EPCOR Utilities, a Canadian power and water utility company.
1085392_15_ITEM10_P6_S4	Mr. Hawkins serves on the boards as a representative of AimCo s ownership interest in the Company, pursuant to the terms of the Puget Energy and PSE bylaws, and brings to this service his skills in financial oversight of utilities.
1085392_15_ITEM10_P7_S0	Steven W. Hooper , age 61, is a director on the boards of both Puget Energy and Puget Sound Energy, which positions he has held since January 2015.
1085392_15_ITEM10_P7_S1	Mr. Hooper is currently co-founder and partner of Ignition Partners, a venture capital firm that focuses on technology based in Bellevue, Washington, which position he has held since 2000.
1085392_15_ITEM10_P7_S2	Previously, Mr. Hooper was the co-CEO of Teledesic (1998-2000) and CEO of Nextlink (1997-1998) and AT T Wireless (1994-1997).
1085392_15_ITEM10_P7_S3	Mr. Hooper also currently serves on the boards of directors of Recreational Equipment, Inc. (REI) and Blucora, Inc.
1085392_15_ITEM10_P7_S4	An independent director not affiliated with any of the Company s investors, Mr. Hooper s leadership skills, experience with the challenges facing regulated businesses, and involvement with regional educational and civic organizations are some of the reasons that led to his appointment to the Puget Energy and PSE boards.
1085392_15_ITEM10_P8_S0	Alan James , age 61, has been a director on the boards of both Puget Energy and PSE since February 2009, as a representative of the Company s Macquarie affiliated investors consistent with the Puget Energy and PSE bylaws.
1085392_15_ITEM10_P8_S1	Mr. James is currently the Chairman and Senior Managing Director of Macquarie Capital (USA) Inc. based in New York where he specializes in providing M A advice and capital raising solutions to the utility, power and renewable sectors in North America, which position he has held since 2005.
1085392_15_ITEM10_P8_S2	Prior to that time, Mr. James was Managing Director and Head, Investment Banking Australia and New Zealand at Citigroup from 2002 to 2005 and held various positions with Deutsche Bank AG in Australia and Europe from 1993 to 2002 specializing in the energy sector.
1085392_15_ITEM10_P9_S0	Mr. James provides the boards the benefit of his broad experience with the financial needs and operational and regulatory challenges of infrastructure providers.
1085392_15_ITEM10_P10_S0	Christopher Leslie , age 50, has been a director on the boards of both Puget Energy and PSE since February 2009, as a representative of the Company s Macquarie affiliated investors consistent with the Puget Energy and PSE bylaws.
1085392_15_ITEM10_P10_S1	Mr. Leslie is currently an Executive Director of Macquarie Group Limited, which position he has held since 2005, President of Macquarie Infrastructure and Real Assets Inc., and since 2006 Chief Executive Officer of Macquarie Infrastructure Partners Inc.
1085392_15_ITEM10_P10_S2	Mr. Leslie served as a director on the boards of Duquesne Light Holdings, Inc. and Duquesne Light Company in 2009 and 2010.
1085392_15_ITEM10_P10_S3	In addition to his management and banking skills, Mr. Leslie provides the Puget Energy and PSE boards the benefit of his experience with electric utilities, gas distribution systems and other aspects of the infrastructure sector.
1085392_15_ITEM10_P11_S0	David MacMillan , age 62, has been a director on the boards of both Puget Energy and PSE since November 6, 2012.
1085392_15_ITEM10_P11_S1	Mr. MacMillan currently is a non-executive director of Viridian Group Ltd., an energy company based in Northern Ireland, and serves on the boards of Potentia Solar Inc. and Eagle Creek Renewable Energy, LLC.
1085392_15_ITEM10_P11_S2	He has also served as managing director and senior advisor to Good Energies Capital (now named Bregal Energy), a New York-based private equity fund focused on the renewable energy sector, which positions he held from 2007 to 2010, non-executive director of Ontario Power Generation (from 2004 to 2012) and Intergen (from 2006 to 2008).
1085392_15_ITEM10_P12_S0	Mr. MacMillan serves on the boards of Puget Energy and PSE as a representative of CPPIB's ownership interests, pursuant to the terms of the Puget Energy and PSE bylaws, and brings to this service his skills in project finance and experience with managing the capital requirements of energy companies.

1085392_15_ITEM10_P13_S1	Ms. McWilliams was most recently the Executive Director at Washington Health Alliance, which position she held from 2008 to 2014.
1085392_15_ITEM10_P13_S2	She also served as President and Chief Executive Officer at Regence BlueShield from 2000 to 2008.
1085392_15_ITEM10_P13_S3	In addition, Ms. McWilliams serves as a Board member of the Virginia Mason health system and Seattle Branch of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco.
1085392_15_ITEM10_P13_S4	Ms. McWilliams s significant experience managing consumer-focused organizations with challenging regulatory and compliance regimes, as well as her extensive knowledge of the western Washington economy generally, are some of the reasons that led to her appointment to the Puget Energy and PSE boards on behalf of the CPPIB.

1085392_15_ITEM10_P14_S1	Mr. Murphy is currently a Senior Managing Director at Macquarie Infrastructure and Real Assets Inc. ( MIRA ), which position he has held since January 2013.
1085392_15_ITEM10_P14_S2	Prior to joining MIRA, Mr. Murphy was an Executive Vice President of NRG Energy, Inc., a power and energy company, from December 2006 through November 2012 and served in several roles during that time, including head of the Strategy and M A team (from August 2011 to November 2012), President of NRG s Northeast Region (from February 2009 to July 2011) and General Counsel (from December 2006 to February 2009).
1085392_15_ITEM10_P14_S3	Mr. Murphy is a director on the boards of Duquesne Light Holdings, Inc. and Duquesne Light Company.
1085392_15_ITEM10_P14_S4	Mr. Murphy serves on the boards of Puget Energy and PSE as a representative of the Company's Macquarie affiliated investors consistent with the Puget Energy and PSE bylaws, and provides the Puget Energy and PSE boards the benefit of his experience managing and overseeing the legal, regulatory and operational affairs of regulated utilities.

1085392_15_ITEM10_P21_S2	In addition, any other material amendments of these codes will be disclosed.
