1085392_16_ITEM1_P46_S0	Other Electric Supply, Exchange and Transmission Contracts and Agreements PSE purchases electric energy under long-term firm purchased power contracts with other utilities and marketers in the Western region.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P46_S1	PSE is generally not obligated to make payments under these contracts unless power is delivered.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P47_S0	PSE has seasonal energy and capacity exchange agreements with the Bonneville Power Administration (BPA) (for 44 aMW of capacity), and with Pacific Gas Electric Company (for 300 MW of capacity).
1085392_16_ITEM1_P47_S1	PSE expects to participate in an Energy Imbalance Market (EIM) operated by the California Independent System Operator (ISO) effective October 1, 2016, which is expected to reduce costs for PSE customers, enhance system reliability, integrate variable energy resources, and leverage geographic diversity of electricity demand and generation resources.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P48_S0	PSE has entered into multiple various-term transmission contracts with other utilities to integrate electric generation and contracted resources into PSE s system.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P48_S1	These transmission contracts require PSE to pay for transmission service based on the contracted MW level of demand, regardless of actual use.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P48_S2	Other transmission agreements provide actual capacity ownership or capacity ownership rights.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P48_S3	PSE s annual charges under these agreements are also based on contracted MW volumes.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P48_S4	Capacity on these agreements that is not committed to serve PSE s load is available for sale to third parties.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P48_S5	PSE also purchases short-term transmission services from a variety of providers, including the BPA.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P48_S6	In 2015 , PSE had 4,646 MW and 695 MW of total transmission demand contracted with the BPA and other utilities, respectively.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P48_S7	PSE s remaining transmission capacity needs are met via PSE owned transmission assets.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P49_S0	Natural Gas Supply for Electric Customers PSE purchases natural gas supplies for its power portfolio to meet demand for its combustion turbine generators.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P49_S1	Supplies range from long-term to daily agreements, as the demand for the turbines varies depending on market heat rates.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P49_S2	Purchases are made from a diverse group of major and independent natural gas producers and marketers in the United States and Canada.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P49_S3	PSE also enters into financial hedges to manage the cost of natural gas.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P50_S0	PSE utilizes natural gas storage capacity and transportation that is dedicated to and paid for by the power portfolio to facilitate increased natural gas supply reliability and intra-day dispatch of PSE s gas-fired generation resources.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P50_S1	During 2015 , approximately 77% of natural gas purchased for the power portfolio originated in Canada and 23% originated in the United States.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P51_S0	Integrated Resource Plans, Resource Acquisition and Development PSE is required by Washington Commission regulations to file an electric and natural gas integrated resource plan (IRP) every two years.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P51_S1	The 2015 IRP was filed on November 30, 2015 and identified the following capacity needs:
1085392_16_ITEM1_P52_S0	The expected capacity needs reflect the mix of energy efficiency programs deemed cost effective in the 2015 IRP.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P52_S1	In 2015, PSE renewed all the Mid-Columbia (Mid-C) transmission available for renewal during the year to meet peak capacity needs.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P53_S0	PSE projects that beginning in 2021 its future energy needs will exceed current resources in its supply portfolio.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P53_S1	The IRP identifies declining regional surpluses, requiring replacement of supplies to meet projected demands.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P53_S2	Therefore, PSE s IRP sets forth a multi-part strategy of implementing energy efficiency programs and pursuing additional renewable resources (primarily wind) and additional base load natural gas-fired generation to meet the growing needs of its customers.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P54_S0	If PSE cannot acquire needed energy supply resources at a reasonable cost, it may be required to purchase additional power in the wholesale market, subject to the sharing bands of the PCA mechanism, at a cost that could, in the absence of regulatory relief, increase its expenses and reduce earnings and cash flows.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P55_S0	_____________ Includes amortization of prior year collection/refund, reduction related to excess rate of return, and a reduction related to amounts that will not be collected within 24 months.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P56_S0	NATURAL GAS SUPPLY FOR NATURAL GAS CUSTOMERS PSE purchases a portfolio of natural gas supplies ranging from long-term firm to daily from a diverse group of major and independent natural gas producers and marketers in the United States and Canada.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P56_S1	PSE also enters into physical and financial hedges to manage volatility in the cost of natural gas.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P57_S0	All of PSE s natural gas supply is ultimately transported through the facilities of Northwest Pipeline GP (NWP), the sole interstate pipeline delivering directly into PSE s service territory.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P57_S1	Accordingly, delivery of natural gas supply to PSE s natural gas system is dependent upon the reliable operations of NWP.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P58_S0	_______________ All peak firm gas supplies and storage are connected to PSE s market with firm transportation capacity.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P59_S0	For base load, peak management and supply reliability purposes, PSE supplements its firm natural gas supply portfolio by purchasing natural gas in periods of lower demand, injecting it into underground storage facilities and withdrawing it during the peak winter heating season.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P59_S1	Underground storage facilities at Jackson Prairie in western Washington and at Clay Basin in Utah are used for this purpose.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P60_S0	Clay Basin withdrawals are used to supplement purchases from the U.S.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P60_S1	Rocky Mountain supply region, while Jackson Prairie provides incremental peak-day resources utilizing firm storage redelivery transportation capacity.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P60_S2	Jackson Prairie is also used for daily balancing of load requirements on PSE s gas system.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P60_S3	Peaking needs are also met by using PSE-owned natural gas held in PSE s liquefied natural gas (LNG) peaking facility located within its distribution system in Gig Harbor, Washington; as well as interrupting service to customers on interruptible service rates, if necessary.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P60_S4	PSE expects to meet its firm peak-day requirements for residential, commercial and industrial markets through its firm natural gas purchase contracts, firm transportation capacity, firm storage capacity and other firm peaking resources.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P60_S5	PSE believes it will be able to acquire incremental firm natural gas supply and capacity to meet anticipated growth in the requirements of its firm customers for the foreseeable future.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P60_S6	During 2015 , approximately 57.0% of natural gas purchased by PSE for its natural gas customers originated in British Columbia, 24.0% originated in Alberta and 19.0% originated in the United States.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P61_S0	PSE s firm natural gas supply portfolio has adequate flexibility in its transportation arrangements to enable it to achieve savings when there are regional price differentials between natural gas supply basins.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P61_S1	The geographic mix of suppliers and daily, monthly and annual take requirements permit some degree of flexibility in managing natural gas supplies during periods of lower demand to minimize costs.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P61_S2	Natural gas is marketed outside of PSE s service territory (off-system sales) to optimize resources when on-system customer demand requirements permit and market economics are favorable; the resulting economics of these transactions are reflected in PSE s natural gas customer tariff rates through the PGA mechanism.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P62_S0	Natural Gas Storage Capacity PSE holds storage capacity in the Jackson Prairie and Clay Basin underground natural gas storage facilities adjacent to NWP s pipeline to serve PSE s natural gas customers.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P62_S1	The Jackson Prairie facility is operated and one-third owned by PSE and is used primarily for intermediate peaking purposes due to its ability to deliver a large volume of natural gas in a short time period.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P62_S2	Combined with capacity contracted from NWP s one-third stake in Jackson Prairie, PSE holds firm withdrawal capacity in excess of 453,800 Dekatherm (Dth) per day, and over 9.8 million Dth of storage capacity at the Jackson Prairie facility.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P62_S3	Of this total, PSE holds 397,100 Dth per day of the firm withdrawal capacity and over 9.2 million Dth of storage capacity designated to serve natural gas customers, which represents nearly 44% of PSE's expected near-term peak-day requirement.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P62_S4	The location of the Jackson Prairie facility in PSE s market area increases supply reliability and provides significant pipeline demand cost savings by reducing the amount of annual pipeline capacity required to meet peak-day natural gas requirements.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P62_S5	Of the remaining Jackson Prairie storage capacity, 56,700 Dth per day of firm withdrawal capacity and 641,000 Dth of storage capacity is currently designated to PSE's power portfolio, increasing natural gas supply reliability and facilitating intra-day dispatch of PSE's natural gas-fired generation resources.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P62_S6	In addition, PSE has temporarily released approximately 6,100 Dth per day of firm withdrawal capacity and 178,500 of Dth of storage capacity to a third party, in exchange for temporary firm pipeline capacity on a constrained portion of NWP's system.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P63_S0	The Clay Basin storage facility is a supply area storage facility that provides operational flexibility and price protection.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P63_S1	PSE holds over 12.8 million Dth of Clay Basin storage capacity and approximately 107,000 Dth per day of firm withdrawal capacity under two long-term contracts with remaining terms of two and four years and has rights to extend such agreements.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P63_S2	PSE has temporarily released a portion of its Clay Basin storage services to third parties, and its net storage capacity and maximum firm withdrawal capacity at Clay Basin is 8.9 million Dth and over 74,000 Dth per day, respectively.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P64_S0	LNG and Propane-Air Resources LNG and propane-air resources provide firm natural gas supply on short notice for short periods of time.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P64_S1	Due to their typically high cost and slow cycle times, these resources are normally utilized as a last resort supply source in extreme peak-demand periods, typically during the coldest hours or days.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P65_S0	During 2014, PSE, working with NWP determined that the pipeline redelivery service to PSE from NWP s Plymouth LNG facility could no longer be considered firm during peak conditions.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P65_S1	As a result, PSE terminated the service agreement effective October 31, 2015 and removed the resource from its natural gas firm portfolio.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P65_S2	In 2015, PSE and NWP negotiated a new contract for Plymouth LNG service for PSE s generation fleet, which provides for LNG storage services of 241,700 Dth of PSE-owned natural gas at Plymouth, with a maximum daily deliverability of 70,500 Dth.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P65_S3	PSE will use the Plymouth contract as an alternate supply source for natural gas required to serve PSE s generation fleet during peak periods on a daily or intra-day basis.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P65_S4	In addition, PSE acquired 15,000 Dth/day of firm pipeline capacity for the generation fleet.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P65_S5	The balance of the LNG capacity will be delivered using firm NWP pipeline transportation service previously acquired to serve PSE s generation fleet.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P66_S0	PSE owns and operates the Swarr vaporized propane-air station located in Renton, Washington which includes storage capacity for approximately 1.5 million gallons of propane.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P66_S1	This vaporized propane-air injection facility delivers the thermal equivalent of 10,000 Dth of natural gas per day for up to 12 days directly into PSE s distribution system, however, it is temporarily not in-service pending planned environmental, safety, efficiency and reliability upgrades.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P67_S0	PSE owns and operates an LNG peaking facility in Gig Harbor, Washington, with total capacity of 10,600 Dth, which is capable of delivering the equivalent of 2,500 Dth of natural gas per day.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P68_S0	Natural Gas Transportation Capacity PSE currently holds firm transportation capacity on pipelines owned by NWP, Gas Transmission Northwest (GTN), Nova Gas Transmission (NOVA), Foothills Pipe Lines (Foothills) and Spectra's Westcoast Energy (Westcoast).
1085392_16_ITEM1_P68_S1	GTN, NOVA, and Foothills are all TransCanada companies.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P69_S0	PSE pays fixed monthly demand charges for the right, but not the obligation, to transport specified quantities of natural gas from receipt points to delivery points on such pipelines each day for the term or terms of the applicable agreements.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P69_S1	PSE holds approximately 539,000 Dth per day of capacity for its natural gas customers on NWP that provides firm year-round delivery to PSE s service territory.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P69_S2	In addition, PSE holds approximately 453,000 Dth per day of seasonal firm capacity on NWP to provide for delivery of natural gas stored at Jackson Prairie.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P69_S3	PSE holds approximately 253,000 Dth per day of firm transportation capacity on NWP to supply natural gas to its electric generating facilities.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P69_S4	In addition PSE holds over 34,000 Dth per day of seasonal firm capacity on NWP to provide for delivery of natural gas stored in Jackson Prairie for its electric generating facilities.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P69_S5	PSE s firm transportation capacity contracts with NWP have remaining terms ranging from one to 29 years.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P69_S6	However, PSE has either the unilateral right to extend the contracts under the contracts current terms or the right of first refusal to extend such contracts under current FERC rules.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P70_S0	PSE s firm transportation capacity for its natural gas customers on Westcoast s pipeline is 130,000 Dth per day under various contracts, with remaining terms of two to four years.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P71_S0	for PSE to renew its rights under the Westcoast contract.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P72_S0	PSE has firm transportation capacity for its natural gas customers on NOVA and Foothills pipelines, each totaling approximately 80,000 Dth per day, with remaining terms of two to eight years and an option for PSE to renew its rights on the capacity on NOVA and Foothills pipelines.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P72_S1	PSE has other firm transportation capacity on NOVA and Foothills pipelines, which supplies the electric generating facilities, each totaling approximately 40,000 Dth per day, with remaining terms of five to eight years.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P72_S2	PSE s firm transportation capacity for its natural gas customers on the GTN pipeline, totaling over 77,000 Dth per day, has a remaining term of eight years and PSE has a first right-of-refusal to extend such contracts under current FERC rules.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P72_S3	PSE has other firm transportation capacity on GTN pipeline, which supplies the electric generating facilities, totaling 40,000 Dth per day, with remaining terms of five to eight years.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P73_S0	Capacity Release The FERC regulates the release of firm pipeline and storage capacity for facilities which fall under its jurisdiction.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P73_S1	Capacity releases allow shippers to temporarily or permanently relinquish unutilized capacity to recover all or a portion of the cost of such capacity.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P73_S2	The FERC allows capacity to be released through several methods including open bidding and pre-arrangement.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P73_S3	PSE has acquired some firm pipeline and storage service through capacity release provisions to serve its growing service territory and electric generation portfolio.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P73_S4	PSE also mitigates a portion of the demand charges related to unutilized storage and pipeline capacity through capacity release.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P73_S5	Capacity release benefits derived from the natural gas customer portfolio are passed on to PSE s natural gas customers through the PGA mechanism.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P74_S0	ENERGY EFFICIENCY PSE is required under Washington state law to pursue all available conservation that is cost-effective, reliable and feasible.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P74_S1	PSE offers programs designed to help new and existing residential, commercial and industrial customers use energy efficiently.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P74_S2	PSE uses a variety of mechanisms including cost-effective financial incentives, information and technical services to enable customers to make energy efficient choices with respect to building design, equipment and building systems, appliance purchases and operating practices.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P74_S3	PSE recovers the actual costs of its electric and natural gas energy efficiency programs through rider mechanisms.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P74_S4	However, the rider mechanisms do not provide assistance with gross margin erosion associated with reduced energy sales.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P74_S5	To address this issue, PSE received approval in 2013 from the Washington Commission for electric and natural gas decoupling mechanisms, which mitigates gross margin erosion resulting from the Company's energy efficiency efforts.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P75_S0	Since 1997, PSE has recovered direct electric energy efficiency (or conservation) expenditures through an electric rider mechanism.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P75_S1	To recover natural gas expenditures, from 1997 to 2011, PSE used a tracker mechanism, which recovered actual natural gas expenditures in the year following the year in which the expenditures were incurred.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P75_S2	In 2012, the Washington Commission directed PSE to convert natural gas expenditure recovery to a rider mechanism, consistent with the electric expenditure recovery methodology.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P75_S3	The rider mechanism allows PSE to defer the efficiency expenditures and amortize them to expense as PSE collects them in rates over a one-year period.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P76_S0	ENVIRONMENT PSE s operations, including generation, transmission, distribution, service and storage facilities, are subject to environmental laws and regulations by federal, state and local authorities.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P76_S1	The primary areas of environmental law that have the potential to most significantly impact PSE s operations and costs include:
1085392_16_ITEM1_P77_S0	Air and Climate Change Protection PSE owns numerous thermal generation facilities, including natural gas plants and an ownership percentage of a coal plant in Colstrip, Montana coal-fired steam electric generation facility (Colstrip), Montana.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P77_S1	All these facilities are governed by the Clean Air Act (CAA), and all have CAA Title V operating permits, which must be renewed every five years.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P77_S2	This renewal process could result in additional costs to the plants.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P77_S3	PSE continues to monitor the permit renewal process to determine the corresponding potential impact to the plants.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P78_S0	These facilities also emit greenhouse gases (GHG), and thus are also subject to any current or future GHG or climate change legislation or regulation.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P78_S1	The Colstrip plant represents PSE s most significant source of GHG emissions.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P79_S0	Species Protection PSE owns hydroelectric plants, wind farms and numerous miles of above ground electric distribution and transmission lines which can be impacted by laws related to species protection.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P80_S0	A number of species of fish have been listed as threatened or endangered under the Endangered Species Act (ESA), which influences hydroelectric operations, and may affect PSE operations, potentially representing cost exposure and operational constraints.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P80_S1	Similarly, there are a number of avian and terrestrial species that have been listed as threatened or endangered under the ESA or are protected by the Migratory Bird Treaty Act.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P81_S0	of protected species under these two laws have the potential to influence operation of our wind farms and above ground transmission and distribution systems.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P82_S0	Remediation PSE and its predecessors are responsible for environmental remediation at various sites.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P82_S1	These include properties currently and formerly owned by PSE (or its predecessors), as well as third-party owned properties where hazardous substances were allegedly generated, transported or released.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P83_S0	The primary cleanup laws to which PSE is subject include the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation and Liability Act (federal) and, in Washington, the Model Toxics Control Act (state).
1085392_16_ITEM1_P83_S1	PSE is also subject to applicable remediation laws in the state of Montana for its ownership interest in Colstrip.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P83_S2	These laws may hold liable any current or past owner or operator of a contaminated site, as well as any generator, transporter, arranger, or disposer of regulated substances.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P84_S0	Hazardous and Solid Waste and PCB Handling and Disposal Related to certain operations, including power generation and transmission and distribution maintenance, PSE must handle and dispose of certain hazardous and solid wastes.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P84_S1	These actions are regulated by the Solid Waste Disposal Act, as amended by the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (federal), the Toxic Substances Control Act (federal), and dangerous waste regulations (state) that impose complex requirements on handling and disposing of regulated substances.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P85_S0	Water Protection PSE facilities that discharge wastewater or storm water or store bulk petroleum products are governed by the Clean Water Act (federal and state) which includes the Oil Pollution Act amendments.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P85_S1	This includes most generation facilities (and all those with water discharges and some with bulk fuel storage), and many other facilities and construction projects depending on drainage, facility or construction activities, and chemical, petroleum and material storage.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P86_S0	Siting New Facilities In siting new generation, transmission, distribution or other related facilities in Washington, PSE is subject to the State Environmental Policy Act, and may be subject to the federal National Environmental Policy Act, if there is a federal nexus, in addition to other possible local siting and zoning ordinances.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P86_S1	These requirements may potentially require mitigation of environmental impacts as well as other measures that can add significant cost to new facilities.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P87_S0	RECENT AND FUTURE ENVIRONMENTAL LAW AND REGULATION Recent and future environmental laws and regulations may be imposed at a federal, state or local level and may have a significant impact on the cost of PSE operations.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P87_S1	PSE monitors legislative and regulatory developments for environmental issues with the potential to alter the operation and cost of our generation plants, transmission and distribution system, and other assets.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P87_S2	Described below are the recent, pending and potential future environmental law and regulations with the most significant potential impacts to PSE s operations and costs.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P88_S0	Climate Change and Greenhouse Gas Emissions PSE recognizes the growing concern that increased atmospheric concentrations of GHG contribute to climate change.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P88_S1	PSE believes that climate change is an important issue that requires careful analysis and considered responses.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P88_S2	As climate policy continues to evolve at the state and federal levels, PSE remains involved in state, regional and federal policymaking activities.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P88_S3	PSE will continue to monitor the development of any climate change or climate change related air emission reduction initiative at the state and western regional level.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P88_S4	PSE will also consider the known impact of any future legislation or new government regulation on the cost of generation in its IRP process.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P89_S0	PSE's Greenhouse Gas Emission Reporting Each year, PSE is required to submit, on an annual basis, a report of its GHG emissions to the state of Washington including a report of emissions from all individual power plants emitting over 10,000 tons per year of GHGs and from certain natural gas distribution operations.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P89_S1	Emissions exceeding 25,000 tons per year of GHGs from these sources must also be reported to the environmental protection agency (EPA).
1085392_16_ITEM1_P89_S2	Capital investments to monitor GHGs from the power plants and in the distribution system are not required at this time.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P89_S3	Since 2002, PSE has voluntarily undertaken an annual inventory of its GHG emissions associated with PSE s total electric retail load served from a supply portfolio of owned and purchased resources.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P90_S0	The most recent data indicate that PSE s total GHG emissions (direct and indirect) from its electric supply portfolio in 2014 were 9.9 million tons of carbon dioxide equivalents.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P90_S1	Approximately 41.4% of PSE s total GHG emissions (approximately 4.1 million tons) are associated with PSE s ownership and contractual interests in Colstrip.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P90_S2	While Colstrip remains a significant portion of PSE s GHG emissions, Colstrip is an important part of the existing diversified portfolio PSE owns and/or operates for its customers.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P90_S3	Consequently, PSE s overall emissions strategy demonstrates a concerted effort to manage customers needs with an appropriate balance of new renewable generation, existing generation owned and/or operated by PSE and significant energy efficiency efforts.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P91_S0	On January 8, 2014, the EPA issued a proposed New Source Performance Standard (NSPS) for the control of carbon dioxide (CO 2 ) from new power plants that burn fossil fuels under section 111(b) of the Clean Air Act.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P91_S1	The EPA first proposed a NSPS for emissions for CO 2 from new power plants in April 2012.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P91_S2	However, after more than 2.5 million comments on the original proposal, the EPA decided that a new approach was warranted and rescinded the April 2012 proposal.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P91_S3	The EPA is currently proposing an emissions limit for coal-fired sources of 1,100 lb.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P91_S4	CO 2 /MWh, and proposes standards for natural gas combined cycle sources from 1,000 to 1,100 lb.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P91_S5	CO 2 /MWh depending on the size and type of unit.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P92_S0	Under the January 8, 2014 NSPS proposal, the Agency concluded that Carbon Capture and Storage (CCS) has been adequately demonstrated as a technology for controlling CO 2 emissions in full-scale commercial applications at coal-fired electrical generating units (EGUs), while reaching the opposite conclusion, that CCS is not adequately demonstrated, in the case of gas-fired generators.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P92_S1	PSE submitted comments by the end of the comment period on May 9, 2014.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P92_S2	On August 3, 2015, the EPA announced a final rule combining its new and modified proposals into one rulemaking and making several changes.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P92_S3	The rule was published on October 23, 2015, and separates standards for new power plants fueled by natural gas and coal.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P92_S4	New natural gas power plants can emit no more than 1,000 lbs.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P92_S5	of CO 2 /MWh which is achievable with the latest combined cycle technology.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P92_S6	New coal power plants can emit no more than 1,400 lbs.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P92_S7	of CO 2 /MWh, which is less stringent than the draft rule.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P92_S8	The standard for coal plants would not specifically require CCS but CCS was reaffirmed by the EPA as the best system of emission reductions (BSER).
1085392_16_ITEM1_P92_S9	These 111(b) standards are implemented by the states, but states do not have much flexibility to alter the standards set by the EPA.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P93_S0	On June 2, 2014, the EPA proposed a rule under section 111(d) of the Clean Air Act for the control of CO 2 emissions from existing fossil fuel-fired power plants.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P93_S1	The proposed rule was estimated by the EPA to reduce total power sector carbon emissions 30% from 2005 levels by 2030 through the setting of individual emissions targets for each state.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P94_S0	The EPA applied its BSER approach for reducing CO 2 emissions from the electric power sector, consisting of increasing the efficiency of power generation and substituting higher emitting plants with lower emitting technologies.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P94_S1	The EPA announced the final rule for 111(d), the Clean Power Plan rule, on August 3, 2015 and published it on October 23, 2015.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P94_S2	The rule included several changes from the draft rule.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P94_S3	Specifically, the EPA excluded energy efficiency from one of four "building blocks" identified in the draft rule, leaving just three building blocks (i) increased efficiency for coal plants, (ii) greater utilization of natural gas plants and (iii) increased renewable sources.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P94_S4	In the final rule, the EPA provided more flexibility in achieving interim goals by phasing in the reduction and giving states the option to set their own interim compliance glide path and pushing the start of compliance to 2022.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P94_S5	The EPA also adjusted the 2012 baseline to address hydroelectricity variability and provided specific CO 2 mass targets by year for each state.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P94_S6	States have broad flexibility to pick a rate-based or mass-based approach and can design compliance options and decide how to allocate credits and whether to allow trading.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P94_S7	The EPA also gave states the option of seeking additional time, if necessary, to formulate a state plan.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P94_S8	States must submit something within one year but can request up to an additional two years for development of a state plan.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P94_S9	Thus, states must submit a plan for implementing CO 2 reductions to the EPA one to three years following issuance of the final rule.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P94_S10	Based on the October 2015 final version of the rule, the final CO 2 goal for Montana became 26% more stringent than the draft version and the final CO 2 goal for Washington became 35% less stringent.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P94_S11	By 2030 Montana must reduce CO 2 emissions from coal plants from 20.5 million tons of CO 2 to 11.3 million tons of CO 2 which is a 45% reduction in CO 2 emissions.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P94_S12	For reference, Colstrip Units 1, 2, 3 and 4 combined emit 18 million tons of CO 2 .
1085392_16_ITEM1_P95_S0	On January 6, 2016 the Washington Department of Ecology (Ecology) published a draft Clean Air Rule that establishes GHG emission reduction standards for certain stationary sources, petroleum fuel producers or importers, and natural gas distributors operating in Washington state.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P95_S1	The certain stationary sources covered include power plants, petroleum refineries, metal manufacturers, waste facilities and certain organizations responsible for 100,000 metric tons CO 2 emissions.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P96_S0	Natural gas distribution emissions are covered from the combustion of natural gas.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P96_S1	Natural gas distributors are not responsible for CO 2 emissions from natural gas supplied to another covered party (i.e., a party that emits greater than prescribed thresholds, see below).
1085392_16_ITEM1_P97_S0	As proposed, when the rule goes into effect in 2017 the Ecology will set a baseline for each source based on at least a three-consecutive-year average between 2012 and 2016.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P97_S1	The Ecology will then set a compliance pathway for each source that requires a 1 2/3% (one and two-thirds percent) reduction in CO 2 emissions per year (5% every three years) from the baseline.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P97_S2	Covered parties under this rule must (1) reduce their covered GHG emissions to meet the reduction pathway or (2) obtain emission reductions from (a) other covered parties, (b) GHG emission reduction projects or (c) external emission market programs.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P97_S3	The starting compliance threshold for covered parties is 100,000 metric tons/year (MT/yr) CO 2 emissions, and this will decrease by 5,000 tons every year from 2017 to 2035.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P97_S4	By 2035, sources emitting 70,000 tons and over must comply with the rule.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P97_S5	PSE will continue to monitor and participate in the rulemaking process associated with this measure.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P98_S0	Mercury Emissions Mercury control equipment has been installed at Colstrip and has operated at a level that meets the current Montana requirement.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P98_S1	Compliance, based on a rolling 12-month average, was first confirmed in January 2011, and PSE continues to meet the requirement.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P99_S0	The EPA published the final Mercury and Air Toxics Standard (MATS) in February 2012.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P99_S1	Generating units were given 3 years, until April 2015, to comply with MATS and could receive up to a 1-year extension from state permitting authorities if necessary for the installation of controls.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P99_S2	Colstrip meets, or is expected to meet the MATS limits for mercury and acid gases by April 2016.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P100_S0	Additional Colstrip Emission Controls On June 15, 2005, the EPA issued the Clean Air Visibility rule to address regional haze or regionally-impaired visibility caused by multiple sources over a wide area.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P100_S1	The rule defines Best Available Retrofit Technology (BART) requirements for electric generating units, including presumptive limits for sulfur dioxide, particulate matter and nitrogen oxide controls for large units.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P101_S0	The final Federal Implementation Plan for Montana (FIP) for Regional Haze was issued in September 2012.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P101_S1	There are no immediate requirements for Units 3 4, but Units 1 2 will need to upgrade pollution controls to meet new sulfur dioxide and nitrogen oxide limits.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P102_S0	The Sierra Club filed an appeal of the FIP with the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit (Ninth Circuit) on November 15, 2012 and PPL Montana also filed an appeal as the Colstrip operator.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P102_S1	The case was heard on May 15, 2014 in Seattle, Washington, and the final decision by the Ninth Circuit was issued June 9, 2015.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P102_S2	The Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals reviewed the EPA s first phase requirements for Colstrip and found that the EPA had not adequately justified the need for two of the control technologies and remanded these two issues back to the EPA.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P102_S3	The ruling in no way affects the future planning periods for the Regional Haze program or the glide path.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P102_S4	The current EPA assessment is that the state of Montana will require significant emission reductions to meet the natural visibility goal by 2064 which means that additional emission reductions will be necessary in future 10-year planning periods, beginning in the 2018-2028 period, and there is risk and uncertainty regarding potential costs.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P103_S0	Coal Combustion Residuals On April 17, 2015, the EPA published a final rule, effective October 19, 2015, that regulates CCRs under the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act, Subtitle D.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P103_S1	The CCR rule addresses the risks from coal ash disposal, such as leaking of contaminants into ground water, blowing of contaminants into the air as dust, and the catastrophic failure of coal ash containment structures by establishing technical design, operation and maintenance, closure and post closure care requirements for CCR landfills and surface impoundments, and corrective action requirements for any related leakage.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P103_S2	The rule also sets forth recordkeeping and reporting requirements including posting specific information related to CCR surface impoundments and landfills to publicly-accessible websites.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P104_S0	In April 2010, the EPA issued an Advanced Notice of Proposed Rulemaking (ANPRM) soliciting information on a broad range of questions concerning inventory, management, use, and disposal of polychlorinated biphenyl (PCB) containing equipment.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P104_S1	The EPA is using this ANPRM to seek data to better evaluate whether to initiate a rulemaking process geared toward a mandatory phase-out of all PCBs.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P104_S2	The rule was scheduled to be published in July 2015 but due to the number of comments received by the EPA, the rule has undergone multiple extensions and revisions.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P104_S3	The EPA recently updated its schedule once again and the proposal is now slated for publication in June 2016.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P104_S4	At this point, PSE cannot determine what impacts this ANPRM will have on its operations, if any, but will continue to work closely with the Utility Solid Waste Activities Group (USWAG) and the American Gas Association (AGA) to monitor developments.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P105_S0	The executive officers of Puget Energy as of February 26, 2016 are listed below along with their business experience during the past five years.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P106_S0	Officers of Puget Energy are elected for one-year terms.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P107_S0	The executive officers of PSE as of February 26, 2016 are listed below along with their business experience during the past five years.
1085392_16_ITEM1_P108_S0	Officers of PSE are elected for one-year terms.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P0_S0	The following risk factors, in addition to other factors and matters discussed elsewhere in this report, should be carefully considered.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P1_S0	The risks and uncertainties described below are not the only risks and uncertainties that Puget Energy and PSE may face.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P1_S1	Additional risks and uncertainties not presently known or currently deemed immaterial also may impair PSE s business operations.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P1_S2	If any of the following risks actually occur, Puget Energy s and PSE s business, results of operations and financial conditions would suffer.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P2_S0	PSE's regulated utility business is subject to various federal and state regulations.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P2_S1	PSE's regulatory risks include, but not limited to, the following:
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P3_S0	The actions of regulators can significantly affect PSE s earnings, liquidity and business activities.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P3_S1	The rates that PSE is allowed to charge for its services is the single most important item influencing its financial position, results of operations and liquidity.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P3_S2	PSE is highly regulated and the rates that it charges its wholesale and retail customers are determined by both the Washington Commission and the FERC.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P4_S0	PSE is also subject to the regulatory authority of the Washington Commission with respect to accounting, operations, the issuance of securities and certain other matters, and the regulatory authority of the FERC with respect to the transmission of electric energy, the sale of electric energy at the wholesale level, accounting and certain other matters.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P4_S1	In addition, proceedings with the Washington Commission typically involve multiple stakeholder parties, including consumer advocacy groups and various consumers of energy, who have differing concerns but who have the common objective of limiting rate increases or decreasing rates.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P4_S2	Policies and regulatory actions by these regulators could have a material impact on PSE s financial position, results of operations and liquidity.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P5_S0	PSE s recovery of costs is subject to regulatory review and its operating income may be adversely affected if its costs are disallowed.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P6_S0	The Washington Commission determines the rates PSE may charge to its electric retail customers based, in part, on historic costs during a particular test year, adjusted for certain normalizing adjustments.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P6_S1	Power costs on the other hand, are normalized for market, weather and hydrological condition during the applicable rate year, the ensuing 12-month period before rates become effective.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P7_S0	The Washington Commission determines the rates PSE may charge to its natural gas customers based on historic costs during a particular test year.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P7_S1	Natural gas costs are adjusted through the PGA mechanism, as discussed previously.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P8_S0	If in a specific year PSE s costs are higher than the amounts used by the Washington Commission to determine the rates, revenue may not be sufficient to permit PSE to earn its allowed return or to cover its costs.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P8_S1	In addition, the Washington Commission has the authority to determine what level of expense and investment is reasonable and prudent in providing electric and natural gas service.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P8_S2	If the Washington Commission decides that part of PSE s costs do not meet the standard, those costs may be disallowed partially or entirely and not recovered in rates.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P8_S3	For the aforementioned reasons, the rates authorized by the Washington Commission may not be sufficient to earn the allowed return or recover the costs incurred by PSE in a given period.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P9_S0	PSE is currently subject to a Washington Commission order that requires PSE to share its excess earnings above the authorized rate of return with customers.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P9_S1	The Washington Commission previously approved an electric and natural gas decoupling mechanism for the recovery of its delivery-system costs, along with an ERF, a rate plan and an earnings sharing mechanism that requires PSE and its customers to share in any earnings in excess of the authorized rate of return of 7.77% during the term of the rate plan.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P9_S2	The earnings test is done for each service (electric/natural gas) separately, so PSE would be obligated to share the earnings for one service exceeding the threshold, even if the other service did not meet the earnings test.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P10_S0	PSE has been in a stay out period, during which time it could not file for general rate increases (unless for emergency rate relief).
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P10_S1	PSE must file a GRC no later than April 1, 2016, at which time the decoupling mechanism will be subject to continuation pending the result of the 2016 GRC, which PSE plans to file in March 2016.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P11_S0	The PCA mechanism, by which variations in PSE s power costs are apportioned between PSE and its customers pursuant to a graduated scale, could result in significant increases in PSE s expenses if power costs are significantly higher than the baseline rate.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P12_S0	PSE has a PCA mechanism that provides for recovery of power costs from customers or refunding of power cost savings to customers, as those costs vary from the power cost baseline level of power costs which are set, in part, based on normalized assumptions about weather and hydrological conditions.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P12_S1	Excess power costs or power cost savings will be apportioned between PSE and its customers pursuant to the graduated scale set forth in the PCA mechanism.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P12_S2	As a result, if power costs are significantly higher than the baseline rate, PSE s expenses could significantly increase.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P13_S0	PSE s cash flow and earnings could be adversely affected by potential high prices and volatile markets for purchased power, recurrence of low availability of hydroelectric resources, outages of its generating facilities or a failure to deliver on the part of its suppliers.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P14_S0	The utility business involves many operating risks.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P14_S1	If PSE s operating expenses, including the cost of purchased power and natural gas, significantly exceed the levels recovered from retail customers, its cash flow and earnings would be negatively affected.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P14_S2	Factors which could cause PSE's purchased power and natural gas costs to be higher than anticipated include, but are not limited to, high prices in western wholesale markets during periods when PSE has insufficient energy resources to meet its energy supply needs and/or purchases in wholesale markets of high volumes of energy at prices above the amount recovered in retail rates due to:
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P15_S0	Failure of a counterparty to deliver capacity or energy purchased by PSE.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P16_S0	PSE s electric generating facilities are subject to operational risks that could result in unscheduled plant outages, unanticipated operation and maintenance expenses and increased power purchase costs.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P17_S0	PSE owns and operates coal, natural gas-fired, hydroelectric, wind-powered and oil-fired generating facilities.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P17_S1	Operation of electric generating facilities involves risks that can adversely affect energy output and efficiency levels or increase expenditures, including:
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P18_S0	Catastrophic events such as fires, explosions or acts of nature.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P19_S0	If PSE is unable to protect its physical assets from terrorist attacks or its information technology infrastructure and network against data corruption, cyber-based attacks or network security breaches, its operations could be disrupted.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P19_S1	Despite PSE's implementation of security measures, its physical assets and technology systems may be vulnerable to disability, failures or unauthorized access due to hacking, viruses, acts of war or terrorism and other causes.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P19_S2	If our technology systems were to fail or be breached and we were unable to recover in a timely manner, we may be unable to fulfill critical business functions and sensitive, confidential and other data could be compromised, which could have a material adverse effect on our results of operations, financial condition and cash flows.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P19_S3	In addition, these physical asset or cyber-based attacks could disrupt our ability to produce or distribute some portion of our energy products and could affect the reliability or operability of the electric and natural gas systems.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P19_S4	As a result, PSE endeavors to maintain vigilant security programs and procedures to protect against the continuous threat of physical asset and cyber-based attacks, and as a result, PSE may be required to expend significant dollars and other resources to protect against existing and ensuing threats.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P20_S0	PSE is subject to the commodity price, delivery and credit risks associated with the energy markets.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P20_S1	In connection with matching PSE's energy needs and available resources, PSE engages in wholesale sales and purchases of electric capacity and energy and, accordingly, is subject to commodity price risk, delivery risk, credit risk and other risks associated with these activities.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P20_S2	Credit risk includes the risk that counterparties owing PSE money or energy will breach their obligations for delivery of energy supply or contractually required payments related to PSE's energy supply portfolio.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P20_S3	Should the counterparties to these arrangements fail to perform, PSE may be forced to enter into alternative arrangements.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P20_S4	In that event, PSE s financial results could be adversely affected.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P20_S5	Although PSE takes into account the expected probability of default by counterparties, the actual exposure to a default by a particular counterparty could be greater than predicted.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P21_S0	Costs of compliance with environmental, climate change and endangered species laws are significant and the costs of compliance with new and emerging laws and regulations and the incurrence of associated liabilities could adversely affect PSE s results of operations.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P22_S0	PSE s operations are subject to extensive federal, state and local laws and regulations relating to environmental issues, including air emissions and climate change, endangered species protection, remediation of contamination, avian protection, waste handling and disposal, decommissioning, water protection and siting new facilities.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P22_S1	To fulfill these legal requirements, PSE must spend significant sums of money to comply with these measures including resource planning, remediation, monitoring, analysis, mitigation measures, pollution control equipment and emissions related abatement and fees.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P22_S2	New environmental laws and regulations affecting PSE s operations may be adopted, and new interpretations of existing laws and regulations could be adopted or become applicable to PSE or its facilities.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P22_S3	Compliance with these or other future regulations could require significant expenditures by PSE and adversely affect PSE s financial position, results of operations, cash flows and liquidity.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P22_S4	In addition, PSE may not be able to recover all of its costs for such expenditures through electric and natural gas rates at current levels in the future.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P23_S0	Under current law, PSE is also generally responsible for any on-site liabilities associated with the environmental condition of the facilities that it currently owns or operates or has previously owned or operated.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P23_S1	The incurrence of a material environmental liability or new regulations governing such liability could result in substantial future costs and have a material adverse effect on PSE s results of operations and financial condition.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P24_S0	Specific to climate change, Washington State has adopted both renewable portfolio standards and GHG legislation, including an emission performance standard provision and the EPA set CO 2 emission standards with specific state goals.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P24_S1	Recent decisions related to climate change by the United States Supreme Court and the EPA, together with efforts by Congress, have drawn greater attention to this issue at the federal, state and local level.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P25_S0	PSE's operating results fluctuate on a seasonal and quarterly basis and can be impacted by various impacts of climate change.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P25_S1	PSE's business is seasonal and weather patterns can have a material impact on its revenue, expenses and operating results.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P26_S0	Demand for electricity is greater in the winter months associated with heating.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P26_S1	Accordingly, PSE's operations have historically generated less revenue and income when weather conditions are milder in winter.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P26_S2	In the event that the Company experiences unusually mild winters, its results of operations and financial condition could be adversely affected.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P26_S3	PSE's hydroelectric resources are also dependent on snow conditions in the Pacific Northwest.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P27_S0	PSE may be adversely affected by extreme events in which PSE is not able to promptly respond, repair and restart the electric and gas infrastructure system.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P27_S1	PSE must maintain an emergency planning and training program to allow PSE to quickly respond to extreme events.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P27_S2	Without emergency planning, PSE is subject to availability of outside contractors during an extreme event which may impact the quality of service provided to PSE s customers and also require significant expenditures by PSE.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P27_S3	In addition, a slow or ineffective response to extreme events may have an adverse effect on earnings as customers may be without electricity and natural gas for an extended period of time.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P28_S0	PSE depends on an aging work force and third party vendors to perform certain important services and may be negatively affected by its inability to attract and retain professional and technical employees or the unavailability of vendors.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P28_S1	PSE is subject to workforce factors, including but not limited to an aging workforce, loss or retirement of key personnel and availability of qualified personnel.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P28_S2	PSE s ability to implement a workforce succession plan is dependent upon PSE s ability to employ and retain skilled professional and technical workers.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P28_S3	Without a skilled workforce, PSE s ability to provide quality service to PSE s customers and to meet regulatory requirements could affect PSE s earnings.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P28_S4	Also, the costs associated with attracting and retaining qualified employees could reduce earnings and cash flows.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P29_S0	PSE continues to be concerned about the availability and aging of skilled workers for special complex utility functions.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P29_S1	PSE also hires third party vendors to perform a variety of normal business functions, such as power plant maintenance, data warehousing and management, electric transmission, electric and gas distribution construction and maintenance, certain billing and metering processes, call center overflow and credit and collections.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P29_S2	The unavailability of skilled workers or unavailability of such vendors could adversely affect the quality and cost of PSE s gas and electric service and accordingly PSE s results of operations.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P30_S0	Potential municipalization may adversely affect PSE's financial condition.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P31_S0	PSE may be adversely affected if we experience a loss in the number of our customers due to municipalization or other related government action.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P32_S0	When a town or city in our service territory establishes its own municipal-owned utility, it acquires our assets and takes over the delivery of energy services that we provide.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P32_S1	Although PSE is compensated in connection with the town or city's acquisition of its assets, any such loss of customers and related revenue could negatively affect PSE's future financial condition.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P33_S0	Technological developments may have an adverse impact on PSE's financial condition.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P33_S1	Advances in power generation, energy efficiency and other alternative energy technologies, such as solar generation, could lead to more wide-spread use of these technologies, thereby reducing customer demand for the energy supplied by PSE which could negatively impact PSE's revenue and financial condition.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P34_S0	The Company's business is dependent on its ability to successfully access capital.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P34_S1	The Company relies on access to internally generated funds, bank borrowings through multi-year committed credit facilities and short-term money markets as sources of liquidity and longer-term debt markets to fund PSE's utility construction program and other capital expenditure requirements of PSE.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P34_S2	If Puget Energy or PSE are unable to access capital on reasonable terms, their ability to pursue improvements or acquisitions, including generating capacity, which may be necessary for future growth, could be adversely affected.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P34_S3	Capital and credit market disruptions, a downgrade of Puget Energy's or PSE's credit rating or the imposition of restrictions on borrowings under their credit facilities in the event of a deterioration of financial ratios, may increase Puget Energy's and PSE s cost of borrowing or adversely affect the ability to access one or more financial markets.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P35_S0	The amount of the Company's debt could adversely affect its liquidity and results of operations.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P35_S1	Puget Energy and PSE have short-term and long-term debt, and may incur additional debt (including secured debt) in the future.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P36_S0	Puget Energy has access to a multi-year $800.0 million revolving credit facility, secured by substantially all of its assets, which has a maturity date of April 15, 2018.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P36_S1	No amount was outstanding under the facility as of December 31, 2015 .
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P37_S0	Puget Energy's credit facility includes an accordion feature that could, upon the banks' approval, increase the size of the facility to $1.3 billion .
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P37_S1	PSE also has two credit facilities, which provide PSE with access to $1.0 billion in short-term borrowing capability, and include an accordion feature that could, upon the banks' approval, increase the size of the facilities to $1.450 billion .
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P37_S2	The two PSE credit facilities mature on April 15, 2019.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P37_S3	As of December 31, 2015 , no amounts were drawn and outstanding under the PSE credit facilities.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P37_S4	In addition, Puget Energy has issued $1.8 billion in senior secured notes, whereas PSE, as of December 31, 2015 had approximately $3.8 billion outstanding under first mortgage bonds, pollution control bonds, senior notes and junior subordinated notes.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P38_S0	The Company's debt level could have important effects on the business, including but not limited to:
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P39_S0	Limiting the Company's financial flexibility, including its ability to borrow additional funds on favorable terms or at all.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P40_S0	A downgrade in Puget Energy s or PSE s credit rating could negatively affect the ability to access capital, the ability to hedge in wholesale markets and the ability to pay dividends.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P40_S1	Although neither Puget Energy nor PSE has any rating downgrade provisions in its credit facilities that would accelerate the maturity dates of outstanding debt, a downgrade in the Companies credit ratings could adversely affect the ability to renew existing or obtain access to new credit facilities and could increase the cost of such facilities.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P40_S2	For example, under Puget Energy s and PSE s facilities, the borrowing spreads over the London Interbank Offered Rate (LIBOR) and commitment fees increase if their respective corporate credit ratings decline.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P40_S3	A downgrade in commercial paper ratings could increase the cost of commercial paper and limit or preclude PSE s ability to issue commercial paper under its current programs.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P40_S4	Any downgrade below investment grade of PSE s corporate credit rating could cause counterparties in the wholesale electric, wholesale natural gas and financial derivative markets to request PSE to post a letter of credit or other collateral, make cash prepayments, obtain a guarantee agreement or provide other mutually agreeable security, all of which would expose PSE to additional costs.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P41_S0	and amortization (EBITDA) to interest expense for the most recently ended four fiscal quarter periods prior to such date is equal to or greater than 3 to one .
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P42_S0	The Company may be negatively affected by unfavorable changes in the tax laws or their interpretation.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P42_S1	The Company s tax obligations include income, real estate, public utility, municipal, sales and use, business and occupation and employment-related taxes and ongoing appeals issues related to these taxes.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P42_S2	Changes in tax law, related regulations or differing interpretation or enforcement of applicable law by the IRS or other taxing jurisdiction could have a material adverse impact on the Company s financial statements.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P43_S0	The tax law, related regulations and case law are inherently complex.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P43_S1	The Company must make judgments and interpretations about the application of the law when determining the provision for taxes.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P43_S2	These judgments may include reserves for potential adverse outcomes regarding tax positions that may be subject to challenge by the taxing authorities.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P44_S0	Disputes over interpretations of tax laws may be settled with the taxing authority in examination, upon appeal or through litigation.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P45_S0	Poor performance of pension and postretirement benefit plan investments and other factors impacting plan costs could unfavorably impact PSE s cash flow and liquidity.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P46_S0	PSE provides a defined benefit pension plan to PSE employees and postretirement benefits to certain PSE employees and former employees.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P46_S1	Costs of providing these benefits are based, in part, on the value of the plan s assets and the current interest rate environment and therefore, adverse market performance or low interest rates could result in lower rates of return for the investments that fund PSE s pension and postretirement benefits plans and could increase PSE s funding requirements related to the pension plans.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P46_S2	Changes in demographics, including increased numbers of retirements or changes in life expectancy assumptions, may also increase PSE's funding requirements related to the pension plans.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P46_S3	Any contributions to PSE s plans in 2016 and beyond as well as the timing of the recovery of such contributions in GRCs could impact PSE s cash flow and liquidity.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P47_S0	Potential legal proceedings and claims could increase the Company s costs, reduce the Company s revenue and cash flow, or otherwise alter the way the Company conducts business.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P48_S0	The Company is, from time to time, subject to various legal proceedings and claims, either asserted or unasserted.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P48_S1	Any such claims, whether with or without merit, could be time-consuming and expensive to defend and could divert management s attention and resources.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P48_S2	While management believes the Company has reasonable and prudent insurance coverage and accrues loss contingencies for all known matters that are probable and can be reasonably estimated, the Company cannot assure that the outcome of all current or future litigation will not have a material adverse effect on the Company and/or its results of operations.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P49_S0	As a holding company, Puget Energy depends on PSE s ability to pay dividends.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P49_S1	As a holding company with no significant operations of its own, the primary source of funds for the repayment of debt and other expenses, as well as payment of dividends to its shareholder, is cash dividends PSE pays to Puget Energy.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P49_S2	PSE is a separate and distinct legal entity and has no obligation to pay any amounts to Puget Energy, whether by dividends, loans or other payments.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P49_S3	The ability of PSE to pay dividends or make distributions to Puget Energy, and accordingly, Puget Energy s ability to pay dividends or repay debt or other expenses, will depend on PSE s earnings, capital requirements and general financial condition.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P49_S4	If Puget Energy does not receive adequate distributions from PSE, it may not be able to meet its obligations or pay dividends.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P49_S5	The payment of dividends by PSE to Puget Energy is restricted by provisions of certain covenants applicable to long-term debt contained in PSE s electric and natural gas mortgage indentures.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P49_S6	In addition, beginning February 6, 2009, pursuant to the terms of the Washington Commission merger order, PSE may not declare or pay dividends if PSE s common equity ratio calculated on a regulatory basis is 44.0% or below, except to the extent a lower equity ratio is ordered by the Washington Commission.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P49_S7	Also, pursuant to the merger order, PSE's ability to declare or make any distribution is limited by its' corporate credit/issuer rating and EBITDA to interest ratio, as previously discussed above.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P49_S8	The common equity ratio, calculated on a regulatory basis, was 47.7% at December 31, 2015 and the EBITDA to interest expense was 4.9 to 1.0 for the 12 months then ended.
1085392_16_ITEM1A_P49_S9	PSE s ability to pay dividends is also limited by the terms of its credit facilities, pursuant to which PSE is not permitted to pay dividends during any Event of Default (as defined in the facilities), or if the payment of dividends would result in an Event of Default, such as failure to comply with certain financial covenants.
1085392_16_ITEM2_P0_S0	The principal electric generating plants and underground natural gas storage facilities owned by PSE are described under Item 1, Business Electric Supply and Natural Gas Supply.
1085392_16_ITEM2_P1_S0	PSE owns its transmission and distribution facilities and various other properties.
1085392_16_ITEM2_P1_S1	Substantially all properties of PSE are subject to the liens of PSE s mortgage indentures.
1085392_16_ITEM2_P2_S0	The Company s corporate headquarters is housed in a leased building located in Bellevue, Washington.
1085392_16_ITEM3_P0_S0	From time to time, the Company is involved in litigation or legislative rulemaking proceedings relating to its operations in the normal course of business.
1085392_16_ITEM3_P0_S1	The following is a description of pending proceedings that are material to PSE s operations:
1085392_16_ITEM3_P1_S0	Colstrip PSE has a 50% ownership interest in Colstrip Units 1 and 2, and a 25% interest in Colstrip Units 3 and 4.
1085392_16_ITEM3_P2_S0	On March 6, 2013, the Sierra Club and the Montana Environmental Information Center filed a Clean Air Act citizen suit against all Colstrip owners in the U.S. District Court, District of Montana.
1085392_16_ITEM3_P2_S1	Based on a second amended complaint filed in August 2014, plaintiffs' lawsuit currently alleges violations of permitting requirements under the New Source Review program of the Clean Air Act and the Montana State Implementation Plan arising from seven projects undertaken at Colstrip during the time period from 2001 to 2012.
1085392_16_ITEM3_P2_S2	Plaintiffs have since indicated that they do not intend to pursue claims with respect to three of the seven projects, leaving a total of four projects remaining subject to the lawsuit.
1085392_16_ITEM3_P2_S3	The lawsuit claims that, for each of the four projects, the Colstrip plant should have obtained a permit and installed pollution control equipment at Colstrip.
1085392_16_ITEM3_P2_S4	The Plaintiffs' complaint also seeks civil penalties and other appropriate relief.
1085392_16_ITEM3_P2_S5	The case has been bifurcated into separate liability and remedy trials.
1085392_16_ITEM3_P2_S6	The liability trial is currently set for May 2016, and a date for the remedy trial has yet to be determined.
1085392_16_ITEM3_P2_S7	PSE is litigating the allegations set forth in the complaint, and as such, it is not reasonably possible to estimate the outcome of this matter.
1085392_16_ITEM3_P3_S0	Coal Combustion Residuals On April 17, 2015, the EPA published a final rule, effective October 19, 2015, that regulates CCRs under the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act, Subtitle D.
1085392_16_ITEM3_P3_S1	The CCR rule addresses the risks from coal ash disposal, such as leaking of contaminants into ground water, blowing of contaminants into the air as dust, and the catastrophic failure of coal ash containment structures by establishing technical design, operation and maintenance, closure and post closure care requirements for CCR landfills and surface impoundments, and corrective action requirements for any related leakage.
1085392_16_ITEM3_P3_S2	The rule also sets forth recordkeeping and reporting requirements including posting specific information related to CCR surface impoundments and landfills to publicly-accessible websites.
1085392_16_ITEM3_P3_S3	The CCR rule requires significant changes to the Company's Colstrip operations and those changes were reviewed by the Company and the plant operator in the second quarter of 2015.
1085392_16_ITEM3_P4_S0	PSE had previously recognized a legal obligation under the EPA rules to dispose of coal ash material at Colstrip in 2003.
1085392_16_ITEM3_P4_S1	Due to the CCR rule, additional disposal costs were added to the Asset Retirement and Environment Obligations (ARO).
1085392_16_ITEM3_P5_S0	In June 2014, the EPA issued a proposed Clean Power Plan rule under Section 111(d) of the Clean Air Act designed to regulate GHG emissions from existing power plants.
1085392_16_ITEM3_P5_S1	The proposed rule includes state-specific goals and guidelines for states to develop plans for meeting these goals.
1085392_16_ITEM3_P5_S2	PSE filed comments on this rule in December 2014.
1085392_16_ITEM3_P5_S3	The EPA issued a pre-publication version of the final Clean Power Plan rule under Section 111(d) on August 3, 2015 and published a final rule on October 23, 2015.
1085392_16_ITEM3_P5_S4	PSE is reviewing the final rule and working with key stakeholders in preparation towards implementation.
1085392_16_ITEM3_P5_S5	PSE cannot yet provide a determination of how the final rule may impact PSE or its existing generation facilities, if at all.
1085392_16_ITEM3_P6_S0	For more information on litigation or legislative rulemaking proceedings, see Item 1, Business, Recent and Future Environmental Law and Regulation, and Note 14 under Item 8.
1085392_16_ITEM5_P0_S0	All of the outstanding shares of Puget Energy s common stock, the only class of common equity of Puget Energy, are held by its direct parent Puget Equico LLC (Puget Equico), which is an indirect wholly-owned subsidiary of Puget Holdings, and are not publicly traded.
1085392_16_ITEM5_P0_S1	The outstanding shares of PSE s common stock, the only class of common equity of PSE, are held by Puget Energy and are not publicly traded.
1085392_16_ITEM5_P0_S2	The payment of dividends on PSE common stock to Puget Energy is restricted by provisions of certain covenants applicable to long-term debt contained in PSE s mortgage indentures in addition to terms of the Washington Commission merger order.
1085392_16_ITEM5_P0_S3	Puget Energy s ability to pay dividends is also limited by the merger order issued by the Washington Commission as well as by the terms of its credit facilities.
1085392_16_ITEM5_P0_S4	For further discussion, see Item 1A, Risk Factors, Risks Relating to Puget Energy s Corporate Structure and Item 7, Management s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations included in this report.
1085392_16_ITEM5_P1_S0	From time to time, when deemed advisable and permitted, each of PSE and Puget Energy pay dividends on its common stock.
1085392_16_ITEM5_P1_S1	During 2015 , 2014 and 2013 , PSE paid dividends to its parent, Puget Energy, and Puget Energy paid dividends to its parent, Puget Equico, in the amounts shown in Puget Energy's and PSE's Consolidated Statements of Common Shareholder's Equity, included in this report.

1085392_16_ITEM6_P0_S1	This information should be read in conjunction with the Management's Discussion and Analysis and the audited consolidated financial statements and the related notes, included in Items 7 and 8 of this report, respectively.
1085392_16_ITEM7_P0_S0	The following discussion and analysis should be read in conjunction with the financial statements and related notes thereto included elsewhere in this report on Form 10-K.
