1085392_17_ITEM14_P2_S0	Consists of work performed in connection with registration statements and other regulatory audits.
1085392_17_ITEM14_P2_S1	Consists of tax consulting and tax return reviews.
1085392_17_ITEM14_P2_S2	Consists of software and research tools.
1085392_17_ITEM14_P3_S0	The Audit Committee of the Company has adopted policies for the pre-approval of all audit and non-audit services provided by the Company s independent registered public accounting firm.
1085392_17_ITEM14_P3_S1	The policies are designed to ensure that the provision of these services does not impair the firm s independence.
1085392_17_ITEM14_P3_S2	Under the policies, unless a type of service to be provided by the independent registered public accounting firm has received general pre-approval, it will require specific pre-approval by the Audit Committee.
1085392_17_ITEM14_P3_S3	In addition, any proposed services exceeding pre-approved cost levels will require specific pre-approval by the Audit Committee.
1085392_17_ITEM14_P3_S4	The annual audit services engagement terms and fees, as well as any changes in terms, conditions and fees relating to the engagement, are subject to specific pre-approval by the Audit Committee.
1085392_17_ITEM14_P3_S5	In addition, on an annual basis, the Audit Committee grants general pre-approval for specific categories of audit, audit-related, tax and other services, within specified fee levels, that may be provided by the independent registered public accounting firm.
1085392_17_ITEM14_P3_S6	With respect to each proposed pre-approved service, the independent registered public accounting firm is required to provide detailed back-up documentation to the Audit Committee regarding the specific services to be provided.
1085392_17_ITEM14_P3_S7	Under the policies, the Audit Committee may delegate pre-approval authority to one or more of their members.
1085392_17_ITEM14_P3_S8	The member or members to whom such authority is delegated shall report any pre-approval decision to the Audit Committee at its next scheduled meeting.
1085392_17_ITEM14_P3_S9	The Audit Committee does not delegate responsibilities to pre-approve services performed by the independent registered public accounting firm to management.
1085392_17_ITEM14_P3_S10	For 2016 and 2015 , all audit and non-audit services were pre-approved.
1085392_17_ITEM15_P0_S0	a) Documents filed as part of this report: 1) Financial Statements 2) Financial Statement Schedules.
1085392_17_ITEM15_P1_S0	Financial Statement Schedules of the Company, as required for the years ended December 31, 2016, 2015 and 2014, consist of the following: I. Condensed Financial Information of Puget Energy II.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P0_S0	General Puget Energy is an energy services holding company incorporated in the state of Washington in 1999.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P0_S1	Substantially, all of its operations are conducted through its regulated subsidiary, PSE, a utility company.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P0_S2	Puget Energy also has a wholly-owned non-regulated subsidiary, named Puget LNG, LLC (Puget LNG).
1085392_18_ITEM1_P0_S3	Puget LNG was formed on November 29, 2016 and has the sole purpose of owning, developing and financing the non-regulated activity of a liquefied natural gas (LNG) facility at the Port of Tacoma, Washington.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P1_S0	Puget Energy is owned through a holding company structure by Puget Holdings, LLC (Puget Holdings).
1085392_18_ITEM1_P1_S1	Puget Holdings is owned by a consortium of long-term infrastructure investors including Macquarie Infrastructure Partners, Macquarie Capital Group Limited, the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board (CPPIB), the British Columbia Investment Management Corporation and the Alberta Investment Management Corporation.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P1_S2	All of Puget Energy s common stock is indirectly owned by Puget Holdings.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P2_S0	Corporate Strategy Puget Energy is the direct parent company of PSE, the oldest and largest electric and natural gas utility headquartered in the state of Washington, primarily engaged in the business of electric transmission, distribution and generation and natural gas distribution.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P2_S1	Puget Energy s business strategy is to generate stable earnings and cash flow by offering reliable electric and natural gas service in a cost-effective manner through PSE.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P3_S0	Customers and Revenue Overview PSE is a public utility incorporated in the state of Washington in 1960.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P4_S0	PSE furnishes electric and natural gas service in a territory covering approximately 6,000 square miles, principally in the Puget Sound region.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P4_S1	The following tables present the number of PSE customers and revenue by customer class for electric and natural gas as of December 31, 2017 and 2016 :
1085392_18_ITEM1_P5_S0	PSE's revenues and associated expenses are not generated evenly throughout the year, primarily due to seasonal weather patterns, varying wholesale prices for electricity and the amount of hydroelectric energy supplies available to PSE, which make quarter-to-quarter comparisons difficult.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P5_S1	Weather conditions in PSE's service territory have an impact on customer energy usage and affect PSE's billed revenue and energy supply expenses.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P5_S2	While both PSE's electric and natural gas sales are generally greatest during winter months, variations in energy usage by customers occur from season to season and also month to month within a season, primarily as result of weather conditions.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P5_S3	PSE normally experiences its highest retail energy sales, and corresponding higher power costs, during the winter heating season in the first and fourth quarters of the year and its lowest sales and corresponding lower power costs in the third quarter of the year.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P5_S4	While fluctuations in weather conditions will continue to affect PSE's billed revenue and energy supply expenses from month to month, PSE's decoupling mechanisms for electric and natural gas operations are expected to normalize the impact of weather on operating revenue and net income.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P6_S0	Under the decoupling mechanism, the Washington Commission allows PSE to record a monthly adjustment to its electric and natural gas operating revenues related to electric transmission and distribution, natural gas operations and general administrative costs from residential, commercial and industrial customers.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P6_S1	For additional information, see Business, "Regulation and Rates" included in Item 1 of this report and Note 3, "Regulation and Rates" to the consolidated financial statements included in Item 8 of this report.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P7_S0	The following tables present PSE's capital expenditures for the five-year period ended December 31, 2017 and gross utility plant by category and percentages as of December 31, 2017 :
1085392_18_ITEM1_P8_S0	Employees At December 31, 2017 , PSE had approximately 3,140 full-time equivalent employees.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P8_S1	Approximately 1,110 PSE employees are represented by the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers Union (IBEW) or the United Association of Plumbers and Pipefitters (UA).
1085392_18_ITEM1_P8_S2	The contracts with the IBEW and the UA were both ratified effective December 2017 and will expire March 31, 2020 and September 30, 2021, respectively.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P9_S0	Puget Energy does not have any employees.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P9_S1	PSE's employees provide employment services to Puget Energy and charges for their related salaries and benefits at cost.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P10_S0	Segment Information Puget Energy and PSE operate one reportable business segment, referred to as the regulated utility segment.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P10_S1	For more information on this segment, see Note 17, "Segment Information" to the consolidated financial statements included in Item 8 of this report.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P11_S0	Corporate Location PSE s and Puget Energy's principal executive offices are located at 10885 NE 4 th Street, Suite 1200, Bellevue, Washington 98004 and the telephone number is (425) 454-6363.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P12_S0	The information required by Item 101(e) of Regulation S-K is incorporated herein by reference to the material under Additional Information in Part III Item 10, "Directors, Executive Officers and Corporate Governance".
1085392_18_ITEM1_P13_S0	Regulation and Rates PSE is subject to the regulatory authority of: (i) the FERC with respect to the transmission of electricity, the sale of electricity at wholesale, accounting and certain other matters; and (ii) the Washington Commission as to retail rates, accounting, the issuance of securities and certain other matters.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P13_S1	PSE also must comply with mandatory electric system reliability standards developed by the North American Electric Reliability Corporation (NERC), the electric reliability organization certified by the FERC, whose standards are enforced by the Western Electricity Coordinating Council (WECC) in PSE s operating territory.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P13_S2	Rate mechanisms include: (i) trackers that typically track specific costs during the previous twelve-month period and (ii) riders that project cost recovery during a forward looking twelve-month period.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P13_S3	Both allow recovery of expenditures without the lengthy process of a full GRC.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P14_S0	General Rate Case Filing On January 13, 2017, PSE filed its GRC with the Washington Commission, the settlement agreement was accepted by the Washington Commission on December 5, 2017 and the rates became effective December 19, 2017.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P14_S1	For further details regarding the 2017 GRC filing, see Note 3, "Regulation and Rates" to the consolidated financial statements included in Item 8 of this report.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P15_S0	Decoupling Filings While fluctuations in weather conditions will continue to affect PSE's billed revenue and energy supply expenses from month to month, PSE's decoupling mechanisms assist in mitigating the impact of weather on operating revenue and net income.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P16_S0	Since July 2013, the Washington Commission has allowed PSE to record a monthly adjustment to its electric and natural gas operating revenues related to electric transmission and distribution, natural gas operations and general administrative costs from residential, commercial and industrial customers.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P16_S1	This monthly adjustment mitigates the effects of abnormal weather, conservation impacts and changes in usage patterns per customer.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P16_S2	As a result, these electric and natural gas revenues are recovered on a per customer basis regardless of actual consumption levels.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P16_S3	The energy supply costs, which are part of the power cost adjustment (PCA) and purchased gas adjustment (PGA) mechanisms, are not included in the decoupling mechanism.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P16_S4	Total electric and natural gas revenue recorded under the decoupling mechanisms will be affected by customer growth and not actual consumption.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P16_S5	Following each calendar year, PSE will recover from, or refund to, customers the difference between allowed decoupling revenue and the corresponding actual revenue during the following May to April time period.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P16_S6	For further details regarding decoupling filings, see Note 3, "Regulation and Rates" to the consolidated financial statements included in Item 8 of this report.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P17_S0	Electric Rate Filings Power Cost Adjustment Mechanism PSE currently has a PCA mechanism that provides for the deferral of power costs that vary from the power cost baseline level of power costs.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P18_S0	The power cost baseline is set in part, based on normalized assumptions about weather and hydrological conditions.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P18_S1	Excess power costs or savings are apportioned between PSE and its customers pursuant to the graduated scale set forth in the PCA mechanism and will trigger a surcharge or refund when the $30.0 million cumulative deferral trigger is reached.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P19_S0	On August 7, 2015, the Washington Commission issued an order approving changes to the PCA mechanism.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P19_S1	The settlement agreement took effect January 1, 2017 and will apply the following graduated scale:
1085392_18_ITEM1_P20_S0	The electric conservation rider collects revenue to cover the costs incurred in providing services and programs for conservation.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P20_S1	Rates change annually on May 1 to collect the annual budget that started the prior January and to true-up for actual compared to forecast conservation expenditures from the prior year as well as actual load being different than the forecasted load set in rates.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P21_S0	Federal Incentive Tracker Tariff The Federal Incentive Tracker Tariff passes through to customers the benefits associated with the wind-related treasury grants.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P21_S1	The filing results in a credit back to customers for pass-back of treasury grant amortization and pass-through of interest and any related true-ups.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P21_S2	The filing is adjusted annually for new Federal benefits, actual versus forecast interest and to true-up for actual load being different than the forecasted load set in rates.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P21_S3	Rates change annually on January 1.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P22_S0	Power Cost Only Rate Case A power cost rate case is a limited-scope proceeding to reset power cost rates.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P22_S1	In addition to providing the opportunity to reset all power costs, the PCORC proceeding also provides for timely review of new resource acquisition costs and inclusion of such costs in rates at the time the new resource goes into service.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P22_S2	To achieve this objective, the Washington Commission is not required to but historically has used an expedited six-month PCORC decision timeline rather than the statutory 11-month timeline for a GRC.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P23_S0	The residential exchange program passes through the residential exchange program benefits that PSE receives from the Bonneville Power Administration (BPA).
1085392_18_ITEM1_P23_S1	Rates change bi-annually on October 1.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P24_S0	The purpose of the property tax tracker mechanism is to pass through the cost of all property taxes incurred by the Company.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P24_S1	The mechanism was implemented in 2013 and removed property taxes from general rates and included those costs for recovery in an adjusting tariff rate.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P24_S2	After the implementation, the mechanism acts as a tracker rate schedule and collects the total amount of property taxes assessed.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P24_S3	The tracker will be adjusted each year in May based on that year's assessed property taxes and true-up from the prior year.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P25_S0	The purpose of the CRM is to recover capital costs related to projects included in PSE's pipe replacement program plan on file with the Washington Commission with the intended effect of enhancing the safety of the natural gas distribution system.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P25_S1	Rates change annually on November 1.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P26_S0	Purchased Gas Adjustment PSE has a PGA mechanism that allows PSE to recover expected natural gas supply and transportation costs and defer, as a receivable or liability, any natural gas supply and transportation costs that exceed or fall short of this expected natural gas cost amount in PGA mechanism rates, including accrued interest.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P26_S1	PSE is authorized by the Washington Commission to accrue carrying costs on PGA receivable and payable balances.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P26_S2	A receivable or payable balance in the PGA mechanism reflects an under recovery or over recovery, respectively, of natural gas cost through the PGA mechanism.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P26_S3	Rates change annually on November 1.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P27_S0	The purpose of the property tax tracker mechanism is to pass through the cost of all property taxes incurred by the Company.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P27_S1	The mechanism was implemented in 2013 and removed property taxes from general rates and included those costs for recovery in an adjusting tariff rate.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P27_S2	After the implementation, the mechanism acts as a tracker rate schedule and collects the total amount of property taxes assessed.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P27_S3	The tracker is adjusted each year in May based on that year's assessed property taxes and adjustments to the rate from the prior year.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P28_S0	Natural Gas Conservation Rider The natural gas conservation rider collects revenue to cover the costs incurred in providing services and programs for conservation.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P28_S1	Rates change annually on May 1 to collect the annual budget that started the prior January and to true-up for actual versus forecast conservation expenditures from the prior year as well as actual load being different than the forecasted load set in rates.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P29_S0	For additional information on electric and natural gas rates, see Management's Discussion and Analysis, "Regulation and Rates" included in Item 7 of this report.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P30_S0	_______________ Includes decoupling cash collections, rate of return excess earnings, and decoupling 24-month revenue reserve.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P31_S0	_______________ National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA).
1085392_18_ITEM1_P32_S0	Average megawatt (aMW) usage by customers divided by their maximum usage.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P33_S0	Electric Supply At December 31, 2017 , PSE s electric power resources, which include company-owned or controlled resources as well as those under long-term contract, had a total capacity of approximately 4,737 megawatts (MW).
1085392_18_ITEM1_P33_S1	PSE s historical peak load of approximately 4,912 MW occurred on December 10, 2009.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P34_S0	In order to meet an extreme winter peak load, PSE may supplement its electric power resources with winter-peaking call options and other instruments.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P34_S1	When it is more economical for PSE to purchase power than to operate its own generation facilities, PSE will purchase spot market energy when sufficient transmission capacity is available.

1085392_18_ITEM1_P36_S1	The FERC license authorizes the full 54.4 MW; however, the project's water right issued by the State Department of Ecology limits flow to 2,500 cubic feet and therefore output to 47.7MW.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P37_S0	Columbia River Electric Energy Supply Contracts During 2017 , approximately 13.3% of PSE s energy supply requirement was obtained through long-term contracts with three Washington Public Utility Districts (PUDs) that own and operate hydroelectric projects on the Columbia River (Mid-Columbia).
1085392_18_ITEM1_P37_S1	PSE agrees to pay a share of the annual debt service, operating and maintenance costs and other expenses associated with each project in proportion to its share of projected output.
1085392_18_ITEM1_P37_S2	PSE s payments are not contingent upon the projects being operable.
